fields.headline: Eriksson finds middle parts missing
fields.standfirst:
England have half a dozen midfielders out already, reports David Lacey
Beckham: 'I'm not a natural born leader'
fields.trailText: With half a dozen midfielders out, England are already in danger of lacking heart under Sven-Goran Eriksson, reports David Lacey.
fields.body:
England are already in danger of lacking heart under Sven-Goran Eriksson, but not in the defeatist sense. It is just that the new coach looks like losing five midfield players from his squad for tomorrow night's friendly against Spain at Villa Park.

Paul Scholes became the latest casualty when he awoke yesterday with an attack of gastroenteritis that will keep the Manchester United player out if his stomach is not better this morning. "If he's not good today, then I doubt if he'll be well enough for Wednesday," Eriksson observed gloomily.

Injuries have already forced the withdrawals of Steve McManaman, Kieron Dyer and Ray Parlour and, although Michael Carrick reported for duty in the midlands yesterday, the West Ham man will return to his club today for treatment to a damaged hamstring.

With Liverpool's Steve Gerrard ruled out before the squad was picked, this means that, in spite of announcing a huge party of 31 on Friday, Eriksson's options have been seriously curtailed in England's most problematic area.

"While we picked 31 names we are unlucky because the five who are unfit are all midfielders," Eriksson added. "It's always a pity when you lose players - and very, very good players for sure - but you have to talk about those you have, not those that are injured. We still have some young players of good quality and I'm sure they can do a good job."

If the England coach was depressed or deflated by such an early reminder of the frustrations of the job, he kept it well hidden. Yet there is no escaping the fact that the loss of Dyer's speed, McManaman's experience and, in all probability, Scholes's all-round international qualities will limit Eriksson's chances of learning anything valuable from tomorrow's match to take into the World Cup qualifiers against Finland and Albania a month from now.

Had Dyer and McManaman been fit, for example, he could have played David Beckham in a central position and in the sort of team he might field against the Finns. Now it would seem more likely that Beckham will face Spain in his usual Manchester United role wide on the right.

Perhaps Eriksson intended doing this anyway. "I think we are going to play with everyone in more or less the positions they fill for their clubs," he said yesterday. "I hope to do that as much in the future for the simple reason that you don't have time before inter national games to practise with players in new positions."

This has to be good news. From Don Revie using Manchester United's Brian Greenhoff as a sophomore sweeper for a World Cup qualifier in Italy to Kevin Keegan's woebegone wheeze of playing Gareth Southgate in midfield against Germany last October England have suffered too often from the square-peg syndrome.

Yet Eriksson is now bound to play an experimental, inexperienced midfield against the likes of Gaizka Mendieta and Luis Enrique tomorrow night. For, though he still has a choice of seven players, only Beckham, with 37 caps, has a prolonged England track record. Half of Nick Barmby's international appearances have been as a substitute, Nicky Butt has started only five games and Jamie Carragher, capped twice, Frank Lampard, once, and the uncapped Joe Cole and Gavin McCann are tyros at this level.

Assuming Scholes does not play, it seems that the best Eriksson can do is play Beckham, Carragher and Barmby with Lampard or Joe Cole or employ Teddy Sheringham and Robbie Fowler behind a front man, Emile Heskey.

All will be revealed tomorrow and Eriksson is clearly not a member of the nod-and-a-wink school of international coaches. "I think we are going to see some interesting things" was the only hint he gave yesterday while adding the caveat that "to prepare a team with a new manager in two training sessions, that's not perfect".

For what it is worth Eriksson will reveal the name of his captain today. And precisely what the job is worth will be gauged from his choice.

Beckham led Peter Taylor's team of up-to-30s competently enough in England's previous match, the 1-0 defeat in Turin last November that proved little except that there was life after Keegan. So far Eriksson has made polite noises about Beckham without committing himself to allowing the Manchester United man to retain the armband.

Sol Campbell and Gary Neville are the other fancied candidates, Campbell because he cuts a commanding figure at the back, Neville because in this squad only David Seaman has won more caps.

At least the England coach feels the responsibility of a captain should extend beyond calling correctly when tossing for choice of ends. "It's much more important than that," Eriksson insisted. "If you are captain of any team, you are there to help direct the players."

The truth is that there is no obvious candidate for the England captaincy at present and whoever is appointed will be not so much Captain Marvel as Captain Maybe.

 Real Madrid's veteran centre-back Fernando Hierro will miss the game after discovering that he is suspended. He has been replaced by the Zaragoza defender Paco Jemez.

webTitle: I'm not a natural born leader, says man who would be king

fields.headline: I'm not a natural born leader, says man who would be king
fields.standfirst: Jon Brodkin on David Beckham's reluctance to take the armband tomorrow
fields.trailText: Jon Brodkin on David Beckham's reluctance to take the armband tomorrow.
fields.body:
Sven-Goran Eriksson announces today who will lead his England side and if he plumps for David Beckham he could be in for a surprise. The Manchester United midfielder, by his own admission yesterday, is not a natural captain.

Having worn the armband in Italy last November, Beckham is a strong candidate to continue in the job. What he made plain ahead of tomorrow's friendly against Spain is that he would need time to adjust.

"I've never been captain before apart from in the youth teams and once at United when no one else wanted it," he said, referring to a game against Leeds this season when Roy Keane went off injured and the armband was left lying around at half-time. "But players learn different things throughout their career. If I stay captain I'll have to adapt to that."

Although Eriksson has chosen his captain, by yesterday evening he had not informed his squad. If Beckham loses the honour he sounds unlikely to trash one of his cars.

"It won't be a blow really," he said. "I love being captain but I said to myself 'If it doesn't happen again I can always say I've been England captain'."

Of more importance to him is being recognised as the best. At the age of 25 Beckham has more medals and more millions than most can dream of but a burning desire to improve still drives him.

"I've reached a level which has got me where I am today but I need to go above that," he said. "Last year I was sixth in the world player of the year vote and the year before that I was second, so I want to carry on and try to get to No1."

His ability is undoubted, though of late questions have been asked. Twice against Valencia in the Champions League he was stifled by tight marking, so much so that after being substituted in the first match the Spanish press derided him as "the man who did not turn up".

Then on Friday Steve McClaren, the assistant manager at Old Trafford and a member of Eriksson's coaching team, said Beckham had suffered a "dip in form" and was "not playing to his usual standards". The player begs to differ.

"There's a lot been said needlessly about the way I've been playing," he said. "About a month ago I had 'flu and should have sat it out and missed three games. But being the person I am I played through it and it was catching up with me."

On Sunday against Arsenal, he says, he felt a lot better for the first time. Certainly flashes of his talent were evident down the right and later through the middle. After Valencia's experiences, Spain may prefer him on the flank; Beckham would rather hold central ground. "Any chance to go in the middle I enjoy," he said.

With Steve McManaman, Kieron Dyer and Ray Parlour injured, his wish may not be granted. On the right, he knows what to expect. "When we come up against teams in Europe they tend to be marking me tighter or there will be two men on me," he said.

"That's the thing I've got to get used to. It's possibly easier when I'm in the middle to get out of situations but if I'm on the right in that situation I've got to learn to get out of it."

His capacity to learn should not be in doubt. The flashes of impetuousness which have cost him dear in the past continue to be kept under wraps. When he was kicked in the air by a Valencia player at Old Trafford last week he refrained from lashing out.

"It's been happening in a lot of games," he said. "I have just got on with it where a couple of years ago I might not have done. I've learned to get on with things and just enjoy the football.

"Kids are watching these games and a lot's been said about kids looking up to their idols. I'd rather kids were watching me cross a ball or score a great goal than the other things that have gone on."

A captain's example, whether he leads England or not.

fields.headline: Rangers return to Holloway
fields.trailText: QPR have named former Loftus road regular and Bristol Rovers boss Ian Holloway as their new manager.
fields.body:
Ian Holloway, a ray of sunshine at gloomy Loftus Road, took over as Queens Park Rangers' manager yesterday. "I've always been an eternal optimist," he said, "and I can't wait to take this challenge on."

QPR lie fourth from bottom of the First Division after losing 5-0 away to Wimbledon on Saturday. "We've had some cruel injuries," Holloway said, "but I think with determination and belief it's amazing what you can achieve."

Holloway, who played almost 150 league games for the west London club between 1991 and 1996, was sacked as Bristol Rovers manager last month. He has signed a 16-month contract and will once again link up with Gerry Francis, the previous manager, who has become the club's director of football.

"I was lucky enough to work with him for nearly 10 years at two different clubs," Holloway said. "Until I met him I thought I knew a lot about football. After I met him I knew nothing."

Holloway was chosen ahead of Iain Dowie, who was working as Francis's assistant until last week, and Steve Perryman, the former Tottenham captain who has been working part-time at Exeter City while hoping to resume a successful coaching career in Japan.

 Roberto Mancini has taken over as coach of Fiorentina. The former Italy striker, who has played for Leicester this year, replaces Fatih Terim, who resigned yesterday.

webTitle: Cardiff police fear Cup final gridlock

fields.headline: Cardiff police fear Cup final gridlock
fields.trailText: South Wales Police are seeking urgent talks to prevent FA Cup final and the Nationwide play-offs being blighted by the same traffic gridlock in central Cardiff that led to the Worthington Cup final to be delayed.
fields.body:
South Wales Police are seeking urgent talks with the game's authorities to prevent May's FA Cup final and the Nationwide play-offs being blighted by the same traffic gridlock in central Cardiff that caused thousands of supporters, mainly Birmingham fans, to miss the start of Sunday's Worthington Cup final even though the kick-off was put back by 10 minutes.

The police match commander, Chief Supt Gerry Toms, said: "We had 65,000 or so people inside the Millennium stadium, waiting for the game to start. How long do you wait to get everyone in, that's the problem. We have to sit down with the clubs and get better information so we can make preparations here in Cardiff."

Paul Sheldon, secretary of the Redditch Birmingham supporters' club, said he was appalled by the chaos and demanded the authorities "get their act together".

"We had eight coaches and they all got there on time," he said. "But we had trouble getting into the car park even though we had the right passes. We were shipped off to side streets instead.

"I know of some supporters' coaches that left at 10am and didn't get there until half an hour after kick-off. We also had problems leaving Cardiff with the roads congested and didn't get back until midnight."

Chief Supt Toms said the problems stemmed from too many of the 73,500 crowd coming by road rather than rail. "More [than expected] came by car so the car parks that had been prepared were over-loaded. That caused the queues. Cardiff railway station normally deals with 25,000 people on event day. Yesterday there were less than 10,000.

"Too many cars, too many coaches, all descending on Cardiff too quickly. The police are left at the sharp end. It was like a quart in a pint pot."

The Football Association and the Football League have struck a three-year deal for the Millennium stadium to host showcase events while Wembley is being rebuilt.

Football's lawmakers will decide whether to make an international rule of the 10-yard punishment option, which has been on trial this season in the English and Scottish professional game, when the International Football Association Board meets in Edinburgh on March 10.

The rule gives referees the power to move a free-kick a further 10 yards forward in the event of unsporting behaviour.

 The Leeds midfielder Gareth Evans has become the fourth United player to face charges of assault and affray this year and will appear in court tomorrow. The alleged offences took place outside a pub in the 20-year-old reserve team player's home town of Rothwell last Friday.

webTitle: Foot and mouth outbreak forces UK tourist attractions to close

fields.headline: Foot and mouth outbreak forces UK tourist attractions to close
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: In the wake of the recent outbreak of foot and mouth disease in farms across England, tourist attractions around the country have chosen to close their doors in order to reduce the risk of any further spread of the infection.
fields.body:
In the wake of the recent outbreak of foot and mouth disease in farms across England, tourist attractions around the country have chosen to close their doors in order to reduce the risk of any further spread of the infection.

Common land within Dartmoor National Park has been closed to public access until further notice. Northumberland National Park, situated close to Heddon on the Wall where the recent outbreak is thought to have originated, has closed its car parks in a bid to discourage walkers, and has instructed visitors to stay away from farmland within the park "until the infection is clear". Graham Taylor of the Northumberland National Park Authority said that the effect of a prolonged closure of the national park could be "very serious". Unless the outbreak was contained within the next few weeks, he said, the tourist season over Easter would be "desperately quiet" and, given that in the remoter areas of Northumberland up to 30% of jobs are directly dependent on the tourist industry, the impact on the local economy would be highly detrimental.

The Cumbria tourist board has also asked visitors to stay clear of farmland, although the board was careful to stress that the Lake District was "not shut". Operations director Ian Stephen declared that "visitors need not be put off from coming. There are plenty of places where they would not come into contact with farms or livestock, particularly the towns and villages which are not out of bounds".

Elsewhere, both Edinburgh Zoo and Chester Zoo were closed today as a precaution against further transmission of the disease. A spokesperson for the Edinburgh tourist board said that, despite the fact that no cases of the disease had as yet been confirmed in Scotland, Edinburgh Zoo nevertheless felt that "such precautions were very necessary". The spokesperson added that although the Zoo is one of the city's top tourist draws, there are numerous alternative attractions for tourists to visit within the city.

In London, Richmond, Bushey and Hampton Court Royal Parks, all home to large herds of deer which are susceptible to the disease, have closed their gates to the public in response to the outbreak. The National Trust has limited access to all its land supporting livestock.

The spokesperson added that although the Zoo is one of the city's top tourist draws, there are numerous alternative attractions for tourists to visit within the city. In London, Richmond, Bushey and Hampton Court Royal Parks, all home to large herds of deer which are susceptible to the disease, have closed their gates to the public in response to the outbreak. fields.headline: Travel with care
fields.standfirst:
Taking a year out from studying is becoming more and
                                                  more popular, but there can be hidden dangers in
                                                  travelling abroad
fields.trailText: Taking a year out from studying is becoming more and more popular, but there can be hidden dangers in travelling abroad
fields.body:
Taking a gap year to travel abroad is the ideal way to break out of the cycle of study and work for many students in Britain. Prince William's recent, much-publicised stint in Chile has even given globe-trotting for a year between school and university a royal seal of approval.

Prince William was one of among an estimated 23,000 students who deferred their entry this academic year to begin their course the coming September. What's more, an increasing number of students from all dis ciplines are spending a term or a year abroad at a foreign university as part of their course.

Officials at the Erasmus exchange programme, the British branch of which is based at Kent University, say that at least 10,000 UK students are abroad in Europe in any given year as part of their studies. And throughout Europe there are more than 100,000 students mobile over the course of any academic year from the 2,000 European universities that participate in the Erasmus programme.

But for a lot of students, whether backpacking or studying, a year abroad can be an uncertain and even nightmarish experience. A lack of familiarity with local customs and an ignorance of legal rights and working practices have caused many an upset for those who had set off with dreams of broadening their horizons.

Alan Lansdowne, a graduate from Sheffield University, was almost beaten to death in a small town in Russia. As part of a year abroad for his degree in Russian and German, he was living in the town of Voronezh, situated about a nine-hour drive south from Moscow. Although Lansdowne, now 24, and his British friends were told not to walk alone at night, they began to flout the rules as they became more familiar with the town.

One January night, Lansdowne was drinking with some friends and decided to walk home alone in the early hours of the morning. "I got to a crossroads, and these guys were standing there, asking me to come towards them," he says. The gang surrounded him within minutes and started punching and kicking him. He managed to stagger home, the 10-minute journey taking him more than an hour. When inside the flat, he collapsed, waking his Russian landlady. He was taken to the local hospital where doctors found that as well as having extensive internal bleeding, he had also ruptured his spleen.

Lansdowne later found out that his beating may have been part of a local ritual that none of the foreign students had been warned of. He was told by a Russian friend that the night he was beaten marked the beginning of the new year for Russian Orthodox Christians, a coincidence which may have been the reason for the events of that evening. "The experience has made me wiser. I say to myself, if I can go through that, then I can do anything," he says now.

As well as the thousands of students taking a gap year before starting their degree studies, there are many who do the same after graduation. Almost all of those who take a gap year before committing themselves to full-time employment say they need to see the world and experience different things before settling down.

Burhan Uddin Ahmed, 25, from east London, was one of those students who wanted to see more of life after his studies. Having completed his MA in journalism studies at London's Goldsmith's College, Ahmed bought a round-the-world air ticket. He flew to Thailand and then on to Australia, but it was while in Brazil that he was confronted by a gunman.

Ahmed, who recently returned to London, knew coach hijackings were frequent, but nevertheless decided to take a 14-hour coach journey from the north-eastern city of Puerto Seguro to Salvador at night. At three in the morning, passengers were awoken by a lone gunman who demanded money and valuables from everyone on board.

Ahmed says he felt extremely nervous, as he was sitting near the front, very close to where the gunman was standing. "I knew if the gunman started firing I would have been one of the first to get shot," he says. The gunman eventually fled after taking valuables and cash from all the passengers.

Although he reached Salvador, he flew back to England shortly afterwards. Like Lansdowne, he now puts this traumatic event down to experience.

Although violent cases like these are rare, other problems abound. Many British students abroad become victims "of low pay, sexual harassment and downright exploitation," according to a recent survey by the BBC Essentials website.

One in 20 of those surveyed said they had been victims of sexual harassment while abroad. "Almost double the amount of boys to girls had been sexually harassed," explains Zillah Myers, the producer of the website. She adds that women were more likely to be paid a poor salary than men.

The most popular jobs among gap-year students who earn as they travel were bar work and waiting on tables. But of the 509 people interviewed in the BBC survey, one-third complained of working very long hours, and a substantial number told how they were badly treated by their native work colleagues.

Leighanne Springate, 25, was one of the participants in the survey. After graduating from Leeds University with a degree in maths and management in 1998, she travelled for a year before settling down to a full-time job as a finance manager. Part of her year out was spent in the US working in a children's summer camp. She was paid $800 for two months' work.

"The camp job was a nightmare," she says. On average, she claims, she worked for 13-14 hours a day, getting up at 7.30 in the morning, and finishing at around 10 in the evening. She now wishes she had found out more about the working conditions at the camp before setting off.

Despite the potential pitfalls, experts believe that gap years are set to become even more popular in the future. Michael Snoughton, an official at the Gap Activity Project, believes that the reason behind this increased enthusiasm may be that students are more hard-up than ever before, and so want to improve their CVs - and maximise their earnings - by boasting of this sort of experience.

Gap years, he says, have become steadily more popular in the past four or five years, as a university education becomes steadily more expensive. UCAS figures support this view. In 1994, they show that 14,530 students took a gap year, compared with 22,522 in 1999. Figures for this year are expected to be higher still.

Snoughton, whose organisation offers a package travel deal combined with voluntary work, believes that gap years abroad are immensely beneficial to students, giving them different perspectives in the world of politics and culture as well as skills. "Every 18-year-old should consider it," he says. But - even if the idea is to escape study for a while - they would be well advised to do their homework first.

Survival guide

When planning a gap year or a study period abroad, research your chosen region before setting off. If on a study exchange programme, find out all you can about the host university and its location from your own department. If on a gap year, get advice from the Foreign & Commonwealth Office about the possible dangers of visiting some countries (see its website). When abroad, note the telephone number and address of the nearest British Embassy, which can provide invaluable help in a crisis situation. Get vaccinated against illnesses like TB and malaria before you go. Take out good medical and possession insurance. Find out about work permits and other documents if you want to work in some areas. Illegal workers can do nothing if employers refuse to pay them. Don't carry much cash with you. Traveller's cheques are safer and ATM machines are in almost all countries. Don't go out alone at night in areas you don't know. Stick with a group of people you trust. In some countries, especially South American, avoid long journeys by night on a coach or by road. Highway robbery is frequent.

webTitle: Guidebook causes furore in Tuscan town

fields.headline: Guidebook causes furore in Tuscan town
fields.trailText: Describing his voyage through the inferno, the medieval poet Dante included the Tuscan town of Lucca among the damned. A successor has been even less kind.
fields.body:
Describing his voyage through the inferno, the medieval poet Dante included the Tuscan town of Lucca among the damned. Its inhabitants were greedy, he wrote - and the mud stuck for 700 years.

A successor has been even less kind. In the preface to an official guidebook, a local author, Cesare Garboli, said the inhabitants of Lucca were worse. Much worse.

"Almost all the sins of man, the darkest vices, money, avarice, fraud, lust, gluttony, live in the heart of the Lucchesi, frequently accompanied with a shady feeling of terror and greed."

Tourists are warned that behind the renaissance walls lies suffocating parsimony and reserve. "In Lucca people live corruption and know it more profoundly than anywhere else in the country," Professor Garboli writes.

The town is in uproar. The mayor wants to sue for libel, the book may be withdrawn and 2,000 demonstrators are expected to protest today.

A battle has erupted between the left-controlled province of Tuscany, which commissioned the book, and the town, controlled by the right, which brands it a monumental smear.

The book, Tuscany of Alps and Sea, was launched at a tourism convention in Milan two weeks ago but it was only last weekend that a member of the centre-right Forza Italia party noticed the preface and demanded action.

Guidebooks usually describe Lucca, with its Pisan Romanesque style cathedral, as one of the most beautiful spots in Tuscany.

Prof Garboli, 72, who was not born and bred in the town, said: "I confess that all this disorientates me. I really did not want to create a scandal."

He told the daily La Repubblica that his preface should be seen as a sincere effort to grapple with the fortress town's contradictions. "I wrote that it is not easy to penetrate the mysterious history of Lucca. I think that the inhabitants of this town are intelligent and have understood that."

Not all of them. "Cesare Garboli has even insulted our dessert," shouted one youth, objecting to the professor's dismissal of buccellato, a type of bun, as verging on insipid.

Fuelling indignation is anger over the 13th century onslaught of Dante Alighieri. In the Divine Comedy, a vernacular masterpiece detailing his voyage to heaven from the underworld, Dante singled out Lucca for harbouring corrupt swindlers.

The offending passage is from canta 21, verse 40: "And to that city which is full of people. Every person there is a swindler except for Bonturo; for money one says yes instead of no".

Bonturo was a notoriously sleazy Lucca politician and the reference drips sarcasm, said Simon Gilson, lecturer in Italian at the University of Warwick.

"Dante condemned almost every major Italian town but that reference is traditionally understood to mean Lucca."

Maurizio Dinelli, a Forza Italia councillor, said a supposed advertisement had condemned Lucca in the eyes of the world: "What an own-goal. We already had to put up with Dante speaking badly about us Lucchesi and now comes this book."

fields.standfirst: From Sheena
fields.trailText:
Have been following your travels with (envy) interest.

On deciding whether to go east, west or south in Australia (see Sue's diary) it depends on several things, mainly (a) time
(b) money!
which governs
(c) form of transport.
fields.body:
Hi Sue

Have been following your travels with (envy) interest.

On deciding whether to go east, west or south in Australia (see Sue's diary) it depends on several things, mainly (a) time
(b) money!
which governs
(c) form of transport. East, by which I guess you mean the Barrier Reef, Daintree Rainforest, Atherton Tableland, etc is really good though more touristy, it is much easier to get around and to find accommodation, and has a very varied flora/fauna/geographical range. West, by which I guess you mean the Kimberley, is also fantastic - Bungle Bungles, Windjana Gorge, Broome, King George Sound, Marima Nat. Park, etc. (where Rosy and I went in our 4WD) but it requires either your own transport or a tour; I don't think it could be done on your own. Though of course it is much more of an adventure, not on the usual tourist track. Of course Alice Springs and Ayers Rock is fantastic too and lots to see and do around there! (not helping much am I?) To be honest I would go east, there is a greater diversity of things to see and do, a greater diversity of transport, a greater diversity of accommodation (there ain't much in these outback WA towns I can tell you!).

If you get the chance whilst in Bali to go to Lombok (and even the Comoros to see the Komodo Dragons) it would be worth it. Lombok is like Bali was 20 or 30 years ago! Hope this helps you decide - I'm off to see if the can of fly spray I sprayed on the huntsman spider has killed it yet (they're our biggest spider, about the size of a saucer including leg span)! Yuck.

webTitle: Blair takes control as foot and mouth crisis deepens

fields.headline: Blair takes control as foot and mouth crisis deepens
fields.standfirst:
• Five more cases confirmed today
• Tony Blair calls ministerial crisis meeting
• Horse racing suspended from tomorrow

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The prime minister, Tony Blair, today called an emergency ministerial meeting in an effort to  take control of the foot and mouth crisis as five more cases of the disease were confirmed.
fields.body:
The prime minister, Tony Blair, today called an emergency ministerial meeting in an effort to take control of the foot and mouth crisis as five more cases of the disease were confirmed.

The new cases - including the first to hit Wales - take to 17 the number of confirmed outbreaks. Following today's meeting, Mr Blair extended a ban on animal movement to March 16. The current ban was due to end on Friday.

The chief veterinary officer, Jim Scudamore, reported new outbreaks in Anglesey in north Wales, in Lancashire, County Durham, and Northamptonshire. A further case at an abattoir in Witton-le-Wear, County Durham was confirmed later in the afternoon.

The news came as the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, indicated a possible easing of the ban on livestock movements to allow some animals to be transported directly to abattoirs under "strictly controlled" conditions.

But Mr Brown also said that the government will allow local authorities to block access to public footpaths and rights of way. Statuatory powers came into effect at 2pm today to let local authorities seal off certain areas to prevent spread of the disease.

As the crisis worsened, the Jockey Club announced that all horse racing in Britain is to be suspended for one week starting tomorrow. A rugby international meeting between Wales and Ireland - scheduled to take place on Saturday - has been postponed.

Of today's outbreaks, the case in Anglesey is at an abattoir that has been under investigation for some time. The animal involved was transported from Yorkshire.

The other cases were in Wolsingham, County Durham, involving a sheep bought at Darlington market; at Withnell in Lancashire, with an animal traced back to Hexham market; and a case in Wootton, Northamptonshire, traced to a farm in Devon.

No cases have yet been found outside Britain, but other European nations are worried the highly infectious virus will cross the English Channel and are already taking precautionary measures. The French agriculture minister, Jean Glavany, has ordered the destruction of 20,000 sheep imported from Britain since 1 February. Germany, Spain and the Netherlands have also ordered animals imported from Britain to be destroyed.

The European Union's standing veterinary committee extended an EU embargo on animal and meat imports from Britain to 9 March.

fields.headline: Taliban order all statues destroyed
fields.trailText: Afghanistan's Taliban rulers yesterday extended their hardline vision of Islamic law by ordering the destruction of all statues, including the world's tallest standing Buddha.
fields.body:
Afghanistan's Taliban rulers yesterday extended their hardline vision of Islamic law by ordering the destruction of all statues, including the world's tallest standing Buddha.

The edict came directly from Mullah Mohammad Omar, the Islamic militia's leader, a recluse who has rarely left his home in Kandahar, southern Afghanistan.

"Based on the verdict of the clergymen and the decision of the supreme court of the Islamic emirate all the statues around Afghanistan must be destroyed," he ordered.

"Because God is one God and these statues are there to be worshipped and that is wrong. They should be destroyed so that they are not worshipped now or in the future."

Officials from the Ministry for the Prevention of Vice and the Promotion of Virtue will be sent out to destroy the statues.

Mullah Omar's order, the latest in a long line of anti-cultural and misogynistic decrees, appeared to be a stark response to a visit by western diplomats who travelled to Kabul after reports that ancient statues in the capital's museum were being destroyed.

The diplomats met the Taliban's information and culture minister yesterday but were not allowed into the museum.

More than a dozen pre-Islamic artefacts in the museum have been damaged in recent months by zealous Taliban soldiers. Most of the building's finest treasures were looted in fighting which followed the decade-long Soviet occupation.

Over the past 20 years many of Afghanistan's richest archaeological finds have been smuggled across the border to Peshawar, Pakistan, and sold to private collectors. Others have been destroyed by artillery and rocket fire.

In the past Mullah Omar has ordered non-Islamic artefacts to be protected, although to little effect.

Afghanistan's finest archaeological site is in Bamiyan, 90 miles west of Kabul, where the world's tallest standing Buddha is 53 metres high, carved out of a sandstone cliff-face. Nearby stands another Buddha 37 metres (120ft) high.

Although the sculptures, carved in the 2nd century AD, withstood Genghis Khan's invasion, the land was mined during the Soviet occupation and they stand in a region where the Taliban are still fighting opposition forces.

In September 1998 the shorter Buddha's head and folds of the robes were blown up by a Taliban commander. He then fired rockets at the groin and the folds of the clothes of the larger statue.

Since seizing Kabul four years ago the Taliban have enforced a brutally strict interpretation of Islamic law.

In his earliest decrees Mullah Omar ordered the destruction of all portraits and pictures, describing them as idolatry.

Other decrees included a ban on kite-flying, keeping pigeons, playing music and dancing. Women were ordered to wear all-covering cloaks, or burqas, and travel only with a male relative. Men were ordered not to shave their beards.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Rich
fields.trailText: When you get to Bangkok, if the noise and pollution gets too much for you, visit Dusit Zoo. It's a calm green island in a lake of traffic, and provides a welcome respite from the fumes.
fields.body:
Hi Milly,

When you get to Bangkok, if the noise and pollution gets too much for you, visit Dusit Zoo. It's a calm green island in a lake of traffic, and provides a welcome respite from the fumes. Animals outside cages are often more interesting than those inside, including turtles, pelicans, brightly coloured lizards, all wandering free. I've also seen huge monitors hissing at passers-by from behind a hedge, and a two-metre snake swimming across the lake, scattering the pedal boats. They're all native and the zoo grounds provide a green and safe habitat, even in the centre of the city.

I also recommend getting about by river and canal as much as possible - although the city planners have decided to fill most of them in. Most of the places a visitor might want to go to are ranged along the river, and you can get a riverbus all the way out to the harbour mouth for a few pence. There are no traffic jams, the scenery is great and the air a lot cleaner. But best of all, if you can afford it, is a river taxi/longtail speedboat - superb.

Sam

fields.headline: Tough times ahead warns United
fields.trailText: 9.30am: Lord Hollick's United Business Media has hinted at a difficult year ahead, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Lord Hollick's United Business Media has hinted at a difficult year ahead by confirming an uncertain outlook for the vital US high-tech market.

Analysts have voiced mounting concern about United's exposure to the US technology market, with the sector providing a third of the group's profits.

United today said that "the outlook for the US high-tech market remains uncertain," although it believes that £3.2bn it raised from disposals last year will see it through any difficulties.

The company transformed itself last year into a business information group, dumping its old name of United News & Media and its three ITV licences and the Express newspaper group.

However, its reliance on business-to-business publishing has exposed it to the crumbling US technology market, which is reeling from a series of profit warnings sparked by a cutback in IT spending and a downturn in the US economy.

But United is bullish about the future, after reporting pre-tax profits of £342m for last year, up 11% from £307m in 1999.

"We have transformed the group, selling our ITV, publishing and non-core B2B assets at premium prices totalling £3.2bn and delivered our strategy to create a leading international business information group with a strong financial base for expansion," said Lord Hollick, chief executive of United.

United's core businesses are its CMP magazine business, its PR Newswire operation and its United Information market research group.

But United has yet to entirely turn its back on consumer businesses - it still owns 35% of Channel 5 and 20% of the ITN news service.

Speculation is mounting that the company is on the verge of selling its Channel 5 stake to majority shareholder RTL, but the companies have very different opinions on the value of the holding.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Gay and Jeremy
fields.trailText: Have a wonderful time in Australia. We can thoroughly recommend the northern area of Queensland, Port Douglas, north of Cairns. There you can continue to be "batty" and see flying squirrels. A trip on a boat to the Great Barrier Reef to do some snorkelling is also essential. Our guide was Rod, a dead ringer for Paul Hogan.
fields.body:
Hi Sue

Glad you enjoyed being cooler (and wetter) in Cameron Highlands. Glad you saw the fireflies. I wish I had forced my son and his wife to do the trip there (with us in tow) when they were in KL at the end of their honeymoon. He wasn't that keen. I am now even more keen to see them before we leave this part of the world.

Have a wonderful time in Australia. We can thoroughly recommend the northern area of Queensland, Port Douglas, north of Cairns. There you can continue to be "batty" and see flying squirrels. A trip on a boat to the Great Barrier Reef to do some snorkelling is also essential. Our guide was Rod, a dead ringer for Paul Hogan. The shelf is really awesome. You swim around corals just below you and then you go on a yard or two to a sea of such depth that it reminds you of the quote "measureless to man".

In Sydney there is some cheap lodging to be found in the Kings Cross/ Paddington area, popular with back packers, but close to an area with similar facilities to those found in Soho, London!

We have a trip to K.L. soon. We continue to enjoy your reports.Take care.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Charlotte
fields.trailText: I'm writing to tell you about my time in Malawi as I had a fantastic four months there.
fields.body:
Hi Sam, I'm writing to tell you about my time in Malawi as I had a fantastic four months there.

Firstly, Bilharzia: my thoughts are, if you worry about it you'll get it! One of the worst areas is meant to be Cape Maclear... we swam there and showered, although the guide books generally state that if you go near the water there you will get Bilharzia. At first we were cautious, but we met people who had lived in supposedly risky areas their whole lives and never caught it. There's lots of government research going on and it's all still a bit unknown. However, just in case, we decided to get the drugs in Malawi which combat the disease, they were only £2 but would be about £100 in UK. I think the best advice is to swim but then go to a local doctor and get the drugs in case you get any symptoms.

The places we visited at weekends: * Cape Maclear, a bit of a pain to get to, very beautiful but spoilt by the fact that the local beach bums are constantly hassling you to buy from them. We went here early on in our stay and thought we'd be back but found places that were twice as nice. Stayed at Steven's Lodge, and Fat Monkeys is also recommended. * Zomba Plateau, had drinks on the terrace of the Ku Chawe Inn, amazing view, didn't do any walking but friends walked down the "Potato Path" which takes you back into Zomba town and is very steep. * Played golf in Zomba... browns rather than greens! very friendly caddies! * Nanchengua Lodge, on Mangochi to Monkey Bay Road, amazing place, private beach and cool bar, family run while we were there but they were moving to Mozambique so may be in different hands now. * Travelled up to a school near Dedza and visited the famous pottery walking from Dedza itself, very nice. * Climbed Mount Mulanje, absolutely amazing and worth the pain in my legs for the next week! We were lucky enough to know a bloke from a mountain club through Africa Venture and he took us up although it was strongly advised against during the rainy season. We walked up on Saturday and stayed in a hut at the top, them back down on the Sunday. * Often stayed at Doogles in Blantyre which is a backpackers lodge (in Lonely Planet); it's brill (hot showers), however it had just been taken over the last time we stayed there and so don't know what it will be like now. They throw amazing parties though and even got me dancing on the bar one night!!! Oh dear! For the last three weeks of our time in Africa we were allowed to travel around freely before we had to meet in Harare for our organised safari. Watched a football match at the Mususu stadium in Blantyre which was definitely an experience!! We then travelled on the Shire bus from Blantyre to Nkarta Bay, this journey took 12 hours. Stayed for a week in Nkarta Bay at Backpackers Connection which was excellent. Some people went on the steamer up the lake and said it was spectacular although first class tickets must be booked in advance. The Ilala did also stop running while we were in Nkarta bay which messed up people's arrangements. Others stayed at Africa Bay which was huts on the beach. Nkarta Bay was fantastic: lots to do, boys did a scuba diving course at Aqua Africa which comes highly recommended. Loads of nice places to eat and cool bars. However leaving Nkarta Bay was extremely hard, bus didn't turn up for two nights and was full on the third night, so if you do go make sure you start to try and leave a few days before you actually have to be anywhere!!! (Our visas were about to expire!) Travelled back down to Blantyre then got on the Shire bus which goes from Blantyre to Harare but we got off in Tete in Mozambique where we had decided we wanted to visit the Cahora Bassa Dam (in Lonely Planet), very spectacular. Tete suspension bridge was amazing as well, very hot though. Got back on the Shire bus after a few days and travelled down to Harare. Safari around Zim was also brilliant!! I hope this info has been of help, just let me know if there is anything else you want to know. I'm off travelling again at the end of April. Fly to Cairns then six weeks travelling to Sydney, four weeks in New Zealand, two weeks in Rarotonga then a week in LA before flying home. I can't wait!! Take care, Charlotte

webTitle: Major under pressure to disclose fees for speeches

fields.headline: Major under pressure to disclose fees for speeches
fields.standfirst: List puts renewed spotlight on former PM after he declines to            follow watchdog's advice
fields.trailText: The row over whether John Major should have to declare his huge earnings from speaking            engagements was reignited yesterday when the new register of MPs' interests was published            showing he had no fewer than 11 expenses paid trips abroad in the last year.
fields.body:
The row over whether John Major should have to declare his huge earnings from speaking engagements was reignited yesterday when the new register of MPs' interests was published showing he had no fewer than 11 expenses paid trips abroad in the last year.

The former prime minister was advised last year by Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner for standards, that he should lodge a copy of an employment agreement he had with the Washington Speakers Bureau - the agency he engaged to arrange his tours - with her office.

She also said he should register his fee from WSB as well as listing individual clients who paid the fees. She cleared him of not registering the engagements.

But Mr Major, who earlier this month gave evidence to the Commons standards and privileges committee , has declined to follow Ms Filkin's advice after speaking to lawyers.

A statement issued by his office said: "Mr Major has taken legal advice to ensure he has provided all the information required of him."

Mr Major's office said he had not submitted an employment agreement with WSB as one never existed, adding: "He does not think it appropriate to submit an artificial document." The Labour MP Denis Turner, whose complaint began the commissioner's investigation, said Mr Major's latest entry in the register appeared to put him at odds with Ms Filkin.

"I don't think he is abiding by the spirit or the letter of the rules," he said yesterday.

Many MPs who were rapped on the knuckles by Ms Filkin last year have provided a much more comprehensive entry.

Ken Livingstone, the London mayor and MP for Brent East, who was ordered to list all his speaking contracts, now has the longest entry in the book, running to two pages.

Tony Baldry, Conservative MP for Banbury, who had to apologise to the Commons for not declaring a financial relationship with a City lawyer he had proposed for an honour, has a page of entries. There is a long list of Tories with an interest in oil firms -headed by Alan Duncan, MP for Rutland and Melton and a trade and industry frontbench spokesman, who declares three expenses paid visits to Oman.

A number of Tories have created consultancy firms. James Gray, MP for North Wiltshire, has set up James Gray Consultants, which lists a City software provider as a client.

Other Tory frontbenchers are making money through their literary skills. Ann Widdecombe received pounds 100,000 for the publication of her first novel.

fields.headline: Disease and modernity
fields.standfirst:
Modern farming practices have a lot to answer for in the food and mouth outbreak, writes Guardian columnist George Monbiot

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: February 27: Modern farming practices have a lot to answer for in the food and mouth outbreak, writes George Monbiot.
fields.body:
Foot and mouth is an ancient disease which thrives on modernity. It loves the black holes into which farm animals are crammed, and the debilitated condition in which they stagger through their miserable lives. But even more than that, it loves the long-distance economy which now governs the distribution of nearly all our food.

By the time we knew there was a problem, half the lambs in Northumberland were in Devon, and half the lambs in Devon were in Northumberland, and the disease was emerging everywhere. Why should this be? Were there not enough sheep in Devon already? Do people in Northumberland refuse to eat local lamb? Do farmers take their animals on holiday?

The long-distance food economy is a disaster for farmers, a disaster for the environment, a disaster for consumers and a disaster for animal welfare. But it's a bonanza for big business.

Just as the big biotech firms have tried to capture food production through genetic engineering and patenting, so the big superstores and haulage companies have sought to capture food distribution, and the government, as always, has been only too willing to assist.

Small slaughterhouses have been closed down in droves not because Europe says so (in France, despite the same regulations, hundreds persist and thrive), but because the Ministry of Agriculture has been pursuing a deliberate programme to wipe them out.

As the superstores buy directly from the biggest and cheapest farmers, local livestock markets close, forcing those producers who don't sell to the big chains to drive their animals to markets ever further away.

The superstores want to sell "Scotch beef", so they send cattle to pasture in Scotland for a fortnight, after which they can be legally described as such. They want Welsh lamb, so they send English and Scotch lambs to Wales before killing them.

These practices, we are told, permit us all to enjoy cheap food. In truth, they merely force us to pay by other means, such as disease eradication programmes. The thousands of animals being burnt today are being sacrificed on the altar of supermarket profits.

fields.bodyText: Foot and mouth is an ancient disease which thrives on modernity. It loves the black holes into which farm animals are crammed, and the debilitated condition in which they stagger through their miserable lives. But even more than that, it loves the long-distance economy which now governs the distribution of nearly all our food. By the time we knew there was a problem, half the lambs in Northumberland were in Devon, and half the lambs in Devon were in Northumberland, and the disease was emerging everywhere. Why should this be? Were there not enough sheep in Devon already? Do people in Northumberland refuse to eat local lamb? Do farmers take their animals on holiday? The long-distance food economy is a disaster for farmers, a disaster for the environment, a disaster for consumers and a disaster for animal welfare. But it's a bonanza for big business. Just as the big biotech firms have tried to capture food production through genetic engineering and patenting, so the big superstores and haulage companies have sought to capture food distribution, and the government, as always, has been only too willing to assist. Small slaughterhouses have been closed down in droves not because Europe says so (in France, despite the same regulations, hundreds persist and thrive), but because the Ministry of Agriculture has been pursuing a deliberate programme to wipe them out. As the superstores buy directly from the biggest and cheapest farmers, local livestock markets close, forcing those producers who don't sell to the big chains to drive their animals to markets ever further away. The superstores want to sell "Scotch beef", so they send cattle to pasture in Scotland for a fortnight, after which they can be legally described as such. They want Welsh lamb, so they send English and Scotch lambs to Wales before killing them. These practices, we are told, permit us all to enjoy cheap food. In truth, they merely force us to pay by other means, such as disease eradication programmes. The thousands of animals being burnt today are being sacrificed on the altar of supermarket profits. webTitle: Comment: Politicians should be open about friendship

fields.headline: Let's learn to stick together
fields.standfirst: Politicians should be open about friendship - it's good for them
fields.trailText: Friendship. There are no tax allowances for it. No rites celebrate its birth; no ceremonies lament its passing. But BT will give you reduced rates to sustain it. It is unique to humans, but for the English a dog is its best example. Politicians can't afford it.
fields.body:
Friendship. There are no tax allowances for it. No rites celebrate its birth; no ceremonies lament its passing. But BT will give you reduced rates to sustain it. It is unique to humans, but for the English a dog is its best example. Politicians can't afford it.

A British politician finds it difficult to be a friend or to have one. Telephoning a friend carries its own political dangers. Sir Anthony Hammond's pending report on the Mandelson affair and the accusations of crony appointments against the Lord Chancellor Derry Irvine remind us of the politician's essential solitariness. The occupation has always been a lonely one: nobody climbed a ladder with anyone else.

Now there's a new zeal about keeping the public figure away from the private friend. Of course the politician's company directorship is declared but at which point do gregariousness and hospitality cloud the judgment? The embassy cocktail and the high commission's canapes after all are not dis-interested objects. They are offered as a means of influencing the next foreign affairs debate.

We want our tribunes to be beyond reproach. But the purity we want them to attain and maintain comes at a social cost - their withdrawal into a professionalised purdah beyond any possible temptation. And -being rather hypocritical about this - we also complain about the bloodlessness and remoteness which is the consequence.

In most of history and across vast areas of the modern world government simply has not been and cannot be like this at all. We look at India through western eyes and castigate "corruption". In the Middle East we categorise the rulers as the heirs to ancient and vicious "oriental despotism". In both cases we ignore the fact that the problems are post-colonial ones - the result of imposing the styles of modern nation states on more ancient forms of life and government.

I n American government, with its vast powers of presidential patronage, it is the hypocrisy of objectivity which offends - subsuming as it does the cheque to the campaign coffers. Here the president's friends are just the heirs to the king's friends of the 18th-century politics which survives in the White House.

Where the state is weak the friendships of private life spill over into public world with a special ease. In the west a political friendship means automatic partiality, something to be guarded against as a source of clouded judgment and dubious private gain. But in the world made by Islam and the Arab revolution, friendship means life itself. It sustains the trader - that ideal common to all semitic peo ples, Jew and Arab alike. It cuts across the classes from the palace to the souk as the bread is broken, the salt is passed and the stranger is welcomed at the hearth and into the heart.

In the Mediterranean world we see the bribery and the violence of Marseilles and Naples, of Sicily and Nice. Mafiosi arrangements only retain their power because of a tacit popular consent, by the power of friendship as well as the threat of the gun.

Ancient Athenians worried about friendship when they established their democracy. They tried to ban the private drinking and dining club, the hetaireiai, which flourished in the city. When Cleon the populist seized power at the beginning of the Peloponnesian war his first act was to renounce his friends and claim that friendship among politicians was a kind of prostitution.

Over-professional, boringly bourgeois Britain also takes an impoverished view of friendship as a coldly instrumental relationship Here our "friends at work" are the kind whom the ads suggest will steal our jobs when we are ill.

But politicians should be less hypocritical about friendship, more open in acknowledging its humanising appeal and its necessity in making an institution work. Here it's the quality of the friendship, not its existence, which is the concern.

True, Peter Mandelson's neurotic way of demonstrating loyalty to a friend was to brief against that friend's colleagues - actions which ensure that he had no friends to keep him in office. But Lord Irvine of Crony stumbles but does not fall because he has not presumed on his protégé-patron's friendship. Keith Vaz, having used a Foreign Office room to help settle a petitioner's insurance claim, did nothing wrong. The problem lay with the context and not with the act. In Asian Britain, as in Asian Asia, he would have behaved badly had he not responded.

The mote here is in our squinting eye, which sees any personal response as a vicious corruption. In our public life friendship is viewed as the last refuge of the scoundrel rather than the first call of the heart. Like any consensus conclusion it is both restrictive and dispiriting.

webTitle: Foot and mouth crisis: Call for debate angers minister

fields.headline: Foot and mouth crisis: Call for debate angers minister
fields.trailText: February 27: Brown fears 'diversion of resources' over Yeo call for debate
fields.body:
Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, yesterday accused the Tories of undermining government attempts to wipe out foot and mouth disease after the Tories tabled a lengthy House of Commons debate on the issue for tomorrow.

To uproar on the Tory benches, Mr Brown said: "It will divert resources, both ministerial resources and scarce veterinary resources, from the frontline which is bearing down on this disease."

Tim Yeo , the shadow agriculture minister, infuriated Mr Brown when he announced that the Tories would devote half of tomorrow's opposition day debate to the foot and mouth crisis.

Mr Brown, who will have to take part in the debate, accused the Tories of hypocrisy for announcing the debate while pledging to help the government. "If their idea of helping is to divert resources from dealing with the disease outbreak to dealing with a parliamentary debate, including ministerial time, I'm glad they're not setting out to disrupt us," he said.

The spat between Mr Brown and Mr Yeo came as some surprise because both sides attempted to mend fences after they clashed last week on the government's initial response to the crisis.

Mr Yeo opened by offering his support for the measures. He said: "We on this side of the house, in the opposition, will give our full backing to all the measures that are needed to contain the spread of foot and mouth disease, to assist livestock farmers through the crisis, to maintain food supplies and to restore export markets."

But Mr Brown snapped when Mr Yeo criticised the government for not setting aside time for a Commons debate on the crisis. Announcing that the Tories would hold the debate in their own time, Mr Yeo asked: "Do you recognise that the heartbreaking prospect for many farmers today is not just the loss of their livelihood, but the destruction of their life's work? The risk of human tragedies under these circumstances is very real."

Eric Pickles, Tory MP for Brentwood and Ongar where the outbreak was first identified, praised the "sharp-eyed" veterinary official who had spotted the disease and prevented an even worse disaster. But Mr Pickles criticised the government for failing to update its website on the crisis on a regular basis.

Angela Smith, Labour MP for Basildon, rounded on "irresponsible" journalists who had walked across farms within exclusion zones. "The best story for a farmer is that there are no new outbreaks and that all reporters should act with the utmost responsibility," she said.

Mr Brown said that camera crews were buzzing over infected land in helicopters, possibly spreading the disease.

Gordon Prentice, Labour MP for Pendle, said he could not understand how farmers could claim that they were not aware of the signs of the disease. He said that when he visited the government website to find out what a pig with the disease looked like he found that its snout became "very, very strange indeed".

fields.headline: The future of the Tube
fields.standfirst: Special report: Transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The London mayor Ken Livingstone and his transport commissioner Bob Kiley are lined up against the government over the future of the city's underground system. Mark Oliver explains the issues.
fields.body:
The London mayor Ken Livingstone and his transport commissioner Bob Kiley are lined up against the government over the future of the city's underground system. Mark Oliver explains the issues.

Has there been any progress on this saga?
Not really, no. Tony Blair has closed ranks with John Prescott and Gordon Brown in their determination to force Mr Livingstone and Mr Kiley to "knuckle down" and work within the government's £15bn blueprint for modernising London's Underground system. The government's public-private partnership (PPP) plan has been savaged by the pair. PPP should have started almost a year ago and with both sides so entrenched and talks barely sputtering along, you can expect more delays before a deal is agreed upon.

What is PPP?
It is the Treasury's concoction of a public-private partnership that would split the tube into four sections. Three of these would be run by the private sector on 30-year leases. Just one of the sections - the actual running of the trains and signals - would stay in the public sphere. The private sector would raise the funds and be reimbursed by the users of the lines, London Underground and the government.

What are the objections to PPP?
Mr Kiley, an American who has had success in rejuvenating similar underground networks in New York and Boston, has said that the proposed split-responsibility is unsafe and that a "unified management" is crucial. He has an alternative proposal, centred on unified management. Mr Kiley would keep the basic structure of the tube in one piece and use private sector bidders as long term contractors under his control. One way of doing this would be for him to have a 51% holding in the companies.

However, the Treasury appears to have taken little interest in his ideas, and he complains that he can not get through to talk to the people who matter to work towards an alternative. He claims that what the Treasury envisions is essentially privatisation. What is needed, he says, is simple government funding of the necessary investment in infrastructure, which he estimates at £500m-£700m a year. "The 'fatal flaw' is simply that the public will own the system but not control it", Mr Kiley says of PPP.

What is the government's position?
It is complicated by their being two camps - the Treasury which wants to push through PPP and the Prescott camp, which is more open minded about alternatives and has some of Mr Blair's sympathies.

Mr Kiley has painted a picture of Mr Brown, as "the Wizard of Oz", pulling the levers behind the scenes to control Mr Prescott, who is officially leading the talks.

The cost of sorting the tube out could amount to £13bn over the next 15 years and the Treasury appears adamant that this should be kept out of public accounts, which an unmodified PPP plan does very neatly. They don't want the taxpayer being ultimately responsible for the risk as they would be under Mr Kiley's vision.

The Treasury's argument is that although the work would inevitably cost much more if done by profit-making, private firms, this would be recouped be heightened efficiency of private managers.

Ministers are concerned that public sector management is irreparably inefficient. They point to the Jubilee line extension which doubled in cost to £3.5bn and was completed 18 months late.

The government are also concerned that if PPP were not adopted, it would also leave Aslef, the train driver's union, in a powerful position, as it showed earlier this month by just about closing the entire network for a day.

How are talks going?
On February 2 it was agreed that Transport for London and London Underground would have "unified management of the Underground" and that the commissioner would "take the lead" in making this happen, Mr Kiley said.

However, he said that on February 14 senior government representatives requested a special meeting with him at which he was told the private sector must control the three new private companies being set up to provide and maintain infrastructure for the tube and that this was "non-negotiable". Mr Kiley now believes further talks under the February 2 agreement would be "fruitless".

What do the private firms think?
Frustration is the dominant emotion from the four consortiums left in the running. The companies complain that the delay - PPP should have been online by April last year - is costing them, and that they have had to shed scores of planners.

There are noises of some degree of flexibility coming from the firms about tweaking PPP but not anywhere near the scale of change wanted by Mr Kiley. They definitely don't want to pour millions into a business if it is controlled by someone else. There are also complaints that any major deviation from the original plan would cause crippling delays as firms would have to tender their bids again.

However, no one is going to walk away just yet, as doing so would mean losing the potential £30m in compensation each bidder is entitled to if PPP does not go ahead.

Why is it time for change?
London's underground network has its roots in the 1800s: the world's first underground railway - between Paddington (Bishop's Road) and Farringdon Street - was opened by the Metropolitan Railway on January 10 1863, with trains hauled by steam engines. Although the existing infrastructure is not quite that old, much of it does date back to the 1920s and it is just not able to cope with today's daily commuters, which number in the hundreds of thousands. The government reckons several billion pounds are needed to update the network to one that can handle that volume of traffic.

Tony Travers, director of the London School of Economics Greater London Group, says: "For decades the tube was subjected to pitiful levels of investment. Old wires were not replaced, tunnels were not strengthened, track has not been renewed."

There was an increase in investment in the early 90's in the wake of the Kings Cross fire but the levels then fell again.

Among transport experts there is a belief that chronic under-investment has compromised safety, which would leave the government ill-equipped to defend any disaster which claimed human lives.

What happens next?
There needs to be some light at the end of the tunnel and many believe this is only possible of the prime minister intervenes and introduces a better framework for either working out a deal between Mr Kiley or just pushing through with PPP regardless.

fields.headline: Lib Dems unveil campaign poster
fields.trailText:
3.30pm: The Lib Dems have unveiled a campaign poster which tries to turn voter apathy to their advantage, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Jan 31: Lib Dems claim moral high ground
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats have unveiled an election campaign poster which tries to turn voter apathy to its advantage.

The campaign, unveiled today by Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy, cites evidence from Mori polls indicating that 36% of people would vote for the party if they thought it could win in their constituency.

The posters feature a map of Britain largely coloured in the party's trademark yellow.

Next to it are the words, "If you thought the Liberal Democrats could win in your area, this is how you'd vote."

The campaign was created at banc by director of advertising Peter Harold. It was unveiled today along with the party's election slogan, "A real chance for real change", which appears on the poster.

"There is a strand of Liberal Democrat in all of us," said Banc chairman Robert Bean.

"If we all allowed ourselves to vote that way, the picture would be stunning, as this map shows."

webTitle: Kennedy tax plans to boost schools and NHS

fields.headline: Kennedy tax plans to boost schools and NHS
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrats are to enter the general election as the only main party committed to raising income tax under plans to put extra revenues into health and education.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats are to enter the general election as the only main party committed to raising income tax under plans to put extra revenues into health and education.

The party's alternative budget, published yesterday and forming the basis of its manifesto, reaffirms the Lib Dems' best-known policy - an extra penny on the basic rate of income tax to fund an increase of £3bn a year for education.

The party will also stand apart from Labour and the Tories in pledging a new top tax band, introducing a 50p rate for those earning over £100,000. The extra income created by this and changes to capital gains tax would go towards new investment in the health service, including an average extra £1,000 a year for nurses, an extra 11,000 hospital beds and guaranteed access to NHS dentists.

The proposals leave the Lib Dems as the sole defenders of increased taxation, but maintaining that they will forego "stealth taxes" imposed by the chancellor, Gordon Brown.

The Lib Dem Treasury spokesman, Matthew Taylor, yesterday said his party's proposals offered transparency. The party proposes sending every taxpayer an annual "citizen's tax contract", spelling out exactly how much tax is being raised.

The Lib Dem leader, Charles Kennedy, said the proposals amounted to an "honest, fully costed" package of investment.

Labour said the plans did not add up and suggested that the Lib Dem policy of a penny on income tax for education, would not raise enough money to match Labour's education spending. The chief secretary to the Treasury, Andrew Smith, called the plans "a menu without prices ... uncosted promises funded over and over again by the same tax increases".

"In their 1997 election manifesto, the Lib Dems pledged £3.5bn extra for the NHS over five years but with Labour, between 2000 and 2004, NHS investment is set to grow by a third in real terms," he said.

webTitle: Scientists' 20-year fight against foot and mouth

fields.headline: Scientists' 20-year fight against foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The government's draconian response to the outbreak of foot and mouth disease was based on 20 years of research in British universities.
fields.body:
The government's draconian response to the outbreak of foot and mouth disease was based on 20 years of research in British universities.

Since the last major outbreak of foot and mouth disease in 1967-1968, researchers in the UK have gained a better understanding of how airborne diseases are transmitted and how to discover what type of the disease is being faced. This information has allowed the government to formulate predictions about the extent of transmission and to justify drastic measures to prevent the disease's spread.

But the crisis in agriculture is now preventing the continuation of that very research.

A better understanding of how foot and mouth disease was transmitted dates from the last major outbreak. Glasgow University's head of microbiology and public health, Professor Oswald Jarrett said, "In two of the worst areas, it was noticed that the disease had spread with the prevailing wind over a wide area."

As a result of that realisation, researchers from universities' laboratories around the country explored how far particular strains of the disease can spread. This information proved very accurate when combined with advanced computer modelling. For example, in 1981 foot and mouth disease spread to the Isle of Wight from France, and the Ministry of Agriculture was able to correctly predict that the distance between the island and the mainland was great enough to prevent the disease from spreading.

Key to proving that the 1981 outbreak came from France was research over the 20 years before that allowed much more reliable typing of diseases. Once the government could show that the type of foot and mouth in the Isle of Wight was the same as that across the Channel, it was hard to argue about its source.

Specialists from university veterinary departments worked collaboratively over decades on this research, but it was the Institute of Animal Health that made the greatest breakthroughs. Because they have very secure containment facilities, they could most directly study infected pigs without posing a risk to the countryside.

Twenty years of research revolutionised the understanding foot and mouth disease. But, that does not make the current outbreak less damaging. Professor Bob Ward, Liverpool's senior lecturer in farm medicine said: "There is now a lot more we can do with vast amounts of information about this disease. But, we can't say that we'll cope better now than in the 60s. The ground rules have changed: the structure of farming has changed. But I'm sure that both these advances have been helpful."

However, Britain's agricultural research centres are as paralysed in the countryside as everyone else is. Professor Donald Bloom, a Cambridge University professor of animal welfare believes that at the moment research is not affected, but that if the ban on non-essential travel to the countryside continues, veterinary discovery could suffer.

Professor Bloom said, "There is the potential that if researchers can't go out to herds, then serious damage could be done to their work. We do have research areas that will be affected."

His colleagues agree. Professor Ward said, "I've got a colleague who works with diseases in dairy cattle and it'll delay things. She can work on other things at the moment, but it depends how long the crisis lasts."

Professor Jarrett said, "It must have all sorts of ramifications for research, it's a real nightmare."

webTitle: Exeter takes legal action after Ofsted verdict

fields.headline: Exeter takes legal action after Ofsted verdict
fields.trailText: Exeter University is taking legal action in a bid to prevent the Teacher Training Agency withdrawing its accreditation and jeopardising an estimated £1.4m in funding.
fields.body:
Exeter University is taking legal action in a bid to prevent the Teacher Training Agency withdrawing its accreditation and jeopardising an estimated £1.4m in funding.

The agency began the process of withdrawing Exeter's accreditation for initial teacher training after one course failed an Ofsted inspection.

The unprecedented move comes after years of tension between universities and colleges on one side and Ofsted and the agency on the other over teacher training methods. Under Chris Woodhead, the former head of the inspectorate and an outspoken critic of "trendy" child-centred methods, the system of assessing teacher training was tightened and a second round of visits carried out.

The announcement raises the prospect that British universities are prepared to go down the American route and become more litigious over accreditation and quality assessments by Ofsted or the Quality Assurance Agency.

Inspectors failed the English component of the primary undergraduate degree programme at Exeter's school of education but the university said it was not contesting the result itself. However the agency's action in withdrawing accreditation - and so funding - was "disproportionate and unreasonable", said a spokesperson.

"If the decisions are implemented, the school will lose an estimated £1.4 million in funding and associated income over the next three years, and it faces the prospect of losing accreditation for the whole of its ITT provision."

The university stated its intention to close the now failed course some time ago. Their final intake of thirty-five degree students was in October 2000.

Exeter said its school for education had been one of the country's leading providers of initial teacher training in the UK, placed in the top category of providers for almost all secondary courses. The last inspection in primary mathematics resulted in seven grade ones, one of the best results in the country, added the university.

The university spokesperson went on: "In many respects, the University is doing exactly what the government and the TTA want: it is recruiting well to national areas of teacher shortage. All of this is put at risk because of the TTA's decisions to commence withdrawal of accreditation procedures and impose massive cuts in funding across all primary provision on the basis of one inspection of one component of a degree course that is closing. It will seriously damage other ITT areas of the School and indeed non-ITT areas of activity - activities that are meeting the national agenda so successfully."

Because of the impending legal action, the TTA refused to comment on this specific case, but a spokesman argued that, "removing accreditation is the standard result of failing an OFSTED report. This process is designed to help failing educational institutions."
