fields.headline: Cash we must have
fields.standfirst: A new funding review produced by cash-starved university heads has set them on a collision course with a government saying a pre-election 'no' to top-up fees.  Donald MacLeod  weighs up the options
fields.trailText: "We can't go on like this" is the refrain of the vice-chancellors' review of funding options.
fields.body:
"We can't go on like this" is the refrain of the vice-chancellors' review of funding options.

Whatever David Blunkett may insist about no top-up fees under a second Labour government, it is clear that university heads have by no means abandoned the introduction of market fees as a possible - indeed probable - outcome to fill the funding gap. A four-year parliament would not be a long preparation for this kind of change, pointed out Sir Howard Newby, president of Universities UK, formerly the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals.

Its report, hopefully entitled New Directions for Higher Education Funding, sets out the "significant damage" done by many years of underfunded expansion. Since 1989 resources per student have fallen by 38 %, following a decrease of 20% between 1976 and 1989.

Staff-student ratios declined to an average of 1 to 17 (1 to 23 if funding for research which is included in the average unit of funding is excluded), libraries and lecture halls were run down, drop-out rates increased, especially among universities offering access to the disadvantaged. So it argues for additional funding of at least £620m a year including;

* maintaining funding per student in real terms at 2000-01 levels - £75m;

* selective improvements in pay and conditions to recruit and retain staff and to provide for improved staff development - £195m;

* an improved funding premium for disadvantaged students - which could cost up to an additional £100 million if the suggestion of an increase in the premium to 20% is implemented.

The costs of expansion and equal opportunity changes for staff would bring the total to £900m per annum.

Four main options have been distilled by the steering group chaired by Sir William Taylor. The Cubie option adopted in Scotland is relegated to an annexe but the key concept of graduate contributions to replace upfront fees is considered, as is the Tory plan to endow institutions with windfall tax profits.

FOR - additions to funding through increased block grants are readily identifiable. The government would be keen to acknowledge what additional funding it had provided. Notwithstanding the policy changes in Scotland and the commitment by the Liberal Democrats to abolish fee contributions, they appear in practice to have been accepted at their present level, even if grudgingly, by a majority of electors, parents and students.

Fees at their present level make a modest contribution to equity by charging most to those best able to pay. In theory this option o

AGAINST: this option is wholly dependent on how favourably the government of the day is prepared to look upon the funding needs of higher education. There can be no guarantee, if additional funding is secured in the short-term, that it will not be subsequently eroded as economic circumstances become less favourable or following a change of government.

The option increases the dependency of institutions on public funds and is therefore likely to add to rather than decrease the demands for scrutiny and accountability.

Market fee s - fees could be charged according to the cost of providing courses (engineering more expensive than business studies, for instance); or by the return to graduates - higher fees for law and medicine and lower fees for history, as the Australians have attempted to do. They could also be differentiated by subject and institution on the basis of market forces.

FOR - fee deregulation would in principle allow institutions to set their fees at levels that, subject to the pressures of market forces, more nearly reflected the costs of providing teaching. To meet the level of funding need of some £620m identified in Section 2 would require average fees per person to increase by about £700 per annum before taking into account the need to fund scholarships for the poorest students. Deregulation of fees would also encourage diversity amongst institutions and potentially offer greater choice to students. Higher average fees could also be expected to increase the pressure on institutions from individuals and their families to meet their expectations about levels of support and feedback from staff and quality of resources more generally. They could thus improve value for money in the provision of teaching and learning.

AGAINST - on the assumption that scholarship schemes would be in place to enable the poorest students to pay their fees, there would be substantial consequences for students from families with intermediate incomes.

There is evidence from the DfEE study that many parents in 1998-99 were not making their contribution to fees. The financial implications for different institutions and subjects would also be very uncertain and potentially damaging. Those institutions that have been most successful in attracting students from the poorest families would be least well placed to charge substantially higher fees and might also be under the most pressure to reduce fees in certain subjects. They would then find it even more difficult to provide for the additional needs of those students from the poorest backgrounds.

Income-contingent graduate contributions

FOR - with a graduate contribution at the level proposed in Scotland of £2,000 this option could generate some £600m a year for an endowment fund with current annual numbers of graduates across the UK. Much of this would, however, come from publicly funded income-contingent loans.

There would be less of a barrier to participation because there would be no up-front fees and money could be steered to institutions opening up access. This option could also provide an incentive to employers to pay the graduate contribution as a form of "golden hello", especially in fields where competition for graduates is strongest.

AGAINST - this option would require additional public funds to replace the current private contributions to fees. This would put institutions at greater risk of further reductions in the level of funding per student. It is more likely that over time that public funding will be reduced as funds flow from an endowment fund and this source of funds will cease to be truly additional.

Institutional endowment

FOR - this is one of the few schemes that could give universities increased autonomy and independence of action if the right terms are agreed. It would enable the most competitive and popular institutions and maybe also those specialist institutions operating in a niche market fully to exploit their comparative advantage, and facilitate the further development of world class universities and specialist institutions. It could encourage development of a "culture of giving" such as exists in the US.

AGAINST - given the sums involved, it would take many yers to endow the whole sector. Meanwhile, there would be a return to an explicit dividing line between institutions.

Would any Government be willing to give universities the degree of freedom that, theoretically at least, this option entails? The Conservatives have already stated that even endowed universities would not be free to determine their own undergraduate fees. Would any universities seek to opt out if deregulation stopped short of fees? Such a scheme might have a negative impact on widening participation.

Full report on www.universitiesuk.ac.uk/funding/report3.asp

webTitle: Rethink on school tests threatens a rite of passage

fields.headline: Rethink on school tests threatens a rite of passage
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Questions over the usefulness of SATs could end an adolescent rite of passage, says Julian Borger
fields.body:
The three most important letters for any American teenager who wants to go to college are SAT. It stands for Scholastic Aptitude Test, a multiple-choice general examination that often sets the path for your future. It has been a rite of passage for generations.

But now the biggest "consumer" of SAT scores in the country, the University of California, is questioning their usefulness. The university's president, Richard Atkinson has recommended that the basic aptitude test, known as SAT I, be dropped from the entrance requirements, arguing that they put black and Hispanic students at a disadvantage.

In its place, he said, his university would take a more "holistic" approach to assessing applicants, one that more closely reflects overall achievement in school.

His announcement, delivered at the American Council on Education, has been a front-page bombshell around the country. It is hard to exaggerate the centrality of the SAT to middle-class American life. School life is increasingly oriented around the test, with teachers (who are judged on SAT results as well) taking more and more time instructing students on how to "beat" the test.

Nervous parents pour money into extra-curricular coaching. Last year for example, 150,000 students spent more than $100m on SAT preparation courses. When Mr Atkinson visited a class of 12-year-olds at an expensive private school last year, he learned that they spent hours every month doing drills like studying long lists of analogies.

"The goal was not developing the students' reading and writing abilities but rather improving their test-taking skills," he said. After further investigation he concluded: "America's overemphasis on the SAT is compromising our educational system."

Mr Atkinson's proposals have yet to be considered by the university's governing board, but the fact that such a giant figure on the educational stage should question this shibboleth is significant enough. His remarks also have political ramifications, at a time when a newly-elected president is extolling the virtues of standardised testing and calling for more of it.

It also dips into US racial politics. The policy of affirmative action (a system of preferences for ethnic minorities) was scrapped in California in 1996, and since then black and Hispanic enrolment has dropped. The SAT tests are a major factor here, as blacks on average score 198 points left than whites. For similar reasons, about 300 small private colleges have abandoned SAT I as an indicator of aptitude.

Mr Atkinson has dived into turbulent waters. Many in the educational establishment believe that the right way to address low test scores in poor, black schools is to address their academic problems, not simply lower the bar.

In any case, they argue, "holistic" testing (which are supposed to provide a broader test of achievement through school grades, interviews and focused single-subject tests) are just as open to systemic cultural prejudice.

Private school pupils are more likely to have the confidence to shine in the limelight. In the absence of a unifying standardised test, universities and colleges could more easily be challenged on their acceptance criteria.

It is a debate that goes to the heart of US education, which is lagging badly behind the school systems in mainland Europe and Japan. As part of the nationwide rethink nothing, it seems, is sacred.

It is a debate that goes to the heart of US education, which is lagging badly behind the school systems in mainland Europe and Japan. As part of the nationwide rethink nothing, it seems, is sacred. fields.headline: Mum, my loan's hurting
fields.standfirst: Students are mobilising parents in their battle against loans and fees, reports  Donald MacLeod
fields.trailText: Parents are being recruited by the student movement as allies in their campaign for better funding and an end to tuition fees.
fields.body:
Parents are being recruited by the student movement as allies in their campaign for better funding and an end to tuition fees.

Old-style campaigning this week, such as a shutdown of lectures on Thursday and other publicity stunts under the slogan of "Don't suffer in silence", are unlikely to get much attention off campus, let alone trouble ministers. But now the leadership of the National Union of Students has decided to tackle the Blair government where it is most sensitive: middle class swing voters with aspirations.

Letters are going out to all secondary schools inviting parent- teacher associations to become involved in campaigning for a better deal for students. The aim is to build up a database of parent contacts, explained Owain James, NUS president. Students might not like their parents being asked for tuition fees, but there are no doubts about seeking their support in the campaign.

"Over time we will look to build alliances. We feel the more people who are involved the better. Just because parents are not organised in a trade union does not mean they should not be involved. They have their kids' best interests at heart. Many of them are middle England swing voters who have aspirations for their children," he said.

Aware that it is difficult to arouse student activism these days, the NUS is trying to make its views heard via the i nternet with a relaunched website. They are being urged to use faxyourMP.com to contact politicians. A postcard petition is being organised jointly with the lecturers' unions, Natfhe and the Association of University Teachers.

The announcement by David Blunkett, the education secretary, that top-up fees were ruled out for the next parliament if Labour won the election, threatened to steal the students' thunder before the week of action. But they claim some credit for persuading the political parties to drop the idea.

They also believe that even though the danger of fee increases by some universities has been lifted, they have a growing grievance over the level of support. Mounting evidence of student debt and increased drop-out rates has been given to the Commons select committee on education.

The NUS argues that the government now has an extra £950m available to spend on higher education because of changes to the accounting rules for public borrowing. Broadly, the change means that student loans are not counted as straight public spending on the Public Sector Borrowing Requirement because a large part of the money will come back to the Treasury.

The change would, for instance, make it much less expensive for the government to introduce nationwide the graduate contributions scheme adopted in Scotland following the Cubie report. Ministers have up to now ruled it out on cost grounds.

Although Blunkett has made his position clear on top-up fees, vice-chancellors remain convinced that market fees set by universities are a real option in time. It is one of four main options set out in a report by Universities UK (see page 14).

James expressed his disappointment at the vice-chancellors' report and said they had downplayed the Cubie option which the NUS regarded as the best.

"The report fails to cover the inseparable issue of how a student can bear the cost of increased fee contributions on top of mounting debt. What is the point of increasing the funding per student and improving the learning experience if students can't afford to benefit from it?"

Students were already paying £1.5bn a year more than in 1997, he said. "NUS is worried that the serious issue of equal access to higher education is being ignored whilst additional fees remain on the agenda."

www.nusonline.co.uk

fields.headline: Mind the gap
fields.standfirst: Taking a year out from studying is becoming more and more popular, but there can be hidden dangers in travelling abroad, says  Abul Taher
fields.trailText: Taking a gap year to travel abroad is the ideal way to break out of the cycle of study and work for many students in Britain. Prince William's recent, much-publicised stint in Chile has even given globe-trotting for a year between school and university a royal seal of approval.
fields.body:
Taking a gap year to travel abroad is the ideal way to break out of the cycle of study and work for many students in Britain. Prince William's recent, much-publicised stint in Chile has even given globe-trotting for a year between school and university a royal seal of approval.

Prince William was one of among an estimated 23,000 students who deferred their entry this academic year to begin their course the coming September. What's more, an increasing number of students from all dis ciplines are spending a term or a year abroad at a foreign university as part of their course.

Officials at the Erasmus exchange programme, the British branch of which is based at Kent University, say that at least 10,000 UK students are abroad in Europe in any given year as part of their studies. And throughout Europe there are more than 100,000 students mobile over the course of any academic year from the 2,000 European universities that participate in the Erasmus programme.

But for a lot of students, whether backpacking or studying, a year abroad can be an uncertain and even nightmarish experience. A lack of familiarity with local customs and an ignorance of legal rights and working practices have caused many an upset for those who had set off with dreams of broadening their horizons.

Alan Lansdowne, a graduate from Sheffield University, was almost beaten to death in a small town in Russia. As part of a year abroad for his degree in Russian and German, he was living in the town of Voronezh, situated about a nine-hour drive south from Moscow. Although Lansdowne, now 24, and his British friends were told not to walk alone at night, they began to flout the rules as they became more familiar with the town.

One January night, Lansdowne was drinking with some friends and decided to walk home alone in the early hours of the morning. "I got to a crossroads, and these guys were standing there, asking me to come towards them," he says. The gang surrounded him within minutes and started punching and kicking him. He managed to stagger home, the 10-minute journey taking him more than an hour. When inside the flat, he collapsed, waking his Russian landlady. He was taken to the local hospital where doctors found that as well as having extensive internal bleeding, he had also ruptured his spleen.

Lansdowne later found out that his beating may have been part of a local ritual that none of the foreign students had been warned of. He was told by a Russian friend that the night he was beaten marked the beginning of the new year for Russian Orthodox Christians, a coincidence which may have been the reason for the events of that evening. "The experience has made me wiser. I say to myself, if I can go through that, then I can do anything," he says now.

As well as the thousands of students taking a gap year before starting their degree studies, there are many who do the same after graduation. Almost all of those who take a gap year before committing themselves to full-time employment say they need to see the world and experience different things before settling down.

Burhan Uddin Ahmed, 25, from east London, was one of those students who wanted to see more of life after his studies. Having completed his MA in journalism studies at London's Goldsmith's College, Ahmed bought a round-the-world air ticket. He flew to Thailand and then on to Australia, but it was while in Brazil that he was confronted by a gunman.

Ahmed, who recently returned to London, knew coach hijackings were frequent, but nevertheless decided to take a 14-hour coach journey from the north-eastern city of Puerto Seguro to Salvador at night. At three in the morning, passengers were awoken by a lone gunman who demanded money and valuables from everyone on board.

Ahmed says he felt extremely nervous, as he was sitting near the front, very close to where the gunman was standing. "I knew if the gunman started firing I would have been one of the first to get shot," he says. The gunman eventually fled after taking valuables and cash from all the passengers.

Although he reached Salvador, he flew back to England shortly afterwards. Like Lansdowne, he now puts this traumatic event down to experience.

Although violent cases like these are rare, other problems abound. Many British students abroad become victims "of low pay, sexual harassment and downright exploitation," according to a recent survey by the BBC Essentials website.

One in 20 of those surveyed said they had been victims of sexual harassment while abroad. "Almost double the amount of boys to girls had been sexually harassed," explains Zillah Myers, the producer of the website. She adds that women were more likely to be paid a poor salary than men.

The most popular jobs among gap-year students who earn as they travel were bar work and waiting on tables. But of the 509 people interviewed in the BBC survey, one-third complained of working very long hours, and a substantial number told how they were badly treated by their native work colleagues.

Leighanne Springate, 25, was one of the participants in the survey. After graduating from Leeds University with a degree in maths and management in 1998, she travelled for a year before settling down to a full-time job as a finance manager. Part of her year out was spent in the US working in a children's summer camp. She was paid $800 for two months' work.

"The camp job was a nightmare," she says. On average, she claims, she worked for 13-14 hours a day, getting up at 7.30 in the morning, and finishing at around 10 in the evening. She now wishes she had found out more about the working conditions at the camp before setting off.

Despite the potential pitfalls, experts believe that gap years are set to become even more popular in the future. Michael Snoughton, an official at the Gap Activity Project, believes that the reason behind this increased enthusiasm may be that students are more hard-up than ever before, and so want to improve their CVs - and maximise their earnings - by boasting of this sort of experience.

Gap years, he says, have become steadily more popular in the past four or five years, as a university education becomes steadily more expensive. UCAS figures support this view. In 1994, they show that 14,530 students took a gap year, compared with 22,522 in 1999. Figures for this year are expected to be higher still.

Snoughton, whose organisation offers a package travel deal combined with voluntary work, believes that gap years abroad are immensely beneficial to students, giving them different perspectives in the world of politics and culture as well as skills. "Every 18-year-old should consider it," he says. But - even if the idea is to escape study for a while - they would be well advised to do their homework first.

Survival guide

When planning a gap year or a study period abroad, research your chosen region before setting off.
If on a study exchange programme, find out all you can about the host university and its location from your own department.
If on a gap year, get advice from the Foreign & Commonwealth Office about the possible dangers of visiting some countries (see its website).
When abroad, note the telephone number and address of the nearest British Embassy, which can provide invaluable help in a crisis situation.
Get vaccinated against illnesses like TB and malaria before you go. Take out good medical and possession insurance.
Find out about work permits and other documents if you want to work in some areas. Illegal workers can do nothing if employers refuse to pay them.
Don't carry much cash with you. Traveller's cheques are safer and ATM machines are in almost all countries.
Don't go out alone at night in areas you don't know. Stick with a group of people you trust.
In some countries, especially South American, avoid long journeys by night on a coach or by road. Highway robbery is frequent.

Useful websites BBC Essentials
Erasmus
Foreign & Commonwealth Office
Gap Activity Project
World Challenge Expeditions

fields.headline: Foreign mission
fields.standfirst:
There were only 20 new science teachers in South Africa last year. So should we be relying on them to solve our teaching shortages? Chris McGreal reports
"It's pupils spitting on the floor I find most shocking": new recruit Daryl Niewenhuys
fields.trailText: They don't know it, but those South African teachers who make it as far as an interview with the headteachers from London's Borough of Newham are practically guaranteed a job.
fields.body:
They don't know it, but those South African teachers who make it as far as an interview with the headteachers from London's Borough of Newham are practically guaranteed a job.

Youth and inexperience are no bar, but near-incomprehensible English is one of the few disqualifications. So is the revelation made by a couple of white teachers that they were looking to escape black rule in the new South Africa. Newham is hardly the place to go to seek racial exclusivity.

The demand for teachers in Britain is such that Cauthar Tooley, head of Sarah Bonnell girls' comprehensive in Stratford, and Richard Lucas, head of Essex primary, would have taken all 75 teachers they interviewed in Port Elizabeth last week had they all been suitable. As it is, more than 60 are likely to end up in east London in the coming months.

The two headteachers spent their half-term break in South Africa to recruit for all of Newham's 14 state secondary schools and numerous primaries. This week they are moving on to Johannesburg for more interviews. A team from a second London borough, Tower Hamlets, is currently hiring in Cape Town and Durban.

The two boroughs could easily scoop up a couple of hundred of South Africa's best teachers, much to the chagrin of the country's education minister, Kadar Asmal, who has accused British schools of "raiding" his own of staff they can ill afford to lose.

The Newham team try to dress up their hunt for teachers to South Africa's best advantage. "It's a reciprocal arrangement," says Lucas. "We need teachers. It will fulfil their need for career development. If you're losing 10% of your teachers but 90% come back with their experience enhanced, I think that's actually to the benefit of South Africa.

"The situation in my school at the moment is that we have three South Africans and an Australian covering long-term vacancies. People go sick and I'm faced with this situation because there are no supply teachers."

More than 1,000 teachers applied for interview in Port Elizabeth. They came from across the Eastern Cape, from privileged white private schools as well as from rural primaries in the once nominally independent homeland of Transkei.

Recruitment is organised by TimePlan, the UK's largest teacher-supply agency. It flew the Newham and Tower Hamlets delegations out, and whittled the applicants down to those chosen for final interview. Lucas was struck by the high standard of applicants and the poor conditions they claimed to work in.

"The horror stories we hear: class sizes, lack of resources and lack of opportunity for professional development. I think these teachers have a very difficult time of it," he says. "We're not going to take rubbish. These are good teachers who can't find decent jobs."

Mark Conely was an easy choice. For a start, he teaches maths and physics. He is eloquent and, with a fiancee and young son remaining behind, committed to returning to South Africa, which defuses the politics somewhat.

"I would like to teach in a class of 25 pupils where I can enrich myself in terms of my skills," he says. "I thought it would be a great experience to go to a highly developed country like England to gain knowledge in my subject area and compare the two systems. I see myself as the type of person who can go and stand in any classroom in the world."

Conely is 35 and "coloured", or mixed-race. For nine years he has taught at Bertram secondary school in the "coloured" township on the outskirts of Port Elizabeth. The school has a good reputation with close to a 90% pass rate in the matric exams, nearly double the national average and far above most township schools. But the average class size is 45 pupils and there is a serious short age of text books and science equipment. The good students are despatched one day a week to a nearby university to use its resources.

Conely's extra-curricular activities - he is a founder of the schools life skills programme - went down well. To the teachers from London, that demonstrated a dedication beyond the immediate demands of the classroom - another prerequisite for teaching in Newham.

"Mark seems to be a very committed, hard-working teacher," says Tooley. "Look at the success of Mark's school. You don't get that unless the teachers are very committed."

But it is precisely that commitment that Asmal, the education minister, fears losing. Conely is in the category of teachers - experienced in maths and science - that the country most needs. South Africa produced only 100 new maths teachers and 20 new science teachers last year.

"There is a disturbing trend for recruitment campaigns to be run in South Africa to recruit professionals due to the excellent higher education provided at our universities and technikons. However, those doing and supporting such campaigns often have little concern for the development needs of South Africa and the costs and effort that have been put into producing good-quality graduates," says Asmal.

TimePlan recruits from a number of European and Commonwealth countries but its literature says South African teachers are particularly welcome in the UK. The agency argues that it is not plundering the country's teaching stock because there are more teachers than jobs available in South Africa, and those who go to the UK frequently return with additional skills. But it concedes that a major attraction for applicants is the high rate of pay in Britain compared with South Africa. Most teachers earn about four times as much in the UK and, although living costs are higher, taxes are considerably lower.

Conely is torn. "I agree to a certain extent with our minister. He's right to be concerned. There are doctors and other professionals leaving the country permanently. But we are a free market system. You must balance the right of the individual to move with the needs of the country," he says.

Dawn Mbalekwa, 25, is more typical of the recruits heading for Newham. She trained as a primary school teacher but has no full-time experience. The young Xhosa woman says she wants to improve her skills and return to South Africa, but she freely admits that her primary reason for taking a job in Newham is to travel.

"Everybody in my class at Rhodes university got jobs [as teachers]. I didn't apply for a job here. I want to travel. I'll go to England and then maybe after that to Australia or America," she says.

Until she sat down in front of the headteachers from Newham, Mbalekwa had little idea what kind of school she might find herself in. "From what I've been gathering, I won't be going to one of the posh schools. I'm just lowering my expectations," she says.

Then there are those teachers who have no intention of returning, if only they can get out of South Africa in the first place. "Two of the teachers we didn't take were whites who were very discontented and we didn't feel they would be right for Newham," explains Tooley. "We didn't think they'd fit in. There are 74 languages spoken in my secondary school."

That is part of the attraction of recruiting South African teachers. Mbalekwa is black. She speaks English, Afrikaans and three African languages. She knows about multiracial environments. She has also been briefed on British racism, which may not be as overt as the kind she is used to but can be just as insidious.

But even sensitivity to such issues raises its own problems. Many South Africans continue to call themselves "coloured" even though it is an apartheid term; some believe it marks out their community as having a distinct identity. Others just want to distinguish themselves from the black population.

But Tooley is offended by the word "coloured" and insists on calling Mark Conely "mixed-race". He doesn't want to be called that either.

"That suggests that I don't have a race. I think you should just call me South African," he says, to general agreement.

The school has a good reputation with close to a 90% pass rate in the matric exams, nearly double the national average and far above most township schools. But the average class size is 45 pupils and there is a serious short age of text books and science equipment. The good students are despatched one day a week to a nearby university to use its resources. Conely's extra-curricular activities - he is a founder of the schools life skills programme - went down well. To the teachers from London, that demonstrated a dedication beyond the immediate demands of the classroom - another prerequisite for teaching in Newham. "Mark seems to be a very committed, hard-working teacher," says Tooley. "Look at the success of Mark's school. You don't get that unless the teachers are very committed." But it is precisely that commitment that Asmal, the education minister, fears losing. Conely is in the category of teachers - experienced in maths and science - that the country most needs. South Africa produced only 100 new maths teachers and 20 new science teachers last year. "There is a disturbing trend for recruitment campaigns to be run in South Africa to recruit professionals due to the excellent higher education provided at our universities and technikons. However, those doing and supporting such campaigns often have little concern for the development needs of South Africa and the costs and effort that have been put into producing good-quality graduates," says Asmal. TimePlan recruits from a number of European and Commonwealth countries but its literature says South African teachers are particularly welcome in the UK. The agency argues that it is not plundering the country's teaching stock because there are more teachers than jobs available in South Africa, and those who go to the UK frequently return with additional skills. But it concedes that a major attraction for applicants is the high rate of pay in Britain compared with South Africa. Most teachers earn about four times as much in the UK and, although living costs are higher, taxes are considerably lower. Conely is torn. "I agree to a certain extent with our minister. He's right to be concerned. There are doctors and other professionals leaving the country permanently. But we are a free market system. You must balance the right of the individual to move with the needs of the country," he says. Dawn Mbalekwa, 25, is more typical of the recruits heading for Newham. She trained as a primary school teacher but has no full-time experience. The young Xhosa woman says she wants to improve her skills and return to South Africa, but she freely admits that her primary reason for taking a job in Newham is to travel. "Everybody in my class at Rhodes university got jobs [as teachers]. I didn't apply for a job here. I want to travel. I'll go to England and then maybe after that to Australia or America," she says. Until she sat down in front of the headteachers from Newham, Mbalekwa had little idea what kind of school she might find herself in. "From what I've been gathering, I won't be going to one of the posh schools. I'm just lowering my expectations," she says. Then there are those teachers who have no intention of returning, if only they can get out of South Africa in the first place. "Two of the teachers we didn't take were whites who were very discontented and we didn't feel they would be right for Newham," explains Tooley. "We didn't think they'd fit in. There are 74 languages spoken in my secondary school." That is part of the attraction of recruiting South African teachers. Mbalekwa is black. She speaks English, Afrikaans and three African languages. She knows about multiracial environments. She has also been briefed on British racism, which may not be as overt as the kind she is used to but can be just as insidious. But even sensitivity to such issues raises its own problems. Many South Africans continue to call themselves "coloured" even though it is an apartheid term; some believe it marks out their community as having a distinct identity. Others just want to distinguish themselves from the black population. But Tooley is offended by the word "coloured" and insists on calling Mark Conely "mixed-race". He doesn't want to be called that either. "That suggests that I don't have a race. I think you should just call me South African," he says, to general agreement.

webTitle: 'It's pupils spitting on the floor I find most shocking'

fields.headline: 'It's pupils spitting on the floor I find most shocking'
fields.trailText: "It's the pupils spitting on the floor and the bad language that I find most shocking," admits Daryl Niewenhuys about his new teaching post in England. He arrived from his native Cape Town at the end of December - one of 33 teachers from the area recruited by the London Borough of Newham through Timeplan during a visit to South Africa the previous month.
fields.body:
"It's the pupils spitting on the floor and the bad language that I find most shocking," admits Daryl Niewenhuys about his new teaching post in England. He arrived from his native Cape Town at the end of December - one of 33 teachers from the area recruited by the London Borough of Newham through Timeplan during a visit to South Africa the previous month.

Adjusting to our national curriculum and learning about the torrent of government education initiatives has apparently been a breeze compared with having to deal with the behaviour of some of the more unruly teenagers attending Cumberland School, a sprawling secondary in Canning Town, east London.

Niewenhuys, who turns 27 next month, says: "They spit on the floor, but then you meet the parents and find they do the same so it's not surprising. The language used by pupils towards their teachers is appalling and I'm regularly told to 'fuck off'. If that happened in South Africa, I would immediately go to the school office and get the child removed from class."

At university, Niewenhuys took a BSc in zoology and environmental biology before studying for a postgraduate higher diploma in education. He then taught for four and a half years in two different schools in Cape Town before deciding to apply for a job in London. He had been aware of adverts before, but it took him five years before he was financially and professionally ready to move. Now he is teaching science to 11- to 16-year-olds. Making the adjustment has not been easy. His first days in the classroom were "terrible -a real culture shock, when I had problems getting the lingo right".

But friendly, supportive staff (and particularly headteacher Jane Noble) have helped enormously, he explains, as have plenty of opportunities for "top-up" training. He knows five or six other fellow South Africans who are teaching over here, so does not feel isolated. He is also enjoying the many positive aspects of the job. Last week during half-term, for example, he helped pupils wanting extra support for forthcoming GCSE exams. "They were a highly motivated group who worked hard. They are likely to do well because they want to do well. It was a very different and positive kind of teaching experience for me".

This year, only 23% of pupils at Cumberland got five or more good GCSEs at grades A*-C, although this is still a marked an improvement on 1996, when it was only 10%. Niewenhuys says the pupils come from a very diverse range of backgrounds - representing many countries from all over the world. Overall, he describes them as "very creative and very active".

Niewenhuys is clear that the experience in the UK will, ultimately, make him a better teacher. And the other attractions are clear. He is making the most of his time in London, and the extra money he is earning. "Back home I would earn in a month what I can earn here in four days", he reveals.

fields.headline: Class notes
fields.trailText: * Tony Blair and George Bush pressed the flesh in Washington last week for the first time since Dubya finally landed the top job. But as well as the Blair entourage, there were other British visitors to Camp David and the White House. On Thursday afternoon, the three main winners of an Anglo-American essay competition originally promoted in Guardian Education - whose judges on the US side included none other than Oscar-winning film star Tom Hanks (pictured) and film producer Steven Spielberg - met the US president during a visit to Washington, the top prize for the contest. The lucky winners were Jenny Steer of Stroud High School, Jordan Skittrall of St Edmund's College, Ware and Christopher Hassan-Houghton of Kelvin Hall, Hull. Now we wait to see whether it will become an annual event.
fields.body:
* Tony Blair and George Bush pressed the flesh in Washington last week for the first time since Dubya finally landed the top job. But as well as the Blair entourage, there were other British visitors to Camp David and the White House. On Thursday afternoon, the three main winners of an Anglo-American essay competition originally promoted in Guardian Education - whose judges on the US side included none other than Oscar-winning film star Tom Hanks (pictured) and film producer Steven Spielberg - met the US president during a visit to Washington, the top prize for the contest. The lucky winners were Jenny Steer of Stroud High School, Jordan Skittrall of St Edmund's College, Ware and Christopher Hassan-Houghton of Kelvin Hall, Hull. Now we wait to see whether it will become an annual event.

*The competition was launched last year at the Imperial War Museum in London, where there were massive queues during half-term to the new exhibition based on Channel 4's 1940s House programme. School parties have also been eager visitors to the attraction, which features a reconstruction of the entire house, right down to every last period furnishing. But we've some good news for those of you worried that you might miss it. Originally due to last for only six months, we hear there are plans to extend the exhibition and possibly even make it permanent.

*A former primary school headteacher who suffered a series of heart attacks will this week start a year-long trek around the coast of Britain to raise funds for charity and to help children understand the importance of a healthy lifestyle. Alan Profitt has become the only quadruple heart bypass patient to run marathons, after deciding to throw his energies into helping young people. Footballer Ian Wright will be on the starting line to help 60-year-old Alan on Thursday as he begins his Step Forward for Life walk. He hopes to raise £1m for the drug prevention education charity Life Education Centres to provide a further 20 mobile classrooms for the project. "Twelve years ago I could hardly walk and was expected to die," he said. "I hope that by supporting Life Education Centres I can help more children learn the important lessons that I didn't. The money raised in each area will go towards educating local children about the dangers of drugs and the benefits of a healthy lifestyle". Watch out for Alan on his travels . . .

fields.headline: Can cook, will cook...
fields.standfirst: Our competition winners put their prize to good use, says  Rebecca Smithers
fields.trailText: Jamaican patties, spring rolls, Caribbean salsa salad and calzone were all on the menu for a slap-up school dinner for 70 year 4 pupils from St Teresa's primary school in Morden, Surrey, earlier this month. The pupils all helped to cook the two-course meal - washed down with home-made traditional lemonade and ending with fresh fruit kebabs - with celebrity chef James Martin on the RSA Waitrose Focus on Food Cooking Bus.
fields.body:
Jamaican patties, spring rolls, Caribbean salsa salad and calzone were all on the menu for a slap-up school dinner for 70 year 4 pupils from St Teresa's primary school in Morden, Surrey, earlier this month. The pupils all helped to cook the two-course meal - washed down with home-made traditional lemonade and ending with fresh fruit kebabs - with celebrity chef James Martin on the RSA Waitrose Focus on Food Cooking Bus.

The school won first prize in the Guardian Focus on Food competition 2000 after answering a series of questions about food from around the world. It was an imaginative tie-breaker penned by pupil Ganu Mohanathasan that caught the judges' attention. The bus - a "culinary pantechnicon" that houses a state-of-the-art kitchen and teaching facilities - was used by the school's pupils and teachers for a two-day cooking extravaganza. Parents were invited along to sample the children's cooking in what turned out to be a family and community event.

The Focus on Food campaign was launched by the Royal Society of Arts to tackle the growing problem of youngsters no longer being able to enjoy practical cookery in the classroom. It encourages young people to learn, think about and appreciate food and its preparation. The theme for last year's activities and the competition was to learn about the range of cuisines from across the world that are enjoyed in this country today.

The school's headteacher, Sister St Joseph, said the entire school had benefited from the exercise, while the winning class had worked hard on their entry. She said: "The children undertook a lot of home research around the subject and they were absolutely thrilled to have won.

"The competition was a golden op portunity to celebrate our cultural diversity." Flavia Lasrado, the class teacher, added: "I thought the competition was absolutely brilliant. It gave us the chance for some interesting cross-curricular study and all my pupils enjoyed looking up the words they didn't know and learning a bit more about them. I love cooking - in fact it is one of my favourite hobbies - but there are fewer and fewer opportunities to study it at school because of the focus on literacy, numeracy and IT. The children were over the moon to have won."

Anita Cormack, Focus on Food director, commented: "We were delighted by the number and quality of entries that we received, but we were thrilled that the winning school got so much out of their prize. It was wonderful to see children who don't get many opportunities for hands-on cooking having a go and clearly getting so much enjoyment out of it. The response to the competition reflected the tremendous amount of thought that schools have put into linking food education with the learning of other subjects and the great enthusiasm that teachers and pupils have for practical food education.

fields.headline: On the board
fields.standfirst: The diary of a parent governor
fields.trailText: Half-term, and I can never make up my mind whether I should feel "So soon!" or "At last!". Some of each, perhaps.
fields.body:
Half-term, and I can never make up my mind whether I should feel "So soon!" or "At last!". Some of each, perhaps.

This time, though, to be truthful, "At last!" might win out: our daughter is off to stay with her grandparents for a few days, temporarily solving the childcare headache and rendering the house an almost spookily serene place.

Half-term is a brief respite from the ongoing crisis that is my attempt at so-called "work-life balance". It enables me to start an archaeological dig on some of the stuff that has been forming the paper equivalent of geological sediment in my in-tray marked "governor". Last term's Governor's Bulletin from the local authority, for instance.

Actually, leafing through, I find there's nothing very substantial that I ought to know that I don't already. Under "items to note", I duly note the determinedly upbeat item about the council's participation in public-private partnership. The bulletin reports the selection of Acme Enterprises as "preferred bidder for the delivery of education services in the borough". Few staff, parents, or governors are so chipper about this appointment as the bulletin seems to be. Acme Enterprises is a data services and "software solutions" company.

Underneath the bulletin, however, lies a more interesting document: Report No.16 from the National Association of Governors and Managers (NAGM) research group.

"Governing Body Responsibilities - STILL too great a load?" it asks. The researchers sent out a survey last summer to its members. The return rate was only 25% (which implies a fairly resounding "yes" to the report's main question), so the author acknowledges it is a snapshot, not an exhaustive picture. Yet, more than half of those surveyed had had experience of chairing their governing body; and two-thirds had more than four years' experience.

"The body is now expected to carry out a substantial and increasing management function," she writes. "It is apparent from responses this year that these governors are increasingly of the opinion that their workload and responsibilities are unrealistic. They identify this increase in responsibilities as exacerbating existing problems in the recruitment and retention of governors."

Concern was expressed about the demise of LEAs (see above!). "I am not paid to be a manager," complains one governor quoted by the author. Or indeed paid at all. "I've had enough of this job!" exclaims another, for whom the fact that someone could be bothered to inquire how she or he actually feels was to breach a dam of pent-up frustration. But my favourite line in the report is one noting that, in this year's survey (as opposed to previous years'), "a degree of cynicism has crept into responses". No kidding.

This is definitely more interesting reading, but, once again, not exactly news. For, by coincidence, at the governors' meeting immediately preceding the half-term break, the assembled company was rather stunned to learn from the head, Mr Richardson, that our chair of governors had resigned her post.

Mrs Anthony, a city solicitor (early- to mid 40s, severe bob, charcoal-grey skirt suits; crisp, efficient, discreet, sparing with the old SOH - everything you'd expect), could not be present to convey the news herself. Mr Richardson had instead, he explained, received a letter the day before citing "personal reasons".

For several minutes, the meeting is thrown into disarray - the neatly typed agenda forgotten. Of course, everyone is deeply curious about the "reasons" for Mrs Anthony's apparently sudden decision, but nobody wants to appear nosy. Mr Richardson is either as baffled as the rest of us, or is masking a loyal discretion behind his customary diffidence.

Whatever the true story, what it means for the remaining governors is more work: there will have to be another meeting, and soon, at which the election of a new chair is the chief item on the agenda. On reflection, perhaps it was Mrs Anthony who wrote: "I've had enough of this job."

fields.headline: What choice?
fields.standfirst: 'Parental choice' should allow you to pick the best school for your child. But, says  Alex Benady, whose son was rejected by the local primary, it's the schools that really get to choose
fields.trailText: Deep in the minds of most parents these days, there lurks an unspoken fear of what you might call "the iron law of schooling". The "law" is this: getting your child into a good school equals academic success, fulfilment and a long, happy life. Pick a bad school and the result is academic failure, lowered horizons and a lifetime stacking shelves.
fields.body:
Deep in the minds of most parents these days, there lurks an unspoken fear of what you might call "the iron law of schooling". The "law" is this: getting your child into a good school equals academic success, fulfilment and a long, happy life. Pick a bad school and the result is academic failure, lowered horizons and a lifetime stacking shelves.

It was with these comforting thoughts that I sat with my partner outside the headteacher's study at a local primary school early one Tuesday evening last June. We, like an increasing number of parents, had decided to appeal against the school's decision not to give our son a place in its reception class.

Whatever the rights and wrongs of our case, it didn't occur to us that the appeal - which, after all, forms the cornerstone of the government's policy of "parental choice" - would be anything but impartial, fair and civil. The last thing we expected was an intimidating, ill-tempered slanging match in which the school's representative acted as judge and jury, chairing the meeting, directing the mute appeals panel and deciding what was admissible evidence.

Perhaps on reflection we shouldn't have been surprised. As many parents of children currently receiving rejection letters from their preferred schools will testify, "parental choice" can be little more than a soundbite, given a selection process that is often arbitrary, opaque and unfair from start to finish.

The attempt to inform parental choice through Sats results and league tables has left some schools oversubscribed by a factor of 10 or more. Without the certainty of a place, parents have to apply to several schools. The result is an educational lottery in which some children end up with multiple offers, while others receive none at all.

This hands power to the oversubscribed schools, which are faced with the need to choose between a large number of children - all of whom meet their selection criteria. You don't have to be especially paranoid to imagine that this encourages a certain "subjectivity" in the way some select their intake.

It is the resulting parental bewilderment at the lack of transparency that makes the right to appeal so important. It was certainly a sense of frustration at not being levelled with that moved us to appeal.

The school in question is a good local primary. Not brilliant, but it is the place where all our son's friends from the neighbourhood go. Despite the fact that it had 200 applicants for 30 places, it was the school that we wanted for our son.

We knew that we scored poorly on the school's three admission criteria as laid out in the prospectus. We don't live especially close - it's about a 10- minute walk. Our son has no siblings at the school and no special needs.

But through our local network we learnt that the entire nursery class was being promoted to the reception class. Nothing wrong with that, except that the school's prospectus stated quite clearly that this would not be the case. What's more, we knew that many children in the nursery class fitted the admissions criteria even less well than our son - and we could name individuals.

Unfortunately, despite its protestations of belief in parental choice, the government gives only very limited grounds for appeal. You have to prove that either the individual refusal was "unreasonable" - whatever that means - or that the child would have been offered a place if the admissions arrangements had been properly implemented. We decided to appeal on the grounds that, as the school's admissions practice was so obviously at odds with its stated policy, our son's application could not have been given a fair hearing.

When we arrived for the meeting, we were at first daunted by the queue of hopeful parents who had also decided to take their applications to the wire. It looked like a long wait ahead.

To our surprise the appeals committee was dispatching these supplicants at speed. No sooner had one set of parents shuffled in than they shuffled out again.

When it was our turn we found out why. Appeals committees are supposed to be not only independent of the school, but seen to be independent. But there was the school's representative chatting with the three-member panel, in a clear breach of DfEE guidelines. It felt like walking into court only to find the prosecuting counsel enjoying a joke with the judge before the case.

The school's representative - the "presenting officer" in DfEE parlance - then proceeded to effect introductions, outline the role of the appeals committee, and define (inaccurately) the basis on which appeals could be admitted. In other words he chaired the meeting. It was as if the prosecuting counsel, having had his joke, had then declared himself judge as well.

Next he invited us to make our case. Given the complexity of the issues we had written out our argument. To ensure that we didn't miss anything, we read it verbatim.

The presenting officer then went into overdrive, asserting that our argument was inadmissible and refusing point-blank to answer questions about the admissions policy. He claimed that the school had already consulted lawyers about its policy and therefore it couldn't be anything but completely watertight. By implication we were wasting our time.

In the run-up to the appeal, the committee had asked us in writing to identify specific cases in which the school had not followed its own rules. At the meeting, however, the presenting officer refused to discuss individual cases (wrongly, as we later found out). He even refused to discuss our key point - that the entire nursery class had been promoted to reception - which would have given the lie to his claims that the admissions policy had been fairly implemented.

We rebutted his points with mounting irritation. The panel said nothing throughout and as the meeting drew on we dropped the pretence of addressing the chair and ended up engaged in what was little more than a stand-up row.

Had my partner not been a teacher in the same borough who fully understood the ins and outs of admissions procedures, and had we not spent hours poring over DfEE guidelines, we would have been swatted away like the other parents who had gone in before us. We kept hammering away at our case until it was clear that everybody was repeating themselves for the fourth time and the hearing ended.

A few days later the appeals committee wrote to us with the news that that they hadn't actually come to a decision on our case. Instead they asked the school to reconsider our application. It came as no surprise when the school wrote back to us with the news that yes, they had reconsidered our case and no, they weren't going to give us a place.

We felt we had only one course of action left open to us: we called in the local government ombudsman. Strictly speaking, his remit is simply the administration of the appeal. But the investigating officer hardly bothered with that, simply noting our "serious complaints" and that "the school had not furnished any evidence to show that the admissions arrangements were properly applied."

Instead the officer went into detailed criticism of the school's admission criteria. "They were not easy to understand," he wrote, "and there was no clear provision for a tie-breaker to deal with the situation that there may be too many children qualifying under those criteria."

He also demanded that the commonly used catch-all "special needs", be more closely defined: "Does it mean statemented educational needs or social or medical requirements, none, or all of these things?"

And he suggested that a section in the prospectus which states that the admission policy is based on "the need to maintain an ethnic, gender and social balance" is probably illegal.

This was a pleasing vindication of our case. Even more satisfying is that the local education authority involved is now incorporating the ombudsman's ruling in its guidelines on schools admissions. The world will be a marginally fairer place as a result of our action.

The headteacher subsequently left the school and the new head seems to have obeyed every one of the ombudsman's suggestions to the letter. "We have amended the prospectus where necessary and in the future we will adhere tightly to what it says," he says. Oh, that all schools would play with such a straight bat.

You could say the system works, because in the end we were treated fairly. But many parents would not have had the time, the confidence, the determination or the inside knowledge to ensure that their voices were heard.

We decided to decline the ombudsman's offer of a new appeal and sent our son to another school. But we remain convinced that the policy of so-called "parental choice" has given too much power to schools. Headteachers often see parental rights - particularly the right to accurate information about why a child has been refused a place - as an irritation. As a result the admissions process is rarely, as DfEE guidelines state it must be, "clear, fair and objective".

So those parents now contemplating rejection letters should not assume that justice will be done because of the self-evident fairness of your case. It won't.

You need to be tenacious, clued-up and prepared to challenge people who appear to speak with incontrovertible authority. And the sad truth is that even the most bolshy among us aren't like that most of the time.

How to tackle an appeal

According to the DfEE, 53,400 appeals were heard in 1998, up 4% on the previous year. The good news is that 38% of them were successful.

With your rejection letter the school should provide the address of the clerk to the appeals committee to whom all correspondence should be addressed (ie not to the school).

You should write to the clerk stating that you wish to appeal. The DfEE says this should be done within 14 days although schools "should not unreasonably" reject later appeals.

The admissions authority should then reply, setting the date for your appeal but giving you at least 10 days' notice.

The DfEE Code of Practice on Appeals provides very limited and technical grounds for appeal. Any appeal outside criteria is likely to be a waste of time. So forget emotional arguments and study the guidelines carefully to make sure your case is admissible and robust.

Prepare your case. Remember the school is obliged to answer all rea sonable questions. It is also worth mugging up on DfEE guidelines for the administration of the appeal to ensure you are dealt with properly.

You are allowed to take someone with you for support at the hearing and they can make your case for you if you wish. You are likely to be feeling nervous and/or emotional so it may be best to read out your statement.

If you feel the appeal wasn't fair, check with DfEE guidelines and then complain to your Local Government Ombudsman. It's an easy process. Re member they can order a new appeal but they can't overrule the school.

To obtain the DfEE's Code of Practice on "Schools Admissions Appeals" and or its "Schools Admissions", call 0845 602 2260.

Their website contains a wealth of supporting material such as template letters.

The Advisory Centre For Education has a booklet on appeals and a telephone helpline: 020-7354 8321.

fields.headline: Lead kindly light
fields.standfirst: School heads will be a major plank in the new vision of education, says  Rebecca Smithers
fields.trailText: Ministers this week will announce the next stages of a major new strategy for professional development for teachers, to help equip them with the skills and qualities necessary to deliver education well into the 21st century.
fields.body:
Ministers this week will announce the next stages of a major new strategy for professional development for teachers, to help equip them with the skills and qualities necessary to deliver education well into the 21st century.

Fleshing out some of the proposals in the recent education green paper, they will set out details of a £92m three-year plan based on the findings of a nationwide consultation with the profession last year.

Following the General Teaching Council's proposal that all teachers should get the chance to take sabbaticals of up to six weeks to enable them to pursue activities that will benefit them and their school, schools minister Estelle Morris is expected to announce that, as a start, experienced teachers in "challenging" and inner-city areas will be able to do so. And ministers have also responded to concerns that relatively new teachers in their second and third years in the classroom need extra support, building on earlier induction.

The importance of school leadership and professional development for teachers were key themes in the government's recently published green paper, and will come under the spotlight at two big conferences in London this week. Whether or not he remains education and employment secretary after the forthcoming election (and assuming a Labour victory, the smart money suggests he won't), David Blunkett has put his faith in headteachers by trusting them with the implementation of his ambitious education programme.

Lord Puttnam, chairman of the General Teaching Council, commented: "Professional development is the make-or-break issue for many of the current education reforms. The majority of the proposals outlined for the next decade rely crucially upon the existence of a strong and motivated teaching workforce. If we want a first-class education for our children and young people, we need to give teachers every opportunity to grow and develop as professionals. The General Teaching Council believes that all teachers are entitled to high-quality professional development. There needs to be an absolute commitment both in terms of time and funding to enable teachers to enthusiastically take up these opportunities."

Russell Hobby of Hay McBer, the education management consultancy which regularly advises the education department, and which is co-presenting a conference with the Guardian on Friday, added: "Hay's research into leadership in schools has found that effective leadership makes an enormous difference for teachers and pupils. Leadership creates an atmosphere which inspires, channels and rewards motivation - with a direct impact on learning.

"In a sense every adult in a school is a leader. You can't force people to be creative and you can't order pupils to learn. You can only create an environment where people want to achieve, through your initiative, your ability to communicate, your persuasiveness, vision and enthusiasm. Leadership can be learnt. In fact, the very best leadership is always learnt - because it depends on gathering and understanding feedback on the impact we make."

The issue is not without controversy. After all, the quality of our headteachers has become a political hot potato under the current government. Heads of failing schools are regularly thrust into the media spotlight in the same way as the bosses of loss-making companies. In fact, it is thanks largely to a barrage of new initiatives from Blunkett and Tony Blair that the job of the headteacher has changed beyond recognition over the last few years. Heads running medium-sized to large schools are virtually company bosses, having to become accountants as well as personnel officers and sometimes even social workers.

But it is clear that the government has recognised that there is now a strong case for honing leadership skills in particular, as well as building and updating existing skills to take account of changes in the classroom. The new National College for School Leadership - currently an online operation but with a Nottingham headquarters on the drawing board - is at the heart of the new framework designed to make headteachers better at their jobs.

One of the college's main purposes will be to provide a dedicated support structure for those moving into leadership positions within the teaching profession. Blair has called it "a driving force for world-class leadership in our schools and education service".

Last week the development of the college moved a step forward after ministers approved its corporate plan and gave the green light to it, taking responsibility for the separate strands of leadership training: the revamped National Professional Qualification for Headship; the Headship Leadership and Management Programme; and the Leadership Programme for Serving Heads.

One key shift in the government's thinking is the recognition that the enormous divide between "heads" at the top of the tree and "everyone else" lower down should be narrowed. Leadership skills are just as important and relevant for deputy heads, middle managers, subject co-ordinators, bursars, pastoral heads and heads of year. In short, the pool of prospective leaders is much wider than just heads.

The National College for School Leadership will therefore aim its events and activities beyond the elite group of some 30,000 serving heads, to a prospective pool of as many as 100,000 senior staff. The more the merrier.

By narrowing the gap in this way, the natural career path towards becoming a headteacher could be smoothed. NCSL director and chief executive Heather du Quesnay also believes that teachers should start being groomed for leadership much earlier in their teaching careers, so that the prospect of applying for a headship is not so daunting.

"There is clearly scope for building a more clearly defined ladder to leadership," she said. "We need to be more proactive about recruiting heads, and we need to build up a more detailed picture in terms of where the short ages are. We also need to take account of all the regional differences in applications. Although the overall figures are not alarming, there are difficulties in some parts of the country, such as London, and even in rural areas."

Despite those tear-jerking video clips from Teaching Awards ceremonies showing award-winning headteachers described by their colleagues as "born leaders", du Quesnay is sceptical. "Some people do have a magical quality," she admitted, "but they are very few and far between. But if you give most people the opportunities to improve what they are doing already, and the chance to whet their appetite and enthusiasm to go on and be better, then that can pay equally rich dividends".

fields.headline: Letters
fields.trailText: Make the rich pay
fields.body:
Make the rich pay

Gail Sudall claims ("We've got to pay up", Letters, Feb 13) that the nation cannot afford good education and good healthcare. In fact, there is plenty of money sitting around to fund both - we just need a government with the courage to stand up to the rich and make them pay.
Adam Funk, Sheffield

A system for children

Having read through parts of the government's education green paper over the last week I am left wondering why this is the only vision we have for educating our children.

They have admitted that schooling has failed to address the real needs of children and yet we are stuck in the rut of the "school model" that we seem unable to escape.

All I see in this paper are externally imposed agendas, arbitrary, meaningless standards and sweeping generalisations about the needs of children. If flexibility and adaptability are the watchwords for the future then we need to provide an education that is genuinely flexible and adapts to the needs and interests of the individual rather than one that labels children according to their age and then arbitrarily imposes a preordained curriculum.

The admission that post-14 children should have a wider variety of opportunities is long overdue - why are we dictating the content of children's learning to such a massive degree? And why cannot all children have access to a system that permits real intellectual integrity, flexibility of attendance at all levels and gives access to a variety of resource and learning centres alongside participation in the wider community? I think that sooner or later our society needs to question who this system is really designed for - the government? Parents? Teachers? Or could we perhaps have one designed for the children?
Martine Archer, Harrogate

A way out

This is the end of the road - I'm retiring from teaching at Easter at the grand old age of 65. I'm quite rare because I'm still a classroom teacher, and I've no bitterness and few regrets. Unfortunately, I have arrived at this blissful watershed by cheating. Eleven years ago I had the opportunity to take early retirement from mainstream teaching and landed a part-time job teaching at a campus of three small schools for children with disabilities. I could not have survived the last 11 years as a mainstream teacher.

I am required to teach national curriculum maths to children who struggle to count above 10 but they remember my name, what is happening on the soaps, how Aston Villa did last Saturday and the time we went for a picnic in Sutton Park. There is potential for learning that could be built upon - but it is not in this government's bureaucratic books.

Did you see the TV news about the green paper on secondary education? Bright secondary pupils were interviewed and asked what they thought of new proposals to make their education more effective. All of them brushed the proposals aside and pleaded instead for some attention to be given to those of lesser ability. They are wiser than us.
Sam Greenbank, Atherstone, Warwickshire

Religion rules

I remember back in the late 1940s attending mass with my mother, when the priest declaimed from the pulpit that he was shocked to see women not wearing their hats. The women concerned looked suitably embarrassed. I recall the slightly smug look on my dear old mum's face, because being a good Irish Catholic girl it wouldn't have occurred to her to challenge this man who was telling her how to dress.

Reading "If you ask me" (Feb 20) was so depressing, for we have the resurgence of male-dominated religions with young minds being told how to think and what to wear. And in anticipation of all those letters telling me that the Koran is very women-friendly; I have read it, and it isn't. But like the Bible, men will offer to interpret it for me in a different way, so I will see the light.
Joe Phillips, Bingham, Notts

Teachers not required

I am due to celebrate my 50th birthday at the end of February and had been persuaded that the teaching profession was in need of qualified and experienced people like myself. I hold two diplomas in art and design; a diploma in social work; a diploma in higher education; a BA in philosophy; a Master's in art history and another in gallery studies (exhibition organising). I have spent some years practising design, further time working on exhibitions and some years as a social worker.

I received a letter from Fast Track Teaching saying that I "need to demonstrate a strong academic record as well as evidence of other skills and attributes". Short of attaining a PhD, I am not too certain how I would demonstrate any further academic ability, nor exactly what skills teaching is looking for.

Unless there is a coded message there about the actual age required? Perhaps people of experience are not required for teaching, after all.
Martin Bradley, Clacton, Essex

Research doesn't travel

Christopher Ball is greatly mistaken when he states that "Good research benefits everyone, not just the nation of origin" (Higher, Feb 20). Two points have been well established: first, that new industries arise around good research universities (eg Heriot-Watt, Cambridge etc), not at a distance; second, that intellectual property does not travel as easily as he thinks. This is because knowledge is of two kinds, organised in print and elsewhere (which does travel) and tacit (ie in people's heads, which doesn't). The Japanese were able to base much of their industry on our basic work because of the tacit knowledge they had of how to do things. In order to benefit from published knowledge a nation needs a pool of people trained in a similar way to those who made the discovery. Japan had this; India, China, etc, did not.

I entirely agree with the waste of academic time spent on the Research Assessment Exercise and Quality Assurance Agency assessments. This arises because "trust" has been lost; the government does not trust universities to do their jobs properly and even vice-chancellors do not now trust their heads of departments, so control has been centralised both in universities and nationally.
Emeritus Professor JF Lamb, Cupar, Fife
