fields.bodyText: Make the rich pay Gail Sudall claims ("We've got to pay up", Letters, Feb 13) that the nation cannot afford good education and good healthcare. In fact, there is plenty of money sitting around to fund both - we just need a government with the courage to stand up to the rich and make them pay. Adam Funk, Sheffield A system for children Having read through parts of the government's education green paper over the last week I am left wondering why this is the only vision we have for educating our children. They have admitted that schooling has failed to address the real needs of children and yet we are stuck in the rut of the "school model" that we seem unable to escape. All I see in this paper are externally imposed agendas, arbitrary, meaningless standards and sweeping generalisations about the needs of children. If flexibility and adaptability are the watchwords for the future then we need to provide an education that is genuinely flexible and adapts to the needs and interests of the individual rather than one that labels children according to their age and then arbitrarily imposes a preordained curriculum. The admission that post-14 children should have a wider variety of opportunities is long overdue - why are we dictating the content of children's learning to such a massive degree? And why cannot all children have access to a system that permits real intellectual integrity, flexibility of attendance at all levels and gives access to a variety of resource and learning centres alongside participation in the wider community? I think that sooner or later our society needs to question who this system is really designed for - the government? Parents? Teachers? Or could we perhaps have one designed for the children? Martine Archer, Harrogate A way out This is the end of the road - I'm retiring from teaching at Easter at the grand old age of 65. I'm quite rare because I'm still a classroom teacher, and I've no bitterness and few regrets. Unfortunately, I have arrived at this blissful watershed by cheating. Eleven years ago I had the opportunity to take early retirement from mainstream teaching and landed a part-time job teaching at a campus of three small schools for children with disabilities. I could not have survived the last 11 years as a mainstream teacher. I am required to teach national curriculum maths to children who struggle to count above 10 but they remember my name, what is happening on the soaps, how Aston Villa did last Saturday and the time we went for a picnic in Sutton Park. There is potential for learning that could be built upon - but it is not in this government's bureaucratic books. Did you see the TV news about the green paper on secondary education? Bright secondary pupils were interviewed and asked what they thought of new proposals to make their education more effective. All of them brushed the proposals aside and pleaded instead for some attention to be given to those of lesser ability. They are wiser than us. Sam Greenbank, Atherstone, Warwickshire Religion rules I remember back in the late 1940s attending mass with my mother, when the priest declaimed from the pulpit that he was shocked to see women not wearing their hats. The women concerned looked suitably embarrassed. I recall the slightly smug look on my dear old mum's face, because being a good Irish Catholic girl it wouldn't have occurred to her to challenge this man who was telling her how to dress. Reading "If you ask me" (Feb 20) was so depressing, for we have the resurgence of male-dominated religions with young minds being told how to think and what to wear. And in anticipation of all those letters telling me that the Koran is very women-friendly; I have read it, and it isn't. But like the Bible, men will offer to interpret it for me in a different way, so I will see the light. Joe Phillips, Bingham, Notts Teachers not required I am due to celebrate my 50th birthday at the end of February and had been persuaded that the teaching profession was in need of qualified and experienced people like myself. I hold two diplomas in art and design; a diploma in social work; a diploma in higher education; a BA in philosophy; a Master's in art history and another in gallery studies (exhibition organising). I have spent some years practising design, further time working on exhibitions and some years as a social worker. I received a letter from Fast Track Teaching saying that I "need to demonstrate a strong academic record as well as evidence of other skills and attributes". Short of attaining a PhD, I am not too certain how I would demonstrate any further academic ability, nor exactly what skills teaching is looking for. Unless there is a coded message there about the actual age required? Perhaps people of experience are not required for teaching, after all. Martin Bradley, Clacton, Essex Research doesn't travel Christopher Ball is greatly mistaken when he states that "Good research benefits everyone, not just the nation of origin" (Higher, Feb 20). Two points have been well established: first, that new industries arise around good research universities (eg Heriot-Watt, Cambridge etc), not at a distance; second, that intellectual property does not travel as easily as he thinks. This is because knowledge is of two kinds, organised in print and elsewhere (which does travel) and tacit (ie in people's heads, which doesn't). The Japanese were able to base much of their industry on our basic work because of the tacit knowledge they had of how to do things. In order to benefit from published knowledge a nation needs a pool of people trained in a similar way to those who made the discovery. Japan had this; India, China, etc, did not. I entirely agree with the waste of academic time spent on the Research Assessment Exercise and Quality Assurance Agency assessments. This arises because "trust" has been lost; the government does not trust universities to do their jobs properly and even vice-chancellors do not now trust their heads of departments, so control has been centralised both in universities and nationally. fields.headline: Book reviews
fields.trailText: Poems Then and Now | Cloud Wolf
fields.body:
Poems Then and Now, compiled by Fiona Waters (Evans, £10.99) Age 12+

Excellent poetry anthologies abound but this is well worth space in classrooms and libraries. Each poem faces a related partner, traditional or contemporary, and the result is both a lovely book to browse through and a splendid resource. The themes, under which each poem is headed, are not adventurous, reflecting a canny eye for the curriculum. But the contents page is a helpful start, listing the broad range of poetry selected. John Donne is paired with Andrew Fusek Peters, Robert Burns with Andrew Motion and Christina Rossetti with Ted Hughes. But don't stop at the chemistry - it's the poetry that elevates this book above the average.

Cloud Wolf, by Paul Stewart and Chris Riddell, (Transworld, £1) Age 8-12 yrs

By now, every school in the country should have received a World Book Day pack crammed with ideas to promote reading well beyond World Book Day on March 1. In the pack, teachers will find a £1 book token for every child in the school. As an added encouragement, Cloud Wolf plus the following three books will be widely available: Little Wolf's Postbag, by Ian Whybrow and Tony Ross, (Collins, age 5-9); The Gruffalo Song, by Julia Donaldson and Axel Scheffler (Macmillan, age 3-7); and Shop Dead, by Kate Cann, (Scholastic, age: 13-18). Price: £1 each. Pupils who spend their tokens on these books won't be disappointed.

fields.headline: Island hopping in Greece
fields.standfirst:
I want to hop around the Greek islands close to Turkey, staying at different B&Bs or two star hotels. Where can I find out about the ferry links and list of such accommodation? Any suggestions on where I should go?
Gus Cabre
fields.trailText: I want to hop around the Greek islands close to Turkey, staying at different B&Bs or two star hotels. Where can I find out about the ferry links and list of such accommodation. Any suggestions on where I should go?
fields.body:
 You can get to almost anywhere in Greece from Athens with a combination of buses and ferries. The Greek national tourism organisation's website will give you bus and ferry departure times from Athens. It's cheap and fairly comfortable and you don't have to worry about your luggage on and off the ferry - it stays on the bus, which is driven on board. Just remember that while most of the buses have air conditioning, they don't have toilets, so take advantage of the comfort breaks along the route!

Carol Martin

 For ferry links try www.phantis.com - a Greek search engine (in English) which has extensive information about travelling around the country.

Worth noting that when booking tickets, agencies may only handle specific ferry companies. If islands are served by a few companies it's worth asking at a few ticket agencies so you are able to ascertain all your options as far as your holiday timetable is concerned. It's also worth paying extra (not substantially so) for a better class of travel. "Economy" or "tourist" class can be uncomfortable. Especially during overnight sailings.

NTOG (National Tourist Organisation of Greece) has a comprehensive list of hotels; listed by category. Prices per category are set by law each year. However, most travellers stay in "rooms" - strictly speaking these are not given a classification and the price should be discussed with the owner. During the summer season owners of hotels and rooms are generally waiting for the arrival of ferries at the port in a bid to gain custom. During peak season it would be advisable to book ahead. (most travel agencies will have a copy of the NTOG accomodation guide).

Island hopping in the Dodecanese chain of islands, or the islands of the north Aegean, affords you many options in view of which island will be your central port (assuming that you will be flying to Limnos, Kos, Samos, Lesbos or Rhodes, rather than Athens). Bear in mind that many of the islands in this region are small and will not have frequent connections to others. It's also worth noting that during the summer months the Aegean can get windy, which of course affects sailings. Make sure that you leave plenty of time to be able to return to your port in time for your flight home!
S Cromack

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Alex
fields.trailText: Just thought I'd join in your NZ debate. I struggle to understand why people like Simon feel the need to slag NZ off. Its weather certainly isn't tropical or anything. I imagine Sydney is much hotter. But you're a Brit, so you know a thing or two about wet weather...
fields.body:
Hey Milly,

Just thought I'd join in your NZ debate. I struggle to understand why people like Simon feel the need to slag NZ off. Its weather certainly isn't tropical or anything. I imagine Sydney is much hotter. But you're a Brit, so you know a thing or two about wet weather, nothing to be scared of. But NZ is far too stunning to not go there - believe me, and it is just so completely different from Australia, you'll enjoy the variety. Don't let the NZ bashers get you down, I went there last year and absolutely adored it.

Alex

fields.headline: School report: JamC@m digital camera
fields.trailText: JamC@m 3.0
fields.body:
JamC@m 3.0

(www.taglearning.com tel: 01474 537886)

Price £89.95 + VAT & delivery

Age/ability range 5+ yrs

The manufacturer says: "JamC@m is a revolutionary new digital camera designed to be used by all age groups and even those with little or no experience of digital photography."

Elaine Waugh, ICT coordinator, Condorrat Primary School, Cumbernauld, Scotland, says: "This was a really good camera - light, but sturdy, and very easy to operate. Its simplicity and durability are real pluses. There's a slot for a multimedia card and it can be connected to a PC or Mac. It's suitable for all ages from five upwards, with assistance only really required with downloading. The kids noticed that the photo quality was poor at times, but we used this minus point to compare and contrast with other digital cameras they have used, which was a good learning experience. I would definitely prefer to have half a dozen JamC@ms in my school than one standard digital camera. I used the product with a class of 10- and 11-year-olds for a Shrove Tuesday project. They made pancakes, taking pictures of every stage of the process, then downloaded the pictures, cropped them, changed skin tones, etc, and finally put on a slide show. The children thoroughly enjoyed it and learnt about RE, sequencing and ICT."

Curriculum links

ICT, primary: Representing information graphically, creating pictures, multimedia information.

fields.headline: The CD-rom
fields.trailText: Rainforest Development: The Amazonian Experience (4Learning, £49.99 inc VAT) Age KS3
fields.body:
Rainforest Development: The Amazonian Experience (4Learning, £49.99 inc VAT) Age KS3

This title is aimed at the KS3 geography curriculum, enabling pupils to find out about life in the Amazonian rainforest and the economy of a less well-developed country. High-quality video clips are a highlight, providing valuable activities away from the computer. The content is relevant, well presented and stimulating. There are also useful links. Navigation is intuitive, with all pupils able to access the program with ease. The multimedia element allows pupils to find out more. Few ICT skills are needed to get the best out of this program.

Neighbourhood Map Machine (Brighter Vision Education, £58.69, inc VAT) Age KS1 & 2

This program helps children develop map-making and reading skills. It is primarily a geography package, but allows the science aspects of ecology, land use and conservation to be explored. The title introduces children to appropriate geographical language and also touches on aspects of maths, such as symmetry, direction and position. The title has been successfully used to develop key geographical skills. Thanks to extensive support materials, it also offers valuable activities away from the computer, along with preliminary and extension tasks as further features.

fields.headline: If you ask me_
fields.standfirst: We plan to take our children, aged five and nine, travelling for six months to a year. We're sure they're going to learn a lot, but how far should we go to safeguard their conventional education too?
fields.trailText: We plan to take our children, aged five and nine, travelling for six months to a year. We're sure they're going to learn a lot, but how far should we go to safeguard their conventional education too?
fields.body:
John Coe of the National Association of Primary Education

I'm sure you're right, and that your children will learn lots and be all the better for their experience. But I do think there's a need for regular educational sessions along the way. What you need to do, before you go, is talk to staff at your children's school. Tell them what you're planning, and ask their advice on what to take with you in terms of workbooks and textbooks etc - they may not be willing to supply these, but they'll certainly be able to give you the titles you need and obtaining them shouldn't be any trouble.

The main things you'll need to be aware of are literacy and numeracy - when your children return to education after your travels, you'll want to make sure they're not behind and that they can fit back in easily with their classmates. Find out from their teachers what will be covered in the terms your children will miss, and aim to at least cover the main topics while you're abroad.

Another thing I'd suggest is that you seek out opportunities for your children to sample life in school in any of the countries you visit. It may be that this isn't possible, and of course it won't be possible everywhere, but if you're staying with another family for more than a week or two, and they've got children of similar ages to your own, why not ask whether your children could go to school as well for a few days? This could be enormously enriching from all points of view, and it will help to remind your children of the classroom atmosphere that they're not currently part of, but will be again.

Beverley Young of Education Otherwise, a support organisation for parents who home educate

Lucky you - the sorts of experiences and education your children will receive just soaking up the cultures and languages of your trip will be far richer than they could ever experience at school. Being exposed to different languages in itself is wonderful, and all the things they'll see around them will lead to so much learning.

As you're planning to return your children to mainstream education, it's going to be a good idea to keep an eye on the national curriculum. I suspect you'll be fairly shocked when you look at how little they will be missing: when you think about it, a lot of what happens in school is to do with keeping these 25 or 30 children together, and given that you'll be able to input one-to-one on your trip, I think it's highly unlikely your children will fall behind. They may even return further ahead.

You can't underestimate how much benefit your children are going to get from the input you'll be able to give them. When they ask questions, you'll have time to answer them; when you're looking around the places you visit, you'll be able to devote yourselves to telling them about the history or geography of where you are. That's enormously educational.

Duncan Roberts , headteacher of Honeywell Junior School in Battersea, London

The school needs to be notified right away - you should do this verbally and in writing. They'll almost certainly have to take the children off the school roll and would then offer the places to the next children on the waiting list (if they have one). Informing the school as early as possible is both courteous and helpful - it may even be beneficial to you in the long term, as there may be places for your children when you return.

I would also speak to the school about the sort of work your children will be missing. That shouldn't be difficult - if I was their headteacher I would certainly be happy to list the topics the children will be missing over the year. With the numeracy and literacy strategies there are now clearly published schemes of work that precisely detail what skills and knowledge will be taught and when in maths and English. In science most schools follow a clear scheme of work and again the yearly work is clearly explained. Once this has been ascertained I would recommend a selection of books that you could easily get from somewhere like WH Smith.

Much of the strength of your trip is that the children will be experiencing and discovering new cultures, environments and lifestyles, and I would certainly not want this to be buried under a ton of books and formal exercises. However, you are intending to return within the year and you obviously want to ensure the children are not at a disadvantage when they come back to school.

Compiled by Joanna Moorhead

Coming next

Do I have an alternative in London to either a state or an independent school for my five- and 10-year-olds? We want a school where children can think for themselves and where they feel free to be a child, albeit a well-behaved one.

Do you have a problem with your child's education? Is something bothering you about his or her school? Each week we ask leading experts to advise on a specific issue. Please send in your "problem" marked "If you ask me" to Guardian Education, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or fax them to 020 7239 9933 or email to education.letters@theguardian.com

fields.headline: On the Web
fields.trailText: Ancient Egypt | Modern Irish History
fields.byline: Compiled by Jim Merrett, Amanda Grimwood
fields.body:
The British Museum

www.ancientegypt.co.uk

Suitable for KS1/2 pupils & teachers

An excellent site, full of high-quality photographs, interesting stories, fascinating statistics and tempting challenges. There is a wide range of themes to explore in depth, including Egyptian life and the story of the pyramids.

The Ancient Vine

www.ancientsites.com

Suitable for KS2 teachers

Select "Egypt" for a chance to do some interesting research from the articles available. "The use of colour in Ancient Egypt" was an interesting, if rather specialised, theme among the wide variety available.

PBS

www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/pyramid

Suitable for KS1/2 pupils & teachers

This site will appeal to children interested in archaeology, which is considered with reference to the wonderful discoveries that have been made in Egypt. There is a chance to explore some pyramids, including a detailed cross-section view and, most spectacular of all, the view from the top of Khufu's Pyramid. Just click and drag on the photograph for a 360-degree panoramic view.

Carnegie Museum

www.clpgh.org/cmnh/exhibits/egypt/index.html

Suitable for KS1/2 pupils & teachers

Well illustrated and informative, this site covers a wide range of themes including the natural world and funerary customs, plus links to museum exhibits.

Think Quest

http://library.thinkquest.org/10805/egypt.html

Suitable for KS2 pupils & teachers

This site should certainly play a part in the study of the topic as it includes a key resource in the form of a large, helpful historical map of the area. It also gives a full listing of the succession of dynasties, helping to place the better known pharaohs in context.

Discovery

www.discovery.com/guides/ancientworlds/egypt/egypt.html

Suitable for KS1/2 pupils & teachers

The chance to fly through the tomb of Rameses II and unwrap a mummy are among the exciting options in this site. Also worth looking at is the "Fun and Games" section, which can be used as a method of assessing children's knowledge of the subject.

Compiled by Amanda Grimwood

Conflict in Ireland

http://cain.ulst.ac.uk

Suitable for KS3/4/5 pupils & teachers

The definitive website from Cain (Conflict Archive on the Internet), part of the University of Ulster. A wealth of information and related links. It is accessible (with guidance) for KS3 pupils and indispensable for GCSE/ A-level. Key events range from the early civil rights movement to the Omagh bombing.

Historical documents

wwwms.utexas.ed/~jdana/irehist.html

Suitable for KS3/4/5 pupils & teachers

This site from the University of Texas covers many aspects of Irish history. The catalogue of historical documents is particularly useful for teachers. These range from the papal bull of Pope Adrian IV to the Anglo-Irish agreement.

Murals, posters and cartoons

http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/images/symbols/repubmurals/htm
cain.ulst.ac.uk/images/posters

www.dup.org.uk/scripts/dup_s/posterquery.idc

Suitable for KS4/5 pupils & teachers

All of the above are extremely useful for students undertaking coursework on the Troubles and for a more general appreciation of visual sources. Posters include those from the Republican movement, specific issues such as the hunger strikes, as well as general election posters. The DUP website contains cartoons and posters from a Unionist stance.

General overview

news.bbc.co.uk/hi/English/events/northern_ireland/history/default.stm

Suitable for KS3/4

Extremely accessible. Chronological events, from 1170 to 1998, are divided into chunks, each with subtitles and pictures as well as narrative. For KS3 pupils there are useful sections relevant to the Making of the UK, which would also provide a thumbnail sketch of Irish history as an introduction to the Troubles for GCSE students.

Flags

www.connect.ie/users/morley/flags.htm

Suitable for KS3/4 pupils & teachers

An alternative look at the development of political history in Ireland, north and south, through the flags that have flown in the country through the ages. Each is presented with a discussion of the associated symbolism.

The peace movement

www.irishpeace.com

Suitable for KS4 pupils & teachers

An extensive site that is mainly useful for the related sites it lists, in particular the groups that work towards cross-community collaboration.

fields.headline: Lecturers lured by loot
fields.standfirst: Anne McHardy  reports on the haemorrhage of college staff - to secondary schools
fields.trailText: Anne McHardy reports on the haemorrhage of college staff - to secondary schools
fields.body:
The lecturer shortage crisis in colleges is set to get even worse as teaching staff desert the sector to find jobs in schools. Secondary schools, themselves desperate to plug the holes in their recruitment, are hiring further education staff via a loophole in DfEE regulations, which allows unqualified staff to work as instructors at the discretion of heads.

There are many routes by which lecturers are leaching out of further education, but the lure of secondary schools, where they can be employed at higher rates of pay, even as instructors rather than as qualified teachers, is increasingly significant.

Working through agencies rather than directly to a local authority, pay can be higher for instructors. An instructor earning a base-rate of £12,000 per annum if employed by a local authority can earn up to £16,500 for a 195-day year through an agency. In schools skills in art, design and computing are increasingly needed as the curriculum becomes more vocational.

Sue Dutton, deputy chief executive of the Association of Colleges, said she was aware of the drift, which she hoped would be stopped by new further education initiatives.

"The pay in schools is attracting full- and part-timers out of further education, though that is not the only way staff are leaving. The biggest drift out is to private sector employers. Any teacher who has a transferable skill in further education is open to a better offer."

Natfhe spokeswoman, Sue Berriman said: "People will be looking to other options. It is a sorry state of affairs. There are also quite a distinct number of part-time lecturers who do not want full-time work."

Keith Sorrel is a graphic designer and lecturer in desktop publishing who is amazed to find himself enjoying working as a supply teacher in secondary schools. He also works two days a week for the graphics firm which first steered him into part-time further education vocational lecturing, work he thoroughly enjoyed.

"In recent years, though, the paperwork has increased ten-fold. To be honest I have been driven out. Every day I had to deal with half an hour's paperwork before I had could get on with my job. They got rid of all the admin staff and dumped it on us."

At Christmas the agency he now works through, Select Education, suggested secondary teaching. "It terrified me, but the money was there."

Lack of job security, as colleges cut permanent staff, is also a factor. Keith Naylor, 50, an English teacher who was made redundant from Warrington College last year is thinking of dropping his remaining college teaching. In further education he earns £17 an hour, which would give him a better day-rate than teaching in schools. But his norm of two hours, four nights a week earns a potential £504 a month. In school, on a day-rate of £85, he can earn that in six days. Naylor had several reasons for leaving the sector: "The morale was terrible. Not only did people feel management was overweening, great animosities developed between people. It was part of the whole government revolution. In further education it came late, but with a vengeance." He also disliked moves to new full-time contracts.

At Select Education, one of the bigger schools' supply agencies, further education lecturers are seen as vital to fill gaps in schools. The agency has 300 on its books, mostly in the midlands and north. Select Education's operations director, Helen Mylroie, said: "We are applying very strict quality procedures. This includes the clear policy that we match appropriately experienced and skilled lecturers with relevant schools."

fields.headline: Bullet Points
fields.trailText: What a bummer
fields.body:
What a bummer

Nobody within Whitehall focuses more on their alphabet than the folk in the Adult Basic Skills Strategy Unit. Which is as it should be. The DfEE's shock troops do, after all, face a foe of seven million and the alphabet starts to look puny with those odds. But their current concern goes way beyond daily ABC practice. It has become an obsession. But cast no blame on them. Fling it instead at this modern tyranny of the acronym. Basic skills, you see, for all its euphemistic correctness, doesn'tring bells with the masses, especially not with those who don't view reading and writing as anything special. The problem comes in reverting to the old words. Adult Numeracy And Literacy. Nice enough ring to it. But you try telling your mates you're going off for your ANAL test. Reshuffling the letters offers no relief. Adult Literacy And Numeracy throws up the first name of the chap who heads the,well not rival exactly, but the other organisation in the field: the Basic Skills Agency. Even the DfEE's Wykehamist egg-heads can't solve this. They need your help. Best suggested title on a postcard by next Tuesday will win a bottle of champagne.

Acid comment

Which reminds me. How are those psychedelic groovers at the LSD Agency bobbing along since they scrapped their old Further Education Development Agency title and chose the more with-it Learning and Skills Development Agency? When we finally coaxed one to the telephone, we got our answer. When it was FEDA, man, it was real boring. But now, man, the colours! Wow! You gotta believe it. Anyway. Nice talking. I gotta fly now. Wheeee!

fields.headline: In for a fight
fields.standfirst: Government fears sixth-form flare-up before election, reports  Francis Beckett
fields.trailText: Government fears sixth-form flare-up before election
fields.body:
One of the clearest indications that a general election is imminent is the way that the issue of sixth forms has been locked firmly in its cupboard and told not to disturb anyone. But it may refuse to stay there. The latest consultation paper calls for replies by Friday of this week, and the government is likely to find that even its carefully modulated phrases have opened some raw wounds.

Few things upset middle England so much as the idea that their school might lose its sixth form. But when the new Learning and Skills Council takes on responsibility for funding all post-16 education, school sixth forms and colleges will be funded from the same pot, and this implies a move away from schools (whose other activities will not be funded by the council) and towards colleges. As for the colleges, few things upset them so much as the fact that sixth forms get more money per pupil than they do.

Schools believe that colleges use slick and dubious marketing methods to lure away potential sixth-formers. Colleges believe schools avoid their duty to tell potential students that they have a choice, or to distribute college prospectuses. They are both right.

Even among the colleges themselves there are divisions and suspicions. Many general further education col leges complain, with some justification, that their results are unfairly compared with those of the sixth-form colleges, when the latter can select those pupils with the best GCSE scores and the further education colleges cannot.

For much of last year there was a lively debate in which the government and Ofsted participated noisily. In April, Ofsted recommended that Hackney and Islington's school sixth forms should be closed, or at least radically reorganised. In other places, including Bristol and Lewisham in south London, local education authorities are considering moves in the same direction.

In June, lifelong learning minister Malcolm Wicks revealed government statistics which showed that school sixth forms with fewer than 50 pupils get the worst results. Next come general further education colleges. The best results are obtained by pupils in sixth forms with more than 200 pupils, and by sixth-form colleges.

By then the government was comparing the cost of running sixth forms with the cost of running colleges, and finding that the latter cost about £1,500 less for each student taking three A-levels. The gap was likely to increase with the broader A-level curriculum, which the National Association of Head Teachers says will cost an average size school sixth form an extra £100,000 a year. School sixth forms began to feel a noose tightening around their necks.

Schools pointed out that they spend more on pastoral work and out-of-school activities. Colleges said that, unlike schools, they had had no money for their teachers' pay rises since 1993 (though colleges passed much of this shortfall on to their teachers, who are now paid at least 10% less than schoolteachers.)

By November ministers were talking of turning many further education colleges into specialist colleges, which not only sent a shiver down the spines of the grammar schools (fearful of losing their elite status) but also of the colleges (fearful of not being among the chosen, and ending up as underfunded second class institutions).

But before the year was out, the name of the game turned into reassurance. On December 13 came an abstruse document, "Technical paper on school sixth-form funding - views invited", accompanied by a pledge from Wicks that no sixth form would suffer financially so long as it maintained its numbers. But you can't reassure everyone in this business, and those colleges which read the document carefully became concerned that they would be treated worse than schools.

Eagle-eyed college principals, such as David Percival of Plymouth College of Further Education, spotted two problems. One paragraph reads ominously: "While we understand the level playing field argument, we think it is right to recognise the particular position of schools and what it is realistic to expect of them." Schools therefore would be required to collect and submit data less frequently than colleges. A small point - but on top of years of underfunding, it rankles.

The other much more substantial problem is the amount of money the colleges will get. The document talks of increasing funding for inflation, pupil numbers, and the new, broader curriculum. But it wants to use this year's figures as a base. Any college principal will tell you that years of funding discrimination against colleges means that they start from a much lower base. If all you do is increase the funding from that base, they will never catch up with schools.

For their part, schools feel equally threatened. "Many Labour politicians, including New Labour ones, believe that there should be a tertiary break at 16," says David Hart of the National Association of Head Teachers'. That could be the "hidden agenda", he says. But there will not be enough money to go round. "Most secondary school sixth forms have been short changed on the additional costs of broadening the sixth form curriculum," says Hart.

Competition between schools and colleges will become more intense and more bitter, he says. "It will be a very competitive market. Schools per ceive that colleges are on a new recruitment initiative."

On the other hand, Natfhe's Paul Mackney says: "The great achievement of general further education colleges in providing a second or third chance for people written off by the school system has attracted little or no recognition from people like Andrew Adonis." Adonis is the Prime Minister's education adviser, and Mackney, among others, credits him with the idea of specialist colleges, and with aiming in the end to have a system of super-techs at the top, and what Mackney calls "tertiary moderns" at the bottom. Mackney foresees something very like the old split between grammar schools and secondary moderns opening up in the post-16 sector.

In all this, ministers are keeping their heads down and probably hoping the issue will not blow up before the election. "Good sixth forms have nothing to fear from the changes. The government wants a successful and vibrant sixth-form sector," is all the education department will say. The embryonic Learning and Skills Council is a little more enlightening. "We see no reason why sixth forms should not continue. They will be one way of getting post-16 learning. Our hope is that in time the Learning and Skills Council can create an environment for post-16 learning where provision suits its various customers," says its spokesman.

fields.headline: Borrowed time
fields.standfirst: College students aren't averse to loans, if they are flexible. By  Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: An official loan scheme would be welcomed by many further education students - as long as repayment was linked to their subsequent incomes, new evidence shows.
fields.body:
An official loan scheme would be welcomed by many further education students - as long as repayment was linked to their subsequent incomes, new evidence shows.

A significant minority of students aged 19 and over would consider borrowing if they felt confident that a course would benefit them financially, and that repayments would be suspended if they became ill or lost their job, according to a report by the Learning and Skills Development Agency (LSDA).

Despite the apparent link between dips in university recruitment this year and higher education student loans, the government is thought to be considering a loan scheme.

Last summer the third report of the National Skills Task Force explicitly recommended that loans should be available to help adults cover learning costs. It urged that a new system of income-contingent loans, together with high-quality advice and guidance services, should be available for adult learners pursuing recognised qualifications.

The report on student finance was compiled by Derek Wanless, group chief executive of NatWest bank, at the request of education secretary David Blunkett after the task force's first report. No one outside the DfEE has officially read it, but it is assumed to consider the case for student loans in further education.

In 1988 the Tories introduced their own loan system for the sector. So-called Career Development Loans (CDLs) still exist - although according to Mick Fletcher, LSDA development adviser, the take-up has hardly been high. In total only 105,000loans - whose average value has risen from £2,500 to £3,500 - have been taken out. Yet for people who who did finance themselves this way, the loans played a key role in their decision to study. More than 80% said they would not otherwise have done the training the loans supported.

Many CDLs, Fletcher notes, financed courses which were not available at subsidised rates in the public sector, such as flying lessons or HGV driver training.

Recent research has established that over a quarter of further education students are in debt, while more than half have experienced financial hardship. Fletcher asked two groups - the first aged 16 to 24, the second aged 25 to 54, both including employed and unemployed people - whether they would be prepared to borrow money to finance further education and training. Generally they said that if learning costs were less than £1,000 they would try to avoid formal loans. Above that, they said, they would need a loan or a grant.

What emerged quite clearly, however, was that people did not like straight repayment loans such as the CDL. "There was a very clear preference for the features of the higher education loan, and the critical factor was income contingency," says Fletcher.

Unlike the higher education sector, where students show an antipathy to student loans, in further education this was not the case. This may be because, unlike in higher education, where loans were introduced just as maintenance grants were being scrapped, there has been no comparable prior support in the FE sector.

Fletcher points out that less than a third of further education students actually pay for tuition.

Fees at further education colleges are generally not high, and are usually considerably cheaper than private training courses - most students who pay are liable for less than £100. Those who don't have to pay fees are exempt because they are between 16 and 19, because they get unemployment benefit or income support, or because they satisfy individual colleges' exemption policies.

A significant factor in a student's willingness to take out a loan would be the financial returns of the qualification gained. Recent research has shown that lower-level national vocational qualifications, for instance, do not yield significant economic return, but that the returns to qualifications at level 3 and over are significant.

fields.headline: Rostrum
fields.standfirst: Colleges' hard-won independence is once more under threat, says  John Brennan
fields.trailText: Colleges' hard-won independence is once more under threat
fields.body:
Since 1992 college managers and governors have enjoyed having responsibility for managing their institutions without the sometimes petty restrictions that existed under local education authority control. Subsequent years have demonstrated unequivocally the wisdom of that independence - and that, whatever problems they may have encountered, the overwhelming majority of governors and managers have exercised that stewardship responsibly and effectively.

At the heart of the autonomy lay the responsibility for the financial management of institutions - for planning educational programmes, for setting and managing budgets, for determining investments, for ensuring solvency and for accounting for their activities. External auditing of the financial statements recording the outcomes of these processes, undertaken by auditors chosen by the corporation themselves, has been a key expression of that independence.

So the Further Education Funding Council's proposal - put forward last year - that it and its successor, the Learning and Skills Council, should take over responsibility for the appointment of external auditors, struck at the heart of colleges' independence. It threatened a fundamental change in the relationships between the council and colleges, which would allow the council to influence, if not dictate, the accounting policies for every college, and through that penetrate into every area of college management. So it was not surprising that the sector reacted strongly, and voted overwhelmingly against the proposals.

We might have hoped the council's subsequent decision not to proceed showed belated recognition that what had been presented as a largely technical audit exercise, aimed at resolving problems between checking individualised student returns and funding claims, and the auditing of college accounts, opened up much wider issues about relationships between funding body and providers.

The reappearance of the proposal in new form, through the DfEE's consultation on revisions to Instruments and Articles of Government for Colleges, suggests, however, that optimism may be premature. The proposal that the Learning and Skills Council has a new power to appoint auditors confirms the doubts expressed about the legal validity of the original funding council proposal.

It also raises a question: is the government bent on changing the 1992 college governance model with no regard to sector views? Ministers have repeatedly given assurances about not wanting to undermine the autonomy of college corporations. But whereas the funding council set out a reasoned, if unsatisfactory case for a change in external audit arrangements, the current DfEE consultation offers no justification for taking such powers, nor any explanation of how they might be used. As they stand, the LSC could use the powers for one college or for all, according to criteria it adopted at any time.

Why should colleges be subject to external control of their audit, when no such proposal has been put for ward for private training providers or other recipients of LSC funding - in contradiction of the department's own declared policy of seeking to create a level playing field between different types of LSC provider?

In addition, in the absence of primary legislation giving LSC an explicit power to control the appointment of auditors, the legal basis of the proposal remains distinctly questionable.

The Association of Colleges vigorously opposed the original funding council proposals on its members' behalf, and it will fight the current DfEE proposals equally strongly. It believes that the Learning and Skills Council's control over the audit of financial statements would fundamentally alter the relationship between the council and colleges in a way that could only undermine the independence of corporations.

In recent years the intervention in the operation of colleges has made the task of management increasingly difficult. It remains unclear whether the present plans represent a considered policy of seeking to tilt the balance even further in the direction of control, or are simply a hangover from the original funding council proposals. In the Association's view, the government should say so openly if it believes the current model of college governance is inadequate. It should put up its alternative, and allow the sector an opportunity to respond to that challenge, not seek to erode college autonomy by backdoor methods.

fields.headline: Furthermore
fields.standfirst:
Janet Jones uses fire drill to check out the dress codes of academic
subcultures
fields.trailText: What do we wear in further education? The best way to carry out an informal survey, I've discovered, is to hang around until the fire alarm goes. You won't have to hang around long in our college: our fire alarms are regular, running at about three times a day at the height of the season. Off peak we're down to once a week. "Whatever we wear," we agree as we while away some of our many moments kicking our heels on our inner-city pavements, "we are making a statement."
fields.body:
What do we wear in further education? The best way to carry out an informal survey, I've discovered, is to hang around until the fire alarm goes. You won't have to hang around long in our college: our fire alarms are regular, running at about three times a day at the height of the season. Off peak we're down to once a week. "Whatever we wear," we agree as we while away some of our many moments kicking our heels on our inner-city pavements, "we are making a statement."

Some sensible people I know, who took positive action to avoid our ongoing street assemblies, were informed that "disciplinary procedures" might follow if fire alarms are ignored. We can see the point of fire alarms. But non-consenting adults who tried to continue to work have our sympathy.

So there we are, every single one of us avoiding disciplinary procedures and standing around in the fog and frost. We are a motley lot, and first mention must go to the fire service: their brown overalls and matching yellow accessories (helmet, gloves and boots) cut quite a dash in SW8. Sometimes there are four fire engines full of them. Sometimes only two.

Next you notice our own fire stewards - or maybe fire marshals - who display Day-Glo vests, or maybe jackets, on top of whatever else they may be wearing. You can't help noticing the vests because of their virulence, though whether they are yellow or green is a matter of opinion.

Distinctive, too, are the hair and beauty personnel. Interrupted in the middle of their sessions of colouring and massaging and perming and waxing, wrapped under towels, they are not at all happy to be out on the street. The painters and plumbers are more relaxed but just as conspicuous. Their overalls are not regulated like the fire service brown: they range from white to black with all the colours in between.

There are white coats to be seen as well, with all their antiseptic and clinical associations. These are worn by engineers and cooks and potters and manicurists and interior designers. They may be worn by other people also, for all I know. Most of the rest of us have had to invent our own uniforms. If we are 16-19 it tends to be black; management above a certain level tends to follow suit. Then there are those, over 19, who make a uniform of not wearing uniform. It usually involves leisurewear merging into sports.

The combined effect is theatrical: as if a colossal cast has suddenly been stranded in the middle of nowhere, without its play and without its props and without its plot. In among us there are the occasional one-offs. Shakespeare had them too and called them a jester or a rogue, a clown or a spirit or a fantastic. There is the member of the Dracula Society, for example. Or the person who was sent home for not wearing enough of anything. And there is me. When the youngest Jones exclaimed: "You're not going to work looking like that!" I had to ask: "Like what?"

"An old bag," he told me.

And so an old bag stands out on the pavement too with the best of them, her head held high.

fields.headline: Small is beautiful
fields.standfirst: Will creating fewer and larger employer training organisations sharpen up their act, or blunt their effectiveness? Report by  Simon Midgley
fields.trailText: Will creating fewer and larger employer training organisations sharpen up their act, or blunt their effectiveness?
fields.body:
The government wants to create a new generation of employer training bodies better able to meet the nation's skill needs in the 21st century. It plans to reduce the number of national training organisations (NTOs) in the UK from 73 to fewer than 30. Those NTOs which survive will, it is hoped, be stronger and more focused on ensuring that the workforce has the right skills for current and future business needs.

However, some of the smaller NTOs are fearful that they might disappear altogether.

One response to the proposal has already been tabled for discussion by Eric Strange, chairman of the Photo Imaging NTO, which represents the photographic industry with around 50,000 employees.

His plan is that in future there should be some 15 groups of NTOs representing different sectors. Under this scheme smaller NTOs in similar fields, for example the media and printing, would cluster together in groups, each represented by a governing committee that would have a representative on a national training board. This board would also include representatives from the Department for Education and Employment, the Qualifications and Curriculum Authority, and learndirect.

The board would have statutory rights and have the same status as other statutory bodies, such as the Learning and Skills Council and the regional development agencies. It would also have subcommittees specialising in careers, the regions, audit and qualifications and awards.

Under this proposal none of the 73 NTOs would be abolished. The NTOs would continue to look after the specific training needs of their discrete sectors, while the main board would communicate national skill needs to the regional development agencies, the Learning and Skills Councils and government departments.

John Stacey, chief executive of the Photo Imaging NTO, said: "We are very anxious as an NTO not to lose our identity nor the fact that we understand our industry and we can represent its training needs better than a large, multi-faceted group.

"We accept that change is necessary to increase the role of NTOs, but we do not want to throw the baby out with the bathwater."

webTitle: So you want to learn... hydrographic surveying

fields.headline: So you want to learn... hydrographic surveying
fields.standfirst: A weekly guide for lifelong learners
fields.trailText: A weekly guide for lifelong learners
fields.body:
I'm lost. Bad luck.

I was hoping you'd know the way out . Can't help, I'm afraid.

Why not? I'm lost too.

Damn. It would be different if we were under water.

It would be wetter. No, I mean I could help.

Why? I'm a hydrographic surveyor.

And what's that? I map, chart and record underwater environments. I specialise in precise positioning and data acquisition in marine environments.

And you can't get us out of this car park? No, we don't find many parking lots on the ocean bed.

You must be a pretty good swimmer. Not bad. But not for work. We scan the sea bed with sonar and navigation equipment. The data is gathered with the help of advanced satellite technology. Basically, our role is the same as a land surveyor but instead of planning and developing land-based projects, we use special resources to map offshore locations.

So where do you work? Lots of different places: from inland waters and rivers to ports and the deep oceans. As land resources become scarce, oceans become of primary importance. The precise measurements hydrographers take are very useful to industries that need to operate at sea: navigation, oil, gas and mineral resource exploration, dredging, coastal works, bridge construction, seabed telephone cables, environmental monitoring, aquaculture, oceanographic research - all these and more are dependent on the hydrographic surveyor for accurate, reliable information.

Tell me more about the environmental stuff. Take the effects of wind, waves, changing land and sea levels, which can create a need for coastal protection. The hydrographic surveyor is a key member of a team of planners, ecologist and civil engineers monitoring the environment.

What qualities does the job demand? You've got to be comfort able with water - the work is often offshore. You need to work in cramped and uncomfortable surroundings. And be prepared to be away from home for long periods, sometimes at short notice and adapt sensibly to changing circumstances. Conscientiousness and the ability to maintain concentration are essential: carelessness or a lapse in concentration may have drastic consequences.

Which qualifications are needed? It's possible to go into hydrographic surveying with a degree in most disciplines, but a postgraduate qualification is essential. A related degree would increase the chances of getting onto a postgraduate course. Postgraduate study could be completed whilst in related employment on a part-time basis. A sound scientific background and the ability to use computers are highly desirable.

But still you can't find the way out of this car park? Not without sonar and a satellite.

Telephone 02476 694757
www.rics.org

 Hydrographic Society , University of East London, Longbridge Road, Dagenham, Essex RM8 2AS

Telephone 01330 850359

www.hydrographicsociety.org

webTitle: No-cover action: what it means and why it's happening

fields.headline: No-cover action: what it means and why it's happening
fields.standfirst: London and Doncaster members of the NASUWT are to take industrial action over teacher shortages, with the NUT likely to join them. What is likely to happen and what effect will it have?
fields.trailText: London and Doncaster members of the NASUWT are to take industrial action over teacher shortages, with the NUT likely to join them. What is likely to happen and what effect will it have?
fields.body:
Why are the NASUWT and the NUT taking industrial action? I thought the government had just put up teachers' pay and that more staff were being recruited.
Teachers' pay did go up by a minimum of 3.7%, but not by as much as the unions would like - particularly since new recruits and Londoners benefited far more than older, experienced teachers. (See The pay rises at a glance). The unions argue that the government has burdened them with a heavy administrative workload and failed to reward the teachers who have borne the brunt of it.

Members of the NUT are also particularly angry that the government is forcing all teachers to pay a £25 annual subscription to join the General Teaching Council, a new body set up by the government to represent teachers' interests.

However, pay is not the main reason for this action, although it has certainly played a part in teachers' disaffection. It is the practise of asking teachers to cover unfilled teaching posts that they regard as unacceptable.

How many unfilled posts are there?
That's a difficult question. The government says one in 200 primary teaching posts are unfilled and 0.8% of secondary posts. But there are wide variations between regions, and the unions contend that the true number of vacancies is higher - particularly since they say it is much harder to find supply teachers for short-term vacancies, which are not included in the government figures.

So this isn't a strike?
No - teachers are 'working to rule' and NASUWT members are still prepared to cover up to three days' unforeseen absence. But if supply teachers can't be found, this may still mean that pupils are sent home in areas with a shortage.

How many schools will be affected?
Possibly as many as a thousand. But 'no-cover action' has already taken place in Finchley, Surrey, Northumberland, Hertfordshire, Sandwell and Kent without undue disruption. If it turns out that schools do not have to be closed, then the unions' contention that teacher shortages are severe will inevitably be weakened.

Will the action spread beyond London and Doncaster?
It may do, if union members in the other areas being balloted - which include Manchester, Leicester, Nottingham, Southampton and Reading - vote for 'no-cover action' too.

(See The pay rises at a glance). The unions argue that the government has burdened them with a heavy administrative workload and failed to reward the teachers who have borne the brunt of it. Members of the NUT are also particularly angry that the government is forcing all teachers to pay a £25 annual subscription to join the General Teaching Council, a new body set up by the government to represent teachers' interests. However, pay is not the main reason for this action, although it has certainly played a part in teachers' disaffection. It is the practise of asking teachers to cover unfilled teaching posts that they regard as unacceptable. How many unfilled posts are there? That's a difficult question. The government says one in 200 primary teaching posts are unfilled and 0.8% of secondary posts. But there are wide variations between regions, and the unions contend that the true number of vacancies is higher - particularly since they say it is much harder to find supply teachers for short-term vacancies, which are not included in the government figures. So this isn't a strike? No - teachers are 'working to rule' and NASUWT members are still prepared to cover up to three days' unforeseen absence. But if supply teachers can't be found, this may still mean that pupils are sent home in areas with a shortage. How many schools will be affected? Possibly as many as a thousand. But 'no-cover action' has already taken place in Finchley, Surrey, Northumberland, Hertfordshire, Sandwell and Kent without undue disruption. If it turns out that schools do not have to be closed, then the unions' contention that teacher shortages are severe will inevitably be weakened. Will the action spread beyond London and Doncaster? It may do, if union members in the other areas being balloted - which include Manchester, Leicester, Nottingham, Southampton and Reading - vote for 'no-cover action' too. fields.headline: Teachers vote for industrial action
fields.standfirst: NASUWT members will not cover for unfilled posts
fields.trailText: London and Doncaster members of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers voted to refuse to cover for unfilled teaching posts today. The NASUWT predicted that the action would mean pupils were sent home in a third of London's schools.
fields.body:
London and Doncaster members of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers voted to refuse to cover for unfilled teaching posts today. The NASUWT predicted that the action would mean pupils were sent home in a third of London's schools.

Further ballots are being held in Leicester, Middlesbrough, Nottingham, Portsmouth, Southampton, Kent, Manchester and Reading over the next fortnight, raising the possibility of more disruption.

Ninety-three percent of NASUWT members voted to refuse to cover unfilled teaching posts on a 30% turnout. A similar result is expected from the National Union of Teachers' ballots.

NASUWT general secretary Nigel de Gruchy announced that "enough is enough."

"Supply teachers are deployed to cover the permanent vacancies the government denies exist," he said. They are no longer available to carry out their true purpose of day-to-day absence. After one week NASUWT members will only "cover to contract" - that is, cover for unforeseen absences up to a maximum of three days. I estimate that about a third of schools in London and Doncaster could be forced to go on some form of part-time schooling."

Education secretary David Blunkett, who has announced a raft of measures to boost recruitment this winter, declared the action "counterproductive". "Industrial action will not solve the recruitment problem - all it will do is to make the task of raising standards and engaging children's commitment that much harder," he said.

"What we need is positive ideas to build on the emerging success of the recruitment policy so that we can attract teachers back into the profession now as well as new recruits from September."

But Mr de Gruchy said the measures were "too little, too late and often irrelevant to the experienced classroom teacher."

He said the union would co-operate to ensure any closures were organised in "an orderly fashion".

fields.headline: Campbell's hires Abbott Mead Vickers
fields.trailText: 6pm: The Campbell Soup Company has awarded its £5m UK ad account to Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO without a pitch, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The Campbell Soup Company, the US foods giant whose iconic red and white tins were made famous by Andy Warhol, has awarded its £5m UK ad account to Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO without a pitch.

The account, which also includes the Homepride sauce brand, was previously handled by Rainey Kelly Campbell Roalfe/Y&R.

The decision to switch to AMV is part of a global agency realignment and reflects the fact the BBDO network handles the business in the US.

Campbell's business is split between the Young & Rubicam and BBDO networks internationally.

It is not clear whether the realignment will affect Oxo and Batchelors, the two UK brands the Campbell Soup Company acquired from Unilever last year.

But the decision is likely to put AMV in pole position if, as seems likely, the company decides to review its advertising arrangements for the former Unilever brands.

The move does not affect Y&R's hold on the Campbell's brands in Europe.

webTitle: Councils face higher bill for asylum seekers

fields.headline: Councils face higher bill for asylum seekers
fields.trailText: Councils that rely on government funding to meet the costs of supporting destitute asylum seekers were told by the high court today that thousands of refugees are not covered by the scheme.
fields.body:
Councils that rely on government funding to meet the costs of supporting destitute asylum seekers were told by the high court today that thousands of refugees are not covered by the scheme.

A judge ruled that the Home Office's National Asylum Support Service (NASS) applied only to refugees whose need for support and accommodation arose "solely" from their destitution, and not to those who were also in need because of sickness, disablement or old age.

The ruling will dismay councils across the country, but will hit hardest those in the south-east, such as Kent and the London borough of Hillingdon, that cover major ports of entry and so bear the brunt of rising levels of asylum seekers.

The decision, based on a strict interpretation of the 1999 Immigration and Asylum Act which introduced NASS, was a defeat for Westminster city council in its bid to recover the cost of supporting asylum seekers with such special needs.

It is understood from the ruling that NASS will continue to pay basic allowances for areas such as accommodation, but anything extra will now have to be paid for by councils.

Kent leader Sandy Bruce-Lockhart hit out at the ruling, and called for assurances from the government that ministers would meet the additional costs. "It seems an extraordinary judgement," he commented.

Mr Justice Stanley Burnton granted Westminster permission to launch an urgent appeal after being told that the authority faced the prospect of having to support "possibly several thousand people" at a cost for which it was unprepared.

Westminster had described as "absurd" the government's claim - upheld by the judge - that local government must shoulder the burden of supporting those very asylum seekers whose needs were the greatest and most costly to provide for. The judge agreed that the result was "curious" and left "a number of incongruities", but he was driven to that conclusion by the wording of the Act, in particular the use of the word "solely".

The council had challenged the refusal of NASS to accept responsibility for Sabiha Mirza Y-Ahmad, 49, an Iraqi Kurd asylum seeker fleeing from Saddam's regime, and her 13-year-old daughter.

Mrs Y-Ahmad is not only destitute, but is confined to a wheelchair by spinal myeloma, for which she is being treated at St Mary's Hospital, Paddington. The judge said Mrs Y-Ahmad therefore required, in addition to her essential living needs, accommodation with wheelchair access within reach of St Mary's and with enough space for her daughter and carers.

At present, she was staying at a west London hotel at a cost of £176 per day.

webTitle: Lib Dems insist on tax rise to boost schools and NHS

fields.headline: Lib Dems insist on tax rise to boost schools and NHS
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrats are to enter the general election as the only main party committed to raising income tax under plans to put extra revenues into health and education.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats are to enter the general election as the only main party committed to raising income tax under plans to put extra revenues into health and education.

The party's alternative budget, published yesterday and forming the basis of its manifesto, reaffirms the Lib Dems' best-known policy - an extra penny on the basic rate of income tax to fund an increase of £3bn a year for education.

The party will also stand apart from Labour and the Tories in pledging a new top tax band, introducing a 50p rate for those earning over £100,000.

The extra income created by this and changes to capital gains tax would go towards new investment in the health service, including an average extra £1,000 a year for nurses, an extra 11,000 hospital beds and guaranteed access to NHS dentists.

The proposals leave the Lib Dems as the sole defenders of increased taxation. The Tories are proposing £8bn tax cuts, and the chancellor Gordon Brown - though not expected to cut income tax in next week's budget - will not increase rates amid revelations of a £16bn budget surplus.

However, the Lib Dems will go into the general election in sisting that, while they may be raising income taxes they will forego "stealth taxes" imposed by the chancellor.

The Lib Dem Treasury spokesman, Matthew Taylor, yesterday said his party's proposals offered transparency: "Labour may be taxing more but they are not spending more."

The party proposes sending every taxpayer an annual "citizen's tax contract", spelling out exactly how much tax is being raised.

The Lib Dem leader, Charles Kennedy, said the proposals amounted to an "honest, fully costed" package of investment in health, education and pensions.

Labour said the plans did not add up and suggested that the Lib Dem policy of a penny on income tax for education, which dates back to before the 1997 general election, would not raise enough money to match Labour's education spending.

The chief secretary to the Treasury, Andrew Smith, called the plans "a menu without prices... uncosted promises funded over and over again by the same tax increases.

"In their 1997 election manifesto, the Lib Dems pledged £3.5bn extra for the NHS over five years but with Labour, between 2000 and 2004, NHS investment is set to grow by a third in real terms," he said.

webTitle: 'We humans make mistakes, the animals are the victims'

fields.headline: 'We humans make mistakes, the animals are the victims'
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Today's edition of the German popular tabloid Bild turned to the bible to sum up the sense of doom in Europe over the latest food crisis to hit the continent.
fields.byline: Kate Connolly in Berlin and Jon Henley in Paris
fields.body:
Today's edition of the German popular tabloid Bild turned to the bible to sum up the sense of doom in Europe over the latest food crisis to hit the continent.

"Let us make man in our likeness to rule the fish in the sea, the birds of heaven, the cattle, all wild animals on earth and all reptiles that crawl upon the earth," it wrote quoting Genesis, as the caption to a photograph of a funeral pyre of animal corpses at a British farm.

The paper puts the illness down to yet more human error, and suggests it's time to start looking at what we're doing wrong: "We humans make mistakes, the animals are the victims, the fire is the warning."

Then it asks the question on everyone's lips - where did the disease come from? - before giving a Sun-style reply: "Probably a tourist brought it in - from Africa or Asia. Perhaps it arrived in a sandwich. It was thrown away and an animal gobbled it up..."

The German authorities are certainly taking no chances about allowing the disease to enter Germany in such a careless way. The Berliner Morgenpost shows the picture of a British man who has just arrived from Hamburg on the ferry from England, looking rather cross as the policeman confiscates his bottle of milk.

According to the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, border checks have been stepped up not just at possible entrances from England, but even along the border with Poland at the ports of Rostock and Mukran, where British meat may be arriving on a circuitous route via other suppliers.

The paper quotes the agriculture ministry as saying that customs warehouses are also being searched for meat and other animal products and travellers have been requested to hand over animal products to customs officials on arriving in Germany.

In an editorial in the Süddeutsche Zeitung, the pictures of burning corpses which were on the front of almost every German newspaper this morning, are said to be enough to put people off their meat for good, if the current BSE crisis which struck Germany in November hasn't done so already.

"Those consumers who turned from beef to pork, lamb or veal could lose their appetite for meat altogether after seeing those pictures. The only thing that's missing now is the discovery that the chickens are stuffed full of salmonella and the fish bunged up with worms."

Amid mounting French concern about the spread of mad cow disease, news of the foot and mouth crisis across the Channel - another epidemic seen as born in Britain - has been given extensive coverage in the national press.

"The agricultural earthquake", the left-leaning daily Libération headlined its front page, pointing out that with French domestic beef consumption down by as much as 20% last year and exports down 30%, the country's hard-hit farmers would have difficulty surviving a full-blown outbreak of foot and mouth disease.

"What we are witnessing is a generalised crisis of the European agricultural system," the paper said in its editorial. "While its epicentre is in Great Britain, the crisis is also a French one: in no other European country is the common agricultural policy so important as in France."

Le Monde's London correspondent spoke of a "nightmare scenario" in Britain, with "the potential slaughter of thousands of head of cattle" in a country where "great fires burned made of railway sleepers, straw, petrol and the carcasses of hundreds of pigs slaughtered in recent days in Northumberland and Essex."

The tabloid France Soir concentrated on the risk to France, saying that the disease was "progressing at an alarming rate" in Britain and that the discovery of a new site 600km from the initial farm in northern England augured ill.

The paper said France was particularly vulnerable to the disease, noting that the country imported 40,000 British pigs and 47,000 sheep last month alone, and that the possibility of northern France being contaminated by airborne transmission "could not be excluded by any means".

Le Parisien, another popular tabloid, quoted a recent report from Brussels saying that an epidemic in France would prove "catastrophic". The last outbreak recorded in France was in 1981, the paper said, so most farmers and vets have only seen the disease in books or on videos.

The newspaper, like most in France, praised the speed and severity of the emergency measures taken by the British government, but wondered whether they would be enough to protect France.

"If the disease hit an area of high livestock density such as Brittany," it said, "the situation would rapidly become extremely dangerous and very difficult to control."

fields.headline: UKIP hit by new row over over Holocaust denial
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: A further split has ocurred in the United Kingdom Independence party after an executive member and five-time candidate endorsed the rightwing historian David Irving's denial of the Holocaust.
fields.body:
A further split has ocurred in the United Kingdom Independence party after an executive member and five-time candidate endorsed the rightwing historian David Irving's denial of the Holocaust.

Alistair McConnachie caused resignations from the party when he wrote to the Scottish press saying the Pope had been duped over the Holocaust and attacked the Board of Deputies of British Jews.

Mark Lester, the party's London candidate for the Euro elections, has resigned after the executive (which includes two MEPs) rescinded a decision to expel Mr McConnachie for five years, saying he had a private right to "freedom of speech".

Documents passed to the Guardian show Mr McConnachie took a far stronger line in emails to party members. He wrote to one critic, executive member Christopher Skeate, saying: " I don't accept that gas chambers were used to execute Jews for the simple fact there is no direct physical evidence to show that such gas chambers ever existed... there are no photographs or film of execution gas chambers... Alleged eyewitness accounts are revealed as false or highly exaggerated."

Mr McConnachie has publicly said the Pope had been misled about numbers of Jews killed at Auschwitz, and has accused the board of deputies of "seeking to establish a monopoly in the marketplace of ideas" because it complained to the BBC about the handling of Mr Irving's views.

Mr Lester initially complained about the letters. Minutes of a party disciplinary hearing show it expelled Mr McConnachie for five years for bringing the party into disrepute, though it defended his right to free speech.

This month the executive commuted the penalty to a year's suspension from the executive. Mr McConnachie remains listed as Scottish organiser on UKIP's website, and no publicity has been given to the action taken.

Yesterday he defended his "private right to free speech within the law" and stood by every word in his emails. "The executive did rule I had the right to free speech about an historical situation," he said.

Mr Lester yesterday expressed his "anger and disgust". He wrote to the party secretary, Michael Harvey, saying: "I wish I could say I wish you and the party success in the future - I don't."

He had been put in a totally unacceptable position "as the guarantor to the Jewish community and the media that [the party's] leadership would not countenance individuals with anti-semitic or similarly disturbing viewpoints - the executive is happy to have a supporter of David Irving as a member and activist, so long as he is not on the executive for one year."

Mr Harvey said yesterday Mr McConnachie had brought the party into disrepute, and he had yet to apply to be a candidate at the general election.
