Mr McConnachie has publicly said the Pope had been misled about numbers of Jews killed at Auschwitz, and has accused the board of deputies of "seeking to establish a monopoly in the marketplace of ideas" because it complained to the BBC about the handling of Mr Irving's views. Mr Lester initially complained about the letters. Minutes of a party disciplinary hearing show it expelled Mr McConnachie for five years for bringing the party into disrepute, though it defended his right to free speech. This month the executive commuted the penalty to a year's suspension from the executive. Mr McConnachie remains listed as Scottish organiser on UKIP's website, and no publicity has been given to the action taken. Yesterday he defended his "private right to free speech within the law" and stood by every word in his emails. "The executive did rule I had the right to free speech about an historical situation," he said. Mr Lester yesterday expressed his "anger and disgust". He wrote to the party secretary, Michael Harvey, saying: "I wish I could say I wish you and the party success in the future - I don't." He had been put in a totally unacceptable position "as the guarantor to the Jewish community and the media that [the party's] leadership would not countenance individuals with anti-semitic or similarly disturbing viewpoints - the executive is happy to have a supporter of David Irving as a member and activist, so long as he is not on the executive for one year." Mr Harvey said yesterday Mr McConnachie had brought the party into disrepute, and he had yet to apply to be a candidate at the general election.

webTitle: Not even foot and mouth will get Hague elected

fields.headline: Not even foot and mouth will get Hague elected
fields.standfirst:
Even if the outbreak does mean the election is postponed, Tony Blair is still certain to win, writes political editor Michael White

Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText:
Even if the outbreak does mean the election is postponed, Tony Blair is still certain to win, writes political editor Michael White
Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.body:
When Ben Gill, president of the National Farmers' Union, told Channel 4 News it would be highly dangerous to stage a general election during an outbreak of foot and mouth disease he was stumbling into prime ministerial prerogative.

For months politicians, officials and journalists have been wondering aloud whether Tony Blair would go to the country on May 3, the most widely tipped date; delay until June or even October (unlikely); or surprise the Conservatives by suddenly going to the palace on March 12, five days after the budget, and plumping for April 5.

Now here was a farmer saying, in effect, that if his troops could postpone their countryside march - scheduled for March 18 - then the government could put country before party too.

No one complained. Ministers and MPs (in all parties) have been quick to grasp the enormity of the latest crisis for Britain's already battered agricultural industry, still reeling from the BSE inheritance of the 1980s.

That alone makes it hard for William Hague's team to make much of an issue of the foot and mouth epidemic. Unlike home-grown BSE it is certain to have been imported via the globalised food chain. No Brownie points there for William

But Mr Gill's point quickly became the conventional wisdom at Westminster, not least because it consolidated what most MPs thought anyway. None of the parties were ready, locally or nationally, they needed more time to write those manifestos and print those Vote for me posters.

All the same both William Hague and the Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, had put their troops on alert for April 5 - routine tactics because they have to allow for Mr Blair pulling off that stunt.

As for No 10 it has been happy to encourage media speculation - only 60/40 on May 3, the BBC reported 10 days ago - because it wastes Tory time and money on contingency planning.

But the logic of the 1997 parliament has constantly pulled Mr Blair back to May 3. It would be four years and two days after Mr Blair's 1997 landslide, compatible with the four-year cycle British voters accept.

Prime ministers who go the five year distance, notably John Major in 1997, do so out of desperation and pay the penalty, though in 1992 he confounded the pundits and won at the almost last minute.

That year Mr Major called the April 9 election on March 11, the day after Norman Lamont's tax-cutting budget, the one which piled up debts that are still being paid off. In 1997 he called it earlier, hoping (as Jim Callaghan did against the rampant Margaret Thatcher in 1979) that a less experienced challenger would have enough time to make a fatal mistake.

It failed. It usually does. This time Gordon Brown has been cautious in Labour's early years, not taxing-and-spending in the way other Labour chancellors have done. He has been blessed with good economic weather and has handled it well itself.

The result has been the cascade of extra money for schools, hospitals, transport unveiled in the Comprehensive Spending Review (CSR) last July - coming on stream now. Higher pensions and benefits are also due to be paid during April and Mr Brown is certain to add more goodies on March 7.

That means voters will feel his largesse (it is their own money he is giving back) during April, but not by April 5. Local election day is May 3, so a general election should - in theory - boost turnout and save some Labour councils.

But, but... some Labour stalwarts look at the polls ("Things Can't Get Better for Blair" said a Telegraph headline as unemployment and inflation sank again in February) and say "go now while the going is good". They point to the disruption of the census on April 29 as a potential irritant for many voters. They point to the second Mandelson resignation and the "cash for wigs" row involving the lord chancellor, Derry Irvine, to show how damaging storms come from nowhere. They could also point to this week's cattle-burning.

Except that none of it yet has much impact on the polls. Mr Blair may not be loved, but William Hague is unpopular and his party is 15% behind, according to the latest ICM/Guardian survey; more in other polls. Whatever the date it looks as if Mr Gill and everyone else already knows the result.

webTitle: Fiance in court as Dando trial opens

fields.headline: Fiance in court as Dando trial opens
fields.trailText: Jill Dando's fiance went to the Old Bailey yesterday to see for the first time the man accused of murdering her with a single shot to the head five months before the couple were due to marry.
fields.body:
Jill Dando's fiance went to the Old Bailey yesterday to see for the first time the man accused of murdering her with a single shot to the head five months before the couple were due to marry.

Alan Farthing, a gynaecologist, watched impassively as Barry George, 40, was led to the dock of court no 1 at 10.30am for the first day of a trial expected to last up to eight weeks.

Nick Ross, Miss Dando's co-presenter on the BBC show Crimewatch UK, was another spectator when George, wearing a blue long-sleeved jumper, blue shirt and a yellow tie, stood in court briefly to confirm his name.

George, who lives in Fulham, west London,close to Miss Dando's home, periodically took notes during the afternoon hearing, resting his pad on a bible he had brought to court.

The death of Miss Dando on April 26 1999 and the subsequent police investigation generated enormous publicity, and the trial of George will be followed by journalists from around the world.

Fifty reporters were present yesterday to hear legal arguments presented to the judge, Mr Justice Gage, by George's barrister, Michael Mansfield QC, and the senior Treasury prosecuting counsel (as he is termed), Orlando Pownall.

Scores of other journalists, including photographers and TV crews, were waiting outside.

Legal deliberations will continue today, and it is unlikely a jury will be sworn until tomorrow or Thursday.

fields.headline: The joke's on you!
fields.standfirst: Scream 3, available to buy this week on video, may well be one of the tricksiest flicks to hit your local multiplex. It toys with the idea of its very purpose and outcome (the sequel conundrum) and then performs the most familiar of Hollywood jokes - the film within a film. To celebrate its video release, here's another random collection of such clever-clogs in-jokiness.
fields.trailText:
The Player (1991)
Directed by Robert Altman. Starring Tim Robbins.
fields.body:
The Player (1991)
Directed by Robert Altman. Starring Tim Robbins.

The cast list of over 60 stars conjures up visions of Winnebago hell as Hollywood's finest pile into work and try to find parking spaces. Tim Robbins hits a peak as a Hollywood insider who may well be about to get his comeuppance. Bruce Willis shows his first signs of intelligence in sending up his hero-in-a-vest persona and Richard E Grant plays a writer who deserves a good slapping. Well when doesn't Richard E Grant deserve a good slapping.

Swimming with Sharks (1995)
Directed by George Huang. Starring Kevin Spacey.

Pre-American Beauty, Kevin Spacey is the boss from hell, a big-time movie executive who makes his new employee's life hell with inventive insults, clever ways with an envelope and assaults with office equipment. Frank Whaley is his hapless assistant who gets to have the last laugh when he wreaks revenge by kidnapping the boss.

Irma Vep (1996)
Directed by Olivier Assayas. Starring Maggie Cheung.

The French film industry poking fun at itself is always worth a watch, even if we don't get all the jokes. Few have heard of comic serial Les Vampires which is a central part of the film-making plot - but who cares? It's got Maggie Cheung in a catsuit. Which doesn't happen often enough in my opinion.

Boogie Nights (1998)
Directed by Paul T Anderson. Starring Burt Reynolds, Mark Wahlberg.

A sweeping and stylish homage to 1970s excess and the rise of the porn film industry; a cautionary tale of drugs and sex; Burt Reynolds' memorable comeback performance; William H Macey's scene stealing cocaine freak - and what do we all remember? Mark Wahlberg's (prosthetic) 13-incher. It makes the 70s look hip and it confirmed Andersen's fantastic promise (this was only his second feature).

Ed Wood (1994)
Directed by Tim Burton. Starring Johnny Depp.

Easily the most affectionate of all the film-films, this is a black and white portrayal of transvestism, morphine addiction and good old-fashioned incompetence as Depp cheerfully makes a mess of his career and Bela Lugosi (Martin Landau) gloomily goes to his grave like a gothic Eeyore. And as a tribute to the powers of angora, it could hardly be bettered.

fields.headline: WWAV Rapp Collins tackles Viagra
fields.trailText:
2.30pm: Pfizer has hired the direct marketing specialist to promote the drug across Europe, reports Julia Day.
Feb 9: Pfizer smartens up with 'functional foods'
fields.body:
Viagra manufacturer Pfizer has appointed direct marketing agency WWAV Rapp Collins to help change the image of impotence from a smutty joke to a serious subject.

The Rapp Collins network will create a marketing campaign to build direct contact with potential users of the drug across Europe.

The agency won the pan-European, multimillion-pound account after a competitive pitch.

The campaign is likely to work in conjunction with Viagra's brand advertising to offer men advice on impotence.

UK and European regulations prohibit the promotion of prescription drugs directly to the consumer.

But health education and corporate advertising are permitted to promote drugs as long as the promotions do not amount to disguised brand advertising.

McCann-Erickson handles Viagra's £14m pan-European advertising.

The agency picked up the account last year after a pitch against Saatchi & Saatchi and Publicis.

Pfizer consolidated its £482m US media planning and buying account into Carat New York earlier this month, sparking a similar media pitch in the UK.

The media consolidation was sparked by Pfizer's £62bn acquisition of rival Warner-Lambert last year.

fields.headline: Stefano Hatfield: View from America
fields.standfirst:
He is an expert on advertising both in Europe and America and has won plaudits for his insightful musings about the industry over the last 10 years. Today MediaGuardian.co.uk is delighted to announce that former editor-in-chief of Campaign and Times columnist Stefano Hatfield is joining as one of our star columnists.

Every Tuesday morning, Stefano will bring our readers a taste of Madison Avenue, the home of some of the most powerful figures in the industry. Find out why two of those figures - Sir Martin Sorrell and John Wren - are talking up the recession in his first instalment of View from America.
fields.trailText: Why Sir Martin Sorrell and John Wren are talking up the recession, writes Stefano Hatfield, former editor-in-chief of Campaign and MediaGuardian.co.uk's latest star columnist.
fields.body:
There is a standard advertising industry procedure for dealing with recession.

First, deny there is one. This can go on for a year or more - until those denying start losing their own jobs. Then, when the impact is clear (ie revenue has collapsed), frantically attack your cost base. Start with banning Post-It notes, and then taxis, but move quickly on to people, often the more senior because they save you the most money. Immediately scrap trainees and training.

Next, spend two years listening to clients telling you they are not satisfied with your pared-down agency's performance. They use this as an excuse to reduce your income, and eventually move their account. This you will replace by sacrificing margin to steal business on price from another pared-down agency. Then, as the economy picks up, throw money at inadequately skilled staff at rival agencies to improve your own competitiveness. Income will rise. Costs will rise more.

So, why is the US advertising industry not following procedure? The speed with which the current downturn has taken hold has surprised an entire sector. There is no suggestion of denial. While the likes of John Wren's Omnicom and Sir Martin Sorrell's WPP are unveiling excellent year 2000 results, agency groups in the US have thrown the handbook out of the window, and - if anything - talked the recession up.

Across the country, major agencies are making redundancies in a pre-emptive belt-tightening exercise. Not just - inevitably - the numerous new media arms of the major groups, and struggling names like Young & Rubicam, where it might be expected, but industry leaders such as BBDO.

Advertisers have pulled hundreds of millions of dollars from the 'TV upfronts' (money pledged in spring to buy autumn television airtime, when the networks unveil their big-hitting shows). Suddenly, networks have unsold inventory, and ad-gorged magazines that resembled telephone directories have started making sweeping lay-offs.

What accounts for this downward spiral of negative thought from the brashest industry in the world's most optimistic nation?

One little-mentioned explanation is that virtually all significant agency groups, media owners and their clients are now publicly-held companies, or about to become so - a very different situation to the last US recession a decade ago. Wall Street will not countenance denial. So they are forecasting down, 'restructuring' fast and being seen to be doing so. They tell anyone who will listen that 50% of income now comes from sources other than traditional advertising - such as direct marketing - and from non-US markets.

In short, Wren, Sorrell and co are managing Wall Street's expectations, because not to be cautious just now invites ridicule, and a severe bruising for your stock when next year's results reveal the true softness of the current ad market. That advertising agencies may recover faster and staffers feel less pain than in previous downturns is almost incidental.

 Stefano Hatfield is managing director and editorial director of Ad Age Global.

fields.headline: Brickbats, brats and Brits
fields.trailText: Monkey reports from a night out at the Brit Awards, where Graham Norton's choice of guest raised eyebrows and bad boy Eminem became respectable at last.
fields.body:
In the absence of any rock star misbehaviour, the best story of the night came from two of the guests. Graham Norton raised eyebrows with his choice of dinner partner - Castaway heartthrob Ben Fogle. Eyebrows arched further at the nature of their arrival: in the style of Camilla and Charles, they turned up separately and spent most of the evening a couple of paces apart. Anything you want to tell us, Graham?

ITV chairman Leslie Hill, who took the Bragg-sponsored Brit for most bouffant hairdo, attended at the ceremony for the first time in 10 years. Back in the mists of time, explained Hill, he was the EMI boss responsible for such acts as the Sex Pistols. Staring uncomprehending at Eminem's distortion of the Queen's English, he mused that times had indeed changed.

Corporate rock whore Eminem was stripped of his official title Bad Boy of Rap when, accepting the award for best international male solo artist, he pulled out a scrap of paper and thanked his record company, Polydor. "What a fraud - you wouldn't have heard the Clash thanking CBS," muttered one pop veteran. "He's turning into Andy Williams before our very eyes."

ITV insisted to the Brits organisers that if they wanted their show broadcast, they had better allow the Popstars to perform. So, blinking into the spotlights, up stepped Hear'Say, the band whose members are more familiar to the youth audience than U2,. At least they looked like popstars, for once, not just kids pulled in from the street (which is what, of course, they are). But their slick performance was rather low-key compared with the top showbiz numbers of Destiny's Child and Westlife. Will it be panto by Christmas for Noel, Danny, Myleene, Suzanne and Kym?

The roars of delight from the teenage audience members for Hear'Say were matched by an air of condescending silence from the record industry tables, where executives were clearly aghast that the band formed partly to expose their cynical methods had invaded their party. But their cynicism was not shared by the celebrities who queued up to meet the famous five: Denise Van Outen, Fay Ripley and Robbie Williams were among those who asked to be introduced.

Presenters Ant and Dec put in a creditable performance, despite the execrable nature of their script. The opening monologue barely raised a titter, and the Who Wants to be a Millionaire? routine with Cat Deeley was truly cringe-making. But, troopers that they are, the Geordie duo were unfazed when award presenter Jane Horrocks said of the backstage guests: "They're still looking for Charlie." It was, of course, a reference to Mrs Merton's similar quip two years ago, and not anything remotely to do with the Sun's stupid sniffer dog.

Prize for worst pre-Brits hype goes to the hapless PR who spun the line about Robbie and Geri's Great Kiss - the sole purpose of which was to hand Halliwell the truly sick-making line: "This winner, according to press reports, is giving me one, so it's about time I returned the favour and gave him one." fields.headline: Stefano Hatfield: View from America
fields.standfirst:
He is an expert on advertising both in Europe and America and has won plaudits for his insightful musings about the industry over the last 10 years. Today MediaGuardian.co.uk is delighted to announce that former editor-in-chief of Campaign and Times columnist Stefano Hatfield is joining as one of our star columnists.

Every Wednesday morning, Stefano will bring our readers a taste of Madison Avenue, the home of some of the most powerful figures in the industry. Find out why two of those figures - Sir Martin Sorrell and John Wren - are talking up the recession in his first instalment of View from America.
fields.trailText: Why Sir Martin Sorrell and John Wren are talking up the recession, writes Stefano Hatfield, former editor-in-chief of Campaign and MediaGuardian.co.uk's latest star columnist.
fields.body:
There is a standard advertising industry procedure for dealing with recession.

First, deny there is one. This can go on for a year or more - until those denying start losing their own jobs. Then, when the impact is clear (ie revenue has collapsed), frantically attack your cost base. Start with banning Post-It notes, and then taxis, but move quickly on to people, often the more senior because they save you the most money. Immediately scrap trainees and training.

Next, spend two years listening to clients telling you they are not satisfied with your pared-down agency's performance. They use this as an excuse to reduce your income, and eventually move their account. This you will replace by sacrificing margin to steal business on price from another pared-down agency. Then, as the economy picks up, throw money at inadequately skilled staff at rival agencies to improve your own competitiveness. Income will rise. Costs will rise more.

So, why is the US advertising industry not following procedure? The speed with which the current downturn has taken hold has surprised an entire sector. There is no suggestion of denial. While the likes of John Wren's Omnicom and Sir Martin Sorrell's WPP are unveiling excellent year 2000 results, agency groups in the US have thrown the handbook out of the window, and - if anything - talked the recession up.

Across the country, major agencies are making redundancies in a pre-emptive belt-tightening exercise. Not just - inevitably - the numerous new media arms of the major groups, and struggling names like Young & Rubicam, where it might be expected, but industry leaders such as BBDO.

Advertisers have pulled hundreds of millions of dollars from the 'TV upfronts' (money pledged in spring to buy autumn television airtime, when the networks unveil their big-hitting shows). Suddenly, networks have unsold inventory, and ad-gorged magazines that resembled telephone directories have started making sweeping lay-offs.

What accounts for this downward spiral of negative thought from the brashest industry in the world's most optimistic nation?

One little-mentioned explanation is that virtually all significant agency groups, media owners and their clients are now publicly-held companies, or about to become so - a very different situation to the last US recession a decade ago. Wall Street will not countenance denial. So they are forecasting down, 'restructuring' fast and being seen to be doing so. They tell anyone who will listen that 50% of income now comes from sources other than traditional advertising - such as direct marketing - and from non-US markets.

In short, Wren, Sorrell and co are managing Wall Street's expectations, because not to be cautious just now invites ridicule, and a severe bruising for your stock when next year's results reveal the true softness of the current ad market. That advertising agencies may recover faster and staffers feel less pain than in previous downturns is almost incidental.

 Stefano Hatfield is managing director and editorial director of Ad Age Global.

fields.headline: C5 bids to move evening news to 5.30pm
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Channel 5 bosses last night defended their proposal to abandon news in peaktime, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Channel 5 bosses last night defended their proposal to abandon news in peaktime and move the evening bulletin to a slot that will compete with Neighbours on BBC1.

The station has already moved the bulletin three times but it is struggling to get audiences at 6pm.

Bosses at the station last night defended the latest plan to move the news to an even earlier slot of 5.30pm.

They claimed the time might not be peaktime in London but it would be peaktime in the north.

The station is in talks with regulators about a new slot that will position the news against the formidable competition of Neighbours on BBC1 and Wheel of Fortune on ITV.

Channel 5 marketing director Jim Hytner said moving the news would ensure a bigger audience for the news broadcast because it would no longer compete with BBC1's bulletin.

"We're discussing the move with the Independent Television Commission at the moment," he said.

"Our licence requires us to broadcast news in peaktime, which, at the moment, is defined as 6pm to 10.30pm.

"But for many people outside London, peaktime begins earlier. In Leeds and Liverpool, people tend to be at home by 5.30pm and they have no problem with switching the TV on to watch the news at that time," he said at last night's Mediatel Media Question Time at the BBC's Radio Theatre.

Channel 5's licence states it must broadcast at least 15 minutes of news in peaktime for the first five years of its existence.

The channel originally proposed to broadcast the news at 8.30pm but changed the time to 8pm before it launched.

Fronted by Kirsty Young perching on a newsdesk, its maverick style broke new ground and won the hearts and minds of younger viewers.

At one stage it was being watched by as many as 900,000 viewers and even managed on at least one occasion to beat Channel 4 news in the ratings.

It then brought the news forward to 7pm and again to 6pm, where it has been for the past two years.

The ITC is now looking at Channel 5's request and is expected to look favourably on the proposal.

webTitle: Winter returns to plunge northern Britain into chaos

fields.headline: Winter returns to plunge northern Britain into chaos
fields.standfirst: Special report: weather watch
fields.trailText: Parts of northern Britain has been plunged into chaos today by the return of winter.
fields.body:
High winds, freezing temperatures and heavy snowfall have plunged northern parts of Britain into chaos today, leaving people struggling to cope without power or transport.

Scotland, Northern Ireland and northern England battled treacherous conditions overnight and forecasters have warned that the weather is edging south.

Motorists stranded by snowdrifts were forced to spend the night in their vehicles, while all Virgin trains to and from Scotland were cancelled amid reports of snow on the rails "as high as the platforms".

Seventy passengers were stranded just north of Lockerbie on an overnight train from London when it got stuck behind a broken-down train. The conditions meant the train, which left London 14 hours earlier, could not be towed north.

A ScotRail spokesman said that the passengers would have to be taken south to Carlisle and put up in a hotel.

Elsewhere on the railways, 120 people were stranded on the 6.32am train from Kilmarnock, Ayrshire, to Glasgow, after it became stuck in snow.

A snowplough was used in an attempt to reach the stranded train 10 miles north of Kilmarnock to free the passengers and get refreshments to them.

"The snow is causing major problems and the high winds have made things even more difficult because of the drifting," the spokesman said.

No sleepers will be run from London tonight.

Flights to and from Scotland have also been cancelled, while police closed roads and warned drivers against trying to make any journeys unless they were absolutely essential.

Strathclyde Police said major road routes including the M74 and M77 motorways were blocked in parts.

More than 100,000 homes in Scotland were left without power as electricity company workers fought to reach cables knocked down or damaged by winds gusting up to 70 mph.

Scottish Power said the worst affected areas were from central eastern Scotland, including Fife and East Lothian, down to the Scottish Borders. Hundreds of schools are expected to remain closed.

In Northern Ireland, up to 70,000 homes were left without power as heavy snow and fierce winds caused widespread damage to the electricity network.

Air, sea and rail services were seriously disrupted by winds of 70 mph and scores of schools were closed.

Northern Ireland Electricity warned it could be tomorrow before all supplies were restored. County Antrim and County Down were the worst affected areas.

In Northumberland, the A1 was closed between Alnwick and Scotland due to heavy snow and fallen power cables, while police advised drivers against using the A68, A696 and the A697.

fields.headline: Beckham confirmed as England captain
fields.trailText: David Beckham will be England captain for the match against Spain tomorrow night, Sven-Goran Eriksson has confirmed.
fields.body:
David Beckham will be England captain for the match against Spain tomorrow night, Sven-Goran Eriksson has confirmed.

"It will be the same captain as it was for the game against Italy - David Beckham," Eriksson told a press conference today. "First of all it's a good idea. Secondly I don't see any point in making changes because he did very well against Italy."

Asked if Beckham could be England's long-term captain, Eriksson said: "I have not talked about that. I hope it is going to be for a long time.

"For me everything is new. I do not want to make any commitments for the next two or three years. You have others who could do the captain's job but he did it last time and we go on like that."

Eriksson also revealed that Paul Scholes, who was doubtful with a stomach upset, is almost certain to start against Spain tomorrow. Eriksson said: "He returned to the squad last night and I was very pleased about that. He wanted to be involved and that is the right way to be.

"He really wants to be here. He did everything in practice this morning. He might not be 100% today but he should be tomorrow. He will be in the team tomorrow if he is OK.

But Eriksson was less forthcoming about his team or his formation. "I have the team fixed in my mind and will tell you tomorrow," he told the press.

"We tried something today, something a bit different but a way of playing 4-4-2. Very few will not play in their normal positions but I cannot give any more clues," he added.

fields.headline: Rover extends Olympic sponsorship
fields.trailText: 2.45pm: Rover has signed the first British Olympic sponsorship agreement in the run-up to the Winter Games in 2002, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Rover has signed the first British Olympic sponsorship agreement in the run-up to the Salt Lake City Winter Games in 2002 and the Athens Summer Games in 2004.

The car manufacturer has re-signed its four-year sponsorship agreement with Team GB.

It is the British Olympic Association's first commercial agreement of the new four-year Olympic cycle.

BOA sponsorship for the past four years totalled £15m and a similar figure is required for the next cycle.

The money provides services, awards and training facilities for athletes.

In Sydney, Rover funded the Gold Coast preparation camp.

Other sponsors for the 2000 games included British Airways, Lloyds TSB, Tetley Tea, Kellogg's, Adidas, Marks & Spencer and Lindeman's wine.

A spokesman for BOA said the organisation was negotiating with a number of sponsors, including some of the previous participants.

"As a non-government-funded organisation, the BOA relies upon its sponsors to support its many programmes designed to make a performance difference to our Olympic athletes," said Simon Clegg, BOA chief executive.

"We are delighted Rover has come back on board to sponsor Team GB. Its support will enable us to provide services that will help Britain's Olympic athletes continue their medal-winning ways."

fields.headline: Carnival!
fields.trailText: 1. Today's the day when a large part of the world enjoys one final blow-out before the Christian fast of Lent.
fields.body:
1. Today's the day when a large part of the world enjoys one final blow-out before the Christian fast of Lent.

2. In New Orleans they have the riotous Mardi gras and in Rio the samba-driven carnival.

3. Under our name, Shrove Tuesday, it is better known as time to eat pancakes. Sometimes with lemon juice, sometimes without.

4. The adventourous then may, on occasions, take part in a pancake race.

5. Meanwhile, in New Orleans, the authorities are hoping there will not be a repeat of the 1999 Mardi Gras when they had to arrest 360 people for indecent exposure. (You can follow the action on a webcam.)

6. Carnival is an ancient festival whose name comes from two Latin words - "carnis" and "valedico" - meaning "farewell to flesh".

7. Medieval France marked the day with plenty of wine and sex, elsewhere carnival turned the world upside down as people would dress up, eat too much and sing bawdy songs that mocked manners and authorities.

8. But the Caribbean changed it all when freed slaves took the carnival traditions of the French and Spanish settlers and added the dance and rhythms of Africa to celebrate their emancipation. In Trinidad and Tobago lie the origins of London's Notting Hill carnival.

9. Further south, in Brazil, the carnivals of Salvador de Bahia, Rio and Olinda are some of the world's biggest festivals.

10. Can't get there? Try Cologne, Quebec, Venice, or Santa Cruz de Tenerife.

fields.headline: Deckchair axes third of staff
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Deckchair.com, the travel site launched by Sir Bob Geldof, has axed a third of its staff, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Deckchair.com, the high-profile travel site launched by Sir Bob Geldof, has axed a third of its staff and is discussing merging its business with a rival travel website.

Thirteen staff have been made redundant as Deckchair aims to cut costs and link up with "another party", said Ian Neale, head of sales and development at Deckchair.

Insiders say the unnamed partner is the Online Travel Company - otcuk.com - and a merger will be announced within weeks.

Financial terms are unclear at this stage.

"It's the usual story of huge cash burn, overpaid consultants and a massive advertising spend," said one source of the job cuts and merger discussions:

Deckchair was said to have been in discussions with Lastminute.com last year about a tie-up but no deal materialised.

Deckchair is now operating a lean operation with an estimated 20 staff left running the business, down from a peak of 40 during the site's heyday.

Staff who left over the past year have not been replaced.

Deckchair was set up in April 1999.

Sir Bob, who bagged £7m from the sale of Planet 24 the previous month, got together with former Eidos executive James Page to address what was seen as a gaping hole in the travel market.

However, since the site launched, the online travel market has become increasingly saturated.

Flight companies such as easyJet and Go have successfully cut out the middleman by selling directly to consumers.

At the end of last year, United News & Media bailed out of the online travel market when it closed uTravel.co.uk, citing an uneasy competitive landscape.

fields.headline: How foot and mouth spread
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: 1 Foot and mouth outbreak at Burnside farm, Heddon-on-the-wall, Northumberland
fields.body:
1 Foot and mouth outbreak at Burnside farm, Heddon-on-the-wall, Northumberland

2 Animals at nearby Prestwick Hall farm, Ponteland, are infected, probably as the virus is carried on the wind

3 40 sheep from Prestwick Hall are among 3,500 animals sold at Hexham. The buyer is Willy Cleave, a Devon farmer

4 The sheep are shipped to Longtown market, Carlisle, which acts as a holding centre

5 The sheep are taken to Mr Cleave's Burdon farm, Highampton in Devon

6 Sheep from Highampton are taken to Bromham slaughterhouse in Wiltshire where they develop foot and mouth. Other sheep were sold to Hill farm in Llancloudy, Herefordshire, and another batch were sold at auction in Northampton

7 348 sheep sent before the foot and mouth outbreak was identified were exported from Devon to Germany via Dover. Yesterday they were destroyed as a precautionary measure

fields.headline: Beckham named as England captain
fields.trailText: 3pm Sven-Goran Eriksson has reappointed David Beckham as England captain.
fields.body:
3pm Sven-Goran Eriksson has reappointed David Beckham as England captain.

"To be the captain of a very important team is an extremely important role. I chose hiim because, first of all, he is a very good player, and I think he can grow into a leadership role.

"To be very certain though is difficult, as I have only spent a day and a half with the players."

3:03pm Eriksson says Beckham was " very happy" with the news. "I hope it will be for a long time," he added.

3:04pm Paul Scholes has returned to the England camp despite a bout of gastro-enteritis. "He completed everything in training, he should be available for selection", Eriksson says.

3:05pm Eriksson says he is "almost 100%" sure of the XI he will select against Spain, but that he has not told the players themselves yet. The team will not now be announced until tomorrow.

fields.headline: Farmer Brown suffers foot in mouth outbreak
fields.trailText: With British farmers stuck in the worst crisis for more than 30 years, and many facing the destruction of their whole way of life, they might have expected a government minister to bring them hope and reassurance.
fields.body:
With British farmers stuck in the worst crisis for more than 30 years, and many facing the destruction of their whole way of life, they might have expected a government minister to bring them hope and reassurance - perhaps even to inspire them to some kind of faith in the future.

Instead they got Nick Brown. It's hard to exaggerate just what a drizzlingly depressing fellow the agriculture minister is. If a stunned mullet could talk, it would sound like him. He is glum, depressive, dank and dreary. He is the Leonard Cohen of British politics. If I were a farmer, scarcely able to sleep through worry, wondering if I could survive the next few months, listening to the minister would make me think that perhaps the time had come to join my own animals on the pyre.

You would not imagine, to hear Mr Brown, that any human being was actually suffering. His lengthy statement contained plenty of jargon and bureaucracy about the appropriate certificates, "controlled areas", and "classical swine fever" which in a silly way made me think of those hectic ads on cable television: "Yes, classical Swine Fever. All Swine Fever's greatest hits on one CD! Not available in stores!"

His statement also contained plenty of information about the measures being taken to protect foreign farms from our disease. This is hugely important, though the thought niggles at the back of the mind: Mr Brown has always given the impression that he is more worried about what the French government wants than about what our farmers need.

There wasn't a word about what those farmers are going through. Not a single sen tence to indicate the fear and near panic so many people living on the land must be coping with now.

Instead there was a moment of fine distilled complacency. "I am grateful to consumers who, as I have requested, continued their normal pattern of buying," he said.

"As I have requested"? As the minister requires? Does he seriously imagine that shoppers get into Tesco, head for the meat counter, and ask themselves what Nick Brown wants them to do? What world is he living in?

The entire statement was in pure civil service language, Sir Humphrey without the passion. It was technical, detailed and, I have no doubt, eminently sensible. It also entirely failed to reflect the scale of the crisis or any of the human price. As an ameliorative, it was like giving an aspirin to someone with the Ebola virus.

But things got worse. Tim Yeo, the Tory spokesman, at least managed to express profound sympathy" for the farmers "facing not only loss of their livelihood, but the loss of a lifetime's work". He pointed out that the government had not even offered a debate in parliament on the topic, and said the Tories would give up some of their time tomorrow to raise the subject.

Mr Brown was outraged. "I do not welcome an urgent debate!" he huffed, showing emotion for the first time. "It will divert ministerial re sources and scarce veterinary resources!" (What? Will vets be dragged into the chamber to give their views, or inject the angrier Tories?)

Of course this line could be used about any subject at all. We couldn't debate crime or education, or the bombing of Iraq for precisely the same reason - it would divert ministers from doing what they want to do without the annoyance of consulting MPs.

Mysteriously, the Commons debates the fox hunting bill today, before it goes to the Lords. The death of a few dozen foxes requires hours of debate; the slaughter of tens of thousands of livestock must pass by on the breeze, so as not to "divert scarce ministerial resources."

fields.headline: The crisis in quotes
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Tony Blair: "We will do everything we possibly can, first of all to eradicate the disease, and then to make sure that farmers are properly compensated."
fields.body:
Tony Blair: "We will do everything we possibly can, first of all to eradicate the disease, and then to make sure that farmers are properly compensated."

Nick Brown, agriculture minister: "The government's overriding priority is the containment and eradication of this disease."

Tim Harris, Animal Transportation Association: "More animals than people travel by road every day, and more animals than people travel by aircraft every day. Sadly, unless things change, there will be more outbreaks."

Paul Cheale, Cheale Meats, Essex: "We are just getting on with it and cleaning up."

Liz Procter, Paignton Zoo: "Should this virus be brought into the zoo on footwear or the tyres of vehicles it could potentially have serious consequences for our hoofed animals."

George Thomas, Highampton farm, Devon, confirmed foot and mouth: "I spent every hour through the night worrying about the cattle on the farm ... words cannot explain it. It is devastating."

Anthony Gibson, National Farmers Union: "It is the nightmare scenario, it is about as bad as it could possibly be."

Richard Burge, Countryside Alliance: "These people need to be at home on their farms and in their communities. They have a major crisis to resolve."

fields.headline: Call for debate angers minister
fields.standfirst:
Debate 'would divert resources from frontline'

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, yesterday accused the Tories of undermining government attempts to wipe out foot and mouth disease after the Tories tabled a lengthy House of Commons debate on the issue for tomorrow.
fields.body:
Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, yesterday accused the Tories of undermining government attempts to wipe out foot and mouth disease after the Tories tabled a lengthy House of Commons debate on the issue for tomorrow.

To uproar on the Tory benches, Mr Brown said: "It will divert resources, both ministerial resources and scarce veterinary resources, from the frontline which is bearing down on this disease."

Tim Yeo, the shadow agriculture minister, infuriated Mr Brown when he announced that the Tories would devote half of tomorrow's opposition day debate to the foot and mouth crisis.

Mr Brown, who will have to take part in the debate, accused the Tories of hypocrisy for announcing the debate while pledging to help the government. "If their idea of helping is to divert resources from dealing with the disease outbreak to dealing with a parliamentary debate, including ministerial time, I'm glad they're not setting out to disrupt us," he said.

The spat between Mr Brown and Mr Yeo came as some surprise because both sides attempted to mend fences after they clashed last week on the government's initial response to the crisis.

Mr Yeo opened by offering his support for the measures. He said: "We on this side of the house, in the opposition, will give our full backing to all the measures that are needed to contain the spread of foot and mouth disease, to assist livestock farmers through the crisis, to maintain food supplies and to restore export markets."

But Mr Brown snapped when Mr Yeo criticised the government for not setting aside time for a Commons debate on the crisis. Announcing that the Tories would hold the debate in their own time, Mr Yeo asked: "Do you recognise that the heartbreaking prospect for many farmers today is not just the loss of their livelihood, but the destruction of their lives work? The risk of human tragedies under these circumstances is very real."

Eric Pickles, Tory MP for Brentwood and Ongar where the outbreak was first identified, praised the "sharp-eyed" veterinary official who had spotted the disease and prevented an even worse disaster. But Mr Pickles criticised the government for failing to update its website on the crisis on a regular basis.

Angela Smith, Labour MP for Basildon, rounded on "irresponsible" journalists who have walked across farms within exclusion zones. "The best story for a farmer is that there are no new outbreaks and that all reporters should act with the utmost responsibility," she said.

Mr Brown said that camera crews were buzzing over infected land in helicopters, possibly spreading the disease.

Gordon Prentice, Labour MP for Pendle, said he could not understand how farmers could claim that they were not aware of the signs of the disease. He said that when he visited the government website to find out what a pig with the disease looked like he found that its snout became "very, very strange indeed".

fields.headline: Ginger empire boosts SMG profits
fields.trailText:
11.45am: SMG has posted rising profits on the back of its acquisition of Chris Evans's Ginger Media Group. By Dan Milmo.
Feb 22: SMG ups stakes in Scottish Radio Holdings
fields.body:
Scotland's largest media company SMG has reported a boost in profits on the back of its acquisition of Chris Evans's Ginger radio empire.

The owner of the Grampian and Scottish ITV franchises has been busy in the radio sector over the past year.

It is now in the middle of a takeover battle for national rival Scottish Radio Holdings.

SMG said pre-tax profits for 2000 had risen 18% to £59m, with turnover climbing 25% to £300.5m.

"We continued to expand, emerging as a significant player in UK media, touching the lives of millions of viewers, listeners and readers," said SMG chairman Don Cruickshank.

Although television remains SMG's biggest earner, its also owns the Pearl & Dean cinema advertising firm and the Herald and Sunday Herald newspapers.

The Virgin Radio station it acquired through the Ginger deal contributed £33m to the group's turnover.

Mr Cruickshank added that there was no evidence of a downturn in the advertising market.

However, he said that the slowdown in the US economy and the imminent general election were making advertisers cautious.

"Overall, our businesses are performing well in uncertain market conditions and the group is in good shape.

"If economic uncertainty abates and advertising prospects are confirmed then we will make good progress in the year ahead," added Mr Cruickshank.

SMG said little about its courtship of Scottish Radio Holdings.

But it pointed out that its 24% stake in the company put it in a prime position to take advantage of consolidation in the UK radio market.

fields.headline: McFarland sacked at Cambridge
fields.trailText: Roy McFarland has been sacked as manager of Second Division Cambridge United after a poor run of results.
fields.body:
Roy McFarland has been sacked as manager of Second Division Cambridge United after a poor run of results.

In a statement issued on Tuesday, the club said it had decided at a Monday night board meeting "that Roy McFarland will no longer be in charge of first-team affairs with immediate effect."

Former Derby County and Bolton Wanderers boss McFarland took charge of Cambridge in November 1996 and they were promoted to division two in 1999. But they are currently seventh from bottom in division two after six defeats in their last seven games.

The club said it hoped to announce a new manager in time for Saturday's home game against Oldham Athletic.

fields.headline: United shelves C5 sale
fields.trailText:
2.15pm: United Business Media will not be selling its C5 stake this year, according to chief executive Clive Hollick. By Dan Milmo.
Feb 27: Tough times ahead warns United
Feb 21: United vulnerable to US downturn
fields.body:
United Business Media will not be selling its stake in Channel 5 this year, according to chief executive Clive Hollick.

The news is a blow to majority shareholder RTL, which has made no secret of its desire to buy United's 35% holding and assume full control of the group.

"The time to sell commercial TV assets was last year. Now is not a good time to sell, as commercial TV is under pressure," said Lord Hollick.

"We believe that Channel 5 will continue to make good progress over the next few years."

United transformed into a business information group last year after selling its ITV assets to Granada. But it still holds several consumer assets, including a 20% stake in the ITN news service.

The future of the Channel 5 stake has been the subject of intense speculation ever since United and RTL clashed in court late last year over a £10m film deal for the station.

RTL overturned an injunction which United had obtained against the deal.

"Our stance on the running of Channel 5 is that we felt that when commercial TV is under pressure that it was not the best moment to push the boat out in terms of programming.

"Events this year have confirmed that," said Lord Hollick.

However, Lord Hollick confirmed that the loss-making Rapture clubbing channel should be sold over the next six months.

"We have had quite a lot of expressions of interest and we expect a lot of interest in it," he added.

Feb 21: United vulnerable to US downturn

fields.headline: Players and their pages
fields.trailText: Germans aren't boring and humourless, laughs Markus Babbel
fields.body:
Germans aren't boring and humourless, laughs Markus Babbel

"This is a time for celebration. It is the first silverware that Liverpool has held for quite a while. I am very proud to have taken part in the win today that has shown our opponents that Liverpool are back, firing on all cylinders again! Let's hope it's not the last!

"We certainly are in a mood to party tonight. Along with my former Bayern Munchen teammates at Liverpool, I think we can show the Liverpool born lads how to have a good time. Germans may be considered boring and humourless but it is going to be an entertaining time tonight.

"We get good practise at the Munich beer festival (Oktoberfest) and tonight will be "Rockfest!" But although we deserve to have fun tonight, tomorrow we will be back training for our continued assault on the Premier League. We will make The Worthington Cup really Worth(ington) while!"

For more on Markus's Worthington Cup joy, click here.

Stephane Henchoz: conceding a penalty 'felt like being stabbed'

"I still find it hard to describe exactly how I feel at having won the first medal of my career. To me especially, and I'm sure to the rest of the team, the penalty we conceded in the last minute of normal time felt like being stabbed.

"I made the tackle, and I think the referee was probably right in his decision. I was about four or five yards away from the Birmingham player when I went for the second ball in our 18-yard box. I thought he was going to shoot and I tried to block his attempt, but I got there too late and he went over. When the referee pointed to the spot I couldn't believe it because we were so close to winning the game. This just wasn't happening!

"Naturally I was hoping Darren Purse would miss, but deep down I knew that was unlikely and that we'd have to start our work all over again. I just had to forget what had gone before and try to concentrate on the next 30 minutes, which I knew were going to be very tough and in fact, Birmingham made it a real struggle for us. God, it was hard out there! However, it was a pleasure to play in the Millennium Stadium yesterday, which must be one of the finest venues around. And to win there made it even more special."

Read more at Stephane Henchoz's homepage: click here.

Julian Joachim: film star

"It appears I've got a new cameo role alongside Anthony Hopkins in the new film Hannibal - now I'm just waiting for the film company to send my cut!

"I couldn't believe it when I found out I was appearing in one of the scenes because it was the first I'd heard about it. It's given me quite a taste for the acting life actually - I quite fancy myself as the next Vinnie Jones!

"To be honest I haven't seen the film yet but I'm definitely going to see it now. You never know, I could get a few offers flooding in after this. Apparently in one scene there's a close up of me on the TV in the background. Hopefully they'll make another sequel and I can star in person. You never know, they might write me in as Hannibal's sidekick or perhaps even the hero. I might even make a few quid out of it!"

For more information about what else Joachim is up to click here<.a>.

fields.headline: Saved by the whistles
fields.standfirst: After racist chanting by Hellas Verona's supporters, the club was threatened with a ban on home games. But in the clash with Bari, the fans make use of a peculiarly Italian get-out clause . . .
fields.trailText: After racist chanting by Hellas Verona's supporters, the club was threatened with a ban on home games. But in the clash with Bari, the fans make use of a peculiarly Italian get-out clause . . .
fields.body:
Verona Vergogna d'Italia ," shouts a headline - Verona Disgrace of Italy. "The city of Verona is like Alabama in the 50s," claims one journalist. "Close the Bentegodi!" insists another. The Bentegodi is Hellas Verona's stadium. The Brigate Gialloblu , our hardline fans, are in trouble again. The club has been fined 70m lire (£22,800) for a prolonged chorus of racist monkey grunts.

Here's a curious thing then: while American or German tourists explore the piazzas and palazzi of Verona in a daze of admiration, imagining themselves at the very heart of renaissance elegance and humanist civilisation, the rest of the country is dismissing the town as bigoted, workaholic and, above all, irretrievably racist. What's more, the Veronese always vote to the right and this is an election year. The knives are out.

Back in October, Verona played their first home game of the season against Udinese, who were fielding their big Ghanaian defender, Gargo. Interviewed the day before the game, this immensely talented player, black as coal, shiny as granite, newly arrived in the bel paese , claimed that he was going to make the Italians love him; he was going to eliminate racism from Italian stadiums, he said, quite simply because people would admire and love him so much for the generous and gentlemanly and humble and dedicated way he played. Needless to say, a fair dose of narcissism is to be expected from the successful sportsman. Needless to say, at Verona's Bentegodi, Gargo was mercilessly barracked every time he touched the ball. "Ooh-ooh-ooh," grunted the curva . The club was fined.

Now it has happened again with Parma's French international Thuram. Verona crashed two-nil. The curva grunted ooh-ooh. Another big fine. After the game, the club's owner, Giambattista Pastorello, made an unhappy remark suggesting that it would be difficult for him to buy a black player because of the fans. For the whole week, talk shows nationwide could do nothing but condemn racism in Verona. Yet the odd thing is that Verona has one of the highest levels of black immigration and black employment in Italy and cases of violence toward immigrants are extremely rare and getting rarer. Only a stone's throw from the stadium, the city's circular road is thickly patrolled by black prostitutes and their pimps. They are not harassed. This isn't even London in the 70s, never mind Alabama.

"If I can shout vaffanculo at a Juventino, and terrone di merda at a Neapolitan," writes a fan on the club's internet chat line, "why can't I shout ooh-ooh at Thuram? I only want to put him off."

It's fascinating that there are people who really cannot see the difference between these insults. Another contributor writes: "How the hell can they call me racist, Dio povero , I work next to a guy from Vicenza and even get on with him! Forget politics, let's play, fuck, eat and Forza magica Verona! "

But this is no time for joking. The Federcalcio has decided new rules for the second half of the season. As of February 11 racist chants will not just be fined; the stadium will be banned.

"The truth is," someone else writes into cyberspace, "they don't want us to stop the monkey grunts. They love calling Verona racist. They want to close the Bentegodi. We lose home advantage and crash into Serie B."

No one is more ready than the Italian to imagine a conspiracy. I've lived here long enough to share this guy's suspicions. We're being auditioned for scapegoat.

The make or break game is against Bari. Last week we lost away at Perugia. That's three defeats in a row. We are in deep trouble, third from bottom. Four clubs go down. And now there's the threat of a stadium ban too. As we file up to be frisked inside the turnstiles, someone hands us a leaflet: "CIVILISED VERONA SHOUTS: 'FORZA HELLAS', NO TO RACISM, NO TO THE DEMONISATION OF OUR TOWN."

More nervous than ever, my son and I find a couple of seats. Once, when he was very young, I had to forbid him from joining in racist chants. Now he is their fiercest opponent. My own feeling about the chants, though, is that in a curious way they have served a purpose. They doubtless gave voice to a certain intolerance to immigration that many people felt. At the same time, precisely by expressing it, they made most people realise that such behaviour wasn't on, that it is unacceptable to taunt a man because he is black. If an immigrant is attacked at night in a side street, there is little public shame and real damage. But when intolerance is amplified in the huge theatre of the stadium, everyone is involved, even if no one is physically hurt. We know there's a problem; we feel it's our business.

So what's going to happen today? Bari are bottom of the table. They are even more desperate than we are. And they're fielding two black players. Out they come on to the pitch. Both teams are wearing yellow tops that say: Blood has no colour. Red rag to a bull for the hooligans, I fear. The ritual photos are taken. The curva puts on its usual fantastic display of white confetti, blue and yellow smoke bombs. The politically correct tops come off. The whistle blows. The singing swells, "Gialloblu la mia unica fede" , yellow-blue my only faith. And then the Nigerian Enynnaya touches the ball.

But here we have to stop a moment and look at that new regulation again. For the distinguishing feature of all Italian regulations is that they are complicated. They are complicated in order to be lenient, to provide endless scope for defence and discussion. If the racist chants are uncontested, the regulation says, then the club will be responsible, the stadium banned. But if the chants are contested and covered by "normal" fans, then there is no penalty. How interesting!

Enynnaya carries the ball a few yards. The diehards begin their ooh-ooh's. More than racism, one suspects a delirium of transgression. Immediately, the rest of the curva begins to whistle. The ooh's are covered.

As soon as the fans have discovered this new game, it happens every time the Nigerian touches the ball. Ooh-ooh, whistle whistle. Deafening. Since all the noise comes from the heart of the curva , not the rest of the stadium, one begins to suspect a jolly complicity between the two groups, a massive irony at the expense of good society: they are having their cake and eating it. It's theatre. Then the referee gives Bari a penalty. Our goalkeeper has pulled down Osmanovski. The keeper is sent off. The Russian scores from the spot. Verona go into the dressing room one-nil down. All the people around me, friends of old now, are disgusted. There is only one hope: bring on lo zingaro .

Lo zingaro , the Gypsy, is Mutu, the Romanian star who gave Neville hell in the European championships. He often seems lazy and capricious, but the guy can occasionally make the difference. Just 10 minutes into the second half he fights off a storm of shoves and kicks then sends the keeper the wrong way to boot. Rete! Goal!

And at that moment the curva discovers that to yell Mutu, Moo-too, sounds almost exactly like yelling ooh-ooh. It doesn't even need to be covered by whistles. They are still going at it in a triumph of mockery when, five minutes later, the Romanian disturbs Bari's keeper to set up Mauro Camoranesi (Argentinian, Italian passport) to tap in the second. What a mixed up world it is!

Enynnaya is substituted in an absolute gale of whistles. Mutu is celebrated again as he miraculously sneaks in Verona's third. Moo-too! And in the dying moments the Egyptian Said gets one back for Bari and becomes the first Arab ever to score in Italy's Serie A. What a day for racial tolerance! What a day for Hellas Verona!

 Tim Parks is writing a book about following Hellas Verona. A Season with Verona will be published by Secker & Warburg in March 2002. His website is at www.timparks.com

fields.headline: 'Upmarket' ITV gets thumbs-up from advertisers
fields.trailText:
2.15pm update: Advertising agencies have welcomed research that shows ITV is attracting more upmarket viewers than BBC1, writes Claire Cozens.

Feb 27: ITV goes upmarket
fields.body:
Advertising agencies today gave an unqualified welcome to new research that shows ITV is attracting younger, more upmarket viewers than BBC1 for the first time in its history.

And most believe the broadcaster has enough new programming up its sleeve to sustain the trend during the next 12 months.

David Peters, broadcast planning director at media buying agency Carat, said the news was highly significant.

"Historically, young ABC1 audiences have been the Holy Grail for ITV," he said.

"They are acutely aware that those audiences will attract the most money from advertisers.

"The difficulty is to balance that with retaining mass-market appeal, and that's what they've managed to do with programmes like Who Wants to be a Millionaire? and Popstars. And they've got Survivor coming in the summer, which should help them to sustain that."

Mark Collins, broadcast director at MediaCom TMB, described the figures as "very good news for advertisers".

"The criticism that people have levelled at ITV for some time is that they've gone for the lowest common denominator," he said.

"This shows they have addressed that. Popstars has gone a long way to helping with the 16-34 audiences. Over time interest in that will decline but I think they've got things in their back pocket to retain those audiences."

Neil Johnston, TV buying director at OMD UK, said ITV's beefed up sports coverage would help it continue to attract younger viewers during the summer.

"ITV has achieved its younger and more professional audience by introducing more sport - there's the Champions League and Formula One there already, and the Premier League coming this year," he said.

"Popstars has become must-see TV and Survivor, the hugely successful US reality TV show, is coming to ITV in the summer."

But Mr Johnston warned that the introduction of a fourth episode of EastEnders on BBC1 could reverse the trend.

"The problem for ITV is that the BBC is not standing still - they're changing as well," he said.

"EastEnders attracts 14m viewers which is roughly the same number as Coronation Street but it's a younger and more upmarket audience. That's what ITV needs to worry about now."

Commercial broadcasters are being urged to target a younger, more upmarket audience because the profile of TV advertisers is changing.

"Traditionally the TV market was dominated by the big FMCG companies who targeted older, more downmarket viewers," said Mr Johnston.

"But they are being replaced by the financial services and computer companies, who want to target younger, more upmarket viewers."

webTitle: Arrests rack up tension ahead of execution

fields.headline: Arrests rack up tension ahead of execution
fields.trailText: A police crackdown on members of the SSP comes ahead of the hanging of one of their number, reports Rory McCarthy from Islamabad
fields.body:
Police in Pakistan have arrested at least 900 members of a radical Sunni Muslim group ahead of next week's execution of a man convicted of the murder of an Iranian diplomat a decade ago.

Those arrested are all members of Sipah-i-Sahaba Pakistan (SSP), or the Guardians of the Friends of the Prophet, a feared extremist group which has been responsible for the murders of hundreds of Shia Muslims.

Most of Pakistan's 140m people are Sunni Muslims, but Shias make up a significant 20% minority. Violent sectarian clashes between extremists from the two groups have become more frequent in recent months.

Haq Nawaz Jhangvi, an SSP member, was convicted of murdering Sadiq Sanji, the director of the Iranian cultural centre, in Lahore in December 1990. Jhangvi, who is being held in a jail in Mianwali, in Punjab province, lost his final appeal earlier this year and is sentenced to hang at dawn on Wednesday.

Police are now patrolling around the jail in armoured personnel carriers and the local government has banned any demonstrations or large gatherings.

Leaders of the extremist group have gone into hiding but have warned they will protest against the execution.

"We will agitate if the execution is not stopped," said Maulana Mujeeb-ur-Rehman Inqalabi, a spokesman for SSP. "These detentions are an attempt to sabotage peace and create anarchy."

The group has strong connections with Afghanistan's Taliban militia, who, like SSP members, studied in religious schools in Pakistan.

In 1998, at the time of another police crackdown, SSP leaders fled to Kabul for protection. Many SSP militants have trained at camps in Khost, in southern Afghanistan, run by the Saudi terrorist Osama bin Laden.

The camps were targeted by a US missile strike in 1998 in response to the bombings of two US embassies in East Africa in which 224 people were killed. Bin Laden has been charged with masterminding the bombings.

Police have said the arrests followed several sectarian killings in recent weeks but the interior minister, Moinuddin Haider, is clearly trying to clean up Pakistan's reputation for violence.

Earlier this month he banned fund raising by militant groups fighting against the Indian army in Kashmir. He has also promised to tackle sectarian violence.

"Over the years many people have been killed in the name of sects and we cannot allow this to continue," Gen Haider said this week.

In a rare visit to Afghanistan this month, Gen Haider presented a list of names of at least 60 Pakistanis wanted for sectarian attacks who were believed to be hiding in Afghanistan.

Top of the list is Muhammad Riaz Basra, a former SSP member who left to found his own militant group, Lashkar-e-Jhangvi. Basra was also convicted of murder in the attack on the Iranian diplomat in 1990 but he escaped from police custody.

Basra is also suspect of attempting to assassinate Nawaz Sharif, the then prime minister, in January 1999, when a bridge near Mr Sharif's Lahore home was blown up shortly before the prime minister was due to drive across.

webTitle: Rural alliance calls off march on London

fields.headline: Rural alliance calls off march on London
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The foot and mouth crisis claimed a further, unexpected, victim yesterday when the pro-hunting Countryside Alliance postponed its march on the capital "until at least early May."
fields.body:
The foot and mouth crisis claimed a further, unexpected, victim yesterday when the pro-hunting Countryside Alliance postponed its march on the capital "until at least early May."

Up to half a million people had been due to descend on London on March 18 to express their concerns about a raft of countryside measures - not least their opposition to government plans to ban hunting.

But yesterday, the alliance withdrew amid fears that the disease could be spread by farmers meeting one another - and in recognition of the more pressing concerns of Britain's stricken farming community.

Announcing the decision, the alliance's chief executive, Richard Burge, said its prime concern had been "to act properly and responsibly in the interests of Britain's farmers as well as our own members and supporters."

The decision, which followed the outbreaks in Devon, was with the support of the leading farming bodies, the NFU, Farmers' Union of Wales and the Ulster Farmers' Association. A new date would be set after weighing up the severity of the outbreak and the government's response to it, Mr Burge added.

While more than 200,000 people had registered to go on the march, many realised they could not come, he added. "There was a genuine feeling that people were starting to think: 'I can't leave my farm'. These people need to be at home on their farms and in their communities not tramping the streets at this point. I think we have a real crisis on our hands and the feeling is it would be wrong to call people to London when they have so much on," he said.

He warned that whenever the march took place, it would be massive. Some 300,000 people gathered before the previous large-scale demonstration in 1998, but after the fuel crisis and the potential ban on hunting as many as half a million had been expected for Britain's biggest peace-time demonstration.

fields.headline: Judge lifts picture ban on Dando suspect
fields.trailText: 11.45am: The first pictures of the man accused of murdering BBC presenter Jill Dando were released today, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The first pictures of the man accused of murdering BBC presenter Jill Dando were released today following a ruling by the judge presiding over the trial of defendant Barry George.

Mr Justice Gage overturned a previous ban on any picture or artist's impression being published when he sat to hear a second day of legal submissions at the Old Bailey.

The submissions are expected to last at least until tomorrow before a jury may be sworn in for what is expected to be one of the most high-profile murder trials of recent years.

Mr George, 40, from Fulham, west London, has denied murdering 37-year-old Miss Dando on the doorstep of her home in Fulham, on April 26, 1999.

Wearing a blue jumper and blue shirt with yellow tie and carrying a bible, he sat in dock flanked by prison officers.

Miss Dando's fiance, gynaecologist Alan Farthing, and BBC Crimewatch presenter Nick Ross were among those at the court. Sitting nearby was George's sister, Michelle Diskin.

Prosecuting is senior Treasury counsel Orlando Pownall, while high-profile barrister Michael Mansfield QC, is defending George.

Sky News was first to broadcast pictures of the man charged with the murder of the BBC presenter with TV footage and a still of Mr George.

The trial has been so over-subscribed by the media that tickets were being issued yesterday for the first day of the trial.

Yesterday 50 reporters were present to hear legal arguments presented to the judge, while others were forced to wait outside.

The murder of Ms Dando, a former BBC Crimewatch presenter and journalist, in Fulham in 1999, attracted huge publicity.

fields.headline: BBC1 current affairs show off to solid start
fields.trailText: 1pm TV overnights: BBC1 current affairs show Kenyon Confronts made a respectable debut last night, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BBC1's great white current affairs hope, Kenyon Confronts, made a respectable debut last night, despite losing heavily to Coronation Street in the ratings.

The BBC1 show drew 5.2m viewers and a 21% audience share, while ITV opposition Coronation Street pulled in a whopping 14.1m, according to unofficial overnights.

But BBC1 schedulers will have been pleased the first instalment of Kenyon Confronts, in which journalist Paul Kenyon investigated the illegal trade in bogus marriages to evade immigration laws, was the best performing show in the 7.30pm slot against ITV's flagship soap so far this year.

In seven previous outings at that time, Watchdog Healthcheck has averaged 4.6m viewers and an 18% audience share.

Elsewhere last night new BBC2 sitcom Two Pints of Lager and a Packet of Crisps, scripted by newcomer Susan Nickson, opened promisingly in the channel's new Monday Comedy Night line-up from 9.30pm.

Two Pints took 2.8m and an 11% share against Channel 4 documentary Nazi Women, which attracted 2.2m.

In the closely fought Monday night 8.30pm slot, ITV's New You've Been Framed got the better of The Weakest Link on BBC1.

New You've Been Framed had 8.5m and a 33% share, compared with 7.8m for Anne Robinson-hosted quiz show.

The Weakest Link had won the slot on the previous two Mondays.

From 9.10pm on BBC1 cop drama In Deep, starring Nick Berry and Stephen Tompkinson as undercover police officers, slipped back against Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? compared with its debut last week.

The first instalment of another In Deep two-parter had 6.8m, after the series opened with 7.4m last Monday.

From 10.35pm BBC1's 90-minute film Bafta highlights - the awards ceremony was broadcast live on Sky One on Sunday night - had 2.9m and a 25% share.

fields.headline: Mancini new Fiorentina coach - probably
fields.trailText: Roberto Mancini could be the new coach of Fiorentina. Then again he might not. Thanks to the complicated nature of Italian football, nobody quite knows this afternoon what role the 36-year-old will take with the club, despite being announced as the successor to Fatih Terim this morning.
fields.body:
Roberto Mancini could be the new coach of Fiorentina. Then again he might not. Thanks to the complicated nature of Italian football, nobody quite knows this afternoon what role the 36-year-old will take with the club, despite being announced as the successor to Fatih Terim this morning.

"From Thursday, Mancini will be in Florence to train Fiorentina with Luciano Chiarugi who has been promoted from the youth-team coach to the first-team squad," said vice-president Mario Sconcerti this morning.

But, because Italian football prevents a manager from being registered with two clubs in a season - Mancini was Sven-Goran Eriksson's understudy at Lazio - not to mention the fact that Mancini does not possess a coaching qualification, the club have been forced to change their tune this afternoon.

"At the moment Mancini does not have a contract at the club," a spokesman said, "but we might be in a position to annouce something later today."

The Viola are expected to get around the problem by naming Chiarugi as coach, allowing Mancini to work behind the scenes, before taking charge officially next season.

Mancini, who made his name as a player in the successful Sampdoria side of the late 1980s and early 1990s, has little coaching experience but has been eager to make the transition to the bench since he retired as a player.

He had been expected to take on a coaching role with Lazio after the Eriksson's resignation but instead opted for a short playing spell with Peter Taylor's Leicester City.

webTitle: Film icons blamed for teenage smoking

fields.headline: Film icons blamed for teenage smoking
fields.trailText: Film stars such as Leonardo DiCaprio, Sharon Stone and John Travolta who regularly smoke on screen are influencing young people to take up cigarettes, according to a study.
fields.body:
Film stars such as Leonardo DiCaprio, Sharon Stone and John Travolta who regularly smoke on screen are influencing young people to take up cigarettes, according to a study.

Psychologists from the United States believe they have concrete evidence that young fans are swayed by the image of their idol with a cigarette between their fingers.

While they accept there are limitations to their study, Jennifer Tickle and her colleagues from New Hampshire said their research found a surprisingly strong link between use by movie stars of tobacco and higher levels of smoking in the teenagers who admire them.

On the strength of the findings, the smoking pressure group Action on Smoking and Health (Ash) is asking the British Board of Film Classification not to give less than a 15 certificate to a film showing teen idols smoking.

Clive Bates, director of Ash, said: "We don't want to censor directors and actors by banning smoking in films by law, but we do call on them to think about harm they are doing.

"Hollywood megastars can find the best support in the world to stop smoking if they want, but for young fans the influence of their favourite actors could be the start of a lifetime struggle with nicotine addiction."

The questionnaire, in the medical journal Tobacco Control published today, featured 632 students, aged between 10 and 19, from five rural New England schools. They were asked about their tobacco use and also the name of their favourite film star. The psychologists then analysed the smoking patterns in recent films of the 43 most popular stars. They found that 65% smoked on screen at least once and 42% portrayed smoking as an essential character trait in one or more films. Three film stars - Leonardo DiCaprio, Sharon Stone and John Travolta - smoked in three or more films.

They found that those teenagers who named a favourite film star who had smoked on screen were more likely to smoke or say they were inclined to smoke. And the more their film idol smoked on screen, the higher the chance that the young person would be a smoker.

"This research shows a clear relation between on-screen tobacco use by movie stars and higher levels of smoking uptake in the adolescents who admire them," said the researchers. They added that there was no evidence that teenagers who already smoked were more interested in the characters who smoked in the films they watched.

"Instead the association between star smoking and attitudes that predict smoking (susceptibility) was even stronger among never smokers, suggesting that the influence of movie star smoking begins before experimentation with cigarettes. We believe this evidence strongly suggests that media portrayals of tobacco use by popular movie stars contribute to adolescent smoking."

They accept that adolescents may admire film stars who smoke because it fits their pre-existing concept of "cool" behaviour.

The results of the study, said the authors, "contribute to a growing body of evidence identifying media exposure to smoking as a major contributing factor in adolescent smoking uptake."
