fields.headline: e-district fires chief executive
fields.trailText:
12.45pm: Online entertainment group e-district has fired its chief executive. By Dan Milmo.
Feb 26: The perils of playing around in traffic
fields.body:
Online entertainment group e-district.net has fired its chief executive after last week's revelation that revenue and registered user figures were "substantially overstated."

The company today confirmed that Steven Laitman had been booted out, days after it began proceedings against him for damages.

"Together with its external advisers, the board has been investigating the facts that have recently come to light and will announce the preliminary results of that investigation as soon as the initial stages are complete," said e-district.

e-district owns the LeisureDistrict.net website and interactive TV channel, offering online games and chat rooms.

The company reiterated that no funds have been taken from the company.

But it has not ruled out the possibility that revenue and user figures were overstated for the whole of last year.

The outcome of the investigation into e-district will determine the future of a company with just £12m left in the bank and 40 staff.

Related story

fields.headline: The day's news, comment and analysis
fields.trailText: Lots of health and social care news today as well as an update on the latest wrangle between the government and Ken Livingstone's office. Don't forget to keep your eye on SocietyGuardian.co.uk to be completely up to date with the public and voluntary sector news.
fields.body:
Lots of health and social care news today as well as an update on the latest wrangle between the government and Ken Livingstone's office. Don't forget to keep your eye on SocietyGuardian.co.uk to be completely up to date with the public and voluntary sector news.

News: Ministers to boost organ donation

The government wants to double the number of people carrying organ donor cards. Ministers are today hosting a "summit" meeting on how to boost the organ donation system, in the wake of the Alder Hey scandal.

http://www.societytheguardian.com

Read our big issue report on the Alder Hey organs scandal

http://www.societytheguardian.com/alderhey

Careers: Call to review women's pay

The government will today be challenged to review women's pay in the public sector as a hard-hitting report finds that Britain's gender pay gap is the worst in the European Union.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/careers

Regeneration: Resorts seek bucket loads of aid

England's seaside resorts are in danger of falling into terminal decline without financial support.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/regeneration

Social care: Parents 'sacked over tax credit'

One of the government's weapons to tackle child poverty is backfiring against many needy parents.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/childreninpoverty

More social care news: Warning over care trust plans

Social care experts are warning the government that social inclusion is under threat from NHS care trust proposals, which have had their second reading in the House of Lords.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/healthandsocialcarebill

Health: Kennedy plans tax boost for NHS

The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, has called for a new 50p in the pound upper tax rate to pay for an increase in health spending.

More health news: BMA slams government for family doctors 'in crisis'

Low morale and chronic staff shortages have plunged family doctors into 'crisis', the British Medical Association has warned.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/health

Local government: Blair backs chancellor despite tube chief's ultimatum

Tony Blair last night closed ranks with John Prescott and Gordon Brown in their determination to force the London mayor, Ken Livingstone, and his transport commissioner, Bob Kiley, to "knuckle down".

fields.headline: 'He belts hell out of everything he can reach'
fields.standfirst: Sir Neville Cardus, "Cricketer" on the Manchester Guardian from the 1920s, wrote these reflections on Bradman's career in the early 1960s. Sir Neville remained the Guardian's chief music critic, and an occasional contributor on cricket, until his death in 1975.
fields.trailText: At Adelaide, at close of play on a hot day on which Donald Bradman amassed 212, I asked Bill Voce, the Nottinghamshire and England fast left-handed bowler: "What's the best ball to bowl at 'the Don'?" Out of his heart, Bill replied: "There's no ruddy best ball to bowl at him."
fields.body:
At Adelaide, at close of play on a hot day on which Donald Bradman amassed 212, I asked Bill Voce, the Nottinghamshire and England fast left-handed bowler: "What's the best ball to bowl at 'the Don'?" Out of his heart, Bill replied: "There's no ruddy best ball to bowl at him."

Bradman scored a century on his first appearance in first-class cricket. One of the opposing bowlers, a famous Australian captain, was asked after his baptism of Bradman: "What's this new young cove like?" "He belts hell out of everything he can reach," was the reply, which, I think, can be taken as the most eloquent of all ways of describing Bradman's batting. He was a killer of all kind of bowling, given a good pitch to play on.

A splendid South African bowler told me that, at Adelaide, Bradman hit him for three fours in one of his first overs, the ball still new. His captain thereupon asked: "What's the matter?" The bowler answered: "Well, if you really want to know, he's just hit for hellfire fours three of the best balls I've ever bowled in my life."

It is a familiar and banal criticism of Bradman that he was mechanical, an adding machine. True, he was not a conventional stylist, all curves and ornamental. But it was exciting to watch, exacting to nerves and imagination to see him gather his energy at the last second and square up to a rising fast ball, then hook it to the boundary with a crack, dispersing the pigeons.

Against the terrifically fast leg-side attack of Larwood, in the Australian rubber of 1932-33, he hit fours to the offside, where the field was more or less uncovered. Larwood had six men at least on the on-side, so Bradman leapt to that side, and actually drove or cut to the off. Larwood expressed his admiration of this daring counter-attack. "Marvellous. He played tennis strokes at me."

Like all great batsmen, Bradman made his strokes very late. He didn't move at all, after he had taken his stance, until the ball was on him. Then, by sudden and superbly concentrated dynamics, the brilliant technique shot forth its devastation. He made strokes which you would swear were entirely his own, not copybook strokes, not strokes out of cricket's gospel, but governed by his instinctive logic.

Few batsmen have equalled Bradman's ability to hit from the bat's middle. If the bat seemed to come to the line of the ball not straight, it was so timed and guided that, at the moment of contact, the willow's strong centre was the propelling point. Even if he edged a ball, as at the beginning of an innings he might (once in a blue moon), he would use the edge's centre.

He wasted no energy. After he had demolished Larwood, Geary, Tate and Richard Tyldesley at Headingley in 1930 (304 not out in a day), he came from the field cool and neat, as though fresh from the bathroom. I asked Dick Tyldesley that evening to give me his opinion of Bradman. His answer was honest and final: "'E's no ruddy use to me."

In the 1930 England v Australia rubber, Bradman's first tour of England, he scored 8, 131, 254, 1, 334, 14 and 232. In 1934, again at Headingley, he scored 304. The Australian innings on this occasion began badly, 39 for three at close of play on the first day. That evening, Bradman went to bed early, saying that tomorrow he'd need to get 200 at least. I reminded him that, in his last Test innings at Leeds, he had scored 334. "The law of averages," I said, "is against your pulling off another vast score tomorrow." "I don't believe in any law of averages," he gently retorted.

It is argued that Bradman seldom mastered a sticky wicket. But Hedley Verity, a great left-handed spinner on a sticky wicket, assured me that, "if he had tried", the Don could have coped in any circumstances. True, at Lord's in 1934 he made no obvious effort to play Verity with any patience on a turning pitch. Bradman held obtuse views about sticky wickets, arguing that they reduced science and skill to nonsense.

Certainly the wickets in Australia in Bradman's time would change from billiard tables to rearing and spinning terrors, after rain and sun. It wasn't fair for a team to be trapped this way, having bowled the day before on a smooth, fast, grassless, batsmen's paradise. Bradman did much towards the covering of wickets in Australia, though I doubt if his propaganda in this cause went so far as to persuade himself to demonstrate of set purpose that even he couldn't bat on them.

He was a shrewd, undemonstrative captain on the field. And, in his early years, his fielding on the boundary was swift and sure, with straight and rapid returns. He had never, or seldom, seen a first-class match until he was 12 years old. He was not coached, so was free to give play to his inborn talent. He was intelligent, had a good head, with a quiet but persuasive personality.

For all the ruthlessness of his batsmanship, and its killing power, there was brain governing his every movement of quick feet. He seldom reacted forward. He played back off the right foot, or drove from a panther leap on the ball. Concentration and organisation - here was his secret, plus, of course, rare gifts from nature. Every ball he received was his first ball, to be played as it deserved to be played.

No cricketer since WG Grace has shared Bradman's sway over the public. He packed cricket grounds everywhere. Day by day he was under an obligation, during a long tour in England, to play. County treasurers drooped if he didn't play. I firmly believe that, throughout his career, most opposing bowlers would have heartily supported any legal means whereby before a match Bradman could have been bought off, so to say, or given 100 runs - on condition that he didn't bat.

webTitle: In brief: life imitates art as Zeta-Jones acts the diva

fields.headline: Life imitates art as Zeta-Jones acts the diva
fields.standfirst: Plus: Hollywood's aging bad boys play house; Lopez and Lewis team up for hard-hitting drama
fields.trailText: Plus: Hollywood's aging bad boys play house; Lopez and Lewis team up for hard-hitting drama
fields.body:
 The latest copy of Heat magazine reports "problems" between Julia Roberts and Catherine Zeta-Jones on the set of their latest film, American Sweethearts. The troubles allegedly started between the A-list pair before filming even began when Zeta-Jones became resentful that Roberts had been cast in the role of Tess Ocean in Steven Soderbergh's remake of Ocean's Eleven, a role she desperately wanted. Then Jones found out that her £9m (£6.22m) pay packet for the film was considerably smaller than Roberts' $20m (£13.83m) and the rift deepened when the fiery Welsh actress discovered that Julia's trailer was bigger than hers, even though she had advanced the argument that she had to accommodate her baby, Dylan, and a nanny. In an uncanny case of life imitating art, Catherine plays a movie diva in the film, while Roberts plays her put-upon assistant.

 Two of Hollywood's oldest hellraisers, Marlon Brando and Jack Nicholson have become housemates after Nicholson broke up with long term partner Rebecca Broussard. The veteran actors both own houses in the exclusive hilltop Mulholland Drive district of Los Angeles and it seemed logical that Nicholson, who has two children with Broussard, should move in with his old pal. Things look set to get tough for the 62-year-old actor, however, as American press reports suggest that Broussard is preparing a court action to ensure that she wins some of Nicholson's multi-million-dollar fortune, after his name was linked to Twin Peaks star Lara Flynn Boyle.

 Try our Hollywood bad boys quiz.

 Jennifer Lopez and Juliette Lewis are to star in a thriller about abused women, according to ananova this afternoon. The film, entitled Enough, will be directed by Michael Apted, who was responsible for the last James Bond outing, The World Is Not Enough. Lopez will play a woman who flees her abusive husband, while Lewis is set to play a waitress who is also a victim of domestic abuse. The film, which is due to start shooting in March, should be in UK cinemas early in 2002.

fields.headline: Foot and mouth hits tourism
fields.trailText:
12.30pm: England's tourist industry is being hit by the foot and mouth crisis, reports Julia Day.
Feb 26: Foot and mouth strikes C4
Feb 23: Agency steps up food safety publicity
fields.body:
England's tourism industry is being hit hard by the foot and mouth crisis as holidaymakers cancel bookings.

Rural hotel owners predict they may be forced out of business if the crisis continues into the busy Easter season.

The English Tourism Council, which looks after domestic tourism within the country, believes the disease could be potentially disastrous for tourism.

"The effect of the foot and mouth crisis could be far-reaching if it persists until Easter," an ETC spokeswoman said.

"Easter is a very important time. The tourism season starts then. Visits to the countryside and self-catering holidays could be a problem," she said.

A spokesman for Cumbria Tourist Board said: "The disease is having a big effect on the industry. We have a 12-month tourist season here based around walking.

"People are now cancelling their holidays and hotels are losing a significant amount of business," he said.

"We have no one here at the moment when all six self-catering cottages would usually be full," said Howard Christie, owner of Cumbrian self-catering business the Wasdale Head Inn.

"Lots of places are the same," he added.

"Because the fells are closed everyone has cancelled their holidays. From yesterday to March 3 we have lost £3,600.

"If I thought this would continue for six months I'd pack up and leave now," he added.

"We are contemplating closure. Lots of small business could go under."

The South West Tourist Board covers a £6bn-a-year industry, including one of the centres of the outbreak, Devon.

SWTB head of operations Simon Bradley said the area's tourist industry was seeking legal and financial support to help it through the crisis.

He is calling on the government to assist.

"This comes on top of the fuel crisis and the strong pound against the Euro, and is a big worry if it continues.

"We need real support for farming tourism.vIn rural areas tourism is immensely important because farms have diversified and now rely on the supplementary income," he said.

The British Tourist Authority, responsible for promoting UK tourism abroad, is reassuring visitors that the UK is still a safe destination to visit.

"We are monitoring enquiries to our overseas offices and telling callers that their travel plans may be affected," said a BTA spokesman.

"We are also asking them to respect any restrictions or hygiene measures that are being imposed."

fields.headline: WPP ends search for chairman
fields.trailText: 12pm: Philip Lader, outgoing US ambassador to the UK, is to head the world's biggest advertising group, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
WPP, the world's biggest advertising group, has ended its search for a chairman with the appointment of Philip Lader, the outgoing US ambassador to the UK.

The hiring of the South Carolina businessman, a close friend of Bill Clinton, is being seen as a coup for WPP founder and chief executive Sir Martin Sorrell.

Mr Lader is a commercial and political heavyweight, whose experience of working in both the US and the UK makes him ideal for the job.

The search for a new chairman began last year after shareholders called for the incumbent, Hamish Maxwell, who is in his mid-70s, to step down.

Sir Martin's original choice for the job is believed to have been Sir Christopher Lewington, chairman of the engineering group TI and a board member of Young & Rubicam, the advertising agency owned by WPP.

But the choice was abandoned after Sir Christopher attracted criticism for drawing a high salary despite a slump in TI's share price.

Mr Lader takes the title of non-executive chairman and will divide his time between the UK and the US, where many of WPP's biggest clients are based.

Before entering government service, Mr Lader was executive vice-president of the late Sir James Goldsmith's US holdings.

Before that he was president of the Sea Pines Company, a resort developer.

WPP owns several of advertising's biggest brands, including Ogilvy & Mather, J Walter Thompson and Young & Rubicam.

webTitle: Queueing up to make superhero movies

fields.headline: The future's bright - the future's green
fields.standfirst: Hollywood's hottest directors are queueing up to make superhero movies.  Danny Leigh reports
fields.trailText: Hollywood's hottest directors are queueing up to make superhero movies. Danny Leigh reports
fields.body:
With its penchant for remakes, franchises and bankrupt, perfunctory sequels (did someone say Hannibal?), Hollywood has never been big on surprises. So it will come as no surprise to learn that - in the wake of last year's smash hit X-Men - there are plans to make at least three more movies devoted to comic- book superheroes.

This time, however, things may turn out rather smarter than usual, thanks to the nature of those charged with undertaking the projects. Each is a maverick talent, and each has been drawn to tales of genetically modified derring-do. Sam Raimi, one-time poster-boy of cult-horror fans, is already preparing a version of Spider-Man, due for release next year. The Hulk, shorn of his "Incredible" prefix but still deeply crabby, looks likely to be brought to the screen by Ang Lee, the master craftsman behind Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon. And the moribund Batman series is set to be revived by Brooklyn wunderkind Darren Aronofsky, director of the harrowing Requiem For a Dream.

Implausible? Nostalgia is partly to blame. Raimi, Lee and Aronofsky were all marked by the last great comic-adaptation boom (1978 to 1983) which saw the definitive Superman and its two sequels; the spin-off Supergirl, and a rash of tributes to, among others, Captain America and the still-Incredible Hulk.

Back then, however, the directors behind comic-book movies were quite different, with the hipsters of the day (Martin Scorsese, John Cassavetes, Michael Cimino) playing no part. Instead, a typical hiring was Richard Donner, a fortysomething TV veteran who had recently struck gold with satanic hokum The Omen; he got to direct Superman in 1978. At best, these film-makers were accomplished journeymen; sometimes, though, they barely appeared to know which end of the camera to point at the actors.

Two decades on, with comics widely considered to be cultural totems, and the lines between art-house and multiplex becoming blurred, the commercial and creative landscapes look very different. All of which surely increases the prospect of finding a hint of subversion in among the Spandex. You need only to glance back to Bryan Singer's X-Men to see a good example of a blockbuster that fuses high-octane action with a streak of cerebral scepticism. More imaginative than Gladiator, more probing than Traffic, and a good deal more satisfying than Erin Brockovich, it was perhaps the most intelligent mainstream movie of 2000. And one, moreover, that gave Singer's career a vital boost after the botched adaptation of Stephen King's Apt Pupil (in much the same way, Tim Burton's baroque Batman of 1989 elevated him from fringe weirdo to A-list auteur). A successful superhero yarn can take a thriving director to another level; so Aronofsky can look forward to joining the elite if he rescues a valuable franchise that has been run into the ground by the cheap hackery of Joel Schumacher, the director of Batman Forever and Batman & Robin .

The other incentive for a director is the chance to mine the story-telling potential of the superhero's fixations: vengeance, self-doubt and the onerous duties of heroism. This will all be pure thematic cat-nip to the likes of Raimi, whose maturation from the morbid frolics of the Evil Dead to A Simple Plan, and the forthcoming The Gift, has revealed a director who is never happier than when knee- deep in morality and melodrama.

For Aronofsky, taking Frank Miller's Batman: Year One to the big screen offers the chance to bring the unforgiving steel of Requiem For a Dream to a far wider audience. On the page, Miller's rain-soaked Gotham City, run by a cabal of dirty cops and dirtier politicians, already has less to do with high camp than the scowling LA Confidential or the pitiless Seven. Aronofsky is likely to take those reference points and increase the darkness, delivering a brutal exposition of the caped crusader's origins set against a vision of Gotham/New York as Miller's "stone rats'-maze".

With his knack for marrying the mundane and the nightmarishly surreal, Aronofsky seems an ideal choice for depicting a world in which the modus operandi of heroes is often indistinguishable from that of villains, and where the innocent suffer either way. Once again, you can't help thinking of X-Men, in which Singer never seemed wholly convinced that the real bogeyman wasn't mankind itself. Our superheroes, it seems, come just as beset by conflicts as the rest of us.

But, if the connection between Aronofsky and his subject seems obvious, the allure of the Hulk's irradiated tantrums for Ang Lee appears less clear-cut - until you recall just how unlikely the idea of such a subtle director making a martial-arts movie once sounded, and how sublime the results turned out. Indeed, many of the motifs of Lee's films find an echo in the story of wide-eyed scientist Bruce Banner struggling to control his over-sized inner child. For a start, there are the strong female characters (in this case, Betty Ross, daughter of the US general intent on eliminating the Hulk); and the indifferent hand of fate as the hapless physicist finds himself increasingly consumed by his strange powers. Most persistently, there is the creeping sense of isolation; or, as the Hulk himself once put it, the knowledge that where he walks, "he walks alone!".

Indeed, with all this in mind, Lee's decision starts to seem like the most natural progression for him to make. You start to wonder if his kind of philosophical preoccupations are, in fact, best served by fantasy, whether in the form of a Marvel comic or the gymnastic warriors of ancient China.

Singer's X-Men took place in a non-specific, not-too-distant future; perhaps the visual flourishes and wholesale convention-flouting in which such directors specialise can only be fully realised away from the costume-free, unheroic strictures of the real world. And should the likes of Joel Schumacher find themselves out in the cold as a consequence . . . well, as any comic book will tell you, every epic struggle has to have a loser.
fields.bodyText: With its penchant for remakes, franchises and bankrupt, perfunctory sequels (did someone say Hannibal?), Hollywood has never been big on surprises. So it will come as no surprise to learn that - in the wake of last year's smash hit X-Men - there are plans to make at least three more movies devoted to comic- book superheroes. This time, however, things may turn out rather smarter than usual, thanks to the nature of those charged with undertaking the projects. Each is a maverick talent, and each has been drawn to tales of genetically modified derring-do. Sam Raimi, one-time poster-boy of cult-horror fans, is already preparing a version of Spider-Man, due for release next year. The Hulk, shorn of his "Incredible" prefix but still deeply crabby, looks likely to be brought to the screen by Ang Lee, the master craftsman behind Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon. And the moribund Batman series is set to be revived by Brooklyn wunderkind Darren Aronofsky, director of the harrowing Requiem For a Dream. Implausible? Nostalgia is partly to blame. Raimi, Lee and Aronofsky were all marked by the last great comic-adaptation boom (1978 to 1983) which saw the definitive Superman and its two sequels; the spin-off Supergirl, and a rash of tributes to, among others, Captain America and the still-Incredible Hulk. Back then, however, the directors behind comic-book movies were quite different, with the hipsters of the day (Martin Scorsese, John Cassavetes, Michael Cimino) playing no part. Instead, a typical hiring was Richard Donner, a fortysomething TV veteran who had recently struck gold with satanic hokum The Omen; he got to direct Superman in 1978. At best, these film-makers were accomplished journeymen; sometimes, though, they barely appeared to know which end of the camera to point at the actors. Two decades on, with comics widely considered to be cultural totems, and the lines between art-house and multiplex becoming blurred, the commercial and creative landscapes look very different. All of which surely increases the prospect of finding a hint of subversion in among the Spandex. You need only to glance back to Bryan Singer's X-Men to see a good example of a blockbuster that fuses high-octane action with a streak of cerebral scepticism. More imaginative than Gladiator, more probing than Traffic, and a good deal more satisfying than Erin Brockovich, it was perhaps the most intelligent mainstream movie of 2000. And one, moreover, that gave Singer's career a vital boost after the botched adaptation of Stephen King's Apt Pupil (in much the same way, Tim Burton's baroque Batman of 1989 elevated him from fringe weirdo to A-list auteur). A successful superhero yarn can take a thriving director to another level; so Aronofsky can look forward to joining the elite if he rescues a valuable franchise that has been run into the ground by the cheap hackery of Joel Schumacher, the director of Batman Forever and Batman & Robin . The other incentive for a director is the chance to mine the story-telling potential of the superhero's fixations: vengeance, self-doubt and the onerous duties of heroism. This will all be pure thematic cat-nip to the likes of Raimi, whose maturation from the morbid frolics of the Evil Dead to A Simple Plan, and the forthcoming The Gift, has revealed a director who is never happier than when knee- deep in morality and melodrama. For Aronofsky, taking Frank Miller's Batman: Year One to the big screen offers the chance to bring the unforgiving steel of Requiem For a Dream to a far wider audience. On the page, Miller's rain-soaked Gotham City, run by a cabal of dirty cops and dirtier politicians, already has less to do with high camp than the scowling LA Confidential or the pitiless Seven. Aronofsky is likely to take those reference points and increase the darkness, delivering a brutal exposition of the caped crusader's origins set against a vision of Gotham/New York as Miller's "stone rats'-maze". With his knack for marrying the mundane and the nightmarishly surreal, Aronofsky seems an ideal choice for depicting a world in which the modus operandi of heroes is often indistinguishable from that of villains, and where the innocent suffer either way. Once again, you can't help thinking of X-Men, in which Singer never seemed wholly convinced that the real bogeyman wasn't mankind itself. Our superheroes, it seems, come just as beset by conflicts as the rest of us. But, if the connection between Aronofsky and his subject seems obvious, the allure of the Hulk's irradiated tantrums for Ang Lee appears less clear-cut - until you recall just how unlikely the idea of such a subtle director making a martial-arts movie once sounded, and how sublime the results turned out. Indeed, many of the motifs of Lee's films find an echo in the story of wide-eyed scientist Bruce Banner struggling to control his over-sized inner child. For a start, there are the strong female characters (in this case, Betty Ross, daughter of the US general intent on eliminating the Hulk); and the indifferent hand of fate as the hapless physicist finds himself increasingly consumed by his strange powers. Most persistently, there is the creeping sense of isolation; or, as the Hulk himself once put it, the knowledge that where he walks, "he walks alone!". Indeed, with all this in mind, Lee's decision starts to seem like the most natural progression for him to make. You start to wonder if his kind of philosophical preoccupations are, in fact, best served by fantasy, whether in the form of a Marvel comic or the gymnastic warriors of ancient China. Singer's X-Men took place in a non-specific, not-too-distant future; perhaps the visual flourishes and wholesale convention-flouting in which such directors specialise can only be fully realised away from the costume-free, unheroic strictures of the real world. And should the likes of Joel Schumacher find themselves out in the cold as a consequence . . . well, as any comic book will tell you, every epic struggle has to have a loser.

fields.headline: Macedonian army fights border rebels
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Fears of war erupting between ethnic Albanian rebels and the Macedonian army increased yesterday after sustained clashes on the frontier between Macedonia and Kosovo.
fields.body:
Fears of war erupting between ethnic Albanian rebels and the Macedonian army increased yesterday after sustained clashes on the frontier between Macedonia and Kosovo.

For two hours gunfire, the crack of light artillery and the dull thud of grenade launchers in and around the village of Tanusevc, just inside the Macedonian border, could be heard.

It is the first sustained period of fighting in the region and follows six weeks of mounting tension in which one Albanian has been killed.

It was unclear what sparked the fighting but a member of the Albanian guerrilla group, who spoke to the Guardian half a mile from the village, claimed Macedonian forces fired the first shots.

"If they enter the village, it will turn into a graveyard for them," he warned. "It's going to explode everywhere."

The emergence of the rebel group, which calls itself the National Liberation Army, along the border with Kosovo has caused huge international concern. The Macedonian government claims it is being supported from within Kosovo.

Shortly after he had finished speaking, a shot landed 10 metres from where he was standing. He was dressed in camouflage fatigues and wore a red badge embroidered with the words Ushtaria Climatare Kombetare, whose initials, UCK, are the same in Albanianas those of the Kosovo Liberation Army.

The rebel fighter acknowledged that the group had the same structure as the KLA. He also said they had built a network across Macedonia, from Tetevo in the west to Skopje, the capital.

More than three hundred women and children have left the village over fears of an outbreak in fighting.

Macedonia's population is estimated to be between 25% and 35% ethnic Albanian.

The government coalition includes the country's leading Albanian party. Diplomats are concerned that an escalation in fighting could lead to conflict elsewhere in the country.

fields.headline: X-Men's Bryan Singer to direct Galactica remake
fields.standfirst: Plus: Mumba double bill in Time Machine; Apes site goes live; Scooby Doo gets a date; Controversial French film rated 18 in UK
fields.trailText: Plus: Mumba double bill in Time Machine; Apes site goes live; Scooby Doo gets a date; Controversial French film rated 18 in UK
fields.body:
 Bryan Singer has signed a deal to bring back cult sci-fi series Battlestar Galactica to TV, according to PageSix.com. The X-Men director will develop a new series based on the 70s favourite and, if not committed to X-Men 2 at the time, may even direct the pilot episode. "The lesson I learned on X-Men is to have a healthy respect for the fan base of sci-fi fantasy franchises, and I'm confident that the Galactica brand is a sleeping giant," Singer told Variety.

 Ain't It Cool reveals that 11-year-old Omero Mumba is being screen-tested for a role in the forthcoming adaptation of HG Wells' The Time Machine where, if successful, he will join older sister Samantha, the vaunted r'n'b star, who already has a role alongside thesp bruisers Jeremy Irons and Guy Pearce.

 The Flash-hungry site for Tim Burton's Planet of the Apes remake has now gone live.

 A tentative release date for the Scooby Doo project has been set firmly in next year's blockbuster sector: June 14 2002. If the thought of Freddie Prinze Jr and Matthew Lillard doesn't grab you, then Dark Horizons says that Pamela Anderson was on set last week to film a cameo.

 Dark Horizons reports that Michael Jackson's long-planned Edgar Allan Poe biopic has been put on hold while the King of Pop puts the final touches to his new album. A single is due next month.

 The controversial French film Baise-Moi was yesterday given an 18 rating by the British Board of Film Classification after a violent rape scene, which fell foul of guidelines banning any erotic portrayal of sexual assault, was cut.

fields.headline: The making of an epidemic
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The impossibly tangled web which Ministry of Agriculture staff began to unravel last week now extends across three animal species, five countries and many British counties as foot and mouth disease carried by British sheep threatens to spread though Europe and even further afield.
fields.byline: John Vidal, Paul Brown, Peter Hetherington,  and  Kate Connolly  in Berlin
fields.body:
The impossibly tangled web which Ministry of Agriculture staff began to unravel last week now extends across three animal species, five countries and many British counties as foot and mouth disease carried by British sheep threatens to spread though Europe and even further afield.

But as mainland Europe continued yesterday to try to identify and quarantine or kill those animals which they suspect may have come into contact with infected British sheep, it was becoming clear that the continental meat trade is so complex that a sheep born in Aberdeenshire could be trucked 1,600 miles before being slaughtered as far away as Beirut.

The detective story starts, for the moment, when 40 sheep were sent from Ian Williamson's Prestwick Hall farm at Ponteland near Newcastle airport to Hexham market on February 13. It is known that more than 3,500 animals were sold that day and all the buyers and sellers have to be traced and their animals monitored. The ministry hopes to complete tracing them in the next 24 hours.

More than a week later, foot and mouth disease was confirmed among cattle at Prestwick Hall farm shortly after Burnside farm at Heddon-on-the-Wall - barely four miles away - was pinpointed by the Ministry of Agriculture as the likely source of the national outbreak. Vets believe the virus was carried from infected pigs by wind to Prestwick Hall farm, and then to a neighbouring farm at Westerhope, near Newcastle - confirmed yesterday as the 10th outbreak.

They believe that the 40 sheep from Prestwick were sold to Willy Cleave, a Devon dealer who has 11 farms in the west country where he keeps sheep before sending them on to British abattoirs or for export. The 40 were then shipped on February 15 to Longtown market, Carlisle, which is one of the largest sheep markets in Europe and also acts as a holding centre. However the ministry still does not know for certain whether these sheep were the infected ones.

What is known is that the Longtown 40 were collected shortly afterwards and taken to Mr Cleave's Highampton farm in Devon. Cattle there developed foot and mouth but it was not known at the time they had caught it from sheep.

On February 21, some sheep from Highampton were trucked to Bromham slaughterhouse in Wiltshire, where they developed foot and mouth. The next day sheep from the same farm were sent to Northampton and sold at the local auction. Normally, about 85% of the 1,500 sheep sold that day would go for export but because the export route had been closed on February 17, these sheep would have been held by dealers. All are now being traced.

Separately Mr Cleave had, on February 12, trucked 348 sheep from Devon to Germany via Dover on the Cap Afrique, Britain's only dedicated livestock export ferry. Since then according to the ministry, he had sold other batches of sheep to British dealers intended for export. All these are also being searched for.

The last sheep exports from Britain to the continent were at 2am on February 17. The Cap Afrique left Dover loaded with hundreds of animals bound for Dunkirk. Farmer's Ferry, the company which owns it, said it had exported about 30,000 sheepin the two weeks before the ban. The ministry is having to trace all sheep exported on the Cap Afrique in the past three weeks.

Yesterday, the German authorities traced the 348 sheep sent directly by Mr Cleave to Germany on February 12 and killed them as a precautionary measure.

The Cap Afrique suspended all operations within hours of the first confirmed outbreak, but the European authorities say it may have been too late to prevent the disease spreading through Europe.

After long journeys from as far away as Scotland, Northern Ireland, Wales and the west country, animals are known to be highly susceptible to disease. If any of those exported in the past few weeks had already been infected, they could easily have passed it on.

Most live sheep exported from Britain are taken first to any one of more than 60 EU registered "holding stations" where they are kept, often with many thousands of other animals, for up to several days. British exporters favour a handful of large stations in Belgium and Holland.

However, according to Gilles Frojet of the major French holding station La Gatevinière at Argenton L'Eglise, there are many unofficial holding stations in mainland Europe which could also have received infected animals and could possibly duck the authorities' investigations.

Tracing livestock movements in Europe is difficult, said Mike Gooding of Farmers First, a British sheep exporter. British animals have full documentation, but many animals in continental holding centres are resold in job lots to buyers who quite legally alter their papers of origin.

"They are all mixed up which adds to the potential for disease and many are bought and sold," said Mr Gooding.

From these staging posts and markets, sheep go all over the continent and many are re-exported with Dutch, French or Belgian papers 1,000 miles or more to abattoirs in Italy, Greece and Spain. Hundreds of thousands of animals are then re-exported outside Europe, especially to the Middle East and North Africa via Italian ports.

Yesterday, the Dutch slaughtered 4,300 animals on 11 farms. The French farm ministry said that up to 47,000 sheep recently imported from Britain had been identified but it had not decided whether to kill them.

German officials announced a programme of slaughter for thousands of livestock. It began on two farms in the state of North Rhein Westphalia which, according to the state's agriculture minister, Bärbel Höhn, has received thousands of sheep and pigs from farms in Britain in the past few weeks, including from some of those which have been struck by the disease.

"If the virus spread to the continent, the entire European Union would risk losing its status as free of foot and mouth disease," said Bernard Vallat, director-general of the Paris-based International Epizootic Office. "The re-emergence of the disease in Britain presents a potential major threat to European exports."

fields.headline: eToys sets date for liquidation
fields.trailText: Embattled online retailer eToys has finally given up its hunt for a buyer and set a date for liquidation.
fields.body:
Embattled online retailer eToys has finally given up its hunt for a buyer and set a date for liquidation.

The company scrapped its British operation last month in an effort to keep the US business alive, but it has now admitted that it will file for bankruptcy protection within 10 days and will close its website around 8 March.

The California-based company has said it does not expect to meet its $270m in debts by selling off its assets, leaving many creditors empty-handed.

Previously, eToys' management said that the company had enough cash to continue running until the end of March. But without a buyer or additional financing - and without the traditional fallback of profits - the company has simply run out of cash.

Although eToys never made a profit, it floated on the hi tech Nasdaq stock market for $20 (£15) a share in May 1999. Yesterday shares were trading for less than 10 cents. Earlier this year, Nasdaq gave the company until 2 May to pull its share price above the $1 minimum requirement or risk being delisted from the stock market.

The fall of the high-profile company, which began with what many industry analysts regarded as a solid path to profitability, will further shake confidence in the already fragile online retailing sector.

The company had already told all of its 1,000 employees that they would be made redundant in April if no additional financing was secured. Now that date will be moved forward.

webTitle: Hard work is paying visible dividends

fields.headline: Hard work is paying visible dividends
fields.standfirst: As the clinic and craft programmes continue to make significant progress, Dr Prue Peart is encouraged by developments on several fronts
fields.trailText: As the clinic and craft programmes continue to make significant progress, Dr Prue Peart is encouraged by developments on several fronts.
fields.body:
Spent this morning with Joyce, the child protection officer from anzania, and Margaret, the safe motherhood officer from Kenya (both working for Unicef). We went back to the clinic - very busy with women and children - and I was pleased to see that the pharmacy had been transformed, with labels put on shelves, lids on pots, and empty boxes and expired medicines all cleared away.

Unicef supplies the hospital with essential drugs and the two Unicef officers were surprised to hear that the hospital is generally giving the clinic expired medicines. There have been many difficulties with the Ministry of Public Health (MOPH) over the past year and I do not think this is a problem I can solve - it will have to come from the suppliers of the drugs. Médecins du Monde applied last year to run this clinic, but MOPH refused them permission for reasons that are not quite clear.

Joyce and Margaret wanted to meet the tailors because they would like to see if they can make 400 baby kits for the newborn babies in the camps. So we went to a village where five women are nearing the end of their six-month tailoring course. They were delighted to hear that they might get some work. The women said that each of them could make 10 outfits a day at a cost of US$2 plus materials (eg 400 buttons @ US$1; 800 metres of ribbon @ US$10). So for very little it looks like a great deal can be achieved.

We also took the opportunity to visit Ockenden's carpet weaving project. Margaret was very interested in commissioning the teacher to make her some carpets in colours that she liked. So it may be that the carpet team also gets some work. I think that both Unicef officers were genuinely very impressed with the work that the Ockenden development team are doing with the women in the villages. Unicef does not have any Afghan women working for them at all.

Stuart also had had a morning of Unicef praising Ockenden at the Watsan (Water And Sanitation for the camps) meeting. The officer-in-charge is visiting from Islamabad and had been to look at the latrines and wells being built at Mazlagh camp. He thought that a good job was being done. However, it is all very well for international agencies to think that the latrines are marvellous, but it still looks as though the people living here are to be convinced - as there are faeces everywhere outside their shelters.

Most of the people from the villages do not have latrines in their homes and have always gone to the fields to go to the toilet, so there is a massive amount of health education to be done. webTitle: In brief: Ridley declines another bite at Hannibal

fields.headline: Ridley declines another bite at Hannibal
fields.standfirst: Plus: I see more dead people; Crouching Tiger name-a-like picked up; record-breaking Euro cartoon kickstarted
fields.trailText: Plus: I see more dead people; Crouching Tiger name-a-like picked up; record-breaking Euro cartoon kickstarted
fields.body:
 Ridley Scott has confirmed to the Sun's Bizarre column that he absolutely won't be returning to direct a new Hannibal Lecter film. When asked about possible involvement in the planned remake of Thomas Harris' Red Dragon, he said: "No. I'm very happy about how it [Hannibal] went but I don't think so." Maybe he's just not one for sequels - he turned down an offer to direct a third Terminator film earlier this year too.

 It had to happen. Coming Attractions reports that Spyglass, the company behind the blockbusting M Night Shyamalan original, is lining up Sixth Sense 2 for production. There's precious little detail about the direction a possible franchise might take, though a series of novels have been published following the adventures of Cole Sear, played by the precocious Haley Joel Osment, in his encounters with the denizens of the spirit world.

 Miramax has picked up the international and North American rights to the suspiciously titled martial arts period piece Flying Dragon, Leaping Tiger, says Screendaily. A rather optimistic moniker for a feature starring hefty kung fu ballast Sammo Hung, the $5m (£3.45m) film has apparently been in development for two years now and so can't be denounced outright as a blatant cash-in on the huge success of Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon. The print is due for delivery in June.

 The most expensive animated European feature is ready to roll, according to Screendaily. Simsala Grimm will go into production in May under the direction of cartoon stalwart Gerd Hahn. The $30m (£20.75m) project is based on a TV series that is in turn adapted from a Russian fairy tale in which evil attempts to take over the land of Simsala. Sounds great, doesn't it? Well, 130 countries have bought into the TV series, leaving the producers in no doubt that the market is begging for Simsala saturation. All that remains to be found is a "top US voice cast and a triple-A artist for the music". Tim Rice: are you out there?

fields.headline: Vauxhall installs 'mobile cinemas' in cars
fields.trailText: 11.30am: 'Drive-in movie" is taking on a new meaning as Vauxhall kits out its cars with DVD video systems, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The phrase "drive-in movie" is taking on a new meaning as Vauxhall kits out its cars with DVD video systems.

Back-seat passengers in Vauxhall's Zafira model will be able to sit back, relax and watch the latest films on the DVD system called AutoVision.

The "mobile cinema" package is unveiled today at the Geneva Motor Show, which opens to the public on March 1.

The second and third row seats in the seven-seat family car will be fitted with headphones and remote controls to enable passengers to watch DVDs. The use of headphones is designed so as not to distract the driver.

The system works via a video unit built in to the roof of the Zafira so it does not interfere with the driver's rear view.

A screen, which measures seven inches diagonally, swings down at the touch of a button and can be folded away when not in use.

As DVDs have enough space for eight hours of film, the initiative should help keep the kids quiet on long journeys.

The system can also be used for passengers to listen to music either through the car's speakers on through the headphones. AutoVision will be available in the Zafira from 2002.

But a spokesman for the AA said the organisation was keeping a close watch on the development of in-car entertainment and information systems.

"If the DVDs can only be seen and heard by the passengers then it is greatly contentious and by and large car manufacturers are getting it right," he said.

"But if drivers are overloaded with too much information from entertainment and navigation systems there is a potential distraction. We are watching development carefully because drivers need to be clear-minded."

Vauxhall is also offering owners of the VX220 to undergo a day's advanced driver training worth £400.

fields.headline: This time it's personable
fields.standfirst: The new Renault Laguna completely outclasses its predecessor. And you don't even need a key to start it up
fields.trailText: The new Renault Laguna completely outclasses its predecessor. And you don't even need a key to start it up.
fields.body:
The new Renault Laguna is so different from the old one - from brake discs to door handles - that Renault have decided to call it Laguna II, making it sound like a proper return to the drawing board. Either that or a film sequel. Laguna II: it's back - and this time it's personable.

Like its predecessor, the new Laguna is a big hatchback or a shrunken saloon, depending on how you want to look at it. But it's been entirely Hoovered out on the inside and thoroughly reshaped on the outside, especially at the back, which now comes with a giant, low-lying, wrap-around rear window and what is clearly the biggest rear windscreenwiper known to man. It looks like the lightning conductor off a church. Maybe it serves a similar purpose.

These are racey times for Renault, which seems to have decided to make a concerted push upmarket. Laguna II, with its fancy painted plastics and electronic seat possibilities, outposhes Laguna I by a factor of about nine.

Plus there's a new advertising campaign, which seems to be asking us to see the company in a new, steely light. In recent years, the car with which Renault has been most strongly associated here has been the happy-clappy Clio - a nice car, but hardly the essence of cool. Now the company is busy thrusting forward, on billboards and in magazine spreads, the strangely thrilling legend: "Créateur D'Automobiles."

It's only a bald job description, but because it's in French it seems designed to evoke, at least for the British market, an organisation staffed by untroubled smokers in black polo necks who calmly redefine the spirit of motoring and then go home to drink wine and have sex.

Maybe, overall, the Laguna seems like the product of somewhere a little more boring than that - the output of a créateur de company cars. But it does have its twists. For instance: still us ing a key to start your car? How passé. The Laguna comes with a thick metallic credit card which you plug into a slot on the dash, as if you were about to remove cash from the air-conditioning system. Renault Card? That'll do nicely. Once the card is in place, you can start the engine by pushing a button beside the steering wheel helpfully marked: "Start/Stop."

Meanwhile, the card has talked to the car's computer and between them they have remembered, among other things, how you prefer your seat adjusted and your chosen settings for the hi-fi. Committed key-janglers - a not insubstantial segment of car-users, surely - must be white with fear at the thought that this technology will catch on. There is every chance it will.

The car comes in five different trim levels, with seven different engines and four different transmissions, making 52 possible model choices in all, almost as many varieties as Heinz managed. I drove a top-of-the-range Initiale, fitted with interesting off-white leather which may have found favour with Peter Stringfellow and/or the Milky Bar Kid. It had a terrifyingly swift V6 engine and, luckily, some very crisp brakes. It was also passionately, but kindly, concerned about my driving. Pulling away with the handbrake on, I was greeted by a soft piano chord as a computerised voice, with no derision whatsoever, informed me of my error.

Needless to say, there was a satellite navigation system on board. And needless to say, it was next to useless. From south-west London I programmed into it a destination in north-east Essex, the quickest route to which I am already familiar with. It strikes me that an awful lot of people use satellite navigation systems this way - not as devices to route one through the unknown (who can bring themselves to trust the satellite that much?), but as machines against which to test and prove the superiority of one's own knowledge.

You ask the system to plan a journey you already know like the back of your hand, then moan and tut when it deviates from the route, the way you do with taxi drivers. I got to moan and tut royally, which was richly satisfactory. Every time the computerised voice advised me to make a U-turn, I was able to let out a smug whinny of disbelief. The system seemed to want me to go to Cambridge first, and became very sulky when I wouldn't.

It showed me a map of Chigwell golf course for the duration of the journey, perhaps as a protest at being ignored. The crowning moment came when it urged me to pull off the A12 at Chelmsford. I would only consider turning off the A12 to head into Chelmsford if either I or one of my passengers was haemorrhaging. Even then I would probably attempt to drive on and reach Witham. It would be a smooth enough ride in a Laguna II.

webTitle: Human rights workers in Colombia face increasing threats

fields.headline: Human rights workers in Colombia face increasing threats
fields.trailText: Paramilitary and guerrilla violence in an area of Colombia noted for its coca-growing activity is making essential humanitarian work increasingly difficult, writes Jasper Corbett
fields.body:
Paramilitary and guerrilla violence in an area of Colombia noted for its coca-growing activity is making essential humanitarian work increasingly difficult, human rights organisations based in the region report.

The Regional Committee for the Defence of Human Rights (CREDHOS) is a Christian Aid-funded organisation based in the north-eastern town of Barrancabermeja, which is close to extensive coca plantations. The organisaion provides legal advice and support to the families of people who have been killed by armed groups or who have disappeared. Its workers say that intimidation has now become a daily part of their lives.

"Our work here is getting harder and harder. Over the past two years the paramilitaries have declared us legitimate military targets on 18 separate occasions," says Francisco Campos, a spokesman for CREDHOS.

Barrancabermeja is fast earning the unenviable reputation as one of the most violent places in Colombia. The town's murder rate is three times the national average. This year alone, there have been more than 90 political killings.

Along with other human rights groups, CREDHOS believes there are links between the paramilitaries and the government armed forces. "There are two battalions of troops, a special terrorist force and members of the secret police in Barrancabermeja," says Mr Campos. "Yet the paramilitaries wander around unhindered, holding public meetings, patrolling the streets, while the authorities turn a blind eye."

Over the past few years human rights workers like Mr Campos have come to rely on unarmed foreign observers from Peace Brigades International (PBI) to protect them. Now PBI, too, has become a target for the armed groups.

On 8 February two paramilitaries burst into the offices of a women's soup kitchen and threatened a Swedish volunteer working for PBI. After confiscating his passport and mobile telephone, the volunteer was told he was now a legitimate military target.

Following an international campaign by several international human rights organisations and development agencies, the paramilitaries handed back the phone and passport and retracted their threat.

Last weekend members of the Colombian government and representatives of civil society met in Barrancabermeja to discuss ways of improving the security situation and putting an end to the violence.

As a result, the government has agreed to set up a regional human rights commission to monitor the situation in and around Barrancabermeja.

Christian Aid's representative in Colombia, James Lupton, who participated in the meeting, said: "Obviously lots more needs to be done to improve the human rights situation, but this is a step in the right direction. Now the challenge is to make the commission work."

As part of a consortium of international charities and UN agencies working in the region, Christian Aid is committed to ensuring the establishment of a human rights commission to enable human rights workers to carry out their vital work without being hindered by threats and intimidation from armed groups.

 Jasper Corbett is a Latin American and Caribbean journalist for Christian Aid.

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: week twenty-six, the expert's view

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week twenty-six, the expert's view
fields.standfirst: It's the last column by Blue Square expert Patrick Murray before he hands over to a camel. Don't worry, all will be explained
fields.trailText: It's the last column by Blue Square expert Patrick Murray before he hands over to a camel. Don't worry, all will be explained.
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):

Scott Murray = £175.54

Sean Ingle = £34.82

Paul MacInnes = £30.01

The Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective = £19.08

Scott Murray: Leicester v Sunderland: 0 or 1 goals scored - £10 @ 9/4

Not even the inspired Mr M can win every week. But then Mr M is a value hunter, he knows he doesn't have to win every week.

This week, apparently, the value lay not in the usual long-odds away team but in Scott's other speciality, the total goals market. He's enjoyed a fair bit of success over the season in backing 0 or 1 goals in carefully selected matches; this week, alas, it was not to be.

With the game finely poised at 1-0, Ade Akinbiyi, clearly hurt by Scott's stinging criticism of his finishing, thwarted the hopes of yet another Murray payout, ballooning one in off his thigh with his trademark pinpoint accuracy. Football can be cruel.

But Scott did nothing wrong - with Leicester less than prolific in front of goal and Sunderland hit by injuries and suspensions 9/4 looked a very fair price. But Scott's a patient man, he knows there's always next week.

Sean Ingle: Udinese to win at Internazionale - £7 @ 7/2

It was with a growing sense of dread that I accessed the Guardian Unlimited site last Friday. Mr Ingle, having made such progress in recent weeks towards curing his addiction to multiples, was showing disturbing signs of imminent backsliding last week. How pleasant (I can't hear that word any more without thinking of Ray Wilkins, which is more than a little disturbing) it was then to find Mr I still multiple-free despite the fact he had found three selections to interest him.

Again, Sean shows every sign of having learned the value singles lesson - backing an unfashionable in-form outsider against an out-of-form giant. But again, unfortunately, he has backed a loser, though Udinese did actually take the lead in this game. But taking prices like 7/2 you must expect to back a lot of losers, knowing you don't have to back a lot of winners to make a profit.

But as long as Mr Ingle's nerve holds I am confident he can turn his season around. Patience is the key.

The Prince of Punts: Derby v Aston Villa, half-time/full-time, Villa/draw - £4.89 @ 14/1

Blimey, the Prince of Punts seems a little riled this week. He claims I "mocked" him; I like to think of it as constructive criticism, but then I think putting "juicy bits" in orange juice is a little strange so I fear I may be out of touch with the prevailing cultural mores.

Regrettably, constructive or not, my criticism has failed to yield a winner this week. The Prince of Punts went for the big one this week with a nice juicy 14/1 shot designed to get him back up to £100, but it was not to be with Villa mischievously refusing to score and Derby contrarily taking the lead in the first half. Still at 14/1 what do you expect? Keep trying, your majesty.

Thomas Keegan of the Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective: QPR to win at Wimbledon @ 10/3. Liverpool to beat Birmingham City @ 4/9. Hartlepool to beat Mansfield @ 8/15. £5 treble (pays about 8.6/1).

Ah. The old "enforced multiple" excuse, eh? Those wicked bookies are thwarting your carefully thought out value single with their dastardly "trebles only in the Nationwide League" rule so you combine it with a couple of short-priced certs. We've all done it. In our youth, before we understood the principles of value.

The simple fact is that a value single quickly loses its value when you put it in with two palpably non-value singles to make up a treble. The bookies have lured Mr Keegan into their trap with their tasty 10/3 and then foisted an unpalatable 4/9 and 8/15 on him, turning a shade of value into a liability.

Personally, I could not even have considered Liverpool at 4/9 given the nature of finals, the shenanigans at Anfield on Thursday, the current form of Birmingham and, above all, the fact that the bookies know they will be snowed under with bets for Liverpool whatever price they go.

And I'm no expert on Third Division football, but I imagine the 8/15 on Hartlepool was no value either; again the bookies almost certainly artificially shortened the favourite in the knowledge it would end up in many a multiple.

webTitle: Brits: Never mind the topicality, feel the whiff of complacency

fields.headline: Never mind the topicality, feel the whiff of complacency
fields.standfirst: In pictures: the 2001 Brit awards
fields.trailText: Compared with the Grammy Awards, which proved that rock warhorses were still alive by handing Steely Dan a best album statuette at last week's ceremony, the Brits should have been a relative oasis of coolness.
fields.body:
Compared with the Grammy Awards, which proved that rock warhorses were still alive by handing Steely Dan a best album statuette at last week's ceremony, the Brits should have been a relative oasis of coolness.

An overhaul of voting procedures in the early 90s meant that the days when Phil Collins and Annie Lennox won everything in sight are gone, and hipper and younger artists now reign.

Even so, the 1,000-strong music industry voting panel appears to have forgotten the lesson of the Collins era, which is that rewarding the same acts every year while overlooking newer talent makes the acts complacent and the industry seem out of touch.

Robbie Williams, who took home three trophies last night, already has a mantelpiece groaning with the things - his total of 12 makes him the most prolific winner in Brits history - and clearly does not need any more, especially for the workaday song which won it, Rock DJ.

We can only ascribe Fatboy Slim's latest triumph with the underwhelming Halfway Between the Gutter and the Stars album to the fact that, a white male in his late 30s with a taste for loud shirts, he resembles the typical Brits panellist.

Where were the industry bigwigs when 19-year-old Craig David (right) became the most acclaimed British singer of last year, selling 1.5m copies of his debut album and teaching even over-30s to associate the word "garage" with dance music rather than cars?

He lost to Williams in three categories, to Fatboy Slim for dance act, young fogeys Coldplay for album - at least it was not the inexplicably-nominated 70s revivalists Toploader - and, most shamefully of all, the boy band A1 for newcomer.

That gong was voted for by Radio 1 listeners, who plumped for the vapid A1 despite the station not playlisting their two number-one singles.

In view of this conservatism, it seems odd to see Eminem as the best international male, but perhaps it is acceptable to go for the controversial choice as long as he lives in Detroit and will not be a fixture on Saturday morning TV.

Meanwhile, same time next year, Robbie?

webTitle: The Brits play safe with Robbie Williams

fields.headline: The Brits play safe with Robbie Williams
fields.standfirst:
Former Take That star dominates annual music industry awards again as Craig David leaves empty handed despite six nominations
Full listIn pictures: the 2001 Brit awards
fields.trailText: Former Take That star dominates annual music industry awards again as Craig David leaves empty handed despite six nominations.
fields.body:
The British record industry rewarded familiarity last night by eschewing the glamour of All Saints and the originality of Craig David and going with what it knows: Robbie Williams.

With four gongs from the five categories in which he was nominated, Williams dominated the Brit Awards for the second consecutive year. It was hardly surprising: in his evolution from Take That teen star to serious recording artist Williams has won 12 Brits.

It was a bitterly disappointing night for David, who had been nominated in all six categories for which he was eligible, including best single and best British male solo artist. There was widespread shock that the 19-year-old R&B singer from Southampton, acclaimed as one of the most distinctive voices on the British music scene, should have been overlooked.

News of the surprise leaked out at the weekend, when David's record company began cancelling parties to celebrate his expected success. Sources at the Brits - which are voted on by an academy of record company officials, retailers, journalists and members of the public - said it was merely an unfortunate coincidence that he had not triumphed in any category.

Another set of British music favourites, Coldplay, fared better: they beat Moloko, All Saints, Radiohead and Toploader to take the award for best British group; while their CD Parachutes beat David's Born To Do It and Williams's Sing When You're Winning for best album.

There was good news, too, for Madonna: after 14 nominations the American singer, who has adopted London as her home, won her first Brit award for best international female solo artist. It comes after a year in which she has once again reinvented herself for a new generation, with her marriage to Guy Ritchie and a run of hit singles.

US rap star Eminem picked up an award for best international male singer. His performance at the awards ceremony, at Earls Court in London, provoked protests from gay rights groups: Peter Tatchell of OutRage! said: "This nomination is the moral equivalent of honouring a Ku Klux Klan singer."

The Irish band U2 took a lifetime achievement award, as well as best international group. The band, schoolboy friends who started 25 years ago, have sold more than 100m albums and earned more than £300m.

It was the presence of a rather more green set of artists that captured as much attention at the event as the international millionaire stars: Hear'Say, the band formed from the ITV series Popstars, performed their first single, Pure and Simple. It was the first live television performance of the record, which will be released on March 12.

Other performers providing the soundtrack to the event included Westlife, who won best pop act; and Sonique, who took the award for best British female solo artist.

The presenters of the Saturday morning children's shows SM:tv Live and CD:UK, Ant and Dec, hosted the awards, which will be broadcast on ITV tonight.

Stars presenting trophies included Noel Gallagher, Kylie Minogue, the actress Fay Ripley, TV chef Jamie Oliver and Pulp Fiction star Samuel L Jackson.


The winners

Best British group Coldplay

Best British album Coldplay, Parachutes

Best British dance act Fatboy Slim

Best British male solo artist Robbie Williams

Best British female solo artist Sonique

Best British single Robbie Williams, Rock DJ

Best British video Robbie Williams, Rock DJ

Best pop act Westlife

Best British newcomer A1

Best international male solo artist Eminem

Best international female solo artist Madonna

Best international group U2

Best international newcomer Kelis

Best soundtrack American Beauty

webTitle: Harrison Ford's wages hit all-time high

fields.headline: Harrison Ford's wages hit all-time high
fields.trailText: Harrison Ford will become the highest paid star in film history when he receives $1.25m per day for his work on the forthcoming submarine thriller K-19: The Widowmaker
fields.body:
Harrison Ford is to receive an incredible $1.25m (£864,000) a day for his work on submarine thriller K-19: The Widowmaker, directed by Kathryn Bigelow, making him the highest paid actor ever.

PageSix.com reports that Ford will be paid $25m (£17.29m) for 20 days' work, breaking down at well over $1m (£690,000) for every 24 hours he spends on set.

The fee breaks the record set by Marlon Brando for four days' toil on Superman when he received $3m (£2.07m) for playing the Man of Steel's dad, a part which garnered him just 10 minutes' screen time.

Mel Gibson also received $25m (£17.29m) for his role in The Patriot, but he spent more than twice as long as Ford working on the film.

Ford told the Sunday Mirror that it wasn't the titanic wage packet that attracted him to the project. "The cash didn't tempt me. I took the part because of the gripping plot," he enthused.

"The tremendous courage and sense of duty exhibited by the Russian submarine force amid the Cold War struggle for nuclear supremacy inspired me to take on the role of Captain Zateyev."

The film's executive producer Tim Kelly said: "We would have paid anything to get Harrison Ford on board. He guarantees a hit."

K-19: The Widowmaker is based on the true story of a Russian submarine commander who managed to avert a nuclear explosion that could have triggered world war three in 1961. The plot has already been criticised by survivors of the real-life tragedy on which it is based (see earlier story), as well as for its close resemblance to last year's Kursk tragedy.

It seems that the only way is up for Ford's bank balance. Figures being touted about for a possible fourth appearance as laconic adventurer Indiana Jones have reached $40m (£27.67m).

"Steven (Spielberg) thinks Harrison is worth every cent. The film would bring a classic end to the series," a studio source said recently.

fields.headline: Marketing bodies may join forces
fields.trailText:
8.30am: The Direct Marketing Association may merge with a new mobile marketing organisation, reports Julia Day.
Feb 23: Labour joins text message frenzy
fields.body:
The direct marketing industry trade body has held merger talks with a new mobile marketing organisation in a bid to stop text messaging becoming a nuisance.

As "brand in your hand" marketing on mobile phones begins to take off, the Direct Marketing Association has held extensive negotiations with the newly established Wireless Marketing Association over a proposition to merge the two groups.

The move cements the view that wireless marketing is a becoming a serious contender for advertisers' direct marketing budgets.

The DMA already has an observer's seat on the WMA board.

But it is believed the new organisation would prefer to go it alone rather than merge with the existing body, at least for the time being.

However, some formal link between the two bodies is likely.

The WMA wants to establish an up-to-the-minute database of consumers, who want to opt in or out of mobile marketing initiatives.

This database could be shared with the DMA.

The WMA was formed in October by mobile marketing services companies.

It is an attempt to form self-regulatory rules to govern the use, and potential abuse, of mobile-phone marketing.

The body last week published a wireless marketing code of conduct in agreement with three of the country's four network operators - Orange, Vodafone and BT Cellnet.

Even the Labour party contacted the WMA last week to check its new text messaging campaign abided by the rules.

The WMA has also appointed Edinburgh agency Summerstreet to create a "kitemark"-style stamp of approval logo for the body.

Members of the organisation will be able to use the logo in their own communications.

The agency is also working on a new website for the WMA.

fields.headline: Headless body is that of missing journalist
fields.trailText: 11am: Prosecutors have ruled a body found near Kiev was that of a journalist known to be a critic of corruption, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Ukrainian prosecutors have ruled that a beheaded body found near Kiev last November was that of a missing journalist known to be a fierce critic of corruption.

Heorhiy Gongadze, who had been missing since September, was a critic of alleged high-level government corruption.

Opposition parties have accused the Ukrainian president Leonid Kuchman being involved in the journalist's death.

Deputy state prosecutor Oleksiy Bahanets ordered Mr Gongadze's mother and wife be recognised as victims in the case, which allows them a legal status to investigate his death.

The ruling is expected to provoke widespread political protest against the government of Mr Kuchman.

fields.headline: Bureau bids to revive online adverts
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The Internet Advertising Bureau has created new formats it hopes will replace the familiar banner, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
An international advertising body is hoping to revitalise the flagging online advertising market by launching a series of alternatives to the ubiquitous banner advert.

The Internet Advertising Bureau - whose members include MSN and Yahoo! - has unveiled a series of advertising formats it hopes will capture advertisers' imaginations.

Big is beautiful seems to be the order of the day.

The new formats include the "skyscraper", a tall, skinny oblong at the side of a web page, and the "rectangle", a horizontal box that is much bigger than a banner.

Many advertisers have tired of the banner format, which relies on internet users clicking on it to go to the advertiser's site.

The format has become so common many internet users ignore it altogether.

Advertisers frequently complain the space is too small to carry their message.

The new, bigger sizes mean users won't have to click through to another site because the advert itself will contain the full message.

The IAB is based in New York but also has offices in several European countries, including the UK. The UK office has said it was in consultation with its US counterpart about the new formats but has yet to adopt them formally.

The Internet Advertising Bureau - whose members include MSN and Yahoo! - has unveiled a series of advertising formats it hopes will capture advertisers' imaginations. Big is beautiful seems to be the order of the day. The new formats include the "skyscraper", a tall, skinny oblong at the side of a web page, and the "rectangle", a horizontal box that is much bigger than a banner. Many advertisers have tired of the banner format, which relies on internet users clicking on it to go to the advertiser's site. The format has become so common many internet users ignore it altogether. Advertisers frequently complain the space is too small to carry their message. The new, bigger sizes mean users won't have to click through to another site because the advert itself will contain the full message. fields.headline: Parents 'sacked over working tax credit'
fields.trailText: One of the government's main weapons for tackling child poverty is backfiring against many of Britain's most needy working parents, according to an analysis of casework by the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux.
fields.body:
One of the government's main weapons for tackling child poverty is backfiring against many of Britain's most needy working parents, according to an analysis of casework by the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux.

It found workers were being sacked by firms trying to avoid the trouble of administering the working families tax credit, a government scheme to top up the incomes of low-paid parents.

In other cases parents felt "cheated and misled" when they found the extra income from the tax credit disqualified them from free school meals and help with rent and council tax.

The tax credit was introduced in October 1999 "to give working families with children a better deal". Together with the national minimum wage, it was designed to ensure that a two-parent family gets an income of more than £200 a week if one parent is working for at least 30 hours.

David Harker, NACAB chief executive, said the credit gave "a real boost to the incomes of many low-paid parents". He added: "But it makes no sense that a scheme that sets out to make work pay is making it more difficult for some people to stay in their jobs, and leaving some families worse instead of better off."

A survey of 700 case reports from advice bureaux throughout England, Wales and Northern Ireland showed employers pressuring staff to reduce their hours so they do not qualify for the tax credit.

"Some employers consider the administrative burden too great for them to manage. In a small number of cases, people have been sacked just for claiming tax credits," NACAB said.

It said a lone mother with three children was dismissed from her part-time job because her employer "could not cope" when the scheme changed from direct payments to delivery of the credit through the pay packet.

Other lone mothers had to give up work because "excessively rigid rules" made it difficult to take advantage of help with childcare costs.

Advice bureaux reported women reconsidering their decision to work and returning to life on benefits when they found their extra earnings were cancelled out by loss of help with rent, council tax and school meals.

Mr Harker said: "Our evidence shows overwhelmingly that people want to work and support their families even when they are no better off in work than on benefit. The government needs to offer people a choice to be paid direct by the inland revenue and to claim help with childcare costs when they need it most."
