fields.headline: Inequality street
fields.standfirst: Women are still being paid less for doing the same job as men, according to a new survey. Why is Britain the most sexist country in Europe, asks  Cristina Odone
fields.trailText: Women are still being paid less for doing the same job as men, according to a new survey. Why is Britain the most sexist country in Europe, asks Cristina Odone.
fields.body:
Poor Baroness Jay. There she was, hoping to hand in her notice as leader of the House of Lords and minister for women and tiptoe out of the back door with as little fuss as possible - and then those nasty busybodies at the Equal Opportunities Commission complete a survey trumpeting the failure of her women's unit. To be fair, the findings, published today, are as much an indictment of New Labour as they are of the unit it created to look after women's interests: in terms of equal pay and equal opportunities, Britain is the most sexist place to work in Europe.

Red faces all around. The party that had raised such hopes and manufactured such hype about its pro-women agenda - remember all the boasts about more female MPs than ever before? The ground-breaking, breastfeeding Blair babes? - will now enter the general election with a set of statistics that will further alienate female voters, a million of whom say they've gone off the government.

The picture is bleak indeed. If you care about how your wage packet compares with the man who does the same job as you, you're better off in France, Germany or even Portugal. The wage gap in these countries is less than in Britain - where a woman working full time earns just 82% of her male colleague's salary. (For a part-time female worker that sinks to 60%.) If you care about paid maternity leave, you'd better up sticks and move to Italy (where a mother gets five months' paid leave) or Finland (nine months, as well as 42 days for paternity leave); in Britain, you get a paltry 18 weeks. Add to this poor childcare provision and, in predominantly female professions such as nursing, an average pay of 6% less than overall average male earnings in the UK, and you can see why the European Council of Ministers told the UK to get down to work on closing the pay gap.

They have their work cut out for them. Thirty years since the Equal Pay Act was passed, women find the workplace as inimical as the factory caricatured in Charlie Chaplin's Modern Times. Talk to staff at the EOC, and they can name endless cases of women who have had to take their employers to court to receive fair treatment. Take Dr Lorna Chessum, a female lecturer at Leicester's De Montfort University, who discovered she had been appointed on a lower salary - £6,000 less - than a similarly qualified male colleague. She received £10,000 compensation in an out-of-court settlement in September 2000.

Then there's Doreen McManus, who worked as a payroll administrator for Rentokil. She claimed that over three years she did the same work as a male colleague, whom she trained, and who was paid £3,000 more than her. She took the matter up with her employer, who agreed to review her pay. Her salary was increased - but she was still earning less than her colleague. She lodged an equal pay claim and Rentokil settled the case, paying her £10,500 compensation.

Two small victories in a war we thought was won long ago. A war in which we cannot count on either government or employer as an ally. Jill Rubery, as the coordinator of the European Commission's expert group on gender and equality, was present when the commission, having seen the UK's National Action Plan for Employment last year, publicly reprimanded the country for its appalling employment figures. "Immediately, our civil servants started to rubbish the data as insufficient and emphasise the high employment rate we have for women - which is well above the 60% target by 2010 set in Lisbon in 1999." The spin machine is likely to go into overdrive after the EOC survey, too, despite its impressive credentials: the research was carried out by the NOP group in the summer last year. It involved a telephone survey of senior human resource managers in 301 organisations with at least 200 employees; telephone interviews with national trade union officials; and in-depth case-study research in 21 selected organisations.

While government apologists may spin against the EOC survey for painting too gloomy a picture of the working woman's lot, critics of the government suspect that the survey in fact lets the government off lightly. Mary Davis, who heads the Centre for Trade Union Studies at the University of North London, argues: "Industry by industry, the gender pay gap has actually widened since 1997. I see no evidence, apart from the introduction of the national minimum wage, to support the view that we are wit nessing a narrowing of the gap. Among working-class women, certainly, things have got worse. If you're living in a textile town, for instance, with the industry bottoming out beneath your feet, you are far poorer than before."

Rubery, who with Damian Grimshaw carried out the research for the EOC, feels that even some of the state's poverty-busting initiatives have had a negative impact on women's wages. The working families tax credit, for example, "contradicted the equal-pay ethos by trapping the second income-earner in a low- paying job". Moreover, as both Davis and Rubery point out, a government that believes that any regulation hinders the market, and has abdicated all responsibility for pay structure, cannot intervene in the one area that most affects the gender pay gap.

The market, indeed, has become a fig leaf behind which employers can hide discrimination: you can get away with paying Jane less than Joe by signing them up to individualised contracts. There are a million weasel words that allow you to claim that what she is doing is not exactly the same as what he does. Equally, there are many ways of explaining away why promotion keeps eluding her.

The trade unions, once the battering rams for victims of unfair treatment at work, have lost their bite. Collective bargaining has declined in recent years; today, less than one in three workplaces is covered by it. Meanwhile, employer accountability has grown ever more nebulous. In an increasing number of situations, there is no single, clear-cut employer - as is the case when work is subcontracted, or joint ventures or partnerships operate. This makes it difficult to uphold legislationbased on "comparable work for the same employer". The fragmentation of the public sector, through the contracting out of services to the private sector, also contributes to the difficulty in monitoring the wage differential. Not surprisingly, this state of affairs gets the thumbs up from employers - 93% of those who took part in the EOC survey cheerfully believed their pay systems were fair.

Those of us who feel that if Jane and Joe carry out the same work they should bring home the same pay packet will simply have to provide fodder for the EOC's case studies. Or move to Lisbon.

webTitle: Ministers urged to review women's pay

fields.headline: Ministers urged to review women's pay
fields.trailText: The government will today be challenged to review women's pay in the public sector as a hard-hitting report finds that Britain's gender pay gap is the worst in the European Union. Thirty years after the Equal Pay Act, women in full-time work are still earning only four-fifths of what men do.
fields.body:
The government will today be challenged to review women's pay in the public sector as a hard-hitting report finds that Britain's gender pay gap is the worst in the European Union. Thirty years after the Equal Pay Act, women in full-time work are still earning only four-fifths of what men do.

The equal opportunities commission's equal pay task force will press ministers to compel employers to conduct pay audits to address the gender gap. Its report, Just Pay, will highlight Britain's place at the bottom of the EU league on equal pay. While women working full-time earn on average 82% of male full-time hourly earnings - up from 69% in 1971, part-time female workers receive only 61% of male full-time hourly wages, compared with a European average of 73%.

The proposal is designed to produce greater pay transparency in businesses, which can be expected to resist the measure on grounds of cost and bureaucracy.

The commission will also call on the government to lead the way in reviewing pay differences, on the basis that many low paid occupations dominated by women - including nursing, caring and cleaning jobs - are in the public sector.

The report will also find that occupations traditionally regarded as women's work are still undervalued in the UK, with women working full-time as nurses earning 6% less than average male hourly earnings. Other European countries also offer women better maternity rights and significantly better childcare provision.

The study, compiled by a task force including business leaders, trade unionists, civil servants and academics, highlights a problem which the government's women's unit has exposed but which ministers have done little to reverse.

A year ago, the unit published research exposing the "female forfeit", and concluding that women earn less than men over a lifetime not because they may take time off to bring up children but because of pay discrimination and their concentration in lower paid occupations.

At the time, women's ministers Lady Jay and Tessa Jowell stopped short of moves to compel employers to examine pay structures, focusing instead on encouraging girls to opt for better paid careers and urging women to ask male colleagues what they earned.

Today's study will confirm both that little has happened since to change the pay gap, and that business will strongly resist any requirement to conduct audits - a key element in the resistance to the move by some in government.

A spokeswoman for the CBI said yesterday: "We don't believe that the pay gap is actually the result of deliberate discrimination by employers. We think pay is a far more complex issue than that." Women had the choice of entering better paid occupations, she said.

The commission's report, however, argues that the pay gap cannot be explained by women's educational and career choices, since often as more women enter a sector the relative pay falls.

webTitle: Blair backs chancellor despite tube chief's ultimatum

fields.headline: Blair backs chancellor despite tube chief's ultimatum
fields.standfirst: PM sticks to Treasury plan as Kiley threatens to quit
fields.trailText: Tony Blair last night closed ranks with John Prescott and Gordon Brown in their determination to force the London mayor, Ken Livingstone, and his transport commissioner, Bob Kiley, to "knuckle down".
fields.body:
Tony Blair last night closed ranks with John Prescott and Gordon Brown in their determination to force the London mayor, Ken Livingstone, and his transport commissioner, Bob Kiley, to "knuckle down" and work within the government's £15bn blueprint for modernising the Underground system.

In a high-stakes battle it raised the prospect that Mr Kiley might make good his veiled threat to resign his £250,000-a-year post - a move that Labour MPs fear may cost London marginals.

With both sides talking tough over who will run the Underground, Mr Blair called in his two chief lieutenants for what was billed as a "knocking-heads-together session".

Board members of Transport for London (TfL) reported Mr Kiley as "white hot with anger" at government obduracy. One member warned: "I am concerned that he may do something stupid, like resigning. That would be a major blow. The people of London would certainly react against the government if he were forced out. The Treasury has to loosen its grip, or there will be all sorts of problems."

On Sunday Mr Kiley, veteran of similar battles in New York and Boston, used an interview with BBC1's Breakfast with Frost to hint that the chancellor, Mr Brown, was the "Wizard of Oz" behind the scenes - stopping Mr Prescott from giving Mr Kiley "unified management control".

In a 17-page document seen by Mr Blair yesterday, Mr Kiley used the same phrase, to the annoyance of ministers who complained that 16 pages attacked their plan and only one provided "10 bullet points" as an alternative. Both Downing Street and the Treasury were dismissive last night, though Mr Prescott's office was more cautious. The mayor is calling a TfL board meeting for Thursday to draw up that alternative if talks remain deadlocked.

"We have gone a long way to offer [Mr Kiley] a real measure of control," said one high-level government source. "There is actually a way through, but he needs to knuckle down and engage - the 10 points he put out were really nothing."

Hopes that the pragmatic Mr Blair would break the deadlock in Mr Kiley's favour look increasingly unlikely - despite the damaging risk of judicial review or of resignation.

After the three ministers met with officials it was made abundantly clear the prime minister was not about to overrule the Brown-backed public/private partnership (PPP) model which Mr Kiley calls "Balkanisation" of the tube at an annual shortfall of £500m a year to be paid by the taxpayer.

It gives virtual ownership to three partnership companies (known as "infra-cos") that would be required to rebuild the network over 30 years - and take the risk. Mr Livingstone and Mr Kiley want to run the tube, and say the shambles of rail privatisation proves their point. Mr Blair points to the huge time and cost overruns when the public sector built the Jubilee line extenstion to the dome in the mid-1990s - barely one-fifth of the scale of the PPP scheme.

Ministers are angry that TfL has, they claim, been briefing against the PPP blueprint without providing a plausible alternative. They accuse Mr Kiley of demanding 51% control, then changing his mind.

But he is proving a formidable adversary. Earlier this month an agreement seemed in view because it appeared to cede control to Mr Kiley. Since then, the talks have gone into reverse with the government denying any such concession.

Downing Street said last night the talks were continuing within the framework of the PPP, an indication it was prepared to make only modest concessions.

"The PPP offers him an extra £7bn of private finance on top of big public money, up front, with a real say on the nature of the contracts, and protection against cost overruns," said one government official.

According to Mr Kiley, under the government's proposal the public would own the system but not control it.

fields.headline: ITV goes upmarket
fields.trailText: 10am: ITV has attracted more upmarket viewers than BBC1 for the first time in its history, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
ITV attracted more upmarket viewers than BBC1 for the first time in its history in the first six weeks of this year.

During that period the commercial channel averaged 1.044m ABC1 viewers across each day, just pipping BBC1, which had 1.008m.

BBC1 has traditionally been regarded as the home of more upmarket viewers, with its diet of costume drama, documentary, natural history and arts programming.

But ITV has hit back in recent years with Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? and a wide range of drama, including costume pieces and critically acclaimed thirtysomething show Cold Feet, which brings in more viewers from the professional classes.

ITV also attracts more 16 to 34-year-olds, thanks to shows such as Popstars and CD:UK, according to the Times.

fields.headline: HTV axes jobs in Carlton move
fields.trailText: 10am: ITV broadcaster HTV is shedding 28 jobs as part of its integration into Carlton, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
ITV broadcaster HTV is shedding 28 jobs as part of its integration into Carlton Communications.

HTV's planning, promotion and presentation department is to be integrated into the Carlton support departments.

Most of the job cuts will be in this area.

Carlton said both HTV Wales and HTV West will keep their branding.

Around 15 new jobs will be created at a new IT support centre in Cardiff.

Meanwhile, HTV's head of programme planning, presentation and promotions Sian Thomas has been appointed to the new post of head of regional programmes for HTV West.

Carlton West Country controller of engineering and operations Mark Chaplin will extend his role.

His job will now include HTV in Wales and the west of England.

HTV controller of finance Mark Davies will take over as head of broadcasting finance.

webTitle: Resorts seek bucket loads of aid

fields.headline: Resorts seek bucket loads of aid
fields.standfirst: England's seaside resorts are in danger of falling into terminal decline unless they receive a significant cash injection from the private sector, a new report has warned
fields.trailText: England's seaside resorts are in danger of falling into terminal decline unless they receive a significant cash injection from the private sector, a new report has warned.
fields.body:
"Sea Changes - creating world class resorts in Eng land", a report from the English Tourism Council published today, says resorts need better marketing and transport links and to make more use of available regeneration grants if they are to stem the tide of holidaymakers who are preferring to take their summer breaks overseas. "The decline of resorts has been slow and subtle . . . [but] the seriousness should not be underestimated," said English Tourist Council chairman Alan Britten.

Mr Britten said the government needed to encour age resorts to think of new ways to entice visitors; public-private partnerships were a must.

The report was drawn up in response to figures showing that the number of Britons taking overseas holidays has more than doubled over the past decade, while the number holidaying in England grew by only 59%.

The number of people spending eight nights or more at an English resort fell 14% in the 1990s, according to the ETC.

Seaside resorts, such as Blackpool, which remains Britain's number one tourist destination with 7m visitors a year, generate around £4.5bn in spending each year. However, the British now spend more than two-thirds of their annual holiday budget overseas.

webTitle: Rowlands clears decks for ZO Media flotation

fields.headline: Rowlands clears decks for ZO Media flotation
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: JellyWorks founder Jonathan Rowland has moved a step closer to a stock market flotation for ZO Media by quitting the board of a rival media firm. By John Cassy.
fields.body:
JellyWorks founder Jonathan Rowland yesterday moved a step closer to a stock market flotation for his new vehicle, ZO Media, by quitting the board of a rival media firm.

Mr Rowland, 25-year-old son of speculator David "Spotty" Rowland, is stepping down as a non-executive director of AIM-listed local TV group VFG just six months after taking up the post.

VFG's non-executive chairman, David Hudd, a Rowland associate, is also resigning from the board of the firm, in which the Rowland family holds a 28.25% stake through a company called Lochangel.

Mr Rowland said he was resigning to concentrate on ZO Media, which is in the process of closing a £4m fundraising round. The Barclay brothers, owners of the Scotsman Newspaper and Ritz hotel, might become investors, he added.

"We're looking to buy an established sports media firm. We're looking at heritage sports media rights; things like squash, tennis, non-league football, equestrianism, maybe formula one.

"We've be getting more involved in companies. We've been a passive investor before."

Mr Rowland's first dabble in the stock market was with JellyWorks, one of the wonder stocks of the dot.com boom which was later sold to the investment bank Shore Capital for less than a quarter of its peak valuation.

VFG started out providing television production equipment for series such as quiz show The Weakest Link.

The company is now building a network of free-to-air local television stations that will sit alongside the existing five terrestrial channels.

Yesterday it reported that "extremely competitive market conditions" led to a £1.6m pre-tax loss.

The company's shares closed down 7% at 25p.

webTitle: Net still fails to snare shoppers

fields.headline: Net still fails to snare shoppers
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: A survey has showed that more than three-quarters of firms generate less than 5% of their sales from e-business. By Julia Snoddy.
fields.body:
The limited impact of e-business on traditional companies was underlined yesterday by a survey showing that more than three-quarters of firms generate less than 5% of their sales from e-business.

"At the moment the figure is so low because companies are still at the stage between having a website for information purposes and having a website for trading and doing e-business", said Nigel Hickson, head of e-business for the CBI.

The survey, conducted by the CBI and KPMG Consulting, shows optimism about the internet's future role for business. "The revolutionary aspect of e-business has been over-hyped but despite the hype real businesses out there are optimistic about using e-business technology for generating revenues in the years to come," Mr Hickson said.

According to the survey, 58% of firms expect to derive at least 10% of their revenues directly from e-business within the next two to three years and 99% of the 1,000 British companies surveyed expect e-business to have some impact over the same period.

"This report undermines some of the pessimism that is being talked about in the e-market place," Mr Hickson said.

According to the report, the internet revolution is much slower than first expected but it has not ground to a halt. Telecoms and retail companies are the most advanced at incorporating e-business into their strategies, managing customer relationships and supply chains over the web.

There are, however, barriers to integration, including fears surrounding internet security, a lack of co-operation from customers and suppliers, the high costs of technology and a lack of internal internet culture or awareness of the potential benefits.

webTitle: CMG may split off booming text unit

fields.headline: CMG may split off booming text unit
fields.trailText: CMG might seek a separate stock market listing for its buoyant mobile phone text messaging unit if telecoms shares return to favour later in the year. By John Cassy.
fields.body:
CMG, the Anglo-Dutch IT services company, said yesterday that it might seek a separate stock market listing for its buoyant mobile phone text messaging unit if telecoms shares return to favour later in the year.

Chairman Corr Stutterheim emphasised that CMG had no immediate plans to realise the value of its wireless services division. But its financial reporting structure had been changed so that it could be run as a standalone business if it were in the best interest of shareholders.

"This is a market-driven development," he said. "We would consider every option and want to be free to do the best thing possible."

Sales at the division doubled to £155m while profits almost quadrupled to £42.3m in the year to December 31 as the popularity of text messages boomed.

CMG builds the technology that allows text messages to be sent and received, and follows rival Logica in saying that the communication method which was developed as an afterthought by phone companies is now becoming a leading driver of profit.

The GSM Association predicts that the volume of text messages will grow 400% this year and Mr Stutterheim said that should ensure divisional turnover growth of more than 50%. The introduction of more advanced types of text messaging was likely to provide further revenues, he added.

Analysts are concerned that the financial doubts being expressed about some of the big telecoms firms and possible delays to the introduction of the next generation of mobile phones could affect trading at CMG.

But the company remains confident that it can weather any downturn.

It believes that phone networks need the sort of "value-added" services it offers to justify the large sums they have spent on their mobile licences.

Shares in CMG climbed 12% yesterday to 768p as the market digested figures showing reassuring signs of future growth.

Group pre-tax profits grew 36% to £117m as turnover increased by a third to £810m. The dividend was increased by 29% to 2.8p.

"We are looking forward to another good year of trading," Mr Stutterheim said.

One potential issue he still needed to get to grips with was the tight recruitment market for IT professionals, he admitted. "There is a chronic shortage of people and the challenge is getting hold of them and retaining them."

The big IT firms have lost hundreds of skilled staff to dot.com companies offering lucrative share option packages but many of those people are now coming back as their start-ups go bust.

However, more people left CMG in 2000 than departed in 1999.

CMG plans to introduce a more attractive option scheme for all staff but might still have to look at buying in teams to keep pace with customer demands.

"We do not exclude small or big acquisitions but only if the fit and culture is right," Mr Stutterheim said.

Trading in CMG's core territories of the Benelux countries and Britain was strong, with profit margins showing good growth.

However, Germany showed "no recovery in the second half", while the introduction of the 35-hour working week in France ate into the local businesses' margins.

fields.headline: Telecom firms talk alliance
fields.standfirst: Mobile operators look to share costs for 3G networks
fields.trailText: Rival telephone companies are considering joining forces to build the next generation of mobile networks, in an attempt to reduce some of the huge costs involved. By Polly Sprenger.
fields.body:
Rival telephone companies are considering joining forces to build the next generation of mobile networks, in an attempt to reduce some of the huge costs involved.

BT-owned Viag Interkom of Germany yesterday became the first operator to reveal it was talking to competitors about the possibility of sharing the costs of building base stations and equipment for the so-called 3G networks.

Other operators - Vodafone, BT Cellnet and Orange - are looking at the same option.

"We are keen on sharing network infrastructure for both financial and environmental reasons," said a BT Wireless spokesman. "The main reasons are financial but environmentally, if you can lessen the impact, so much the better."

He added that BT intended to lease out sites on which competing operators could install 3G networking equipment.

With the costs of the networks estimated at about €5bn (£3.1bn) each, companies could expect to save up to €2bn by sharing sites.

None of the operators would give details about how the site sharing would work, ahead of reaching agreement.

The moves are likely to be welcomed by City investors who have been concerned at the high levels of debt the companies have incurred to fund the new services.

"If they can reduce their cost then [co-operation] is clearly of benefit," said Duncan Warwick-Champion, telecoms analyst at Standard & Poor's.

Worries over 3G expenditures came to a head last week when a senior Intel executive said at a conference that the telecom industry was on the brink of bankruptcy.

More than €100bn has been spent on acquiring 3G licences, but the technology behind the new service is untested, raising questions about when operators will get a return on their investment.

Operators also face resistance from local councils over the installation of new transmission stations after residents complained about potential health risks.

The terms of their 3G licences dictate that operators must offer the service to 80% of the British public by 2007.

Sharing sites that already have planning permission could prevent further delays.

Vodafone and Orange, the number one and number three UK operators respectively, said they would consider cooperation where it was sensible.

"It has always been our policy to use existing buildings and share sites wherever possible," said a spokeswoman for Orange.

"We will be able to use about 70% of our existing sites for our [3G] roll-outs."
fields.bodyText: Rival telephone companies are considering joining forces to build the next generation of mobile networks, in an attempt to reduce some of the huge costs involved. BT-owned Viag Interkom of Germany yesterday became the first operator to reveal it was talking to competitors about the possibility of sharing the costs of building base stations and equipment for the so-called 3G networks. Other operators - Vodafone, BT Cellnet and Orange - are looking at the same option. "We are keen on sharing network infrastructure for both financial and environmental reasons," said a BT Wireless spokesman. "The main reasons are financial but environmentally, if you can lessen the impact, so much the better." He added that BT intended to lease out sites on which competing operators could install 3G networking equipment. With the costs of the networks estimated at about €5bn (£3.1bn) each, companies could expect to save up to €2bn by sharing sites. None of the operators would give details about how the site sharing would work, ahead of reaching agreement. The moves are likely to be welcomed by City investors who have been concerned at the high levels of debt the companies have incurred to fund the new services. "If they can reduce their cost then [co-operation] is clearly of benefit," said Duncan Warwick-Champion, telecoms analyst at Standard & Poor's. Worries over 3G expenditures came to a head last week when a senior Intel executive said at a conference that the telecom industry was on the brink of bankruptcy. "It has always been our policy to use existing buildings and share sites wherever possible," said a spokeswoman for Orange. webTitle: Hugo Young on the government's crime plan

fields.headline: We are kept in a spin over law and order issues
fields.standfirst: Expect more contrary statistics on crime to fly about in the coming weeks
fields.trailText: Expect more contrary statistics on crime to fly about in the coming weeks, warns Hugo Young.
fields.body:
The politics of law and order are entirely about spin. Not just partly. Entirely. There is no field of political conflict where impression more fully eclipses reality. The two may not always be at odds. Some impressions are correct. Crime has doubled over the last 20 years, for example. That is a fact. Politicians' belief that the public wants only heavier sentencing is another truth that's not entirely fanciful. But the raw material Jack Straw and Ann Widdecombe are handling when they promote this as an election issue is not fact but propaganda, otherwise known as spin.

Consider the opening bids made yesterday. Mr Straw, introducing Labour's 10-year plan, said that his record on crime was "the best of any incoming government for 50 years". Sounds impressive. Ms Widdecombe countered that the Tory record from 1993-97 was the best four-year performance any outgoing government could show. Also, relatively, true. But what voter can begin to absorb, let alone believe, either statement, when every party is busy culling statistics to show that things have never been better, or, alternatively, worse in an area of policy where, depending when you start and what you cover and how you exclude and where you shade the figures, both claims are defensible?

Is crime going up? It depends what you're talking about. My colleagues Polly Toynbee and David Walker, in their valuable audit of the government, Did Things Get Better? (Penguin £6.99) take a shot at it. Burglary? Down 21% in 2000. Car thefts? Down 15%, along with a 16% fall in thefts from cars. Crimes of violence fell by 4%. But street robbery? Up 14%. Clear-up rates? "Haven't improved since 1997", according to a worried memo from Straw's political adviser leaked this weekend. Ah, but what about convictions? "Up by 13%," according to Straw on the Today programme yesterday.

Such statistics will fly about in the coming weeks. For the Tories are determined to make crime one of the biggest issues. It's one of the few they've got, perhaps the only one where the glass of governance will always reliably be seen as half empty not half full. For every stat, there may be an explanation that qualifies its meaning, as the Home Office's own research department often shows. What, why, when, where, how? You could write a book on each question applied to every crime, and people do. But in the politics of law and order, sophistication, however true, will always be outgunned by simplicity, however false.

This is made easier by public ignorance. In 1998 the British Crime Survey reported that the public thought judges' sentencing was too lenient. Four out of five people believed they were out of touch with what "ordinary people think". Questioned further, these ordinary people proved startlingly uninformed. Over half underestimated by at least 30% the sentences that were actually handed out. They believed half of male rapists were sent to prison, whereas the actual figure was 97%. House burglars and muggers were similarly thought to be let off, when well over half in each category went to jail. Such are the sometimes grotesque misperceptions on which the reputation of the judiciary as a soft touch is based. Yet that's the image brainlessly cultivated by the tabloid press, which then finds its inescapable way into the critique and policies of ministers.

These policies are not always foolish. Serious experts are always trying to get to grips with the aberrations of social and human behaviour. The Thatcher-Major government passed a criminal justice act every year for so long that the later statutes began to undo what the earlier ones had done. The Blair government has a mixed record with its own creative initiatives. Both curfew orders and anti-social behaviour orders, much brooded on and ostensibly reasonable, have failed to convince the people in the courts and on the ground, and have come to almost nothing.

The latest proposed reforms also have something to be said for them. Explicitly permitting judges to take account of previous convictions when settling a sentence is a rational idea. It addresses the prime problem thrown up by the latest fashionable analysis, the familiar theme that much crime is committed by no more than 100,000 people. The package looks like serious action. It's intended to be so. It should spin well, though the Tories will, as easily and bewilderingly, spin against it.

But through the murk and counter-murk three conclusions stare out, which confront ministers and their opponents with challenges that spinning doesn't adequately address. First, the best things the government wants to try will cost money. Yesterday's package is priced at £700m. Can this be enough to create the new custodial and semi-custodial regimes ministers talk of, pay courts to work twice as hard to accelerate hearings, and seriously increase police manpower all over the country?

Of all remedies for deterrence and detection, common across all these confusing stats and counter-stats, a bigger police force is by far the most persuasive. Quite why Straw has so conspicuously failed to keep promises about police recruitment is a complicated mystery. It may not be entirely about money. But money will help. Is the Treasury committed to providing it for this vastly ambitious programme? Or are we watching mere propaganda sufficient unto May 3?

Second, though Straw, to show his all-round vision, stressed the causes of crime as much as crime itself, and commended the government's education and employment programmes, there's a hole at the heart of the picture. While offering drugs as an explanation for such crime problems as he will admit to, he won't address the drug laws as a focus for reform, despite pressure and expert argument from those who are just as concerned and responsible as politicians. Decriminalising cannabis would wipe out a certain amount of crime at a stroke, freeing up police and courts for other priorities. The spinners dare not look at it.

Third, they dictate that prisons must go on blithely multiplying. Two of the less disputable current statistics are a) that Britain has the highest proportion of its population in prison of any country in Europe, and b) that, in a league table of crime as experienced by victims, England and Wales, with 58 crimes per 100 inhabitants, came out joint first in the industrialised world. No accountable politician is willing to make a connection between these profoundly interesting trends. The lord chief justice, the inspector of prisons, and the director of the prison service have all recently delivered clinical and passionate critiques of prison. The electoral auctioneers dare not change the terms of the debate.

One reason for this is that spinners can only deal with the lowest denominator of opinion, however ignorant. But the spinner always, more or less, lies. A more fruitful approach is available. The beginning of wisdom in the politics of law and order would be to understand that, since nobody can sort out one spinner from another, someone might start the arduous business of addressing the truth.

fields.headline: Tough and tender
fields.standfirst: But Labour refuses to cut prison numbers
fields.trailText: Tony Blair became the first serving prime minister to go to prison yesterday. He visited Pentonville in London. If only he had gone before yesterday's publication of the government's 10-year crime programme, there may have been less emphasis on tougher sentences.
fields.body:
Tony Blair became the first serving prime minister to go to prison yesterday. He visited Pentonville in London. If only he had gone before yesterday's publication of the government's 10-year crime programme, there may have been less emphasis on tougher sentences. A criminal justice system in which three top professionals - the chief inspector of prisons, the prison director general and lord chief justice - have all in the last month emphasised prison's negative results, is still preparing for a further expansion: a £700m programme providing 2,500 extra places over three years.

The prime minister made it clear the Tories were not going to outflank Labour. He boasted about the government's tougher penalties: third-time burglars getting three years, increased penalties for drug traffickers, increased mandatory drug-testing, and "toughened up community sentences so breaches are more likely to lead to custody". There is a similar unequivocal message in yesterday's plan: a "justice gap" which must be closed by catching and committing more hard core criminals. But neither addressed the chief inspector's assertion in G2 this month that 20,000 inmates - women, boys, elderly, mentally ill, petty offenders - should never have been sent.

An election approaches. Do not expect politicians to listen to pleas for a reduction in the prison population, even though we already have the highest in Europe apart from Portugal. Crime may be falling but custody will continue to rise to slake the thirst of an avenging public. They are not as hardline as purported. But who stokes up the presumed public lust for retributive justice in the first place? Politicians of course.

To be fair to the government, it was not all hardline rhetoric. There was considerable constructive tenderness too. And, compared to its predecessors, considerable evidence-based policy making, which progressives can embrace. True to its old mantra, Labour has been tough on the causes. Its multiple anti-poverty programmes - new deals for the unemployed, literacy and numeracy schemes, truancy patrols, support for families under stress, neighbourhood renewal - are playing a key role in the drop in crime.

There is a coherence to their changes to the system: new coterminous boundaries for police, probation and magistrates; a reform process which began with the most urgent areas, youth justice and the crown prosecution service (CPS), which will now move on to courts, sentencing and the police. Just how abysmal it had become can be measured by two related statistics: a fall in conviction rates from 18% of all recorded crime in 1980 to 9% last year; and a CPS, in which even by last November, only one in five lawyers and case workers had access to a computer. CPS gets a 23% increase from April and probation 31%.

The plan contains three large holes, two created by committees - on courts and sentencing - that have still to report. The third is the failure of the government to produce a comprehensive strategy on alcohol, which fuels so much violent crime. There are plenty of ideas which liberals must watch: a clear desire to tilt the system more in favour of the prosecution; more use of previous convictions by judges and jurors; pilot schemes which could create two-tier policing by allowing private security firms to be accredited by the police.

Britain's crime rate, as last week's international survey showed, is among the highest in the world. But there is no need for panic: burglary and car crime have been drastically slashed by targeting. Robbery is rightly next in line.

webTitle: Panic felt across the west country

fields.headline: Panic felt across the west country
fields.standfirst:
Farmers fear the toll that isolation will exact

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: A thick line of disinfectant-soaked straw lies at the foot of the locked gates to Cleave Farm in west Devon. Beside it is a bucket filled with a pungent pink liquid in which feet can be dipped before crossing this boundary.
fields.body:
A thick line of disinfectant-soaked straw lies at the foot of the locked gates to Cleave Farm in west Devon. Beside it is a bucket filled with a pungent pink liquid in which feet can be dipped before crossing this boundary.

Such precautions have been adopted across the country. But for Cleave Farm, it is not a precautionary measure. It is too late. Cleave Farm has been infected by the same ravenous disease that consumed Burdon Farm in High Hampton less than two miles away. Now, it too is an exclusion zone.

As farmers in the area rose early yesterday to check their livestock for blisters in their mouths and feet - the first signs of the disease - they learned that another farm had been affected. One said he would be speaking for all when he said that their "stomachs came up into their mouth".

The local NFU group secretary, Simon Whattler, said a "thinly suppressed panic" was moving across the area.

The outbreak was discovered on a plot rented by William Cleave, a livestock dealer now at the centre of Ministry of Agriculture investigations.

Mr Cleave, 44, is one of the busiest sheep traders in the country and moves hundreds of animals to and from his 13 farms in Devon and Cornwall from all over the country.

Ministry vets have ordered the slaughter of the thousands of sheep and cattle on the 11 farms he runs in Devon. The two he farms in Cornwall are thought to have escaped the cull.

For the farmers in west Devon the reality of this outbreak began to hit home just about the same time as the fear.

Signs at the gates of farms indicate all there is to know; "no entry" and "keep out" markers have been knocked up hastily from old wood, the wording painted in red. Farmers are barricading themselves in, afraid of any contact with the wider public.

Mr Whattler said: "It is very near boiling point. People are very very worried. It's such an intensive livestock area. There are no arable farms in this area, every bit is covered with sheep and cattle."

Mr Whattler and other farmers are also worried about the psychological impact of the disease, which isolates farmers from their fellow farmers. The Samaritans have been briefed.

"We have to be very concerned about people's state of mind. The last thing we want is for anybody to do anything dreadful," Mr Whattler said. "Everybody shuts down when something like his happens. People will not be gathering at pubs or going to markets."

Driving along the Devon lanes, with their newly opened snowdrops, this isolation is evident. There are thick lines of straw at the gates of all farms as well as buckets and canisters of disinfectant, but there are few people and almost all the animals are kept inside.

At West Devon Meat Ltd, the abattoir in Hatherleigh, director Peter Bowyear had just finished the slaughter of 600 sheep and 40 cattle. There will be no more culls because the place has had to close down.

As they finished off the last animals, the workers knew it would be the end of paid work for a while. There is no insurance cover and they must go home and wait without pay.

Mr Bowyear said: "This time, unlike with BSE, there really isn't anyone to blame. We now have depression among the workforce."

The abattoir turns over £35,000 a week, killing 600 cattle and 400 sheep, mostly for export.

Just down the hill, Hatherleigh market is also closed. The sign there says "No implement sale on Saturday. No car boot sale on Sunday."

Like everyone else, dairy farmer James McInnes has been forced to hunker down and pick up most of his information over the telephone.

"Farmers are all distraught, They can't believe that after all that we've been through, that this would happen. We are scared stiff because this disease is all so unknown. There is very little we can do to avoid it. When I heard that we had a second case here, I thought this isn't just a one-off. We are just at the beginning of a proper outbreak."

Mr McInnes said the restrictions would take their toll on farmers. He worried for the sanity of one or two. "Especially when they feel they are locked at home. The market probably won't open for a month at least, so they have nowhere to go ."

fields.trailText: Film stars such as Leonardo DiCaprio, Sharon Stone and John Travolta who regularly smoke on screen are influencing young people to take up cigarettes, according to a study.
fields.body:
Film stars such as Leonardo DiCaprio, Sharon Stone and John Travolta who regularly smoke on screen are influencing young people to take up cigarettes, according to a study.

Psychologists from the United States believe they have concrete evidence that young fans are swayed by the image of their idol with a cigarette between their fingers.

While they accept there are limitations to their study, Jennifer Tickle and her colleagues from New Hampshire said their research found a surprisingly strong link between use by movie stars of tobacco and higher levels of smoking in the teenagers who admire them.

On the strength of the findings, the smoking pressure group Action on Smoking and Health (Ash) is asking the British Board of Film Classification not to give less than a 15 certificate to a film showing teen idols smoking.

Clive Bates, director of Ash, said: "We don't want to censor directors and actors by banning smoking in films by law, but we do call on them to think about harm they are doing.

"Hollywood megastars can find the best support in the world to stop smoking if they want, but for young fans the influence of their favourite actors could be the start of a lifetime struggle with nicotine addiction."

The questionnaire, in the medical journal Tobacco Control published today, featured 632 students, aged between 10 and 19, from five rural New England schools. They were asked about their tobacco use and also the name of their favourite film star. The psychologists then analysed the smoking patterns in recent films of the 43 most popular stars. They found that 65% smoked on screen at least once and 42% portrayed smoking as an essential character trait in one or more films. Three film stars - Leonardo DiCaprio, Sharon Stone and John Travolta - smoked in three or more films.

They found that those teenagers who named a favourite film star who had smoked on screen were more likely to smoke or say they were inclined to smoke. And the more their film idol smoked on screen, the higher the chance that the young person would be a smoker.

"This research shows a clear relation between on-screen tobacco use by movie stars and higher levels of smoking uptake in the adolescents who admire them," said the researchers. They added that there was no evidence that teenagers who already smoked were more interested in the characters who smoked in the films they watched.

"Instead the association between star smoking and attitudes that predict smoking (susceptibility) was even stronger among never smokers, suggesting that the influence of movie star smoking begins before experimentation with cigarettes. We believe this evidence strongly suggests that media portrayals of tobacco use by popular movie stars contribute to adolescent smoking."

They accept that adolescents may admire film stars who smoke because it fits their pre-existing concept of "cool" behaviour.

The results of the study, said the authors, "contribute to a growing body of evidence identifying media exposure to smoking as a major contributing factor in adolescent smoking uptake."

fields.headline: Independent Digital marketing chief departs
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Paul Simon, Independent Digital's commercial and marketing director, has quit after two years, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Paul Simon, Independent Digital's commercial and marketing director, has quit after two years in the job.

Mr Simon, who joined the Independent in summer 1999 to set up the digital division, is expected to leave after Easter.

It is not clear what his next move will be, although he has been linked with a start-up electronic publishing venture. Mr Simon was unavailable for comment.

Before joining ID, Mr Simon was commercial director of News International Internet Publishing, the now-defunct arm of News International, where he teamed up with ex-News International head of new media Richard Withey, who is now managing director of ID.

It is believed Mr Simon's departure is unconnected with the slated relaunch of Independent.co.uk.

Prior to his time at News International, Mr Simon was founder and managing director of United News & Media's online sales house TSMSi, which has now been absorbed into Granada Media Sales.

fields.headline: Soap powder sponsors Crossroads
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Soap powder Surf is to sponsor ITV daytime soap Crossroads in a multimillion pound deal, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Soap powder Surf is to sponsor ITV daytime soap Crossroads in a multimillion pound deal.

Surf manufacturer Lever Faberge has signed up to sponsor the soap, which is returning to ITV after 15 years, until at least the end of 2001.

Crossroads is being scheduled five days a week, at lunchtime and teatime, from next Monday, March 5.

The Surf deal was brokered by Carlton TV director of sponsorship David Prosser and Malcolm Grant of Lever Faberge's sponsorship agency MGA.

Creative concepts for the Crossroads sponsorship are being developed by advertising agency Lowe Lintas.

"We know TV sponsorship produces a variety of different communication benefits for our clients, and it is only just beginning to be recognised that product sales is one of these benefits," said Mr Prosser.

"Surf was the fastest growing detergent brand in the UK last year and we want to build on our recent success through an initiative such as this," said Lawrence Bates, Lever Faberge UK clothes care category director.

A Surf interactive online soap opera, Foam & Away, was launched last autumn by the brand's then owner Unilever.

fields.headline: NTL spends £5m to push broadband
fields.trailText:
4.45pm: Cable giant NTL has launched a £5m campaign to educate viewers about the merits of broadband, writes Jessica Hodgson.
NTL website: what is broadband?
fields.body:
Cable giant NTL has launched a £5m campaign to educate viewers about the merits of one of the most inscrutible terms in the consumer lexicon - broadband communications.

The company is embarking on a new campaign to convince consumers of the benefits of broadband, which will focus on benefits such as "always on" internet access and high-speed connections.

The marketing push follows a survey conducted by NTL which found 69% of respondents had not heard the term "broadband" and 31% thought it applied to radio.

Cable and broadband providers have been frustrated by BT's slowness in converting local telephone exchanges to enable them to receive broadband.

Despite being ordered by Oftel to speed up the process, BT has argued that it is hampered by technical difficulties.

"Cable covers 50% of UK homes. If one in two homes can get broadband, that is a huge market and we have to educate consumers," said a spokesman for the company.

J Walter Thompson has been hired to handle NTL's above-the-line campaign, which will include press advertising.

webTitle: Fischer's troubles an affair of state

fields.headline: Fischer's troubles an affair of state
fields.trailText: The problems faced by German foreign minister Joschka Fischer have repercussions internationally and locally, says John Hooper in Berlin
fields.body:
One of the Berlin papers, Der Tagesspiegel, hit the nail on the head when it said that the controversy over the past of Germany's foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, had become an affair of state.

Mr Fischer was in Washington at the time for his first round of meetings with the Bush administration just a few days after the US-British raids on Iraq that so dismayed many of the two allies' NATO partners in continental Europe.

Germany's reaction was as puzzling as it was unexpected. The present government stands clearly to the left of centre. It is a coalition between the Social Democrats and the Green party, of which the foreign minister is a prominent member.

It might have been expected that such a government would express at least some misgivings over an action which, as France's left of centre administration argued, had no basis in international law. Yet, for a long time, there was absolutely no reaction at all from Berlin, and when finally Mr Fischer spoke up, in Washington, it was to express his understanding for America's position.

The suspicion was left that Germany's response had been conditioned by its foreign minister's personal difficulties.

The Fischer affair is also, ultimately, about the morality of the use of force. His woes began when photographs were published showing him as a young man beating a fallen police officer during a street clash in the early 1970s when he was a radical, militant Marxist.

The whole affair recently took a more serious turn for Mr Fischer when prosecutors in Frankfurt placed the foreign minister under formal investigation on suspicion of having lied to a court. At the trial in January of a friend who turned to terrorism, Mr Fischer dismissed the notion that he had himself ever sheltered a terrorist. Yet a former member of the Red Army Faction has written that she once stayed in the same house - though not in the same flat - as Germany's future foreign minister.

In these circumstances, could Mr Fischer have credibly challenged America's use of force against Iraq? Perhaps he could, but would not the opposition, in any case, have denounced his response as gross hypocrisy?

The foreign minister's problem is that the rights and wrongs of his case have ceased to matter. If it becomes clear that the pressure on him is influencing the way he plays his role as Germany's chief spokesman abroad, then his days as a cabinet minister will be numbered.

But that is not, in fact, what Der Tagesspiegel meant when it said that his past had become an affair of state. It was referring instead to the background to the Frankfurt prosecutors' decision to put him under investigation.

Frankfurt is the main city, though not the capital, of the region of Hesse. And the head of the government in Hesse, Roland Koch, is under almost as much pressure these days as Joschka Fischer.

The Hesse branch of the Christian Democrat Union (CDU) is central to the lingering scandal of how the party was funded in the years when Helmut Kohl was its leader. Most of the reporting of that affair outside Germany has centred on Mr Kohl's acceptance of some DM2m in undisclosed contributions.

But compared to what it known to have flowed illegally into the coffers of the Hesse branch of his party, it was mere petty cash. For Hesse, the most widely accepted figure is DM20m.

Mr Koch has had to do a lot of explaining to show that he had nothing to do with his party's illegal financing. Unlike Mr Fischer, he has faced open calls for his resignation and even the possibility - for the moment, averted - that the election at which he was chosen might be declared null and void because it was fought by the CDU with "dirty money".

Though it is no doubt pure coincidence, the Fischer affair centres on Hesse. It was in Frankfurt that Mr Fischer was active on the far left and it was in Frankfurt that his friend went on trial for murder.

But political commentators have noted with interest that Hesse's hard-pressed premier has been among those in the CDU who have been keenest to keep the Fischer controversy alive. Earlier this month, it was he who first proposed a parliamentary investigation of the foreign minister's tumultuous past.

More controversially, one of his junior ministers, in the Hesse regional government's justice department, Herbert Landau, is reported to have held a meeting with the prosecutors before they took their decision to act. The prosecutors have denied any impropriety and insisted that there are sound reasons for considering whether the foreign minister lied at his friend's trial.

But the suspicion has lingered of a political motive behind Mr Fischer's difficulties that may even have constitutional implications. It could be, indeed, that the fact that the whole affair blew up in a CDU-controlled region - something which must have seemed to the foreign minister a gross misfortune - will turn out in the end to have been a blessing in disguise.

webTitle: Colombian farmers count cost of assault

fields.headline: Colombian farmers count cost of airborne assault on drug fields
fields.standfirst: American-backed crackdown on coca growers hits food crops and spreads resentment among the poor
fields.trailText: American-backed crackdown on coca growers hits food crops and spreads resentment among the poor.
fields.body:
Luckily for the students the village school was closed the day that crop-dusters, escorted by combat helicopters, doused the tin-roofed classrooms with herbicides. Their target was the swath of illegal coca plantations on the low hills around the village, but clouds of defoliant engulfed the school, the Roman Catholic church, and the fields of plantain, cassava and maize.

Miriam Rodriguez, a teacher at the school, said: "The effects have been catastrophic. They sprayed the coca, but they also killed all our food crops."

The schoolchildren complained of rashes, headaches and vomiting after the weedkiller fell. Nearby are half-dead fruit trees, withered maize plants and row upon row of skeletal coca plants.

George Bush will meet the Colombian president, Andres Pastrana, in Washington today as the biggest offensive against drugs ever released on Colombia rolls across the southern jungles and farmland.

The blitz on the coca fields is at the heart of Plan Colombia, a $1.3bn (£900m) strategy to cut drug production by 50% and weaken the leftwing guerrillas and rightwing paramilitaries who finance their operations with its profits. Official US figures put Colombian cocaine production at 520 tonnes a year, but analysts say the figure is likely to be much higher.

Guided by spy planes and US satellites, crop-dusters criss-crossed the skies of Caqueta state in the south and the Middle Magdalena region in the north last week. Flying as low as 15 metres (50ft) they were protected by helicopter gunships. Guerrillas of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (Farc) often shoot at the slow-moving crop-dusters.

The pilots, some of them US contract workers, fly up to five missions a day, spraying on average 3.8 litres of glyphosate herbicide on every hectare.

Senior Colombian officials say the operation is a resounding success: in the first phase, 29,000 hectares of coca were destroyed in the Guamuez valley in Putumayo state, a lawless region on the Ecuadorian border where nearly half of Colombia's cocaine is produced.

But local farmers and officials say crop-dusting has destroyed thousands of hectares of food crops and pasture, devastated the local economy, and sown deep resentment among the rural poor.

"Why should I lie? I had coca. But they've left me with nothing - no work, and no food," said Otoniel Urrea, staring down at his devastated smallholding in a barren gully stripped of vegetation.

Officials say crops are only sprayed after they have been identified as illegal drug plantations, but in high winds the herbicide can drift off target. Farmers often intersperse coca and opium poppies with food crops, making mistakes even harder to avoid. The effects of spraying are not seen straight away, but several days after fumigation, every plant in the affected zone starts to wither and die.

Farmers say that poisoned ground can take months to recover. Mr Urrea says coca was his only source of cash. The nearest city is Mocoa, 12 hours away down a rutted singe-lane road, and transport costs make most legal crops unprofitable to grow.

In some regions, the government has signed pacts promising emergency food aid and long-term development assistance for farmers who tear up their own crops.

Officials describe the Guamuez valley as a vast network of industrial coca plantations financed and managed by drug dealers. Locals disagree.

"It's not one person with a huge plantation, it's a chain of little crops," said Alfonso Martinez, a former mayor in the town of La Hormiga.

"The government has never had a serious social policy in the Putumayo - and they still don't. Two months after they fumigated we still haven't seen any aid," he said, warning that some peasants, despairing of government aid, were already replanting their illegal crops with a new strain of high-yield Peruvian coca.

"There has been a delay, but that's because we're setting up a social programme which is unprecedented in Colombia. We really believe we can solve Putumayo's problems," said Gonzalo de Francisco, who is in charge of Plan Colombia's social development programmes.

At today's meeting in Washington, Mr Pastrana is expected to ask the US for up to $500m a year in extra financial assistance, and trade preferences to help bail out the struggling Colombian economy.

With unemployment nudging 20%, he believes that the anti-narcotics campaign and peace talks with Farc both depend on social investment. He has warned that without greater investment in drug-producing regions, poor Colombians will continue to work in the drugs trade or sign up with the armed factions which have perpetuated Colombia's 37-year civil war.

Most of the first tranche of US aid went towards helicopters, equipment and training for the elite anti-narcotics army battalions leading the fumigation drive.

Troops from the new battalions patrol the roads leading into the Guamuez valley, but towns in the region are dominated by paramilitary groups. In La Hormiga, militiamen with hand-guns in their waistbands keep watch in the town square.

Late last year the paramilitaries launched a campaign of massacres and assassinations to drive out the Farc guerrillas, who had dominated the region for decades. Their success helps explain the lack of guerrilla resistance to the fumigation campaign in Putumayo.

In rebel-dominated Caqueta state, however, fumigation sorties have come under heavy ground fire, and last week an armed rescue unit - including US civilian contract workers - braved guerrilla bullets to save the crew of a downed police helicopter.

But the brunt of the anti-narcotics campaign has been borne by small farmers and Indians, said German Martinez, a local ombudsman in the town of Puerto Asis.

"If this is just about destroying coca crops and burning labs, no matter the price, then it's a victory," he said. "But if you don't tackle the social causes, the peasants will continue growing illegal crops. We shouldn't just be eradicating coca - we should be eradicating poverty."

But the brunt of the anti-narcotics campaign has been borne by small farmers and Indians, said German Martinez, a local ombudsman in the town of Puerto Asis. "If this is just about destroying coca crops and burning labs, no matter the price, then it's a victory," he said. "But if you don't tackle the social causes, the peasants will continue growing illegal crops. We shouldn't just be eradicating coca - we should be eradicating poverty." webTitle: Tributes flow for George Carman, a master of his art

fields.headline: Tributes flow for George Carman, a master of his art
fields.trailText: "We have come here together not to weep," the novelist Frederick Forsyth said in the heart of legal London last night. "For our friend George would have found that profoundly silly."
fields.body:
"We have come here together not to weep," the novelist Frederick Forsyth said in the heart of legal London last night. "For our friend George would have found that profoundly silly."

He was welcoming a varied congregation at a memorial service to honour George Carman, the libel barrister described in St Clement Danes church as "the most celebrated jury advocate of his time and probably of the second half of the 20th century".

Carman died last month aged 71, from prostate cancer. The turnout for him included the lord chancellor, Derry Irvine, 34 QCs, scores of other barristers, a dozen judges and Cherie Blair.

There too was a cast of non-lawyers ranging from Mohamed Al Fayed, the editors of the Sun, Private Eye and the Guardian to Sir Richard Branson, the comedian Ken Dodd and others whose bacon, causes or investigations George Carman saved in court, sometimes against the apparent odds.

They were the colleagues and ex-clients of "Gorgeous George", the supreme courtroom star who - as his friend and fellow-lawyer Lord Alexander of Weedon said in tribute - learned his courtroom tricks at the end of Blackpool pier as well as from the orators of history.

Mr Forsyth said: "There was nothing mean or base to the man. He was a master of his art. To his clients he was a staunch and tireless defender. To his opponents he was a formidable adversary but always scrupulously fair."

Lord Alexander said Carman, who was first a great defence lawyer in criminal cases, worked as a restaurant washer-up in his struggling years as a young barrister on the northern circuit. "It was on circuit that he learned to adapt his performances to different tribunals - above all to shrewd northern juries. He developed a psychological, almost instinctive affinity for what jurors were thinking.

"Some said he appealed to jurors with a conspiratorial nod and a wink. He acknowledged he had learned some of his tricks from the comedians at the end of Blackpool pier."

Libel cases brought into conflict the right of the individual to have a just reputation and the right of the press to comment truthfully, Lord Alexander said.

"The law is there to protect the individual from the juggernaut of the state. Great advocates have long been seen as vital in enlarging the public's understanding of this."

And Carman had broadened that understanding through "his simplicity of speech and ability to stir the blood".

webTitle: Gore's gains in Miami not enough

fields.headline: Gore's gains in Miami not enough
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: George Bush would probably have won last year's US presidential election even if the fiercely disputed manual recounts in four Florida counties had been allowed to go ahead, a new survey suggests.
fields.body:
George Bush would probably have won last year's US presidential election even if the fiercely disputed manual recounts in four Florida counties had been allowed to go ahead, a new survey suggests.

A review of 10,664 uncounted "undervotes" in Miami-Dade county published yesterday shows that Al Gore would not have gained nearly as many votes there as he had hoped, even if the vote count had been allowed to proceed by the Florida secretary of state, Katherine Harris.

The review, which was conducted by the Miami Herald newspaper, shows that Mr Gore would have made a net gain of only 49 votes in Miami-Dade. When combined with his gains in the three other counties in which Democrats pressed for manual recounts, that result would still have left Mr Bush 140 votes ahead.

Even that wafer-thin majority would have been enough to give Mr Bush the 25 electoral college votes from Florida and thus for him to win the presidency. President Bush, responding to the report, said yesterday: "Hopefully all the focus on the past is over with. It's time to move forward."

Miami-Dade county briefly began a manual recount late last November after the Florida supreme court authorised it to do so. But the count was quickly called off when Ms Harris refused to allow an extension of time to complete counting there and in Palm Beach county.

Mr Bush was declared the winner in Florida by 537 votes after recounts in Broward and Volusia counties netted Mr Gore an extra 665 votes.

The Miami Herald survey studied papers which had been excluded from the result because voters had not successfully punched a hole through the ballot. It found that 1,555 Miami-Dade ballots were marked in ways that suggested a vote for Mr Gore and that 1,506 were marked in ways suggesting a vote for Mr Bush. Another 106 ballots suggested votes for other presidential candidates.

The newspaper's team of 15 reporters and researchers adopted liberal standards in conducting its review of the ballot papers, allowing every dimpled or hanging chad to count as a register of the voter's intention.

"There were many people who expected there was a bonanza of votes here for Al Gore, and it turns out there was not," said Martin Baron, the Herald's executive editor.

The Herald's survey is one of several scrutinies by media organisations looking for a more accurate result than the one authorised by Ms Harris. Last month, a survey of excluded votes from Palm Beach county suggested that Mr Gore could have had a net gain of 682 votes there, while a Washington Post survey of excluded "overvote" ballots suggested an even larger gain for him.

The result from the biggest post-election survey - a count of all 180,000 excluded under and overvotes from Florida's 67 counties - is not due until April. The survey is sponsored by a consortium of organisations including CNN, the New York Times and the Washington Post and is being conducted by the National Opinion Research Centre at the University of Chicago.

Republicans said the survey was proof that they had been right all along, and demanded that Democrats give up their efforts to dispute Mr Bush's legitimacy.

Doug Hattaway, a former spokesman for Mr Gore, acknowledged that the Miami Herald survey suggests that the Democrats may have been wrong to focus their Florida recount strategy on just four counties rather than all 67.

fields.headline: Yesterday in Parliament
fields.standfirst: Special report: parliament
fields.trailText: The day in Parliament
fields.body:
Bad day

Lord Falconer. Not only did the Tories call for his resignation for "mind-blowing incompetence" over the dome, but he was forced to admit to an error which led to a government bill receiving its third reading for the second time in the Lords. Peers had passed the regulatory reform bill but Lord Falconer had failed to move the so-called privilege amendment, which acknowledges MPs' control of public expenditure.

Admission of day

Tony Benn. In an interview with Radio Times he admitted being completely taken in by the infamous Ali G interview with him. "Even after I left the studio I thought it was genuine." But he was a little suspicious "when he said Margaret Thatcher was a communist".

Today

Commons: Foreign Office questions. Hunting bill, remaining stages. Lords: social security fraud bill, report.

webTitle: Cabinet cancelled for Hungarian PM's football training

fields.headline: Cabinet cancelled for PM's football training
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Football
fields.trailText: Today's weekly cabinet meeting - at which Hungary's senior ministers were due to discuss pressing affairs of state - has been cancelled due to a clash of fixtures: the prime minister, Viktor Orban, is away playing football for his local team.
fields.body:
Today's weekly cabinet meeting - at which Hungary's senior ministers were due to discuss pressing affairs of state - has been cancelled due to a clash of fixtures: the prime minister, Viktor Orban, is away playing football for his local team.

Mr Orban, 37, one of Europe's youngest leaders, has always believed in preserving a sense of proportion about his country's politics. His commitment to his team mates in Felcsut as a midfielder, however, is beyond question.

Yesterday, the prime minister's office in the capital, Budapest, confirmed that the country's leader had been on holiday since Friday and will not be back in his office to attend to government duties until Thursday. Citing security reasons, the spokesman declined to say in which country Mr Orban was practising.

But Tibor Navracsics, an adviser to the prime minister, confirmed that today's cabinet meeting would not take place.

A report in Blikk, a Hungarian newspaper, insists Mr Orban is in Croatia, at a soccer training camp organised by Felcsut. The newspaper quoted the Felcsut goalkeeper, Attila Grof, who said they were playing in Porec, on Croatia's Dalmatian coast.

Felcsut is a smalltown where Mr Orban spent much of his childhood. The Felcsut team is in a Hungarian amateur league and the prime minister regularly plays for them.

Despite being elected in May 1998, enduring a heavy workload and sharing parental responsibilities for four children, Mr Orban has managed to keep up his appearances on the soccer pitch.

In 1999, a team of British - mostly backbench and Labour - MPs were surprised to find themselves playing (and losing 2-0) to a Hungarian team including the prime minister and the interior minister.

Most of the Hungarians were conservatives, from Mr Orban's Young Democrats-Hungarian Civic Party (Fidesz-MPP). The party originally had an upper age-limit of 35, but adapted this as its leaders moved towards middle age.

webTitle: EU ministers sign treaty but defence plan rankles

fields.headline: EU ministers sign treaty but defence plan rankles
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: EU foreign ministers yesterday paved the way for the bloc to take in up to 12 new member states in the next decade amid increasingly bitter arguments over Europe's nascent defence capability.
fields.byline: Andrew Osborn in Brussels and Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
EU foreign ministers yesterday paved the way for the bloc to take in up to 12 new member states in the next decade amid increasingly bitter arguments over Europe's nascent defence capability.

Though the landmark Treaty of Nice, agreed by European Union heads of government in December and signed yesterday, details the form that a larger and more flexible union will take when countries such as Poland and Hungary join, perhaps its most contentious passage concerns the vexed issue of defence cooperation.

Robin Cook and his EU counterparts yesterday abandoned their monthly meeting in Brussels mid-afternoon and flew to Nice to formally sign on the dotted line, all too aware of the long-term arguments over whether Europe's new defence capability will undermine Nato.

Not that the rest of the treaty was plain sailing or uncontroversial. Differences over how many votes each country should have when it comes to crunch EU decision-making continue to rankle and Tony Blair had to fight hard to keep the national veto on tax policy.

The ceremony yesterday went smoothly, however, and did not overrun its scheduled 45-minute slottoo greatly.

Everyone signed and listened politely as president of the European commission, Romano Prodi, the French president, Jacques Chirac, and the French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, gave short, worthy speeches. But no one wanted to talk about defence.

At a joint press conference with Tony Blair in Washington last week, the US president, George Bush, said the prime minister "assured me Nato is going to be a primary way to keep the peace in Europe. He also assured me that European defence would not undermine Nato and that the planning would take place within Nato".

Iain Duncan Smith, the shadow defence secretary, promptly accused Mr Blair of lying. The prime minister's case is not helped by France's insistence that the EU will have its own "autonomous planning system".

Unfortunately the treaty will do little to resolve what is essentially a partisan dispute. It hedges its bets by stressing the importance of Nato while simultaneously referring to the EU's "autonomous" decision-making powers.

If it serves to underline one thing it is that no one has yet agreed just how Nato and the EU will work together.

Phrases such as "the progressive framing of a common defence policy" sit cheek by jowl with provisos such as provided "it shall respect the obligations of certain member states which see their common defence realised in Nato".

The text then muddies the waters further by stressing that the EU's political and security committee should, where appropriate, have the power to exercise political and strategic leadership in peacekeeping operations.

In a phrase that will be seized on by opponents of an EU army it says the bloc should have "an autonomous capacity to take decisions and actions in the security and defence field". Littered with ifs and buts and apparent contradictions, the text does little to clarify the EU's new defence role. That is clearly an issue that will ultimately be decided by member states.

But where Nato does not want or need to get involved the treaty makes it clear that EU-led operations to cope with international crises, peacekeeping and humanitarian disasters, will be perfectly feasible. But whether individual member states get involved or not will be up to them.

The text of the Nice treaty will now need to be ratified by the EU's 15 national parliaments and the European parliament before it becomes legally binding - probably 2002 at the earliest.

But come 2004 it will be reviewed again and the wording on defence policy is unlikely to remain so hazy.
