webTitle: PM backs Brown in Kiley quit threat

fields.headline: Blair backs chancellor despite tube chief's ultimatum
fields.standfirst:
PM sticks to Treasury plan as Kiley threatens to quit

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Tony Blair last night closed ranks with John Prescott and Gordon Brown in their determination to force the London mayor, Ken Livingstone, and his transport commissioner, Bob Kiley, to "knuckle down".
fields.body:
Tony Blair last night closed ranks with John Prescott and Gordon Brown in their determination to force the London mayor, Ken Livingstone, and his transport commissioner, Bob Kiley, to "knuckle down" and work within the government's £15bn blueprint for modernising the Underground system.

In a high-stakes battle it raised the prospect that Mr Kiley might make good his veiled threat to resign his £250,000-a-year post - a move that Labour MPs fear may cost London marginals.

With both sides talking tough over who will run the Underground, Mr Blair called in his two chief lieutenants for what was billed as a "knocking-heads-together session".

Board members of Transport for London (TfL) reported Mr Kiley as "white hot with anger" at government obduracy. One member warned: "I am concerned that he may do something stupid, like resigning. That would be a major blow. The people of London would certainly react against the government if he were forced out. The Treasury has to loosen its grip, or there will be all sorts of problems."

On Sunday Mr Kiley, veteran of similar battles in New York and Boston, used an interview with BBC1's Breakfast with Frost to hint that the chancellor, Mr Brown, was the "Wizard of Oz" behind the scenes - stopping Mr Prescott from giving Mr Kiley "unified management control".

In a 17-page document seen by Mr Blair yesterday, Mr Kiley used the same phrase, to the annoyance of ministers who complained that 16 pages attacked their plan and only one provided "10 bullet points" as an alternative. Both Downing Street and the Treasury were dismissive last night, though Mr Prescott's office was more cautious. The mayor is calling a TfL board meeting for Thursday to draw up that alternative if talks remain deadlocked.

"We have gone a long way to offer [Mr Kiley] a real measure of control," said one high-level government source. "There is actually a way through, but he needs to knuckle down and engage - the 10 points he put out were really nothing."

Hopes that the pragmatic Mr Blair would break the deadlock in Mr Kiley's favour look increasingly unlikely - despite the damaging risk of judicial review or of resignation.

After the three ministers met with officials it was made abundantly clear the prime minister was not about to overrule the Brown-backed public/private partnership (PPP) model which Mr Kiley calls "Balkanisation" of the tube at an annual shortfall of £500m a year to be paid by the taxpayer.

It gives virtual ownership to three partnership companies (known as "infra-cos") that would be required to rebuild the network over 30 years - and take the risk. Mr Livingstone and Mr Kiley want to run the tube, and say the shambles of rail privatisation proves their point. Mr Blair points to the huge time and cost overruns when the public sector built the Jubilee line extenstion to the dome in the mid-1990s - barely one-fifth of the scale of the PPP scheme.

Ministers are angry that TfL has, they claim, been briefing against the PPP blueprint without providing a plausible alternative. They accuse Mr Kiley of demanding 51% control, then changing his mind.

But he is proving a formidable adversary. Earlier this month an agreement seemed in view because it appeared to cede control to Mr Kiley. Since then, the talks have gone into reverse with the government denying any such concession.

Downing Street said last night the talks were continuing within the framework of the PPP, an indication it was prepared to make only modest concessions.

"The PPP offers him an extra £7bn of private finance on top of big public money, up front, with a real say on the nature of the contracts, and protection against cost overruns," said one government official.

According to Mr Kiley, under the government's proposal the public would own the system but not control it.

fields.headline: Mother killed sons in 'living nightmare'
fields.trailText: A mother desperate for help killed her two severely disabled sons by suffocating them with a pillow after giving them a drugs overdose, an inquest heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A mother desperate for help killed her two severely disabled sons by suffocating them with a pillow after giving them a drugs overdose, an inquest heard yesterday.

In a police interview read out at the hearing, Janquil Turnbull told how she gave her sons Richard, 20, and Robert, 23, an overdose of temazepam, codeine and paracetamol before suffocating them.

The inquest in Newport, Isle of Wight, heard that Mrs Turnbull, 53, and her husband Ron, 57, had cared for their sons all their lives without help, even though both sons had severe cerebral palsy. They were unable to help themselves, were partially sighted and had a poor prognosis for life.

Mrs Turnbull pleaded guilty to manslaughter with diminished responsibility at Winchester crown court last year and was sentenced to three years' probation. A public inquiry is being held into the conduct of the island's social services and health authority.

The inquest heard that Mrs Turnbull was on her own in the family's house in Bembridge on October 19 1999. Mr Turnbull had left the island to look for accommodation for the family.

fields.headline: No 1827 Princess Stephanie
fields.trailText: I object. The Guardian is no place for royal tittle-tattle. But this royal is different. She's considered a rebel.
fields.body:
I object. The Guardian is no place for royal tittle-tattle. But this royal is different. She's considered a rebel.

Has she offered to relinquish her title and overthrow privilege worldwide? No, but she sings on pop records, models haute couture and sunbathes topless.

Ah. The face that adorned a thousand tabloids. Stephanie's turbulent life - she was in the car crash that killed her mother Grace; she's romanced movie stars and mothered three children out of wedlock - has greatly diverted the gutter press.

What's she up to now? She's fallen in love with a man who dresses in spangly clothes and heads a fading dynastic institution dedicated to the exploitation of lesser creatures.

A king? No, a circus ringmaster. Stephanie has fallen for Franco Knie, director of one of Europe's oldest circuses, the Knie Circus.

Was it love at first sight? Hers was a Knie-jerk reaction.

It must be the whip. Franco has vowed to divorce his wife, but pledges: "I will remain loyal to the circus."

What are the odds on Steph's new romance succeeding? Franco's on a tightrope. The Grimaldi monarchy was cursed centuries ago by a spurned witch, dooming them to misery in love. Stephanie's ex, Daniel Ducruet, was exiled from Monaco by her dad, Rainier.

What for? Ducruet was photographed, after a year of marriage to the princess, in flagrante with Miss Bare Breasts of Belgium.

Big tops all round, then! The other men in Stephanie's life have been as colourful: Jean-Claude van Damme, Man Utd keeper Fabien Barthez . . .

They sound OK . . . Michael Jackson.

Please, God, no! Indeed. The princess dueted with the melting-faced grotesque on In the Closet in 1991.

Likely future boyfriends: Billy Smart, John Major, Krusty the Clown.

Why we should rejoice: It's good to see a monarchy brought to its Knies.

fields.headline: I'm only here for the beer
fields.trailText: Two Pints Of Lager And A Packet Of Crisps | Langan Behind The Lines
fields.body:
In the world of Two Pints Of Lager And A Packet Of Crisps (BBC2), Will Mellor was never in Hollyoaks. Had he been, Johnny and Louise might have mentioned how much their friend Gaz looked exactly like Will when they were discussing how he was at home "jerking his gherkin" along to the soap with most blondes per head of population. Similarly, Liz McDonald was evidently never in Coronation Street in this other world, otherwise Donna would have mentioned how her mum bore a striking resemblance to the barmaid/slapper/woman with unravelled rope instead of hair.

Now, before you start marvelling at what a wonderful world that must be and how you really wished you lived in it - no Beverly Callard doing aerobics videos, no Will Mellor releasing cover versions of Leo Sayer songs - consider that the Two Pints Of Lager And A Packet Of Crisps world is also one inhabited by flimsy stereotypes cut out from How To Build Your Own Lad And Ladettes Funbook, who spout pseudo-smart one liners and for whom smoking a fag qualifies as a defining characteristic.

Sometimes, it's better not to try and be all smart and postmodern, especially if the rest of your script is chronically unsophisticated. The higher you raise your audience's expectations, the harder it is for them to forgive you when they hurtle downwards like a tea trolley on a mountainside.

Not that Two Pints Of Lager doesn't have any potential. It has some funny moments and there is the faintest twinkling of interesting, rounded characters. But the writing simply isn't refined enough. With another couple of years of development, Two Pints Of Lager could have been very good. As it is, it is all a bit amateur. The humour is too clumsy, the dialogue cloddish and, with the exception of Ralf Little and Beverly Callard, no one has really got the hang of comic timing. That proves to be a bit of a problem, what with this being a sitcom and all.

If Two Pints Of Lager was made to attract younger viewers to BBC2, whoever commissioned it should have just shot themselves in the foot (or in the kneecaps, for suffering commensurate to that of the casual viewer). More trigger-happy with the remote control than their older counterparts, it is hard to imagine any of "da kids" sitting through this turgid, immature show.

Of course, all of this would be fine on BBC Choice. Alas, being a central plank of BBC2's Comedy Night, Two Pints Of Lager makes the phrase Comedy Night difficult to justify.

Despite its title - which is irritatingly obtuse while at the same time worryingly reminiscent of Kenyon Confronts - Langan Behind The Lines (BBC2) was very watchable. Once you get over Sean Langan's strange resemblance to a Tweenie (only not fluorescent, obviously), his exploits in Afghanistan are genuinely intriguing.

Prompted by a desire to see if the anti-Muslim propaganda that we are fed in the West has any justification, this was the first leg of Langan's tour of Islamic countries. It started off well too. The Taliban he met were very friendly. They shared jokes, gave him cups of tea and even taught him to play The Afghan Egg Game. (It's a bit like conkers, apparently.) Such was their chumminess, we could even forgive them for having banned music. And probably Hollyoaks too.

When Langan got to Kabul, he visited the Ministry of Information. But instead of asking them what becomes of the broken hearted or why cheese, chocolate and butter taste better when they're melting (questions that you would expect a Ministry of Information to know the answer to), he had a bit of tense meeting. Afterwards, it was off to the Office for the Prevention of Vice and Promotion of Virtue. There, an official explained how Islam wasn't an extreme religion, how it was positively moderate and how "we're not mad". Then he detailed how adulterers are stoned to death and homosexuals are given the choice of a) being buried alive or b) having a wall toppled on them. I know what you are thinking - how not-at-all-extreme that is. If you're a Nazi.

The eeriest moment of all came when Langan visited the football ground in which the punishments were carried out, unsure of whether he'd see a football game or a public execution. Clearly he was unaware that at Old Trafford, you get to see both at once. But only if Arsenal are playing.

fields.headline: Whiff of puritanism as stay-at-home MPs spurn free trips abroad
fields.standfirst: Special report: parliament
fields.trailText: It is a most unlikely story. But it happens to be true. MPs, those veterans of the free lunch, the free trip and the free drink are uncharacteristically turning down "one of the perks" of the job in droves.
fields.body:
It is a most unlikely story. But it happens to be true. MPs, those veterans of the free lunch, the free trip and the free drink are uncharacteristically turning down "one of the perks" of the job in droves.

Official figures show that there are 652 free foreign trips going begging for 658 MPs - and there are only four weeks of the parliamentary session left in which to take them.

Details of the new puritanism have been revealed by the Privy Council office, which keeps tabs on MPs' free trips. They show in the last session of parliament only 91 MPs out of the 658 took advantage of all-expenses-paid trips to Europe. This session - which began in November - only six MPs have taken up a free trip.

Every MP is allowed to take one trip a year to an EU institution - either Brussels, Strasbourg or Luxembourg - paid by the taxpayer as part of his or her education.

Over the last year the scheme has been extended to cover a visit to any of the capital cities - from Athens to Stockholm - of the existing 15 EU states and the 11 countries that are applying to join the EU as well.

But despite being offered the delights of a spell in Prague or Budapest, MPs are not taking up their entitlement.

All this is a great disappoint ment to Denis MacShane, the Europhile Labour MP for Rotherham and parliamentary private secretary to the Foreign Office minister, Keith Vaz, who has been arguing for MPs to take up the scheme.

He even wanted to double the number of European taxpayer funded trips available every year - so MPs could go both to an EU centre and to a European capital of their choice.

But this was turned down by Margaret Beckett, the leader of the house, who is known to take a stern view of MPs indulging themselves in any fripperies - or at least anything that Joe Public might perceive as one.

Mr MacShane, a former journalist and president of the National Union of Journalists, believes that MPs are, sadly, no longer so keen on a wet weekend in Tallin, Riga or Berlin.

"Perhaps they are more interested in exotic watering holes in the Caribbean," he commented on the dearth of interest in the scheme.

webTitle: Hugo Young on the government's crime plan

fields.headline: We are kept in a spin over law and order issues
fields.standfirst:
Expect more contrary statistics on crime to fly about in the coming weeks

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Expect more contrary statistics on crime to fly about in the coming weeks.
fields.body:
The politics of law and order are entirely about spin. Not just partly. Entirely. There is no field of political conflict where impression more fully eclipses reality. The two may not always be at odds. Some impressions are correct. Crime has doubled over the last 20 years, for example. That is a fact. Politicians' belief that the public wants only heavier sentencing is another truth that's not entirely fanciful. But the raw material Jack Straw and Ann Widdecombe are handling when they promote this as an election issue is not fact but propaganda, otherwise known as spin.

Consider the opening bids made yesterday. Mr Straw, introducing Labour's 10-year plan, said that his record on crime was "the best of any incoming government for 50 years". Sounds impressive. Ms Widdecombe countered that the Tory record from 1993-97 was the best four-year performance any outgoing government could show. Also, relatively, true. But what voter can begin to absorb, let alone believe, either statement, when every party is busy culling statistics to show that things have never been better, or, alternatively, worse in an area of policy where, depending when you start and what you cover and how you exclude and where you shade the figures, both claims are defensible?

Is crime going up? It depends what you're talking about. My colleagues Polly Toynbee and David Walker, in their valuable audit of the government, Did Things Get Better? (Penguin £6.99) take a shot at it. Burglary? Down 21% in 2000. Car thefts? Down 15%, along with a 16% fall in thefts from cars. Crimes of violence fell by 4%. But street robbery? Up 14%. Clear-up rates? "Haven't improved since 1997", according to a worried memo from Straw's political adviser leaked this weekend. Ah, but what about convictions? "Up by 13%," according to Straw on the Today programme yesterday.

Such statistics will fly about in the coming weeks. For the Tories are determined to make crime one of the biggest issues. It's one of the few they've got, perhaps the only one where the glass of governance will always reliably be seen as half empty not half full. For every stat, there may be an explanation that qualifies its meaning, as the Home Office's own research department often shows. What, why, when, where, how? You could write a book on each question applied to every crime, and people do. But in the politics of law and order, sophistication, however true, will always be outgunned by simplicity, however false.

This is made easier by public ignorance. In 1998 the British Crime Survey reported that the public thought judges' sentencing was too lenient. Four out of five people believed they were out of touch with what "ordinary people think". Questioned further, these ordinary people proved startlingly uninformed. Over half underestimated by at least 30% the sentences that were actually handed out. They believed half of male rapists were sent to prison, whereas the actual figure was 97%. House burglars and muggers were similarly thought to be let off, when well over half in each category went to jail. Such are the sometimes grotesque misperceptions on which the reputation of the judiciary as a soft touch is based. Yet that's the image brainlessly cultivated by the tabloid press, which then finds its inescapable way into the critique and policies of ministers.

These policies are not always foolish. Serious experts are always trying to get to grips with the aberrations of social and human behaviour. The Thatcher-Major government passed a criminal justice act every year for so long that the later statutes began to undo what the earlier ones had done. The Blair government has a mixed record with its own creative initiatives. Both curfew orders and anti-social behaviour orders, much brooded on and ostensibly reasonable, have failed to convince the people in the courts and on the ground, and have come to almost nothing.

The latest proposed reforms also have something to be said for them. Explicitly permitting judges to take account of previous convictions when settling a sentence is a rational idea. It addresses the prime problem thrown up by the latest fashionable analysis, the familiar theme that much crime is committed by no more than 100,000 people. The package looks like serious action. It's intended to be so. It should spin well, though the Tories will, as easily and bewilderingly, spin against it.

But through the murk and counter-murk three conclusions stare out, which confront ministers and their opponents with challenges that spinning doesn't adequately address. First, the best things the government wants to try will cost money. Yesterday's package is priced at £700m. Can this be enough to create the new custodial and semi-custodial regimes ministers talk of, pay courts to work twice as hard to accelerate hearings, and seriously increase police manpower all over the country?

Of all remedies for deterrence and detection, common across all these confusing stats and counter-stats, a bigger police force is by far the most persuasive. Quite why Straw has so conspicuously failed to keep promises about police recruitment is a complicated mystery. It may not be entirely about money. But money will help. Is the Treasury committed to providing it for this vastly ambitious programme? Or are we watching mere propaganda sufficient unto May 3?

Second, though Straw, to show his all-round vision, stressed the causes of crime as much as crime itself, and commended the government's education and employment programmes, there's a hole at the heart of the picture. While offering drugs as an explanation for such crime problems as he will admit to, he won't address the drug laws as a focus for reform, despite pressure and expert argument from those who are just as concerned and responsible as politicians. Decriminalising cannabis would wipe out a certain amount of crime at a stroke, freeing up police and courts for other priorities. The spinners dare not look at it.

Third, they dictate that prisons must go on blithely multiplying. Two of the less disputable current statistics are a) that Britain has the highest proportion of its population in prison of any country in Europe, and b) that, in a league table of crime as experienced by victims, England and Wales, with 58 crimes per 100 inhabitants, came out joint first in the industrialised world. No accountable politician is willing to make a connection between these profoundly interesting trends. The lord chief justice, the inspector of prisons, and the director of the prison service have all recently delivered clinical and passionate critiques of prison. The electoral auctioneers dare not change the terms of the debate.

One reason for this is that spinners can only deal with the lowest denominator of opinion, however ignorant. But the spinner always, more or less, lies. A more fruitful approach is available. The beginning of wisdom in the politics of law and order would be to understand that, since nobody can sort out one spinner from another, someone might start the arduous business of addressing the truth.

Of all remedies for deterrence and detection, common across all these confusing stats and counter-stats, a bigger police force is by far the most persuasive. Quite why Straw has so conspicuously failed to keep promises about police recruitment is a complicated mystery. It may not be entirely about money. But money will help. Is the Treasury committed to providing it for this vastly ambitious programme? Or are we watching mere propaganda sufficient unto May 3? Second, though Straw, to show his all-round vision, stressed the causes of crime as much as crime itself, and commended the government's education and employment programmes, there's a hole at the heart of the picture. While offering drugs as an explanation for such crime problems as he will admit to, he won't address the drug laws as a focus for reform, despite pressure and expert argument from those who are just as concerned and responsible as politicians. Decriminalising cannabis would wipe out a certain amount of crime at a stroke, freeing up police and courts for other priorities. The spinners dare not look at it. Third, they dictate that prisons must go on blithely multiplying. Two of the less disputable current statistics are a) that Britain has the highest proportion of its population in prison of any country in Europe, and b) that, in a league table of crime as experienced by victims, England and Wales, with 58 crimes per 100 inhabitants, came out joint first in the industrialised world. No accountable politician is willing to make a connection between these profoundly interesting trends. The lord chief justice, the inspector of prisons, and the director of the prison service have all recently delivered clinical and passionate critiques of prison. The electoral auctioneers dare not change the terms of the debate. One reason for this is that spinners can only deal with the lowest denominator of opinion, however ignorant. But the spinner always, more or less, lies. A more fruitful approach is available. The beginning of wisdom in the politics of law and order would be to understand that, since nobody can sort out one spinner from another, someone might start the arduous business of addressing the truth. fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Bosnian Croats jailed by UN | Kursk 'sunk by its own torpedo'  |  Body identified as Kuchma critic
fields.body:
Bosnian Croats jailed by UN

A former Bosnian Croat political leader was sentenced to 25 years in jail for crimes against humanity yesterday, the first senior politician to be convicted by the UN war crimes court for former Yugoslavia. Dario Kordic, once vice president of the self-proclaimed Bosnian Croat state, was found guilty of persecuting, killing and detaining Muslims in central Bosnia from late 1991 to 1994.
Reuters
the Hague

Kursk 'sunk by its own torpedo'

A note left by a sailor said the Kursk nuclear submarine was sunk by the explosion of a practice torpedo, the Izvestia newspaper reported yesterday. Russian officials found the note on a crew member during operations to retrieve the bodies of the 118 crewmen in the autumn. Izvestia quoted naval officers as saying it had been written by Lieutenant Rashid Aryapov, who said the explosion that sent the submarine crashing onto the seabed was caused by the misfiring of a practice torpedo.
AP
Moscow

Body identified as Kuchma critic

Ukrainian prosecutors ruled that a decapitated body found near Kiev in November was that of missing journalist Heorhiy Gongadze, whose disappearance led to opposition protests, reports said yesterday. Opponents of President Leonid Kuchma accuse him of involvement in the disappearance of Gongadze, a critic of high-level corruption. Mr Kuchma denies involvement.
AP
Kiev

Shooting spree at Guam clinic

A former clinic employee shot six people at the medical facility in Hagatna, Guam, before being fatally wounded by police yesterday, authorities said. Two women were killed. The gunman later died at Guam Memorial Hospital while undergoing surgery, officials said.
AP
Hagatna

German joke offends Japan

The German ambassador was summoned by Japan's foreign ministry yesterday after the Süddeutsche Zeitung published a picture of Japanese Crown Prince Naruhito with a joking caption questioning his fertility. The picture of the prince and his wife with the words Tote Hose - literally "dead trousers" - printed over the prince's groin related to a story about the couple's lack of an imperial heir.
AP
Munich

webTitle: Leader: Donald Bradman was uniquely superior

fields.headline: A unique superiority
fields.standfirst: Bradman simply redefined the art
fields.trailText: It was a piquant juxtaposition. As England were whingeing that poor umpiring had cost them the first Test in Sri Lanka, tributes were pouring in to Sir Donald Bradman, the greatest batsman the game has ever known.
fields.body:
It was a piquant juxtaposition. As England were whingeing that poor umpiring had cost them the first Test in Sri Lanka, tributes were pouring in to Sir Donald Bradman, the greatest batsman the game has ever known.

Never have the banality of sport and its occasional capacity for transcendence been so starkly contrasted. The sour events in Galle will linger for a day or so; Bradman's deeds will reverberate as long as cricket is played. Statistics can lie, as Graeme Hick's career shows, but in Bradman's case they encapsulate a truth no one disputes: he was not merely the best batsman of all time; he was playing a different game.

Test cricket has been staged for 120 years and a par of 50 to 60 has been established for a great batsman's career average. Hammond, Hutton and Hobbs, England's immortals, are all in the high fifties; Bradman's average, despite losing five prime years to the second world war, was 99.94. He is simply off the chart in terms of both statistics and superlatives.

Bradman, as the mourning across Australia makes clear, had come to embody his country, especially as it sought to define itself in the inter-war years. In the 1930s, crowds would gather outside newspaper offices while games were in progress merely to watch his score inexorably click over on giant scoreboards. Because cricket matches - and careers - are long, the game and its greatest exponents can become part of the texture of life.

As national icon, he is comparable only to two other cricketers - WG Grace and Sir Garfield Sobers. As sportsman, his superiority is unique: if the golfer Tiger Woods can sustain his dominance for the next two decades, his achievement will merit comparison with Bradman's. Certainties in sport are dull, yet a Bradman double (or triple) hundred never was. He turned winning into an act of collective worship, drawing on the public's sense of wonderment that one performer could not merely dominate the stage but redefine the art.

webTitle: Freeze that can put motherhood on hold

fields.headline: Freeze that can put motherhood on hold
fields.standfirst: New frozen egg techniques cut risk of delaying babies
fields.trailText: Women who want to postpone having children could do so with less risk as a result of radical improvements in freezing human eggs.
fields.body:
Women who want to postpone having children could do so with less risk as a result of radical improvements in freezing human eggs.

However the improved technique is likely to increase an international trade in eggs and, ultimately, it has the possible potential for human cloning.

A growing number of IVF clinics around the world, two of them in Britain, offer to freeze eggs for fertilisation and pregnancy at a later date.

In some cases women are about to become infertile as a result of cancer treatment; in others, young women want to conceive in their late 30s, when fertility is lower.

Since the first attempt in 1986, only about 30 babies have been born worldwide from such eggs.

In the journal Human Reproduction, researchers from the University of Bologna today claim to have fertilised 57% of thawed eggs - comparable to the fertilisation rate achieved with unfrozen eggs. Normally, an egg does not survive much longer than 24 hours after ovulation, inside or outside the body.

The team, led by Rafaella Fabbri, protected the eggs during freezing by reducing the water they contained, minimising the ice crystals that can pierce the egg's membrane and kill it.

Dr Fabbri said: "It is very important that we improve the possibilities for women to become pregnant after having their eggs frozen." The technique "will offer hope to women who lose their fertility through medical treatments or who may be at risk of premature menopause.

"It will also help to avoid freezing embryos and storing excess embryos."

Simon Fishel, of the centre for assisted reproduction at the Park hospital in Nottingham, one of two British clinics licensed to freeze eggs, said he received about one inquiry a week about the technique. He said that the split between medical and lifestyle grounds was 50-50, although so far only women facing medical treatment had their eggs frozen. None of the eggs had yet been used.

"It's certainly more reliable than in 1986," he said. "It's going to get more reliable because of the work Dr Fabbri and us and others are doing."

Mohammed Taranissi, head of the other UK clinic licensed to freeze eggs, the assisted reproduction and gynaecology unit in London, said that he and colleagues in the US were achieving results similar to the Italians.

"I think the main application for it now will be egg donation. I think we will see the development of egg banks along the lines of sperm banks. I can see this happening very soon."

Reliable freezing of eggs would also make it practical for a lightly regulated IVF clinic (there are thousands around the world) to gather the large number of eggs required to cope with the high failure rate of cloning.

Scientists in the US and Italy have spoken in the last few weeks about their intention to clone a human being within a year.

Last month the US magazine Wired claimed to have talked to an unidentified western European businessman seeking to clone his dead son with the help of a US-based cell biologist, an IVF clinic in Asia, five to 10 surrogate mothers, and large amounts of money.

webTitle: Major under pressure to disclose fees

fields.headline: Major under pressure to disclose fees for speeches
fields.standfirst:
List puts renewed spotlight on former PM after he declines to follow watchdog's advice
Special report: parliament
fields.trailText: The row over whether John Major should have to declare his huge earnings from speaking engagements was reignited yesterday when the new register of MPs' interests was published.
fields.body:
The row over whether John Major should have to declare his huge earnings from speaking engagements was reignited yesterday when the new register of MPs' interests was published showing he had no fewer than 11 expenses paid trips abroad in the last year.

The former prime minister was advised by Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner for standards, that he should lodge a copy of an employment agreement he had with the Washington Speakers Bureau - the agency he engaged to arrange his tours - with her office. She also said he should register his fee from WSB as well as listing individual clients who paid the fees. She cleared him of not registering the engagements.

But Mr Major, who gave evidence last week to the Commons standards and privileges committee, has declined to follow Ms Filkin's advice after speaking to lawyers.

A statement issued by his office said: "Mr Major has taken legal advice to ensure he has provided all the information required of him."

Mr Major's office said he had not submitted an employment agreement with WSB as one never existed, adding: "He does not think it appropriate to submit an artificial document."

The Labour MP Denis Turner, whose complaint began the commissioner's investigation, said Mr Major's latest entry in the register appeared to put him at odds with Ms Filkin.

"It sounds to me to be in contravention of the advice he was given. I don't think he is abiding by the spirit or the letter of the rules," he said yesterday.

Many MPs who were rapped on the knuckles by Ms Filkin last year have provided a much more comprehensive entry.

Ken Livingstone, the London mayor and MP for Brent, East, who was ordered to list all his speaking contracts, now has the longest entry in the book - running to two pages.

There is a long list of Tories with an interest in oil firms -headed by Alan Duncan, MP for Rutland and Melton and a trade and industry frontbench spokesman, who declares three expenses paid visits to Oman.

A number of Tories have also created consultancy firms. James Gray, MP for North Wiltshire, has set up James Gray Consultants, which lists a City software provider as a client.

Other Tory frontbenchers are making money through their literary skills. Ann Widdecombe, got £100,000 for the publication of her first novel.

More new organisations are offering MPs trips - Labour Friends of India has been particularly active while Glenda Jackson, the former transport minister, has been to Iceland to see a Labour revival there.

webTitle: Top footballers have longer ring fingers

fields.headline: Top footballers have longer ring fingers
fields.trailText: One day team managers might select players by pointing a finger. Researchers at the University of Liverpool have checked the hands of 304 professional footballers and found that the better the player, the more likely he is to have a long ring finger.
fields.body:
One day team managers might select players by pointing a finger. Researchers at the University of Liverpool have checked the hands of 304 professional footballers and found that the better the player, the more likely he is to have a long ring finger.

They checked the hands of coaches, and they compared fingers of the premier league with those of the three other football divisions. They reached for stars such as Ossie Ardiles and the late Stanley Matthews, John Barnes, Paul Gascoigne, Glenn Hoddle and Geoff Hurst and found that fate or an accident of birth had dealt them all the same kind of hand.

They also checked the hands of 125 men and found that success in other sports that needed some sense of spatial judgment - such as cricket and boxing - was highest in those with long ring fingers.

These men were compared with 532 non-footballers. They also report in the latest issue of the journal Evolution And Human Behaviour that winners on the judo mat, running track, hockey pitch, squash court, Olympic pool and the rugby field all had the same distinguishing characteristic: a ring finger that was long compared with the index finger. This was an indicator that the possessor was more likely to have good spatial judgment, good coordination and better physical fitness.

The link, said John Manning and Rogan Taylor, is testosterone levels in the womb early in the pregnancy. "There's a lot of evidence that the male hormone testosterone at that stage affects the developing brain and the cardiovascular system," he said.

"Our fingers tell us how much testosterone we have been exposed to before birth."

Two years ago Dr Manning found that men with the highest sperm count were the ones with the longest index fingers. Last year a team at the University of California at Berkeley found a link between ring-finger length and homosexuality in women.

Testosterone protects against heart attacks in men, according to some results. "Men with long ring fingers, if they have heart attacks, they have them later in life," Dr Manning said. "Women who developed breast cancer early, in their 20s, 30s and 40s, have long index fingers."

webTitle: Richest cabinet in history would gain from Bush tax cuts

fields.headline: Richest cabinet in history would gain from Bush tax cuts
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The Bush administration's generous tax-cut plans were put into perspective yesterday when it was reported that the new treasury secretary, Paul O'Neill, earned more than $56m last year as chairman of Alcoa Inc, the giant aluminium corporation.
fields.body:
The Bush administration's generous tax-cut plans were put into perspective yesterday when it was reported that the new treasury secretary, Paul O'Neill, earned more than $56m last year as chairman of Alcoa Inc, the giant aluminium corporation.

Mr O'Neill, much of whose income came from exercising share options, should feel at home in the Bush cabinet, which is by far the wealthiest in US history.

The cabinet is a veritable tycoons' club with seven of its members owning assets worth more than $10m (£6.8m). Eleven of the remaining 12 are millionaires. The pauper in their ranks is the agriculture secretary, Ann Veneman, whose property's minimum value is only $680,000, but then again under favourable conditions, her net worth could be as much as $2m.

The president has assets valued at $11m-$21m, including a sizeable Texas ranch. Much of that money was made while he was a manager and shareowner of the Texas Rangers baseball team, which benefited greatly from state funding of its stadium.

Twelve of the US cabinet would qualify as millionaires in pounds sterling. Among their British counterparts only the Lord Chancellor, Derry Irvine, could hold his own in such monied company.

The figures, which were revealed in financial disclosure forms submitted to the US Office of Government Ethics, are especially striking in view of the new administration's $1,600bn tax-cut proposal, which Mr Bush has set out to sell to a generally sceptical American public.

As part of that sales pitch, Mr Bush introduced an "ordinary" couple, Paul and Debbie Peterson, who he said would stand to gain $1,100 a year from the plan to cut taxes. However, the president did not mention that, on the basis of its latest tax returns, the Bush family would benefit by up to 60 times that amount, according to a calculation published in the Wall Street Journal.

Under the plan, tax rates on top earners would drop from 39.6% to 33%, while the lowest rate would be brought down from 15% to 10%.

However, many low-earning families would hardly benefit at all, because they already benefit from Clinton-era tax credits designed to help the country's working poor.

The US Census Bureau estimates that 3.7m US households suffer from hunger as a result of being unable to afford to buy basic food items. Many more, about 9m households, have "uncertain access to food".

The agriculture department reported last year that up to 12m people, including a million children, are eligible for food stamps but are not receiving them because of red tape, lack of information or family pride.

Meanwhile, families at the Bush-O'Neill end of the scale will not only benefit from income tax cuts if the Bush plan gets through congress unaltered. The proposals include the elimination of inheritance tax, which affects only the wealthiest 2% of the population with more than $1.35m to leave their children. The Republicans have dubbed it the "death tax".

The Wall Street Journal calculated that all but three of the Bush cabinet were rich enough to benefit from the abolition of the tax.

Richest six in cabinet of tycoons

George Bush, president: $11m-$21.6m

Dick Cheney, vice-president: $19.3m-$81.7m

Paul O'Neill, treasury: $62.8m-$103.3m

Donald Rumsfeld, defence: $61m-$242.5m

Colin Powell, secretary of state: $19.5m-$68.9m

Mitchell Daniels, budget: $18.1m-$75.3m

Source: Office of Government Ethics financial disclosure forms.

Asset values are given in the form of a range, minimum to maximum.

fields.standfirst:
With Peter Mandelson's £10,000 behind them, families of victims of the Omagh bombing, in which 31 died, are planning civil actions against those they believe to be responsible. Esther Addley reports

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: With Peter Mandelson's £10,000 behind them, families of victims of the Omagh bombing, in which 31 died, are planning civil actions against those they believe to be responsible.  Esther Addley reports
fields.body:
Victor Barker has not been consumed by it, he says. He goes to work, he plays golf on Sundays, he tries to spend at least half a day with his three surviving children at the weekend. "I would love to move on. But James is still part of me. And if I can't stand up for him, who else is going to?"

It is two and a half years since Barker's son James died. He was 12, a skinny, tallish, very dyslexic boy with green eyes and a love of sport. James was supposed to be caddying for his father on the day he was killed; it was his elder sister who was meant to be going on the day trip to Omagh. But she wasn't feeling well, and James begged to be allowed to go along.

James Barker died in the bloodiest terrorist massacre ever to take place on British or Irish soil. Thirty one people were killed when the Real IRA bombed Omagh in August 1998, including a pair of unborn twins, and 400 people were injured. Most of the dead were women and children. James had been caught by the full force of the blast and died of multiple internal injuries.

Victor Barker is not consumed, he says, but his anger and frustration are palpable. "It's not a question of closure, but I can't just leave that little guy as an image on the front of the Sunday papers and say, well, that's what those people did, let's just leave it. I'm doing this for James. If I could walk away from this I would."

After exhaustive investigations north and south of the border, the RUC and Irish police believe they know some of the men responsible for the bombing, but no one has been prosecuted for the murders, and only one man, Colm Murphy, has been charged - in the republic - with conspiracy to cause explosions. His case comes up in October.

A BBC Panorama documentary last October examined the evidence against four men from Dundalk, a small town just south of the Northern Ireland border. The police say that there is insufficient evidence to prosecute anyone.

The families have decided to take matters into their own hands. "It looks to us as victims that there will be no justice for us in the short term," says Michael Gallagher, whose 21-year-old son Adrian also died in the blast. "So we were forced to look at other alternatives." The Omagh families are now preparing to launch a civil suit for damages against four, or possibly six, people they believe to have been involved.

"We saw the OJ Simpson case and that came to a conclusion where the family got some measure of justice," says Gallagher. "You don't put people behind bars but you make sure that they can never escape it. Whoever was responsible shouldn't be allowed to get away with it just because they were clever in covering their tracks."

Earlier this month, Peter Mandelson, the former Northern Ireland secretary of state, gave £10,000 to the families' campaign to raise funds for a civil suit - the proceeds, he said, of articles written explaining his case in the Hinduja affair which saw him toppled from his position. The move was greeted with a measure of cynicism in the British press, but the families say Mandelson is the only person in such a position to have shown them consistent, genuine support.

The money will certainly be useful, but the families have a long way to go. Their solicitor, Jason McCue, a specialist in terrorism and human rights cases from the London-based law firm H<+>2 O, estimates they will need to raise £1m by August. Officially, the money is to be held in case the families lose the case and have to meet the other sides' costs. But privately, Gallagher and Barker admit that they have no expectation of getting any cash out of the men they are likely to sue. Win or lose, the case is likely to be an enormous financial burden. "I think those families have been through enough to risk losing their homes," says McCue. "But they are a determined crew. They feel that if they don't follow this up it will be other people next."

No one has ever won a case for damages against anyone accused of terrorism in this country, and McCue believes the case, if successful, would break international ground as well. There have been successful civil suits against unconvicted people believed or later proved to have been killers, however. In 1991 a High Court judge ruled that Michael Brookes had killed Lynn Siddons, a 16-year-old stabbed 40 times in 1978, awarding £10,641 damages. The original police case was found to have been bungled, and Brookes was later convicted in a fresh criminal investigation of the murder.

In 1998, similarly, a judge named Tony Diedrick as the killer of Joan Francisco, a doctor who had been strangled by a vacuum cleaner wire four years before. He awarded her family £50,000, despite acknowledging that there was "no direct evidence" against him. He was also later convicted and sentenced to life.

The option of civil action appealed, says McCue, because of the lower standard of proof required. While criminal convictions require the prosecution to prove their case beyond reasonable doubt, civil cases are typically decided on the balance of probabilities. It is not clear, however, under UK law at least, whether this would, in effect, be the case in a terrorist murder trial.

In the Siddons case, Mr Justice Rougier decided to make his ruling on the criminal standard of proof because the charge was so serious. Mr Justice Alliott, however, presiding over the Francisco case, accepted the civil standard, with the caveat that the allegation could be substantiated only by "truly cogent evidence".

At present McCue is reluctant to reveal the explicit grounds on which the families are likely to seek redress, beyond suggesting that "there would be personal injury elements to it, and other torts like trespass against the person. We looked at a combination of approaches, personal injury and human rights, and we have grafted a lot of those together." Nor will he reveal whether proceedings will be issued north or south of the border, or both, or against whom. "We don't want the potential defendants to have a head start."

McCue is far from bullish about the chances of a successful case against the men, but Gallagher bubbles with alternatives if this avenue should be a dead end. A Catholic, he understands the suspicion many in the nationalist community retain towards the RUC, and is even prepared to discuss the murderers of his son on their own terms, as soldiers. But this does not let them off the hook, he says.

"We have always seen what happened in Omagh as a war crime. It was an unprovoked attack on an innocent civilian population, and we believe that these people should be tried on the same basis as the people mortar-bombing women queueing for bread in Sarajevo." He talks of a UN or European police force, of trials in the Hague. "There are responsibilities for people who are engaged in armed combat. There are rules laid down by the Geneva convention that you shouldn't target civilians. So we have many options."

Barker, however, is more cynical. He believes there are political reasons why the investigation has not progressed as far as it might have done. Neither is he hopeful of any financial redress, not that that is the point. But as a lawyer he appreciates the particular benefit of a civil trial.

"I just want them to stand in front of me and answer some questions. In a criminal prosecution they can look at the wall and not say a word, but in a civil court we want to put to them what we believe they did to people's lives. The truth is that whoever is responsible planted a bomb and gave a misleading warning, to kill as many people as they could. If that isn't the worst kind of evil, I don't know what is."

webTitle: Ministers urged to review women's pay

fields.headline: Ministers urged to review women's pay
fields.trailText: The government will today be challenged to review women's pay in the public sector as a hard-hitting report finds that Britain's gender pay gap is the worst in the European Union. Thirty years after the Equal Pay Act, women in full-time work are still earning only four-fifths of what men do.
fields.body:
The government will today be challenged to review women's pay in the public sector as a hard-hitting report finds that Britain's gender pay gap is the worst in the European Union. Thirty years after the Equal Pay Act, women in full-time work are still earning only four-fifths of what men do.

The equal opportunities commission's equal pay task force will press ministers to compel employers to conduct pay audits to address the gender gap. Its report, Just Pay, will highlight Britain's place at the bottom of the EU league on equal pay. While women working full-time earn on average 82% of male full-time hourly earnings - up from 69% in 1971, part-time female workers receive only 61% of male full-time hourly wages, compared with a European average of 73%.

The proposal is designed to produce greater pay transparency in businesses, which can be expected to resist the measure on grounds of cost and bureaucracy.

The commission will also call on the government to lead the way in reviewing pay differences, on the basis that many low paid occupations dominated by women - including nursing, caring and cleaning jobs - are in the public sector.

The report will also find that occupations traditionally regarded as women's work are still undervalued in the UK, with women working full-time as nurses earning 6% less than average male hourly earnings. Other European countries also offer women better maternity rights and significantly better childcare provision.

The study, compiled by a task force including business leaders, trade unionists, civil servants and academics, highlights a problem which the government's women's unit has exposed but which ministers have done little to reverse.

A year ago, the unit published research exposing the "female forfeit", and concluding that women earn less than men over a lifetime not because they may take time off to bring up children but because of pay discrimination and their concentration in lower paid occupations.

At the time, women's ministers Lady Jay and Tessa Jowell stopped short of moves to compel employers to examine pay structures, focusing instead on encouraging girls to opt for better paid careers and urging women to ask male colleagues what they earned.

Today's study will confirm both that little has happened since to change the pay gap, and that business will strongly resist any requirement to conduct audits - a key element in the resistance to the move by some in government.

A spokeswoman for the CBI said yesterday: "We don't believe that the pay gap is actually the result of deliberate discrimination by employers. We think pay is a far more complex issue than that." Women had the choice of entering better paid occupations, she said.

The commission's report, however, argues that the pay gap cannot be explained by women's educational and career choices, since often as more women enter a sector the relative pay falls.

fields.headline: Trips, gifts and directorships
fields.standfirst: Special report: parliament
fields.trailText: MPs register their interests
fields.body:
Tony Blair

In the gifts and hospitality section of the register, the prime minister records a gift of tickets for four adults and five children for the new year celebration at the Millennium Dome. He also registers a controversial two-day stay as a guest of Tuscan regional president Claudio Martini.

William Hague

In a lengthy list of gifts, benefits and hospitality the Tory leader includes details of 13 occasions when he was provided with private planes and helicopters, including three trips on a plane paid for by the Tory party treasurer, Lord Ashcroft. Mr Hague also declares the "occasional use" of a Range Rover provided by chief aide, Sebastian Coe. Mr Hague records a trip to Israel last June in which transport, accommodation and flights were funded by the Israeli government, and overseas gifts including a hamper from the Sultan of Brunei (passed on to a charitable organisation), a case of Krug champagne from the Qatar ambassador and a pen from the Sultan of Oman.

After criticism that a charitable trust to which he pledged to give speaking fees was never set up, he pledges that any fees from speaking or other engagements will be donated to charity.

Charles Kennedy

Five paid speaking engagements are registered, without detailing the fees received, together with earnings from his book The Future of Politics. As well as rent from a London flat, he also records donations to his office from CA Church Ltd, a Salisbury accountancy firm whose head, Paul Church, is a Lib Dem supporter, and Dominion Press Ltd of Harrow, a company owned by Ramesh Dewan, a party member and supporter who sits on the federal executive.

John Major

Director, Mayflower Corporation PLC. Member, European Advisory Board, Carlyle Group, head office in Washington DC; Chairman, European Advisory Board of Emerson Electric Company, head office in St Louis, Missouri; Various ad-hoc speeches in UK to business audiences including paid by Chase Manhattan; McCann Erickson, Cincinnati Insurance Company and British Telecom.

Paid overseas speeches include: Jan 2000, Expenses paid trip to Dublin. Feb and early March 2000, Expenses paid speaking trip to United States to address business, university and public audiences. Feb 2000, expenses paid trip to Hong Kong. Feb 2000, expenses paid trip to Singapore. May 2000, trip to Berlin paid by Smurfit Group. June 2000, trip to United States, paid by Andersen Consulting. June 2000, trip to Hong Kong, paid by Business Week. June 2000, trip to US, paid by Muchlstein Group. Sep 2000, trip to US, paid by Comerica Bank. Oct 2000, trip to the US,paid by Siebel Systems. Nov/ Dec 2000, trip to US paid by American Trucking Association, Boys and Girls Club of Long Beach, Transamerica Reinsurance; Lakeside Foundation. Jan 2001, trip to US paid by the National Multihousing Council; Desert Forum; Salina Chamber of Commerce.

Some of the more unusual declarations include:

Theresa May , Conservative frontbench spokeswoman on education ,MP for Maidenhead. Gift of a Roux Brothers cookbook during a dinner at the Waterside Inn in Bray.

Eric Martlew, Labour MP for Carlisle. Gift of a model of an electric train loco from Virgin West Coast.

Mike Wood ,Labour MP for Batley and Spen.Sponsorship of Christmas cards by Kozee Sleep Bedding Company; Al Murad DIY and Controlled Demolition.

Peter Ainsworth, Conservative front bench spokesman on culture and MP for East Surrey. Piles of unsolicited classical LPs from the Peter Moores Foundation which could exceed £235.

Gerald Howarth,Tory MP for Aldershot. Gift from US citizen Ed Lemeo of 50 hours free flying time with European Flyers at Blackbushe airport.

Ken Livingstone received over £350,000 for both his nomination campaign and his election fund for London mayor, the register reveals.

His main donors were:

Chris Evans, media tycoon, £200,000; Gimpel Fils, auctioneers of works by Damien Hirst and other artists, £104,642; Neil Pearson, actor, £13,450.50; fund raising event at Hackney Empire (Billy Bragg etc) £6,000; TGWU London region £5,000; Fire Brigades Union, London region, £3,000; RMT union, London region £3,000; electricians on the Jubilee Line, £1,000; John and Maggie Webber £5,000; John Holder, £5,000; Reform Club, £1,000.

Frank Dobson received £100,500 in donations for his London mayoral campaign.

His two top donors were advertising businessmen Frank Lowe and electronics tycoon Sir Maurice Hatter who donated £25,000 each.

His other main donors were:

Iron and Steel Trades Federation, £5,500; Soho Spice Restuarant, £5,000; Barry Townsley, £10,000; Isaac Kaye, chairman of Norton healthcare, £10,000; Clive Bourne, £10,000; Sally Greene, theatre impresario and partner of dome bidder and Labour donor, Robert Bourne, £2,000; John Miskelly, £2,000; GMB London region, £2,000. Four donors also gave £1,000 each, including the Asian Business Network.

fields.headline: Parents 'sacked over working tax credit'
fields.trailText: One of the government's main weapons for tackling child poverty is backfiring against many of Britain's most needy working parents, according to an analysis of casework by the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux.
fields.body:
One of the government's main weapons for tackling child poverty is backfiring against many of Britain's most needy working parents, according to an analysis of casework by the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux.

It found workers were being sacked by firms trying to avoid the trouble of administering the working families tax credit, a government scheme to top up the incomes of low-paid parents.

In other cases parents felt "cheated and misled" when they found the extra income from the tax credit disqualified them from free school meals and help with rent and council tax.

The tax credit was introduced in October 1999 "to give working families with children a better deal". Together with the national minimum wage, it was designed to ensure that a two-parent family gets an income of more than £200 a week if one parent is working for at least 30 hours.

David Harker, NACAB chief executive, said the credit gave "a real boost to the incomes of many low-paid parents". He added: "But it makes no sense that a scheme that sets out to make work pay is making it more difficult for some people to stay in their jobs, and leaving some families worse instead of better off."

A survey of 700 case reports from advice bureaux throughout England, Wales and Northern Ireland showed employers pressuring staff to reduce their hours so they do not qualify for the tax credit.

"Some employers consider the administrative burden too great for them to manage. In a small number of cases, people have been sacked just for claiming tax credits," NACAB said.

It said a lone mother with three children was dismissed from her part-time job because her employer "could not cope" when the scheme changed from direct payments to delivery of the credit through the pay packet.

Other lone mothers had to give up work because "excessively rigid rules" made it difficult to take advantage of help with childcare costs.

Advice bureaux reported women reconsidering their decision to work and returning to life on benefits when they found their extra earnings were cancelled out by loss of help with rent, council tax and school meals.

Mr Harker said: "Our evidence shows overwhelmingly that people want to work and support their families even when they are no better off in work than on benefit. The government needs to offer people a choice to be paid direct by the inland revenue and to claim help with childcare costs when they need it most."

Together with the national minimum wage, it was designed to ensure that a two-parent family gets an income of more than £200 a week if one parent is working for at least 30 hours. David Harker, NACAB chief executive, said the credit gave "a real boost to the incomes of many low-paid parents". He added: "But it makes no sense that a scheme that sets out to make work pay is making it more difficult for some people to stay in their jobs, and leaving some families worse instead of better off." A survey of 700 case reports from advice bureaux throughout England, Wales and Northern Ireland showed employers pressuring staff to reduce their hours so they do not qualify for the tax credit. "Some employers consider the administrative burden too great for them to manage. In a small number of cases, people have been sacked just for claiming tax credits," NACAB said. It said a lone mother with three children was dismissed from her part-time job because her employer "could not cope" when the scheme changed from direct payments to delivery of the credit through the pay packet. Other lone mothers had to give up work because "excessively rigid rules" made it difficult to take advantage of help with childcare costs. Advice bureaux reported women reconsidering their decision to work and returning to life on benefits when they found their extra earnings were cancelled out by loss of help with rent, council tax and school meals. Mr Harker said: "Our evidence shows overwhelmingly that people want to work and support their families even when they are no better off in work than on benefit. The government needs to offer people a choice to be paid direct by the inland revenue and to claim help with childcare costs when they need it most."

fields.headline: Gene therapy halt on cancers
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Some of the most common forms of cancer could be nipped in the bud by a new gene therapy being developed in the US, scientists said yesterday.
fields.body:
Some of the most common forms of cancer could be nipped in the bud by a new gene therapy being developed in the US, scientists said yesterday.

Following dramatic success preventing tumours in mice, researchers plan to begin clinical trials in the next twelve months in humans.

Scientists at Jefferson Medical College in Philadelphia have focused on a gene called FHIT, which appears to play a central role in preventing cancer developing in healthy cells.

The FHIT gene lies on one of the most fragile regions of the human third chromosome. It is easily deleted by carcinogens like tobacco smoke and its disappearance is often the earliest genetic signal that a cell is about to turn cancerous.

The mouse FHIT gene is very similar to humans'. Researchers in Philadelphia created a mutant mouse, born with one FHIT gene missing, which invariably shed the other gene and developed cancer when given a certain carcinogen.

But when mice fed the carcinogen were given viruses modified to carry spare copies of the FHIT gene, the number who developed cancer fell sharply.

In one group of mice, after gene therapy, only three out of eight had tumours. The research is reported in today's online edition of the proceedings of the US National Academy of Science.

The mice were expected to develop stomach cancer. One of the things which astonished scientists was that the virus carrying the "good" gene was able to survive and deliver its cargo through the stomach. Getting replacement genes into the right cells is the hardest aspect of gene therapy.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: GP cleared over drugs
fields.body:
GP cleared over drugs

The General Medical Council announced yesterday it had cleared Peter Lindsay, a GP in Pudsey, West Yorkshire, of inappropriate prescribing of controlled drugs. An investigating sub committee recorded its regret for the considerable distress unsubstantiated allegations had caused him. Through his solicitor Dr Lindsay said he hoped for more caution in handling any such cases in future.

News of World pays damages

The News of the World apologised in the high court to Granada Television for suggesting it gave "VIP treatment" to five suspects in the Stephen Lawrence murder. News Group Newspapers agreed to pay "appropriate" damages to a charity nominated by Granada, and legal costs.

Dead climber is named

A climber found dead alongside his badly-injured colleague after a fall on Ben Nevis was named yesterday as Neil Stoodley, 31, of Bradford. The unnamed survivor was airlifted to Fort William. One of five climbers swept 100ft by an avalanche in the Fannichs, Wester Ross, was taken to hospital.

Man held over hit and run death

A man aged 20 has been arrested by police over the death of an unnamed nine-year-old boy struck by a car while crossing a road, in Hull, East Yorkshire, on Sunday. The car driver and did not stop.

Censors cut film rape scene

The controversial French film Baise-Moi was yesterday given an 18 rating by the British Board of Film Classification after a violent rape scene, which fell foul of guidelines banning any erotic portrayal of sexual assault, was cut.

New search in Lamplugh case

Police investigating the 1986 murder of the estate agent Suzy Lamplugh, 25, resumed a dig on a disused brickworks close to Norton barracks, Worcester, yesterday. The land was flooded when the officers searched the rest of the site in December.

Tarantula found on building site

A three-inch tarantula spider has been re-homed at a safari park in Bewdley, Worcestershire, after it was trapped in a bucket by builders on a site in Birmingham. The RSPCA said the creature could have been imported from South America along with materials delivered to the site.

Four in dog fight ring jailed

Four men who admitted a string of charges related to a dog-fighting ring involving pit-bull terriers were jailed at Mansfield magistrates court yesterday. Kenneth Langan, 32, of Portslade, East Sussex, Jeremy Brown, 46, of Chesterfield, Derbyshire, Ryan Nuttall, 29, of Mansfield, Nottinghamshire and Anthony Mullen, 43, from Birmingham were jailed for up to four months.

Leeds player on assault charge

Gareth Evans, 20, a Leeds United reserve team player has been charged with assaulting a 30-year-old man and affray after an incident outside the White Swan pub in Rothwell, West Yorkshire, on Friday night. Evans, who has played for the Leeds first team, and another man, will appear before Leeds magistrates tomorrow.

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: According to the "news" release from surpriseyourwoman.com, men are three times more likely than women to surprise their partner with a gift every week, while a third of all UK males claim to buy their women a surprise present at least once a month.
fields.body:
Sometimes, Sidelines is sorry to inform its readers, people tell lies. We know this because a survey has found its way to our desk, so ludicrous in its findings that it can only be entirely mendacious. According to the "news" release from surpriseyourwoman.com, men are three times more likely than women to surprise their partner with a gift every week, while a third of all UK males claim to buy their women a surprise present at least once a month. The last time Sidelines was surprised by a present was in 1997 and that was because it involved a pig.

A pig, however, is at least clean, unlike certain household pets. The cat and I shared an intimate moment the other night, when I was awoken by the sound of her vomiting delicately not far from my face. She had, it transpired, eaten a plastic bag. As I stuffed the bedding in the washing machine at 4.30am, I pondered whether I may have taken my small mammal obsession too far. This was almost as bad as having a baby . Was it, in fact, time to get rid of Mathilda? Should I operate some sort of points system, qua driving licence, for night-time sickness offences? Or would it be more humane simply to build the cat her own shed?

Fortunately, the next day a newspaper report offered a solution so obvious, I should have thought of it myself. The Wood Green Animal Shelter is planning a feng shui garden to put distressed cats at ease. The Japanese-style retreat will include water features, bamboo and pebbles. Nigel Mason, head of animal welfare, said: "Many cats come to us in a frozen animation state. They don't tend to respond and get left on the shelf. We want them to get out of the doldrums." It's the perfect solution: freezing the cat, leaving her on the shelf. If you need me, I'm just holding the freezer compartment door closed . . . just kidding, Mathilda. Though I must admit to a soupcon of equivocation in my normally animal-loving soul, having spent the weekend in the country narrowly avoiding foot and mouth disease. Model citizen that I am, I would not have broken the ban on movement betwixt town and country, were it not for a close relative insisting on going ahead with her wedding, despite the risk to farm animals everywhere. I had expected more buckets of disinfectant by the roadside. But I can assure the Ministry of Agriculture that I did change my shoes.

webTitle: Interview: Adrian Noble, artistic director of the RSC

fields.headline: Now buy the T-shirt...
fields.standfirst: Adrian Noble, artistic director of the RSC, sees life beyond Shakespeare. He tells  Lyn Gardner about his plans for musicals, the West End and the 'global brand'
fields.trailText: Adrian Noble, artistic director of the RSC, sees life beyond Shakespeare. He tells Lyn Gardner about his plans for musicals, the West End and the 'global brand'
fields.body:
Adrian Noble bounces into a Covent Garden restaurant looking as if he hasn't a care in the world. This is a man who loves his job as artistic director of the Royal Shakespeare Company. He has been doing it for a decade now and sees no reason that he shouldn't be doing it for a long time to come.

Noble is preparing for the opening of his production of The Secret Garden, the RSC's first West End musical since Les Misérables, a show whose success has effectively cushioned the RSC from financial disaster for the past 15 years. Noble may have wiped out the £3.5m deficit he inherited when he took over the company in March 1991, but a Les Mis-style success for The Secret Garden would be very welcome. Very much a new-style artistic supremo, Noble talks not of plays but of "product" and of the strength of the RSC brand. His latest wheeze is to sign the company up with Andrew Wylie, the man with the reputation of being the world's sharkiest literary agent. "Andrew is simply the best," says Noble. "He's brilliant. He likes the work of the company and we like him. People know about the RSC in every country in the world. We are a global brand and we create product that is of interest to a lot of people, and we are seeking a way by which we can find outlets for that work. It may be workshops, study aids or DVDs, but Andrew will negotiate the best commercial deals."

No doubt the RSC's massive This England cycle of history plays - which reaches its climax in April, when London audiences will be able to see the entire cycle performed chronologically from Richard II through to Richard III - will soon be available on DVD, all 1,413 minutes of it. If there is any project that symbolises Noble's reign at the RSC, it is this. Noble has been its architect and midwife, although curiously he has opted to direct The Secret Garden rather than any of the Shakespeare plays in the cycle. Noble doesn't find it odd. He thinks it is just part and parcel of what it means to be a Shakespearean company in the 21st century, a question he has been thinking about a lot. So what does it mean exactly? "It's a company that draws its inspiration from the Renaissance and provides us with epic, mythic stories but at the same time gives us a compassionate insight into the human condition."

In short, a company that is as likely to embrace a 10-year-old Broadway musical such as The Secret Garden as it is to offer Hamlet or Richard II or a little-known Jacobean revenge tragedy. As far as Noble is concerned, The Secret Garden and The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe, which he also directed for the company, are quite as interesting as any of Shakespeare's plays. In fact, he enthuses about the similarities: "Both draw heavily from Shakespeare. The Secret Garden closely resembles As You Like It - the story of a girl who is banished, enters a forest and through growing self-realisation brings an end to chaos. It is the story of all Shakespeare's plays from Henry V to Twelfth Night."

Certainly Noble sees both The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe and The Secret Garden, which opened in Stratford-upon-Avon before Christmas, as an attempt to change the audience profile of the company, particularly in that town. The RSC's presence sometimes seems a burdensome irrelevance to local people, who may welcome the influx of visitors it brings to the town, but who never step inside any of the three theatres themselves. "I noticed that The Secret Garden encouraged a change of attitude in the people of the West Midlands. While it was on, they regarded the theatre as theirs in a way that they often don't when we are doing Shakespeare."

Only one subject dents Noble's good mood, and that's this year's Olivier awards, in which the RSC received only one nomination while the much- maligned National Theatre had a clutch of nominations and won several prizes. "It is outrageous and unjust and in no way reflects the artistic achievements of the RSC in the year 2000. I've no more to say on the subject except that it's a disgrace, a real disgrace."

But apart from this cloud, Noble reckons that he is a pretty contented man. After a long period when it sometimes seemed that the RSC was controlling him, he believes he is now firmly controlling the RSC: "Change always brings opposition. But in the last couple of years, it has become a fantastic place to work. There are some very talented people in the company, and I now feel we are firing on all cylinders. When I think of some of the work we have done, I feel like a very proud dad. Over the next two months, we will be bringing an amazing body of work to London including This England and Tantalus, as well as a festival of new plays. It is only possible because we've been aggressively entrepreneurial. I am not going to apologise for that."

 The Secret Garden opens tonight at the Aldwych Theatre (0870 400 0805), London WC2.

webTitle: Leader: Gordon Brown fighting world poverty

fields.headline: Relieving world poverty
fields.standfirst:
You have to admire Brown's ambition

Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: When the historians of the future look back on the New Labour era, one question may intrigue them more than most: who was the real Gordon Brown, the Iron Chancellor or Red Gordon?
fields.body:
When the historians of the future look back on the New Labour era, one question may intrigue them more than most: who was the real Gordon Brown, the Iron Chancellor or Red Gordon?

As usual, the run-up to next week's Budget has offered clues in both directions. Iron Gordon insists prudence and stability will remain the watchwords; meanwhile his red brother hints at a pre-election promise of even more money surging into health and education. The City still swoons at a chancellor it admires for bringing unfamiliar serenity to the British economy; at the same time, Roy Hattersley comes away from an interview hailing Equality Brown, keeper of the old socialist flame.

So who is he, Iron or Red? Yesterday the latter Gordon appears to have gained the upper hand. For Mr Brown confounded the cynics by focusing his restless energy on a problem so large most politicians decline even to address it: world poverty. At an international conference hosted in London he called for a global fund to provide cheap vaccines against disease for the children of the developing world.

Next he committed Britain to a fund which would ensure every child in the Commonwealth receives a primary education. These were not mere rhetorical flourishes. The chancellor issued his clarion calls standing alongside the heads of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund. In a testament to his achievement, he also had the crucial aid agencies and non-governmental organisations in the room - and on side.

One cannot but help admire the ambition of the man. Not content with having mastered every nook and cranny of the Treasury - from which vantage point he all but controls British social policy - he has now lifted his sights to the global stage. He has seen the lofty UN target of reducing poverty by 2015 and decided to make it real. To have got both NGOs and the global financial institutions to back him must have taken some neat political footwork.

Of course, Mr Brown has to do more than set out noble goals. He has already persuaded the G7 nations to cancel the debts of poor nations - yet their promise remains to be fully implemented: the poor are still paying billions to the rich. Mr Brown needs to keep his counterparts to their word. But for daring to open a new front in the war against poverty he deserves our applause.
