fields.headline: Little black numbers
fields.standfirst: Can a woman wear these shorts any day of the month  and still feel confident? She can with the new black pantyliner.  Libby Brooks and  Nicola Norton ask what it says about attitudes to bleeding women
fields.trailText: Can a woman wear these shorts any day of the month  and still feel confident? She can with the new black pantyliner.  Libby Brooks and  Nicola Norton ask what it says about attitudes to bleeding women
fields.body:
There are agents of revolutionary change; and then there are Alldays Black. Procter & Gamble, the company who brought us wings and the dri-weave top sheet, are once again pushing the envelope of the sanpro market with the world's first black pantyliner. Sometimes, according to their press pack, everything just has to be black.

So, if sanitary products are undergoing a transformation from the functional to the fashionable, can we expect accessorised pads to become the latest "must have" items for style- conscious females in the 21st century? Maybe the design houses will get a whiff of this new development and produce their own "signature pads" so women can match on the outside and inside. But even if there is something strangely satisfying in the idea of discharging on to a Burberry or Louis Vuitton-printed pad, the whole business of glamorising women's bodily functions smacks more of society's dislike of them than of an attempt to provide women with something they might actually need.

In a further twist, the television campaign for Alldays Black was banned in the UK earlier this month, despite being deemed acceptable in 12 other European countries. The commercial shows a couple preparing to have sex. As the woman's dress falls to the floor, she is horrified to discover that her white pantyliner is visible through her black knickers. "Should have worn Alldays Black" sneers the catchline. The Broadcast Advertising Clearance Centre has refused permission for the ad to air, stating that it considers it "too sexually charged for the product field and therefore likely to cause offence".

The campaign is part of a push to persuade British women to use more pantyliners by breaking their association with periods. The UK market for pantyliners, which women use on light days during their period or to absorb vaginal discharge over the rest of the month, is one of the smallest in Europe. The reasons why are unclear, though one theory is that continental women wear more expensive underwear, which requires handwashing, while British women prefer cheaper cotton knickers that can be worn once and dumped in the machine.

Fielding Claire Rayner, blue ink and roller skates, as a genre, sanpro ads are notoriously risible. While menstruating is a uniquely female experience, its advertising is almost exclusively created by men, which begs the question, who actually wants to be protected, and from what? Much of the advertising is based on the premise that having a period is a debilitating state in which normal function can be restored only by a particular brand of compacted cotton. A period can never just be a period: it's shameful, dirty and a source of worry, or it's a time to get physical, ignore your body, wear white trousers and indulge in extreme sports. But while most women would agree that they don't necessarily look forward to monthly bleeding, the experience is hardly regarded as a handicap today.

So is it better to sexualise these products, as with the Alldays ad? "I think it's outrageous to use sex to sell a pantyliner," says Pip Bishop of Rainey/Kelley/Campbell/Roalfe/Y&R, one of the few female creative directors in her industry. While she believes the BAAC should be more flexible about the type of sanpro ads it allows on to our screens, she agrees with the decision to ban the Alldays advert. But what's the difference between using sex to sell a pantyliner and, say, a car? "Well, you don't need a car . . . "

Bishop works on the Lil-lets account and was behind their recent TV ads which depicted women making light of pre-menstrual angst. "The best advertising concentrates on what women experience, rather than how they look," she says. "A lot of women found the white trouser ads insulting. Women do laugh about the way they behave and what happens to their bodies when they've got their period, and we need to show more of the way they talk to each other about it."

For all our tendency towards immodest emotional gush, as a society we remain remarkably mute about menstruation. And beyond the coyness lie some worryingly anachronistic notions about what comes out of women, when and how. Literally and metaphorically, there is a premium on cleanliness for women, and we've become versed in presentation.

Women buy sanitary products from the chemist in a section marked "Feminine Hygiene", often found at the rear of the shop, near the nappies and incontinence pants. The prevalence of pads that are scented, coloured, G-string shaped, for all days, heavy days, good days, bad days, suggests that women's bodily functions require a uniquely intensive, but above all discreet, type of management. Then there is the language of sanitary protection; the excessive reassurances, the patronising euphemisms, the avoidance of the B word (blood). It all adds up to a convincing message that women's bodies, in their natural state, are unfeminine, unpalatable and in need of mopping up.

"I find quite repulsive the idea that women need to have their underneath nappy-fied," says Naomi, a 33-year-old solicitor. "It promotes the idea that women's bodies are always leaking. I think it's bad that we're being encouraged to wear pads just for everyday discharge. Of course you need something when you have a period, but it seems a rip-off to try to convince you that you need a pad all the time."

She is also unconvinced of the advantages of coordination. "Everyone knows black is the worst colour for showing things up, so why would anyone use a black pantyliner?"

Susie, a 25-year-old teacher, agrees. "I find the idea that you should wear one throughout the month insulting. It's disguising what your body's all about and there's no need. It does seem bizarre that it's more acceptable to talk about how you feel on the days before you bleed than to discuss the process itself. Pre-menstrual syndrome is now recognised as a genuine medical complaint thought to affect around 90% of women at some point in their lives, with a significant proportion suffering regularly from severe symptoms. Nonetheless, we should be wary of fetishising the more superficial, and less serious, aspects of PMS - how progressive is it to reinforce the idea that once a month a woman becomes a vulnerable creature not responsible for her actions? Doesn't that imply something distorting about the nature of femaleness? And why is it that anything that confirms women's inherent tendency towards the hysterical is always the more popular conversation topic?

"People still don't talk about periods in the same way they now do about sex or drugs," says Dr Sally Dibb, a reader in marketing at Warwick Business School. "Women are less embarrassed than they were, but it's still pretty taboo. In fact, there are far more products relating to vaginal hygiene on the market now, despite the fact that we are told by doctors it's a bad idea to use them. That shows we're still concerned about it. It goes right back to childhood. When a girl has her first period, her mother knows about it, it's a rite of passage, but it's not something to be celebrated. When an attitude is so deeply embedded, it's hard to break out of."

But perhaps part of this unease also stems from our modern dislocation from the natural. Scrubbed, sanitised and germ-free, we've become increasingly removed from the nitty-gritty of bodily functions. And while we fetishise the natural (organic! unbranded!), our experience of it is becoming increasingly mediated and containable: the plant extracts in our moisturiser, the biscuits in our cupboard.

As for Alldays Black, natural is not the first descriptive that springs to mind. In their packaging, black pantyliners resemble nothing more than a box of extra-long after dinner mints. fields.headline: Lord Irvine's future
fields.standfirst: What jobs could the lord chancellor possibly do when he retires in 2003?
fields.trailText: What jobs could the lord chancellor possibly do when he retires in 2003?
fields.body:
 Matrix Chambers was much miffed by the negative publicity it got over one of its stars, Nicholas Blake QC, taking a brief from Fiji's not very nice military rulers to argue that their overthrow of the democratic constitution was legitimate. Matrix was particularly incensed by Nick Cohen's passionate piece in the Observer the Sunday before last. To counter it, Matrix asked a number of respected human rights QCs in other chambers to put their names to a letter to the Observer, defending Blake. I gather that some of those approached declined, and no letter appeared in the newspaper.

But I've also found a backlash of sympathy for Blake, whose previous record as a human rights barrister is impeccable, with many of his cases done free, not least appeals by prisoners facing execution in the Caribbean. Blake, under the rules of the Bar, can't defend himself until the Fijian case is over, which may be this week. The odd thing, though, is that it has seemed in the past couple of weeks that Matrix itself has been on trial, and convicted.

 This is Lord Irvine's future: in 2003 he will retire gracefully from the office of lord chancellor. I know this because I've discussed it with many lawyers and politicians over several weeks, and this is the consensus. The argument is that he will want to go out on a high, and by then he will have achieved his aim of being regarded as one of the great reforming lord chancellors of modern times. He's already put away the Human Rights Act and the radical reorganisation of access to justice. In a couple of years, House of Lords reform will be well under way. That's when Irvine leaves, the plaudits of a grateful nation ringing in his ears, his peccadilloes forgotten.

Who takes over? That's easy. There's a general assumption that the current attorney general, Lord Williams of Mostyn, already the most popular and praised figure in the Lords, will become its leader after the election. But it's not really a job with substance, and he'll be bored with it in two years, thus making the timing perfect for him to take over as lord chancellor. There's only one thing wrong with this astute scenario. What would Lord Irvine do? At 63 he'd be too young to go into that half-retirement that awaits other top legal persons - the occasional government commission or inquiry, a few prestige chairmanships of high-profile societies or charities, a worthy book. I don't think he is suited to be a European commissioner; nor the head of an Oxford or Cambridge college, which involves a lot of fund-raising, though usually for more than £200 a nosh. The trouble is, I can't think of any real jobs he could do that would befit his status.

 This I have not come across before - a professional organisation objecting to its own members being offered good salaries. But this is what the Law Society appears to be doing. The other day adverts appeared seeking lawyers to join the new state-salaried criminal defence service and become public defenders. A solicitor with three years experience would get £30,000 a year. Unfair, moaned the Law Society - too much. That's more than similar solicitors make in private practice; it's all a government plot.

If you think I'm exaggerating, here are the actual words used by a Law Society spokesman, after pointing out that salaries were "much greater" than private firms could pay: "It confirms what we have thought all along, that it is an underhand way to destroy us." So what's the government to do? Offer really rubbish salaries so that only rubbish people apply? Precisely. Then, the Law Society could say: "We told you so. Public defenders are no good."

 Here's good news for American artists who want to depict Barbie dolls in sexually explicit positions: it's allowed. The toymakers Mattel, who own the Barbie doll trademarks and copyright, tried to ban Utah artist Tom Forsythe from selling postcards of his photographs of Barbie in poses not normally associated with her famously non-sexual activities. (Boyfriend Ken, I remind you, has no genitals, though Barbie could, of course, be having a secret affair with an anatomically correct doll.) Forsythe claimed his rights of artistic expression and free speech: he used Barbies to critique the materialistic and gender oppressive values the doll embodies. Me, I'd rather spend a day with Barbie than have to read the last part of the last sentence again, but the appeal court thought it was a jolly good argument.

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: First flowers of spring
fields.trailText: First flowers of spring
fields.body:
Cheshire

The spring equinox is still some weeks away, but a steady lengthening of the hours of daylight has not gone unnoticed in the valley. Despite a fortnight of temperatures down to - 6 C, heavy frosts and thick freezing fogs, the woodland floor is now carpeted with the first signs of spring flowers - leaves of bluebell, wood anemone and pignut have all appeared, and grow taller as each day passes. Some plants recognised the slow but perceptible change earlier than others, so that among the rafts of heart-shaped leaves on the long stalks of the lesser celandine along the river bank, many small golden flowers have already started to bloom; but as they only reveal their fully open petals when the sun shines, so far they have not produced that familiar broad splash of spring gold.

In the western woods the first flowers of butterbur, primrose, and the evil-smelling and poisonous dog's mercury have also opened, while tucked away between the exposed roots of a tall oak, a group of early dog violets continue to protect their bright blue petals inside tightly closed buds. A plant that has been in flower since late January, as it is each year, is the small shrub spurge laurel or Daphne laureola, which grows in the northern woods at what is its only site in Cheshire. Positioned in a high rocky outcrop overlooking the river, its ridged stems support a crown of fresh green foliage, while the flowers themselves are green and fragrant, each protected by a tubular waxy coat, and they produce a black berry in autumn which the early herbalists sometimes recommended for certain stomach ailments - "taken in warm water they soon stir the innards" - being poisonous they certainly would!

fields.headline: Take five: the daily news quiz
fields.trailText: Each weekday, we set five questions based on the news. Send in all 25 at the end of the week. The first correct entry out of the hat wins a £100 electronic gift card from Borders.
fields.body:
Each weekday, we set five questions based on the news. Send in all 25 at the end of the week. The first correct entry out of the hat wins a £100 electronic gift card from Borders (www.bordersstores.com).

B1 Donald Bradman has died. In his last ever test he was bowled out for a duck by:

(a) Len Hutton

(b) Harold Lerwood

(c) Douglas Jardine

(d) Eric Hollies

B2 By which name was Batman not known?

(a) The Caped Crusader

(b) The Dark Knight

(c) Black Beauty

(d) Bruce Wayne

B3 The film Interview With The Vampire ran with which tagline?

(a) Drink from me and live forever

(b) We're gonna live forever

(c) Just for the taste of it

(d) Fame! I'm going to live forever

B4 Shrove Tuesday, famous for pancake batter, is not also known as what?

(a) Fasnacht

(b) Carnival

(c) Mardi Gras

(d) Jif Lemon Day

B5 In which episode of Last Of The Summer Wine did Compo become a motorcyclist?

(a) The Woollen Mills Of Your Mind

(b) Catching Digby's Donkey

(c) Enter The Phantom

(d) Oh Shut Up And Eat Your Choc Ice

Entries must reach Take Five, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER by Wednesday March 7. The winner will be notified by March 16.

fields.headline: TV pick of the day
fields.trailText: A Passage To India | Under-21 football
fields.body:
Films

A Passage To India (David Lean, 1984) 8.30pm, Carlton Cinema Lean came out of semi-retirement to make this, 13 years after the troubles of Ryan's Daughter. Although this production of E M Forster's Raj novel isn't a jewel in his crown, it's well crafted and intelligent, graced by fine performances from Judy Davis, Alec Guinness and best of all, Peggy Ashcroft.

Agnes Of God (Norman Jewison, 1985) 9pm, UK Living Jewison's overwrought religious drama is adapted by John Pielmeyer from his award-winning play. Very watchable performances from the three leading women: Meg Tilly's novice nun, apparently mother and murderer of an immaculately conceived child; Anne Bancroft as the mother superior convinced a miracle has occurred; and Jane Fonda's haggard, lapsed-Catholic psychiatrist deciding whether Sister Agnes is mentally fit to stand trial.

Rushmore (Wes Anderson, 1999) 10pm, Sky Premier This delightfully quirky coming-of-age-tale stars the astonishing Jason Schwartzman as Max, a Rushmore Academy student in the nerdy Woody Allen mode. He may be failing in class, but he's brimming with big ideas, and his Serpico is probably the funniest school play ever. But he also has romantic ambitions, and enlisting the help of depressed tycoon Bill Murray, woos a teacher (Olivia Williams) with poignant ineptitude: hilarious, moving, and a real gem.

Red Corner (Jon Avnet, 1997) 11.35pm, Sky Premier Richard Gere's media executive is doing big business in China, but after spending a night with a beautiful woman wakes in the morning to find her dead. Suddenly our heroic American abroad is framed for murder, the victim of a vast, opaque and implacable foreign justice system. But luckily, along comes another beautiful woman (Bai Ling) and this one's a lawyer who believes he's innocent. Kafka it ain't.

Suture (Scott McGehee, 1995) 2.35am, FilmFour McGehee's indie thriller that weaves issues of identity and memory into a noirish plot. Murder suspect Vincent (Michael Harris) invites half-brother Clay (Dennis Haysbert) to his Phoenix, Arizona home and arranges for his car to blow up, leaving Clay amnesiac, burned beyond recognition, and saddled with Vincent's identity. Earlier, the pair have remarked on their uncanny resemblance, though one is black, the other white: a weird and mischievous tale.

Sports

Under-21 football 7.30pm, Sky Sports 2 The good news, for those of you who don't like football, is that our clubs' European adventures have been temporarily suspended. The bad news is that we get internationals instead. Tonight, from Birmingham, by way of amuse bouche for tomorrow's main course, we get the prime of England's much-hyped youth, under the guidance of a good, old-fashioned Englishman Howard Wilkinson, against their Spanish counterparts.

fields.headline: Radio pick of the day
fields.trailText: Afternoon Play | File On Four | It'll Never Last
fields.body:
First Love by Samuel Beckett is not an undiscovered masterpiece, but certainly one of the Irish writer's lesser known works. Written in French in 1946, the short story was not published for 24 years, to protect the subjects of what is an undisguisedly autobiographical story. Radio 4's dramatisation for the Afternoon Play slot (2.15pm) stars Stephen Dillane as the 39-year-old narrator looking back at his 25-year-old self and his "first love" Lulu, a Dublin prostitute.

Another nail in the coffin of the United States' and Britain's campaign to make Saddam Hussein the world's biggest bogeyman is offered by File On Four (Radio 4, 8.0pm). Ten years after an unprecedented alliance backed by a UN security council resolution saw the Western military machine rush to the aid of Kuwait, Gerry Northam asks what were we fighting for. The oil is back on tap, but the opening up and democratisation of Kuwaiti society that we were supposed to be guaranteeing has barely registered.

Episode one of It'll Never Last , Alan Whicker's history of British television (Radio 2, 9.0pm) is bound to be a fast, sparse gallop. No sooner had the BBC got the thing running than war broke out and the screens went blank for almost a decade; Whicker goes from dinner suits to the start of commercial telly in an hour.

webTitle: Hard core criminals targeted in 10-year crime plan

fields.headline: Hard core criminals targeted in 10-year crime plan
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The 10-year crime plan announced by the government yesterday is designed to reverse the longterm decline in detection and conviction rates while breaking the "cycle of reoffending" of the hard core 100,000 more persistent criminals said to commit 50% of all recorded crime.
fields.body:
The 10-year crime plan announced by the government yesterday is designed to reverse the longterm decline in detection and conviction rates while breaking the "cycle of reoffending" of the hard core 100,000 more persistent criminals said to commit 50% of all recorded crime.

Only 9% of all recorded crimes end in a conviction now compared with 18% in 1980, according to figures published in the paper.

Key parts of the plan are awaiting reports later this year from Lord Justice Auld and John Halliday on wide ranging shake-ups of courts and sentencing.

Policing

Introduction of two-tier policing, with the police accrediting and co-ordinating private security guards, park keepers, car park attendants, night club bouncers and others to provide visible patrols and a presence to reduce the fear of crime. New "super bobbies" who co-ordinate this activity would be paid more.

Random patrols of streets ruled out, instead "intelligence-led patrolling" would see new police-accredited patrols outside schools at the beginning and end of the school day or outside commuter stations at rush hours or other places used by large numbers at peak periods.

Officers should no longer patrol in twos but alone, as they are "more likely to engage with local people than if patrolling in company with others". Mobile police stations brought into shopping centres and churches. The public will be able to report minor crimes online.

Civilian investigators will help solve minor crimes such as shoplifting, as in a pilot scheme in Chippenham, Wiltshire. Expansion of trained detective capacity and recruitment of civilian specialists as reinforcements. DNA database to cover whole active criminal population - 1m people - by 2004.

Victims

Separate victims' fund for quicker compensation. All courts passing a community sentence will consider if the victim should be paid reparation. By 2005 victims will be able to track progress of their case online. From April every victim of a sexual or violent criminal will be consulted about conditions of release of their attacker.

Courts

Introduction of a modern criminal code for the first time to ensure simpler and fairer trials. Possible evening courts and extended working hours in crime hotspots, but there will be no 24-hour courts or network of drug courts.

New rules of evidence including disclosure of previous convictions to jurors in limited circumstances, for example where the defendant puts his character at issue. Fuller disclosure of defence evidence before trial. New prosecution right of appeal against judicial rulings to cut number of cases dismissed prematurely.

Prosecution to be given right to challenge defence plea of mitigation. Seven hundred more crown prosecutors and a new prosecutors' college in which to train them.

No televising of trials but cameras to be introduced to appeal hearings. The plan says there is concern about the representative nature of juries, but no decisions yet on reform. Specialist hearings for drugs and domestic violence cases.

Sentencing

New "custody plus" sentence to replace the short prison terms of less than 12 months served by 47,000 inmates each year. Currently inmates leave prison just as illiterate and unemployable as they go in.

It will consist of a fixed period in prison followed by a further period under an enforced programme of supervision and treatment in the community. Those who fail to comply with the conditions of the community sentence will be automatically returned to prison to serve rest of sentence. Review hearings to monitor progress and order future action.

Community element might include 22 sessions on a drug treatment course, weekly meetings with a probation officer and a curfew enforced with a tag from 7pm to 7am.

Jack Straw would not specify yesterday if the time served inside would be shorter than the current six months for those sentenced to a year and if prison numbers would rise or fall as a result of its introduction. He did say however that some persistent offenders now given community sentences would be sent to prison under "custody plus".

Tougher sentencing of the 100,000 persistent offenders. Straw said the clause in the 1991 Criminal Justice Act which had prevented the courts giving progressively heavier sentences to those who kept coming before them had been repealed in 1993 but said its "spirit" still lived on. The clause ensured that the punishment was in proportion to the crime, so nobody was sent to prison for stealing a milk bottle.

The crime plan says new sentencing philosophy will be based on the offender and not the offence. Prolific offenders will face increasingly more severe punishment.

Prisons

2,660 more prison places; 400 more secure training places for young offenders; number of inmates getting qualifications inside to double by 2004; £30m "custody to work" scheme to double number of ex-prisoners going into a job.

Criminal Justice: The way ahead, cm 5074, TSO, £15.70.

fields.headline: Jacket required
fields.standfirst:
Toothpaste and a souvenir coat - Tony Blair's first encounter with George Bush was confusing enough. But then they sat down to watch the movie. Vicki Woods deconstructs the summit

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Toothpaste and a souvenir coat - Tony Blair's first encounter with George Bush was confusing enough. But then they sat down to watch the movie.  Vicki Woods  deconstructs the summit.
fields.body:
George W Bush in his flying jacket - ooh. Doesn't he look like the guy you've been waiting for when you've gone a bridge too far outside Arnhem or Anzio or wherever? The fit, breezy-looking guy with the most tanks and the most K-rations? A flying jacket is a tricky piece of kit for a middle-aged bloke to wear at the weekend - but Dubya pulled it off, didn't he?

He's a Texan. You only have to see him in his cowboy boots and you just know he can ride rodeo and rope steers. You only have to look at him waving goodbye to Tony and Cherie and you just know he could fly their goddamn helicopter back to JFK. It's a controversial wardrobe call, a flying jacket, but it added a certain manly something to their World Leaders Walk Through The Woods photo-op: Dubya striding through the snow in winter-weight boots and his flying jacket; Tony trotting beside him like a history teacher in an Oxford Street jumper and blue suede shoes. Honestly.

It was so sweet of George to get one specially logo-ed up for Tony to take home. "TONY BLAIR" it said. "CAMP DAVID." A very acceptable souvenir. Obviously, Tony's wasn't as nice as Dubya's own - it wasn't leather; it didn't have a presidential seal on it; and it didn't have that sexy world war two-type beaver-fur collar. (Give it to Euan, Tony! He can wear it with a proper po-faced teen irony: "My Dad went to Camp David and all I got was a Star Wars deal, a qualified endorsement on the European de fence initiative, and this lousy flying jacket.")

Tony obviously liked his gift because he put it on straight away for the Pre-Helicopter-Takeoff photo-op. So the world's press got Dubya looking like General MacArthur, Tony looking like the man who cleans the top gun's latrine, and Cherie looking like a woman walking through Brent Cross shopping centre carpark in a hurricane in a 10ft woolly scarf. I thought it was a turban for a minute there.

Obviously, Tony had to put the jacket on for the chopper-ride - he hadn't got anything else to wear. I just don't know what Tony's people think they're doing when they're packing his bag. We'll get to his toothpaste choices in a minute - but doesn't Downing Street watch the world weather reports before they jet him off to foreign parts? Where were his Timberlands? Where was his guernsey? Where was his Barbour?

It's such a pity they've had to cancel the countryside march because of foot and mouth: Tony could have learned something from non-Londoners about dressing for walkabouts in sneaky spring weather. (People down my way have been oiling their boots and fluffing up their Damarts for weeks now.) Where did Downing Street think they were packing for - Portobello Road? The whole idea of a foreign photo-op, with a spring electoral shoo-in round the corner, is to get plenty of footage. You want your man standing next to the leader of the free world looking as well-prepared, well-turned-out and statesmanlike as possible, not shivering through the snow in a telly-presenter's weekend jumper and blue suede shoes. The whole Downing Street crew looked as though they'd left London in a daze - Jonathan Powell even had to borrow an overcoat, he got so chilly.

As to the toothpaste: it was two-nil to the White House. When Bush answered the "So what have you guys got in common?" question with "We both use Colgate toothpaste," I thought Tony was going to choke. Talk about leftfield - it was like watching the Women's Institute. Colgate? Colgate? What dentifricial hell is this? You could see he didn't know Colgate from KY Jelly.

In America, the mostly Democrat-leaning media, who take very little notice of major summit meetings with grinning Brit politicians, just thought the Colgate throwaway was a meaningless Bushism. A subliminable foot-in-mouth - fuhgeddaboudit. The British Embassy in Washington (who take so much notice of major summit meetings that they've been running around for weeks talking up the special relationship) thought it was a savage put-down.

There was a sharp intake of breath and everybody started swaying.

They're still talking about what on earth Bush can have meant - was he just guessing? Is there some blue-collar Texan innuendo about blokes using the same toothpaste? Or was Dubya just proving how well-prepared he was? Maybe the White House butler checks inside the spongebag. Maybe he pre-pastes the visiting VIP toothbrush and leaves it ready-to-brush. We'll never know. We'll never know why he came up with his after-dinner movie idea, either. Meet the Parents? A De Niro vehicle, it is the kind of bland Hollywood comedy you don't even bother to watch on the flight out to Canada. (It actually was the in-flight movie on the Blairs' flight out to Canada.) Dubya isn't an after-dinner movie kind of sophisticate, anyway - he likes to dine at six, retire at ten and rise at five like other rancheros.

So Tony's people are still fretting about this Bushism as well. Was Meet the Parents a diplomatic triumph for Downing Street in that their man managed to keep the president up long past his bedtime? Or was the choice of movie an outright triumph for the White House? ("What have we got that's kind of middle-of-the-road and unspecial? Meet the Parents? Heh-heh, good call.")

I reckon it was a win for the White House, and God knows what Downing Street will have to come up with on the return visit. It'll have to be theatre for Americans, won't it? Art? Lulu? Henry IV? No, no - too highbrow. Buddy? Blood Brothers? No, God, no - think of the headlines. It'll have to be the boring old Beautiful Game, and Tony can give George a football shirt to wear under his flying jacket.

webTitle: Captive audience hears Blair spell out 'jail to work' scheme

fields.headline: Captive audience hears Blair spell out 'jail to work' scheme
fields.standfirst:
PM visits prison hours before launching proposals to tackle persistent offenders and raise conviction rates

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: PM visits prison hours before launching proposals to tackle persistent offenders and raise conviction rates.
fields.body:
HMP Pentonville, the London prison selected to be the first jail to be visited by a serving prime minister, is not one of the "hell holes" - its last report from the chief inspector of prisons was glowing.

There was little danger of Tony Blair being pictured shaking hands with one of Britain's more notorious inmates as none of Pentonville's 1,070 prisoners is in the high risk category.

Instead, when the prime minister visited yesterday he mingled with inmates who had improved their reading and writing, had taken a maths exam while on remand, or were taking part in the jail's "job club".

He was shown into the foundation English class where he sat at a tiny plastic desk before hearing from the prisoners about their experiences. In return he told them about the new "custody to work" scheme to help offenders get jobs on release. He admitted it would take time for employers to accept the idea of employing more ex-prisoners. One inmate, Terry, 36, from Enfield, said he believed it was a good idea for Mr Blair to visit but did not think he was given a realistic look at jail conditions.

Sir David Ramsbotham in his last inspection report on the north London jail said the staff had "a refreshing 'can do' attitude" compared with other large, overcrowded, under-resourced prisons, and wondered why it was not in evidence elsewhere.

The chief inspector particularly praised the "constructive atmosphere and friendly relationships" between staff and inmates. He also liked the variety of workshops, gym sessions and classes, including some for dyslexic inmates, that are not generally available in other local prisons. Sir David was also impressed by the race relations work in Pentonville.

But he also found significant failings at the prison. More than 60% of Pentonville inmates were using heroin at the time of their admission.

There was a good drug detoxification and rehabilitation programme but, the chief inspector said, it could not hope to take on all those who needed treatment.

The prison's greatest problem however was the lack of a proper health care centre.

Sir David has called this a disgrace which should never have been allowed to happen. The last health care centre was demolished in 1995 and at the time of the inspection a year ago had yet to be replaced because of spending cuts.

The number of mentally disordered inmates means the jail runs one of the largest medium secure units in the country yet it has to operate in antediluvian conditions and with gross understaffing.

webTitle: Florida bets on technology to make it count

fields.headline: Florida bets on technology to make it count
fields.standfirst:
As study claims Bush did win the sunshine state, plans are afoot to ensure the ballot fiasco is never repeated

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Only 10 weeks after Al Gore's concession made George Bush president, the state that became a byword for electoral incompetence and malpractice produced its blueprint yesterday for ensuring that it never happens again.
fields.body:
Only 10 weeks after Al Gore's concession made George Bush president, the state that became a byword for electoral incompetence and malpractice produced its blueprint yesterday for ensuring that it never happens again.

But just as part of Florida's political establishment was congratulating itself on arriving at a scheme so rapidly, consensus was foundering on money and the still-elusive perfect voting machine.

And even if there were such a machine, there is no guarantee that enough could be manufactured in time for the next presidential election in less than four years' time.

A taskforce split evenly between Democrats and Republicans recommended spending $20m (£14m) to remove from Florida by the next statewide elections the punch cards that gave the world the hanging chad - ballot cards with bits of cardboard left dangling.

These would be replaced by optical scanners, already used in 41 of Florida's 67 counties, to create a uniform statewide system.

"It's all about restoring voter confidence in Florida," said Christopher Smith, a Democratic state senator and member of the taskforce. "If the governor is serious and the legislature is serious, I think we'll find the money. This is the most important thing in Florida."

But Katherine Harris, the secretary of state who became the most convenient bogeywoman during the poll fiasco, wants to go further. She advocates electronic touch-screens that work like cashpoints to be in place for the 2004 election, at a cost of $200m.

"It's an unnecessary and ridiculous expense," said John McKay, the Republican president of the senate. "That much money for a problem that most counties don't really have is overkill."

And Tom Feeney, speaker of the state's house of representatives, said: "The bottom line is that there were very few technological errors. Voters make mistakes and maybe we should work to make those errors less likely, but we can't think for people."

More than a dozen schemes are in place to improve the voting system, and not just in Florida: nationwide, there are at least 600,000 punch card and lever machines in use in the country's 191,000 voting precincts and only about 30% of electors see modern equipment when they vote.

There are bills in Congress to find money for machines, to tighten voter registration, to examine the effects of exit polls, to close all ballots at 9pm eastern time (which is 6pm on the west coast), and to abolish the electoral college which gave victory to Mr Bush even though Mr Gore won more votes.

Mr Bush has pledged to make reform a priority and one proposal would give states $2.5bn over five years to match money they find for modernisation. But this would miss the 2004 deadline.

And then there is the question of where the machines would come from.

Kimball Brace, a leading consultant with Election Data Service, based in Washington, said: "What happens when Miami-Dade, Dallas and Chicago say all of the sudden, 'We'd like to buy'? There is no manufacturer out there big enough. It's very complex. We have to train poll workers and we have to train the voters. If they were confused with the punch card, wait till they get into this new stuff."

More competition is entering the field, however. Unisys, Microsoft and Dell are working on an electronic system that would employ a smart card.

Some claim that internet voting will be in use by 2004 but others say it will be decades before fears recede that hackers could interfere. "I haven't seen us move fast on any of these things," said Jim Cannavino, chief executive of CyberSafe, a computer security firm. "I don't want to have a president elected by the guys who spray-paint buses."

How to vote: Punch or pull

Paper ballots: voters put an X by name of candidate (introduced 1789) and used in areas with 1% of voters.

Lever machines: devices where votes are cast by pulling a lever beside candidate's name. Introduced 1892: 18%.

Punch cards: voters use stylus to make hole indicating choices then read by computer (1964): 36%.

Optical scanners: voters fill in ballots which are then scanned by computers. Introduced early 1980s: used by 27%.

Electronic: choices indicated by pushing a button or by touching a screen (introduced late 1980s): 9%.

(NB: Areas with multiple methods: 9%)

fields.bodyText: Only 10 weeks after Al Gore's concession made George Bush president, the state that became a byword for electoral incompetence and malpractice produced its blueprint yesterday for ensuring that it never happens again. But just as part of Florida's political establishment was congratulating itself on arriving at a scheme so rapidly, consensus was foundering on money and the still-elusive perfect voting machine. And even if there were such a machine, there is no guarantee that enough could be manufactured in time for the next presidential election in less than four years' time. A taskforce split evenly between Democrats and Republicans recommended spending $20m (£14m) to remove from Florida by the next statewide elections the punch cards that gave the world the hanging chad - ballot cards with bits of cardboard left dangling. These would be replaced by optical scanners, already used in 41 of Florida's 67 counties, to create a uniform statewide system. "It's all about restoring voter confidence in Florida," said Christopher Smith, a Democratic state senator and member of the taskforce. "If the governor is serious and the legislature is serious, I think we'll find the money. This is the most important thing in Florida." But Katherine Harris, the secretary of state who became the most convenient bogeywoman during the poll fiasco, wants to go further. She advocates electronic touch-screens that work like cashpoints to be in place for the 2004 election, at a cost of $200m. "It's an unnecessary and ridiculous expense," said John McKay, the Republican president of the senate. "That much money for a problem that most counties don't really have is overkill." And Tom Feeney, speaker of the state's house of representatives, said: "The bottom line is that there were very few technological errors. Voters make mistakes and maybe we should work to make those errors less likely, but we can't think for people." More than a dozen schemes are in place to improve the voting system, and not just in Florida: nationwide, there are at least 600,000 punch card and lever machines in use in the country's 191,000 voting precincts and only about 30% of electors see modern equipment when they vote. There are bills in Congress to find money for machines, to tighten voter registration, to examine the effects of exit polls, to close all ballots at 9pm eastern time (which is 6pm on the west coast), and to abolish the electoral college which gave victory to Mr Bush even though Mr Gore won more votes. Mr Bush has pledged to make reform a priority and one proposal would give states $2.5bn over five years to match money they find for modernisation. But this would miss the 2004 deadline. And then there is the question of where the machines would come from. Kimball Brace, a leading consultant with Election Data Service, based in Washington, said: "What happens when Miami-Dade, Dallas and Chicago say all of the sudden, 'We'd like to buy'? There is no manufacturer out there big enough. It's very complex. We have to train poll workers and we have to train the voters. If they were confused with the punch card, wait till they get into this new stuff." More competition is entering the field, however. fields.headline: Goodbye to globalisation
fields.standfirst:
America's new focus means greater realism and honesty for the rest of us

Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: America's new focus means greater realism and honesty for the rest of us.
fields.body:
George Bush and Tony Blair sent out a reassuring message from Camp David. Their schmoozing and backslapping was designed to tell the world that nothing much has changed since Mr Bush entered the White House. In fact there has been a momentous shift in America's stance towards the world. As a political project globalisation is dead. The high-flying rhetoric of the Clinton administration has been replaced by a hard-headed focus on American national interest. The US is now more concerned with protecting itself in a dangerous and intractably disordered world than with spreading its values to the last corners of the globe.

It is a development that carries large risks, not least for Britain, but it should also be seen as a triumph of reality over illusion. The era of globalisation was a time of cant, humbug and self-deception on an enormous scale. A chorus of pundits, politicians and business people told us that we were living through an unprecedented economic and technological revolution. At the same time they suggested that everything would go on much as before. On both counts they were wrong.

There is nothing unprecedented in the real changes the world economy is undergoing. The internet is only the latest in a series of technologies that began with the telegraph. There have been near-instantaneous link-ups between world markets ever since transatlantic underwater cables were laid in the last third of the 19th century. Looking further back, we can see that today's new technologies are another phase in a worldwide industrial revolution that began 200 or 300 years ago, if not earlier.

What we also see if we look back over the past couple of centuries is that it was a time of great social and political upheaval. Industrialisation did not go unopposed. Trade unions and social democratic parties were part of a powerful backlash that included less benign movements such as communism and fascism. Worldwide industrialisation went together with wars, revolutions and - in many countries - murderous dictatorships.

The missionaries of globalisation failed to notice its darker side. They confused a genuinely inexorable historical process - the worldwide diffusion of new technologies that abolish or curtail time and distance - with market deregulation, a trend that is clearly on the wane. They were able to pass over the turbulent history of globalisation because a historic boom in world markets had created the illusion that economic history had come to an end.

It is hardly accidental that the fad for globalisation coincided with a bubble on Wall Street. Equally, it is no coincidence that we are hearing a good deal less of it now that the bubble is deflating. The popular idea of globalisation expressed what might be called the Dow Jones interpretation of history - the theory that booming stock prices somehow demonstrated that free markets were spreading irresistibly across the world. With the pricking of the Wall Street bubble, that theory is now itself history.

The Bush administration's stance on foreign policy must be seen in the context of the end of America's long boom. It was easy for Americans to imagine that history was on their side when the stock market seemed to be making them effortlessly rich, but the world has begun to look a good deal more forbidding now that their some of their gains are starting to vanish before their eyes. When the pain spreads from the stock market to the real economy and rising unemployment returns to the US, protectionist pressures in Congress will grow. As the business cycle resumes, perhaps with exaggerated force, the US is likely to revert to something resembling the attitude to the world that it adopted towards the end of the 19th century. It will not drift into isolation, but it will intervene overseas only when it believes its vital interests are at stake.

Many in Europe have been horrified by the shift in attitude in Washington. Partly Europe's shock at Washington's new priorities reflects its failure to take seriously long-standing American intentions. US plans for National Missile Defence (NMD) are objectionable on several counts, notably their highly destabilising impact on arms control. But they are not new. Some version of NMD would very likely have gone ahead if Al Gore had become president. This is one area of clear continuity in American policy. The most worrying aspect of the new American administration may not be its defence plans but its attitude to the global environmental crisis. President Bush has publicly cast doubt on the reality of global warming - thereby breaking with a consensus not only of scientists but also of a growing number of business leaders. This stance bodes ill for relations with Europe, and for the world.

Mr Blair believes he can continue to bridge the divide between Europe and the US, and we must hope that he is right. But the international climate in which he finds himself has altered fundamentally. For more than a decade after the fall of the Berlin Wall, the US seemed committed to spreading "democratic capitalism" throughout the world. The Bush administration has not repudiated that American commitment, merely consigned it to history's memory hole.

On the whole, I cannot help feeling it a change for the better. The world into which we are moving is an increasingly dangerous place, but at least we can begin to think about its risks realistically and honestly, without the disabling illusions of the era of globalisation.

John Gray is Professor of European Thought at the LSE.

fields.headline: Look out LA - here I come
fields.trailText: 'If the first digit of the three-digit numbered interstate highway is an even number, the highway usually connects to interstate highways at both ends and is known as a beltway."
fields.body:
'If the first digit of the three-digit numbered interstate highway is an even number, the highway usually connects to interstate highways at both ends and is known as a beltway."

Oh God. One of the problems about suddenly deciding to move to an entirely car-dependent foreign country but being too busy watching Popstars to actually get round to sorting anything out is that I will soon have to take my driving test along with 500 15-year-old American schoolboys - a dream I had once, but am not particularly looking forward to carrying out in real time.

My plan to go to LA to write the great unawaited screenplay of our times (number of practice screenplays attempted before sub-letting flat and booking flight to Hollywood: none) seems to be throwing up more and more unanticipated problems. Apparently, not driving a car in Los Angeles is the equivalent of turning up and announcing that you aren't going to be breathing air, you'll be breathing water, if that's OK with everyone, and you might as well lie in a bath for three months.

Unfortunately my one brief and unhappy attempt at driving was many years ago, when I got in the dual control car for the first time and the instructor raised his eyes to mine. "Now I don't want to put you off," he intoned, "but there are two things women can't do terribly well . . ."

Just the two? Last I heard we weren't too shit hot at, say, public fart lightage, or global war.

". . . drive, and make compilation tapes."

I was about to confront him with the full heat of my unquestioning 17-year-old feminism before I recalled that I did, in fact, make really really crappy compilation tapes. I haven't sat in the driver's seat of a car since, but now, it appears, I have no choice.

Hmm. How hard can it be? Don't American cars just have two large buttons with "Go!" and "Stop y'all!"? George "D" Bush can drive, can't he? My mother says I'll be fine, as long as I wear this crash helmet here - no, take it, we don't need it, just pop it on every single day.

The sullen locum doctor refused to fill in my driving medical form on the grounds that she didn't know me well enough, despite the fact that the six questions included tricky things like "Are you legally blind?" and "Do you have any amputated limbs?". Also, the question "Are you an alcoholic?" seemed relatively unnecessary, given that in Pennsylvania (where, for unnervingly tedious reasons, I shall be taking the test), the legal limit for drink-driving is - get this - no more than one drink an hour. Wow. Only one pint an hour - for as many hours as I fancy, presumably - and I'd still be perfectly within my rights to head my little red Corvette (I have no idea what one of those is, but it sounds cool) off to the gun shop to pick up my AK47.

Still, at least if I can get my hands on a car I'll have somewhere to sleep, which is more than can be said for me at the moment, despite it being, ooh, almost 20 hours before I get on the plane. Another drawback of being frantically over-ambitious and almost terminally lazy is that I haven't got around to replacing my credit card - the only one I have ever had, since my student days, which I never use and therefore has a credit limit of £24.99. Someone did invite me to stay but then, a couple of days ago, emailed to say: "Sorry, we'd have loved to have had you, but I'm afraid we're off to China to adopt a baby," which at least means these people are imaginative.

Rather alarmingly, the temperature in LA is only about 12 degrees at the moment, thus also putting paid to my well-thought-out sleep-on-the-beach plan B. I just keep repeating the mantra: I'll be fine. I'll be fine. I only wish I could remember why I wanted to go in the first place. There was definitely something to do with fantasising about writing world-class film material that would pluck me out of obscurity and allow me to stretch myself and work with some of the world's most interesting people. But I'm sure there was also something - oh no! I remember now! - about hoping to bump into David Duchovny at the bus stop. Argh! Dammit! How unlike me to not even bother to find out in advance that LA has, in fact, no bus stops.

Missing you already

I can't believe all the great things I'll miss while I'm away. Who shot Phil Mitchell? Celebrity Big Brother. (Is that really going to happen? It sounds like a spoof. Well, if I was Anthea Turner I wouldn't bother packing an overnight bag.) And . . . oh I'm sure there's something else. Oh yes! That general election thingie. I think if I'm going to the trouble to fill in my postal vote form I should get two votes for making the effort, and just in case, as in the American elections, they mostly get accidentally thrown down a well or something.

Formula fun

I think I am generous and credulous to showbusiness on the whole. I think Billie's parents were quite right to let her start her career at 14. I truly sympathise that Victoria Hervey feels that the paparazzi won't leave her alone. But not even I can muster a tiny rat's fart's worth of feeling for women who get engaged to formula one dri vers and then complain that it's not working out.

I don't believe for a second that all men can't keep it in their trousers, and that men can't help themselves if presented with an attractive woman. Of course they can, and loads do. But when you look at the alpha-male, ferociously competitive, fabulously wealthy, young, fit, risk- taking, brave (I realise as I'm typing this that it's not coming across that actually I think they're twats, except for Mika Hakkinen, whom I like because his name is so much fun to say) types, surrounded by beautiful women and amazing luxury, who are deliberately chasing the dream of ultimate masculinity that makes up formula one - well, du-HUH!

 Charlotte Raven is away.

webTitle: In the shadow of  foot and mouth disease

fields.headline: A living on the edge
fields.standfirst:
Sarah Walton and her husband raise sheep and cattle near Heddon-on-the-Wall, the village believed to be the source of the foot and mouth outbreak. Here, in the first of a series of daily diaries, she reveals what life is really like in the shadow of the disease

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Sarah Walton and her husband raise sheep and cattle near Heddon-on-the-Wall, the village believed to be the source of the foot and mouth outbreak. Here, in the first of a series of daily diaries, she reveals what life is really like in the shadow of the disease
fields.body:
Things must look bad to the outside world this morning because Michael, our very reliable postman, asked if we wanted our mail left somewhere else or even delivered to my mother-in-law, who lives eight miles away, rather than him driving up the one-mile road to our farm. The milkman also left our delivery of fresh pints and eggs at the end of the road.

My husband, Peter, and I run an upland livestock farm in Northumberland. We have two teenage children, James and Victoria. Our 1,163-acre grassland farm lies around 13 miles from Hexham, just on the boundary of Infected Area Two, as pronounced by the Ministry of Agriculture on Saturday. This is a mapped-out area where special precautions against foot and mouth should be taken by everyone, especially those living on farms.

Our business up here is breeding and fattening beef cattle and sheep. We grow no arable crops - the land is much too rough, and once ploughed the ground is very stony, with boulders to pick up and move. We are in what is known as a "less favoured area" because our land is all between 620ft (190m) and 750ft (230m) above sea level. The growing season is short, from April to September, and the winds very strong; there are not many trees, except a few small conifer plantations kept for shelter for the livestock. We have almost 40 miles of stone walls dividing up our many fields.

We have a lot of livestock, and this is the great worry for us just now. We have 1,063 ewes, due to start lambing at the end of March. (The lambing season will then last about six weeks.) We worry that being pregnant may make them more vulnerable to infections of all kinds. Just over 600 of these are mule ewes in lamb to our Suffolk rams; the remainder are hill sheep - Scottish Blackface - in lamb to our Cheviot rams. On the farm there are also 200 ewe hoggs, the young sheep that come into the ewe flock in the autumn to replace the old ones. We also have 25 rams, one Limousin bull, 52 An gus cross cows with Limousin cross calves and 65 Limousin cross store cattle (last year's calves, which are being fattened for slaughter).

We have one full-time employee, Graham Dick, and he works as a shepherd-cum-stockman, helping Peter daily to tend to and feed the livestock. He lives on the farm in a bungalow with his wife, Sue, and their two grown-up children. Graham has several very well-trained collie dogs that he uses every day and we just have two pet dogs: a black Labrador and a Capheaton terrier (a Northumbrian speciality: a small, smooth-haired, ginger-coloured terrier that adores children).

As I write this on Monday afternoon, Peter is outside feeding the cattle, which are housed in the shed, on silage. He and Graham work very hard feeding the cattle in the sheds and in the fields twice a day. The sheep are fed once a day at the trough with a compound feed specially prepared for pregnant ewes, and they get hay as well - on the ground and in a covered hay rack - which lasts them overnight.

As we have a good covering of snow on the ground today they are getting extra hay, and it gives us all a chance to look at them a little more closely. During the afternoon feedings each day the cattle are bedded down with clean straw, which we often refer to as "clean sheets". This barley straw was bought in from a supplier in the autumn as we grow no crops of our own except for hay and silage.

Because of the atrocious autumn weather that we've had, there is a great shortage of straw within the livestock industry, and these new movement restrictions may cause some farmers extra difficulties over feed and forage. Peter remains confident just now that we will have enough, though we are desperate, like everyone else in our region, for more disinfectant.

Local supplies ran out on Friday and fresh stocks are urgently needed. I've just rung our local agricultural merchants and they say it will come tomorrow. They have just been let down and had to change their suppliers, so here's hoping. We used the very last of our disinfectant stocks to construct a straw and chemical barrier at the end of the road. This B road and a good part of our land runs alongside the Infected Area Two boundary, but two of our neighbours who find themselves caught in this 10-mile zone also run some of their animals on our side of the main road, in fields next to ours.

News bulletins, phone calls and vital updates via the internet have become a way of life in the past five days. Last Tuesday we sold a few hoggs and old cull ewes at Hexham Auction Mart and we had planned to sell the last of last year's lamb crop on Friday, in preparation for the arrival of this year's crop. But the mart cancelled the sale owing to suspicions about a farm at Heddon-on-the Wall - suspicions that were soon confirmed, as the whole country now knows.

I just saw Nick Brown, the minister of agriculture, give his statement - live on TV - to the House of Commons. My heart gave such a lurch when he announced that the farmer in Devon must have all the stock on all his Devon holdings destroyed. If we were unlucky enough to be infected by this outbreak, it is unlikely that we would want to continue with farming at all because our children, like so many other farm children in the 21st century, are not remotely interested in this way of life. But to be forced to retire by the destruction of all your animals and life's work . . . it hardly bears thinking about.

And so the wait goes on. We check our livestock over and over again; we talk to our neighbours in an attempt to keep each other's spirits up; and we hope - and some of us even pray - that in the morning all will be well, or at least not worse.

What do you think?

fields.bodyText: Things must look bad to the outside world this morning because Michael, our very reliable postman, asked if we wanted our mail left somewhere else or even delivered to my mother-in-law, who lives eight miles away, rather than him driving up the one-mile road to our farm. The milkman also left our delivery of fresh pints and eggs at the end of the road. My husband, Peter, and I run an upland livestock farm in Northumberland. We have two teenage children, James and Victoria. Our 1,163-acre grassland farm lies around 13 miles from Hexham, just on the boundary of Infected Area Two, as pronounced by the Ministry of Agriculture on Saturday. This is a mapped-out area where special precautions against foot and mouth should be taken by everyone, especially those living on farms. Our business up here is breeding and fattening beef cattle and sheep. We grow no arable crops - the land is much too rough, and once ploughed the ground is very stony, with boulders to pick up and move. We are in what is known as a "less favoured area" because our land is all between 620ft (190m) and 750ft (230m) above sea level. The growing season is short, from April to September, and the winds very strong; there are not many trees, except a few small conifer plantations kept for shelter for the livestock. We have almost 40 miles of stone walls dividing up our many fields. We have a lot of livestock, and this is the great worry for us just now. We have 1,063 ewes, due to start lambing at the end of March. (The lambing season will then last about six weeks.) We worry that being pregnant may make them more vulnerable to infections of all kinds. Just over 600 of these are mule ewes in lamb to our Suffolk rams; the remainder are hill sheep - Scottish Blackface - in lamb to our Cheviot rams. On the farm there are also 200 ewe hoggs, the young sheep that come into the ewe flock in the autumn to replace the old ones. We also have 25 rams, one Limousin bull, 52 An gus cross cows with Limousin cross calves and 65 Limousin cross store cattle (last year's calves, which are being fattened for slaughter). We have one full-time employee, Graham Dick, and he works as a shepherd-cum-stockman, helping Peter daily to tend to and feed the livestock. He lives on the farm in a bungalow with his wife, Sue, and their two grown-up children. Graham has several very well-trained collie dogs that he uses every day and we just have two pet dogs: a black Labrador and a Capheaton terrier (a Northumbrian speciality: a small, smooth-haired, ginger-coloured terrier that adores children). As I write this on Monday afternoon, Peter is outside feeding the cattle, which are housed in the shed, on silage. He and Graham work very hard feeding the cattle in the sheds and in the fields twice a day. The sheep are fed once a day at the trough with a compound feed specially prepared for pregnant ewes, and they get hay as well - on the ground and in a covered hay rack - which lasts them overnight. As we have a good covering of snow on the ground today they are getting extra hay, and it gives us all a chance to look at them a little more closely. During the afternoon feedings each day the cattle are bedded down with clean straw, which we often refer to as "clean sheets". This barley straw was bought in from a supplier in the autumn as we grow no crops of our own except for hay and silage. Because of the atrocious autumn weather that we've had, there is a great shortage of straw within the livestock industry, and these new movement restrictions may cause some farmers extra difficulties over feed and forage. Peter remains confident just now that we will have enough, though we are desperate, like everyone else in our region, for more disinfectant. Local supplies ran out on Friday and fresh stocks are urgently needed. I've just rung our local agricultural merchants and they say it will come tomorrow. They have just been let down and had to change their suppliers, so here's hoping. We used the very last of our disinfectant stocks to construct a straw and chemical barrier at the end of the road. This B road and a good part of our land runs alongside the Infected Area Two boundary, but two of our neighbours who find themselves caught in this 10-mile zone also run some of their animals on our side of the main road, in fields next to ours. News bulletins, phone calls and vital updates via the internet have become a way of life in the past five days. Last Tuesday we sold a few hoggs and old cull ewes at Hexham Auction Mart and we had planned to sell the last of last year's lamb crop on Friday, in preparation for the arrival of this year's crop. But the mart cancelled the sale owing to suspicions about a farm at Heddon-on-the Wall - suspicions that were soon confirmed, as the whole country now knows. I just saw Nick Brown, the minister of agriculture, give his statement - live on TV - to the House of Commons. My heart gave such a lurch when he announced that the farmer in Devon must have all the stock on all his Devon holdings destroyed. If we were unlucky enough to be infected by this outbreak, it is unlikely that we would want to continue with farming at all because our children, like so many other farm children in the 21st century, are not remotely interested in this way of life. But to be forced to retire by the destruction of all your animals and life's work . . . it hardly bears thinking about. And so the wait goes on. We check our livestock over and over again; we talk to our neighbours in an attempt to keep each other's spirits up; and we hope - and some of us even pray - that in the morning all will be well, or at least not worse. webTitle: World trade rises in torture weapons

fields.headline: World trade rises in torture weapons
fields.trailText: Trade in torture weapons, including high-tech electro-shock weapons, leg irons, serrated thumb cuffs, and stun belts prisoners are forced to wear, is increasing worldwide, Amnesty International says in a report published today.
fields.body:
Trade in torture weapons, including high-tech electro-shock weapons, leg irons, serrated thumb cuffs, and stun belts prisoners are forced to wear, is increasing worldwide, Amnesty International says in a report published today.

The report coincides with a separate study showing that Nato governments are investing in new weapons that are potentially as lethal as anti-personnel mines banned by the Ottawa treaty.

The human rights group says that the number of countries producing electro-shock equipment has grown from around 30 in the 1980s to more than 130 now. Some batons, which it calls the favoured tool of the modern torturer, even bear the "EC" standard marking approved by the European Union.

Though it is illegal in America to own some of the equipment, the US commerce department has granted sales valued at $97m since 1997 under the category of "crime-control equipment". Recipients include Saudi Arabia, Russia, Taiwan, Israel, and Egypt, says Amnesty.

Amnesty says that in July 1997, Zambian police used tear gas to break up a peaceful protest march in Lusaka. Yet Britain re-supplied tear gas two years later despite the lack of training of the police.

"The government must press the EU to seek an end to the complicity of all its members in the torture trade," said Kate Allen, Amnesty International UK director.

Other countries with companies selling torture equipment include China, France, Russia, Germany, Britain, Poland, Israel, South Africa, Brazil, Mexico, South Korea and Taiwan.

The British-based Landmine Action campaign also identified mines that are "victim-activated and civilian-targeted", designed to get round the Ottawa treaty, which is limited to conventional anti-personnel mines. It says the the government's defence research agency is developing alternatives to conventional mines, including dazzling lasers and high-powered microwaves.

webTitle: US urges Syria to be tougher on Iraq

fields.headline: US urges Syria to be tougher on Iraq
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: The US secretary of state, Colin Powell, continued his whirlwind tour of the Middle East yesterday in an effort to bolster flagging support for sanctions against Iraq.
fields.body:
The US secretary of state, Colin Powell, continued his whirlwind tour of the Middle East yesterday in an effort to bolster flagging support for sanctions against Iraq.

Meanwhile, an Iraqi delegation began two days of talks in New York with the UN secretary-general, Kofi Annan, aimed at resolving the impasse over weapons inspections and lifting sanctions.

Mr Powell has been urging Arab leaders to keep pressure on Baghdad to prevent it amassing weapons of mass destruction.

He has also been sounding out Arab opinion on replacing the blanket embargo against Iraq with "smart" sanctions designed to target the Saddam Hussein regime specifically.

During a three-hour stop in Saudi Arabia, Mr Powell met King Fahd and the foreign minister, Prince Saud.

Although the Saudis were key allies during the 1990-91 Gulf conflict they have since become critical of US policy. Last week Prince Saud signed a joint statement with Syria denouncing recent US-British air strikes around Baghdad.

Shortly before Mr Powell arrived in Riyadh, the interior minister, Prince Nayef, denied that the kingdom had played any role - "direct or indirect" - in the recent bombing.

Mr Powell later flew to Syria where he was expected to confront officials over claims that Iraq was exporting between 100,000 and 150,000 barrels of oil per day through the pipeline to Syria, in violation of sanctions.

The exports could be legitimised and included in the UN's Oil for Food programme at the request of Iraq or Syria, but so far neither has asked for this. Revenue from illicit oil sales outside the UN programme goes directly to the Baghdad regime.

Mr Powell was expected to receive a cool reception in Damascus, where the ruling Ba'ath party's newspaper yesterday contrasted US attitudes to Iraq and Israel. The paper questioned why the US had not launched air strikes against Israel for failing to comply with UN resolutions, and why Israel was allowed to possess nuclear weapons.

Iraq said that the latest talks at the UN would probably fail. This would give the US and Britain a "pretext to take new steps [smart sanctions] that have already been cooked by them," the Baghdad newspaper al-Thawra said.

The talks will focus on getting weapons inspectors back into Iraq, a condition for lifting sanctions. Baghdad has hinted that it might be willing to accept a less intrusive system of arms "monitoring" but is also demanding that Israel rids itself of nuclear weapons.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: Yesterday's G2 cover story, was about two UK Independence party members of the European parliament. It was set at the parliament's Strasbourg site, but the photo on pages 2-3 showed the parliament's Brussels building. Describing the two Ukip MEPs, the text said they sometimes came over "like Caldicott and Charters, the old buffers who kept talking about the Test score while travelling Europe in Strangers on a Train". The two films where Charters and Caldicott worry on trains about catching up with the Test results are Hitchcock's The Lady Vanishes (1938) and Night Train to Munich (1940).

Geographical confusion: Bangui was sited in the Philippines rather than its native Central African Republic in a panel on page 9 yesterday. The text, meanwhile, shifted the Republic of Congo towns of Brazzaville and Pointe Noire to the adjacent Democratic Republic of Congo.

MPs voted by a majority of 244 against keeping the status quo on fox hunting, rather than 224 as stated in an article on page 12, February 22, about whether a commitment to ban such hunts would would be dropped from Labour's manifesto.

"I want to know everything," said the king, asking to be kept informed in 1934 when cricket's great Donald Bradman was seriously ill. The speaker was George V, not VI, as yesterday's panel said on page 6, Sport.

Our Bafta report, page 3, was mistaken in saying yesterday that the film Some Voices was a "massive sleeper hit" in US cinemas.

fields.headline: New age of television
fields.trailText: It is assumed by television commissioning editors (Stranger than fiction, G2, February 26) that the only viewers worth making programmes for are those people in their twenties who would never watch a "serious" documentary at all.
fields.body:
It is assumed by television commissioning editors (Stranger than fiction, G2, February 26) that the only viewers worth making programmes for are those people in their twenties who would never watch a "serious" documentary at all, unless the subject matter can be linked with sex, ancient Egypt or cannibalism and explained in words of one syllable.

When I was writing the script of my last major series for Channel 4, I was pressured by the assistant commissioning editor for arts programmes to hand the writing over to another, younger, writer. "I have been writing scripts for the last 30 years," I told her. "Perhaps that's the problem," she said darkly.
Newbold on Stour, Warwickshire
Karl Sabbagh
Karl.Sabbagh@btinternet.com

fields.headline: Prison bars, lost chances
fields.trailText: By visiting a prison, Tony Blair has done more than any other serving prime minister to demonstrate that the prison service is an important public service and that prisons can take their place alongside schools and hospitals (Behind bars, G2, January 29-February 2).
fields.body:
By visiting a prison, Tony Blair has done more than any other serving prime minister to demonstrate that the prison service is an important public service and that prisons can take their place alongside schools and hospitals. Sadly what he is not prepared to endorse is the place of prisons as one of absolute last resort.

As your series (Behind bars, G2, January 29 - February 2) showed, locking people up shatters family ties, creates homelessness and reduces employability. Time served is often time wasted. All that the better prisons can do, time and resources permitting, is to try to reduce the damage done by imprisonment.

Locking more and more people up for longer and longer periods of time is futile. We already imprison more people in England and Wales than in any other western country except Portugal. Yet more than half of them will reoffend on release.

We are creating a sizeable group of alienated and disenfranchised young adults. More than 75% of this age group will be reconvicted within two years. Early prevention, targeting child poverty, support for vulnerable families, reducing school exclusion, intensive supervision of young offenders, the new youth justice system all have the potential to effect real change. Entrenched problems require long-term solutions, not knee jerk reactions.
Juliet Lyon
Prison Reform Trust

fields.headline: Breaks in transmission of the tale of Charles Boxer
fields.trailText: In claiming that the discovery of a radio transmitter by the Japanese (Secret history of a hero, Saturday Review, February 24) can only have been as a result of its presence being betrayed by a British officer, Captain Charles Boxer, Hywel Williams appears to overlook two things.
fields.body:
In claiming that the discovery of a radio transmitter by the Japanese (Secret history of a hero, Saturday Review, February 24) can only have been as a result of its presence being betrayed by a British officer, Captain Charles Boxer, Hywel Williams appears to overlook two things. First that content analysis of radio transmissions would have eventually alerted Japanese intelligence to the presence of a radio transmitter somewhere in the general area anyway.

And second, patient deployment of direction-finding equipment would have enabled them to narrow down that area until eventually they would have been able to obtain a three dimensional fix on the transmitter's location to within a matter of inches, without their having to be told of its presence by anyone.

As to Boxer's preferential treatment subsequent to the discovery of the transmitter, this seems entirely explicable in terms of his ability to speak Japanese and broad sympathy with Japanese culture - presumably rare qualities in captive British officers at that time. And it was his having enjoyed this unsolicited preferential treatment which may alone explain his reluctance to accept any subsequent decoration. Although presumably being an expert on these matters himself, Mr Williams knows better, and so feels justified in branding the late Captain Boxer a traitor, as a result.
Michael Adams
London
mjadams25@hotmail.com

As the current Camoens professor of Portuguese, the chair formerly held by Charles Boxer, I protest at the attempted character assassination of this extraordinary man by Hywel Williams. The claims about Boxer's "alleged betrayal" of fellow officers in a Japanese PoW camp in Hong Kong in 1943 are not only not substantiated but are based on insidious innuendo.

Mr Williams states that "officially" Boxer "refused the military decoration appropriate to one of his rank and distinction and the MBE gazetted in 1946 was withdrawn", claiming that "his resignation from the army was seen as that of a man under a cloud". In the context of the article the "cloud" appears to be related not to the "grave discourtesy to His Majesty" represented by Boxer's refusal of the decoration and distinction but to "suspicions" about his involvement with the discovery of a radio transmitter in the PoW camp. No mention is made of the fact that Boxer was offered a CBE in 1975, which again he refused.

Had the British government considered that there was any evidence to substantiate suspicions about Boxer, it is hardly likely that some 30 years later he would have been offered a higher distinction than the one he had refused in 1946. It is shameful that an article of such a meretricious nature, with its completely uncorroborated suggestions, should be published.
Helder Macedo
King's College, University of London
