fields.headline: Loot from late arrivals
fields.trailText: On a recent Virgin Train journey to Edinburgh from the West Country we customers discovered a new "people's lottery" for Mr Branson.
fields.body:
On a recent Virgin Train journey to Edinburgh from the West Country we customers discovered a new "people's lottery" for Mr Branson. On payment of a £1 stake, each of us drew a time in 10-minute intervals, of the likely arrival time. On the outward journey we were 66 minutes late and, on the return, 165 minutes late. For at least two of Mr Branson's customers, frustration was tempered by a lottery win.
Eric Bowers
Bridgend, Glamorgan

It is reported that Eminem is claiming he was unaware that Elton John was gay when he agreed to hug him at the Grammys. This is nonsense. It was Elton who didn't realise that the decidedly gay-looking Eminem was straight.
Peter Bradshaw
Liverpool

I agree with your correspondent (Letters, February 24) that the price of condoms is ridiculously high. They are available free from family planning clinics: at least one GP's surgery in Oxford keeps a stock in the patients' wc.
Cllr Susanna Pressel
Oxford City Council

You report that each of Bob Kiley's new proposals for the tube was rejected "after invention from the Treasury" (Tube journey times getting longer, February 26). I take it this should have read "intervention" but I think your version comes nearer the truth.
Tim Bennett-Goodman
London
timbengood@lineone.net

Why does Darshan Kent (What women eat, February 26) who eats fish but not meat call herself vegetarian?
Sandy Marks
Draycott, Somerset

fields.headline: Foot in mouth disease, possibly
fields.trailText: I am absolutely aghast at the stupidity of the Ministry of Agriculture and our government over the last decades regarding the strategy towards foot and mouth disease (Front page, February 26).
fields.body:
I am absolutely aghast at the stupidity of the Ministry of Agriculture and our government over the last decades regarding the strategy towards foot and mouth disease (Front page, February 26). Total elimination of a disease without the cover of vaccination is a desperately high risk approach, especially when the disease has appeared in many other countries in recent years and is highly contagious.

Humans and animals are equipped with a marvellous device know as the immune system which, if stimulated appropriately as Louis Pasteur showed more than a century ago, can prevent infection. Smallpox was eliminated globally by a dedicated effort to vaccinate everyone. The unedifying spectacle of thousands of perfectly healthy pigs slaughtered and burned could easily have been avoided if a strategy of vaccination had been pursued. Especially as it seems that the government has millions of doses of vaccine available.

There is a possibility that foot and mouth disease could be a deliberate act of sabotage: vaccination would stop this. If smallpox was eliminated then there would be no need to vaccinate humans, as is the case with a growing number of young people. But it seems clear that several governments still maintain cultures of smallpox for "research" reasons and virtually no vaccine is available. Like pigs with foot and mouth disease, our children will have no protection against accidental or deliberate release of smallpox.

I suppose that vaccination of animals is just too expensive for our cost-conscious society to cope with.
Julian Wimpenny
Professor of microbiology, Cardiff University Julian@wimpennyj.fsnet.co.uk

There is something frankly quite disgusting in the sight of the well-oiled Maff machine going into action. Whole herds of cattle are being slaughtered and incinerated, districts of the country are put into quarantine and all for a disease that does not affect man. Yet when, as was obvious from the start, there was the possibility of BSE spreading to man, instead of action we got denial; instead of honest inquiry we got lies and mendacity; instead of care for the consumer we got care for farming and the food industry. If only the then government had acted with such speed and resolution when BSE was first identified, then perhaps some of the victims of BSE might have been saved, and our farming and food industries might be in better shape.
Alan Mathison
Harrow, Middlesex

The very regrettable outbreak of foot and mouth disease is a natural risk for the farming industry. The draconian measures put in place to contain it are for the protection of the farming industry. Why, then, is the compensation for this to be funded by the taxpayer rather than by the farming industry? Presumably for the same reason that, when we were deceived into buying and eating infected beef, it was we who had to pay the compensation.

If the industry had to carry the full cost of such outbreaks, would it still follow such practices as shipping pigs from one end of the country to the other to be slaughtered?
John Riseley
Farnborough, Hampshire
johnriseley@hotmail.com

The British farmer is double crossed by consumers who, led by well funded animal rights organisations, make greater and greater demands upon the farmers, but then fail to put their money where their very strident mouths are. This country produces the safest food in the world, reared from cradle to table under the strictest welfare conditions in the world. The British farmer complies with these welfare standards at enormous cost in terms of buildings, feed, safety regulations, bureaucratic-heavy assurance schemes - all imposed, but not adhered to, by farmers in Europe and beyond.

If the infection is traced back to a rogue import of cheap beef, the blame can be laid fairly and squarely at the door of British consumers who, having demanded a high quality product, refuse to pay for it. Instead they fuel a market for cheap food produced under conditions that would make them weep, and which results in the undermining and collapse of an entire industry.
Carole Mann
Lechlade, Gloucestershire
chipps@epinet.co.uk

Is the wind which carries the foot and mouth virus five, 10 or 150 miles the same wind which carries pollen from GM crops a careful 300m?
Tony Winters
Kinver, West Midlands

The plans by the pharmaceutical industry to genetically modify pigs with human genes so that the heart can be used in organ transplant operations raises a number of interesting questions. In theory would it be possible for a transplant patient to contract foot and mouth disease? Would the foot and mouth mutate in that human host and spread?

Perhaps Nick Brown, our esteemed agriculture minister, could volunteer for an operation just to prove its safety, but failing that I am sure that John Gummer could provide one of his relative to go under the knife in order to allay public concern.
Kevin Peters
Aylesbury, Buckinghamshire

fields.headline: Tough and tender
fields.standfirst:
But Labour refuses to cut prison numbers

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Tony Blair became the first serving prime minister to go to prison yesterday. He visited Pentonville in London.  If only he had gone before yesterday's publication of the government's 10-year crime programme, there may have been less emphasis on tougher sentences.
fields.body:
Tony Blair became the first serving prime minister to go to prison yesterday. He visited Pentonville in London. If only he had gone before yesterday's publication of the government's 10-year crime programme, there may have been less emphasis on tougher sentences. A criminal justice system in which three top professionals - the chief inspector of prisons, the prison director general and lord chief justice - have all in the last month emphasised prison's negative results, is still preparing for a further expansion: a £700m programme providing 2,500 extra places over three years.

The prime minister made it clear the Tories were not going to outflank Labour. He boasted about the government's tougher penalties: third-time burglars getting three years, increased penalties for drug traffickers, increased mandatory drug-testing, and "toughened up community sentences so breaches are more likely to lead to custody". There is a similar unequivocal message in yesterday's plan: a "justice gap" which must be closed by catching and committing more hard core criminals. But neither addressed the chief inspector's assertion in G2 this month that 20,000 inmates - women, boys, elderly, mentally ill, petty offenders - should never have been sent.

An election approaches. Do not expect politicians to listen to pleas for a reduction in the prison population, even though we already have the highest in Europe apart from Portugal. Crime may be falling but custody will continue to rise to slake the thirst of an avenging public. They are not as hardline as purported. But who stokes up the presumed public lust for retributive justice in the first place? Politicians of course.

To be fair to the government, it was not all hardline rhetoric. There was considerable constructive tenderness too. And, compared to its predecessors, considerable evidence-based policy making, which progressives can embrace. True to its old mantra, Labour has been tough on the causes. Its multiple anti-poverty programmes - new deals for the unemployed, literacy and numeracy schemes, truancy patrols, support for families under stress, neighbourhood renewal - are playing a key role in the drop in crime.

There is a coherence to their changes to the system: new coterminous boundaries for police, probation and magistrates; a reform process which began with the most urgent areas, youth justice and the crown prosecution service (CPS), which will now move on to courts, sentencing and the police. Just how abysmal it had become can be measured by two related statistics: a fall in conviction rates from 18% of all recorded crime in 1980 to 9% last year; and a CPS, in which even by last November, only one in five lawyers and case workers had access to a computer. CPS gets a 23% increase from April and probation 31%.

The plan contains three large holes, two created by committees - on courts and sentencing - that have still to report. The third is the failure of the government to produce a comprehensive strategy on alcohol, which fuels so much violent crime. There are plenty of ideas which liberals must watch: a clear desire to tilt the system more in favour of the prosecution; more use of previous convictions by judges and jurors; pilot schemes which could create two-tier policing by allowing private security firms to be accredited by the police.

Britain's crime rate, as last week's international survey showed, is among the highest in the world. But there is no need for panic: burglary and car crime have been drastically slashed by targeting. Robbery is rightly next in line.

fields.headline: Banks villains of the piece
fields.trailText: After spending the back end of last week in virtual freefall, software company Autonomy continued where it left off yesterday with concerns over its products and competition issues driving the price down further.
fields.body:
After spending the back end of last week in virtual freefall, software company Autonomy continued where it left off yesterday with concerns over its products and competition issues driving the price down further.

Senior executives who witnessed a 10% fall after Apex Partners decided to sell their 7% stake, could only watch in horror as a further 117p, or 8% fell away as the stock closed at £13.78 last night.

The damage was done by reports suggesting some customers had branded the company's products as expensive and unwieldy.

Autonomy's fall occurred on a generally bleak day all round for the FTSE 100 which closed down 27 points to 5936.4 - its lowest level for 16 months - despite a strong performance from telecoms and technology.

The villain of the piece, rather unusually, was the banking sector which was responsible for the loss of around 40 points from the bluechip index.

Despite earning a reputation as a solid, reliable performer in a volatile marketplace, and Britain's biggest sector being valued at £268bn, the industry looked decidedly jittery after HSBC announced lower-than-expected profits.

As the markets closed last night, HSBC was down 7% at 955p, with Barclays down 3.4% at £21.36 and the Royal Bank of Scotland down 2% at £15.28. Hardly a successful outing.

Overall, gainers and losers were perfectly balanced at 50-50, although there was not much in the way of a boost from Wall Street where the Dow Jones was up just 35 points. The UK equity volume was distorted by an error trade in fund manager Amvescap which showed an incorrect volume of over 1bn shares.

Overall, market turnover was very poor, reaching just 1.2bn, as dealers got to grips with the new central counterparty system for shares traded on the stock exchange's electronic order book, Sets.

In yesterday's rather topsy turvy trading environment, the unpredictable technology stocks were showing good form, buoyed by the comments of Wayne Angell, Bear Stearns chief economist, who predicted a 60% chance of the US central bank cutting rates by half a point.

Key performers included CMG, the Anglo-Dutch computer services firm, which predicted a "good set of results" later in the year and saw its shares leap 80p, or 11.5% to 770p as a result.

In the buoyant telecoms sector, equipment maker Marconi was seeing good demand, despite rumours that analysts at Schroder Salomon Smith Barney had slashed their target to price to 750p from £11. The shares rose 27p to 511.5p as some punters managed to convince themselves the company has attracted the attention of a US predator.

However there are so many stale bulls in Marconi that no one can be sure if this specula tion has any substance. One thing is for sure though - Marconi is looking cheap.

Elsewhere, Grampian Holdings, the name behind Edinburgh Woollen Mills, was back in demand, rising 2p to 72.5p, despite informed sources throwing cold water on renewed hopes of a 95p-a-share bid from private equity house Alchemy. Recent efforts by small shareholders to force Grampian's management to the bargaining table appear to have failed.

It seems Grampian's biggest shareholders are standing behind the company's decision to sell the Edinburgh Woollen Mills operation, so long as it gets a good price. Details of the sale should be revealed within the next week or so.

Tadpole Technology was also attracting solicitous glances on gossip that further deals are in the pipeline. Yesterday the web software group announced the acquisition of business and assets of Systems Synthesis Limited.

However, dealers reckon this is only the hors-d'oeuvre and that another deal with chip giant, Intel, will be served up tomorrow, followed by a fresh deal on Friday.

Tadpole shares ended 1.75p higher at 45p.

fields.headline: At this price?
fields.standfirst: BAT
fields.trailText: BAT.
fields.body:
Despite enduring attacks from the government and anti-smoking campaigners, as well as a virtual barrage of negative press coverage, British American Tobacco is still being lauded in the City.

An investigation by the Department of Trade and Industry into alleged smuggling has failed to dampen investor enthusiasm for the company, which is the world's second largest tobacco manufacturer behind the US firm Philip Morris.

Observers believe the industry, which has been under constant attack over the past couple of years, has emerged relatively unscathed and predict the future now looks a lot brighter. In particular they point to a recovery in south-east Asia and eastern Europe - both key markets for BAT - and a declining risk of litigation in the US as reasons to be cheerful.

While cigarette sales in many parts of the world are generally viewed as being stagnant at best, or in terminal decline at worst, there are signs that global industry volumes are now improving.

The US litigation risk, which principally impacts on BAT's subsidiary Brown & Williamson, is believed to be slightly reducing as a result of lower numbers of legal cases having been brought.

In one analyst's eyes, the litigation outlook is "the best it has been since December 1998" although globally there are still many battles to be fought.

Analysts are also expecting BAT to please the City with a decent set of figures when it announces full-year results tomorrow. Further news should emerge on the progress of its merger with Rothmans as well as the restructuring programme to cut costs in the US.

Michael Smith, of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, believes BAT is on track and, in a recent research note, says 75% of the £250m forecast savings will have been achieved and the target figure could be revised up to as much as £350m.

BAT's stock closed up 1.25p at 528p - still a little off the 553p year-high, but well ahead of the 225p low. Hold.

fields.headline: Fillip for Carpetright
fields.trailText: Carpetright was given a boost in a note from Deutsche Bank which reiterated its view that the shares were a "buy" with good prospects for the future.
fields.body:
Carpetright was given a boost in a note from Deutsche Bank which reiterated its view that the shares were a "buy" with good prospects for the future.

Deutsche Bank says the company has put in an "excellent performance" with like-for-like sales up 8% during a time in which the carpet market remains, at best, flat.

Its new division, Harris carpets at home, which sells quality carpets off the back of a lorry at consumers' front doors had a "slower than expected response" but is still predicted to break through into profit by next year.

Deutsche Bank's profit-before-tax forecast for the year to April 2001 on the firm remains unchanged at £45.5m.

It says that despite the recently strong share price, which last night stood at 650p, the rating was only just catching up with the growth in earnings.

webTitle: Microsoft judges must face Real issue

fields.headline: Microsoft judges must face Real issue
fields.standfirst:
Forget the lies, focus on bundling
Special report: the future of Microsoft
fields.trailText: Forget the lies, focus on bundling.
fields.body:
Microsoft's appeal against last year's anti-trust judgment began in Washington yesterday, with every media-savvy lawyer in the American capital sounding off on every US television channel about just how the case was set to go.

The software company's complaint revolves around a claim that Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who ordered that Microsoft be dismembered, was biased against the company. Much of its evidence comes from disclosures in the book World War 3.0, by New Yorker columnist Ken Auletta, which was serialised on these pages last month.

Mr Auletta managed to get Judge Jackson to talk for a total of 10 hours on what he thought about Microsoft's legal strategy and on the character of its chief software architect, Bill Gates. It was not flattering and included an observation that Mr Gates was acting like Napoleon.

Notwithstanding Mr Auletta's riveting prose and the journalistic feat of getting a senior, sitting judge (albeit an American one) to talk so candidly, there is little of substance in WW 3.0 that was not already known. If Microsoft wondered what Judge Jackson thought of the company and its officers, it had only to read his judgment issued last June: that said the organisation was untrustworthy and its senior executives lied.

What the appeal judges in Washington should focus on now is that the original corporate behaviour complained of - Microsoft bundling products in Windows for free and putting potential competitors out of business in the process - is still happening. There is a big example in Real Networks, run by former Microsoft executive Rob Glaser, whose video and audio software is being usurped by Windows Media. Real's share price has underperformed the wider US market by 45% over the past three months. The reason is simple: it is being Netscaped.

Reverse thrust

The government is almost down to the last bidder for the part privatisation of Britain's air traffic control service. With the withdrawal of Eads, the European aerospace and defence company, we must now expect the Nimbus consortium to fall away.

The government has to ask itself whether it should persist in trying to rush through this truly unpopular privatisation before the election.

From an original list of nine bidders willing to pay £500m for Nats, only the airlines stand ready to assume control of the safety of Britain's skies, across which there are 5,000 flights daily. After Railtrack's appalling safety record over the past few years, is it any wonder that MPs and staff are questioning such a conclusion?

Last year's revolt in the Lords led the government to announce a three-month moratorium, saying it would consult further before reporting back to parliament.

The time has shrunk and so has the government's room for manoeuvre. It has but a matter of weeks to confirm the final bidder and then finish the handover process before the prime minister calls an election.

Even senior Nats managers feel the government could easily delay until after the election. It has the legislation in place and can take its time. Better to drop it now and take stock of a privatisation that never was necessary.

Bank imbalance

After the 7% fall in HSBC's share price yesterday it would have been easy to conclude the business of banking has gone into secular decline. Yet this rarity - a British bank with a true international spread - had just reported bigger profits than any London-listed bank before it.

It has been a busy period for HSBC, completing the takeover of CCF in France, hot on the heels of Safra in the US. Even problems surrounding the introduction - in conjunction with Merrill Lynch - of its bank for the rich should not detract from HSBC being among the first to wake up to this new area.

The hub of the City's disappointment was the fact that only a quarter of the 28% rise in year-on-year profits came from growth in its existing business. What is more, costs rose faster than income - breaking the rule that most bankers chant in their sleep.

Analysts were also spooked by HSBC's far from upbeat assessment of the coming year. Given its bulk, HSBC is financially exposed across the globe and the bank is more susceptible than many to the weakening US economy. Meanwhile, Britain, which counts for 20% of revenues, is highly competitive, as is Hong Kong, its other core market.

So far, lots of short-term worries. But, for those with a longer-term investment view, this is a bank with a diversification strategy that appears to work. HSBC should be put on a par in investment terms with Citigroup of the US, not Barclays or Royal Bank of Scotland.

If Microsoft wondered what Judge Jackson thought of the company and its officers, it had only to read his judgment issued last June: that said the organisation was untrustworthy and its senior executives lied. What the appeal judges in Washington should focus on now is that the original corporate behaviour complained of - Microsoft bundling products in Windows for free and putting potential competitors out of business in the process - is still happening. There is a big example in Real Networks, run by former Microsoft executive Rob Glaser, whose video and audio software is being usurped by Windows Media. Real's share price has underperformed the wider US market by 45% over the past three months. The reason is simple: it is being Netscaped. Reverse thrust The government is almost down to the last bidder for the part privatisation of Britain's air traffic control service. With the withdrawal of Eads, the European aerospace and defence company, we must now expect the Nimbus consortium to fall away. The government has to ask itself whether it should persist in trying to rush through this truly unpopular privatisation before the election. From an original list of nine bidders willing to pay £500m for Nats, only the airlines stand ready to assume control of the safety of Britain's skies, across which there are 5,000 flights daily. After Railtrack's appalling safety record over the past few years, is it any wonder that MPs and staff are questioning such a conclusion? Last year's revolt in the Lords led the government to announce a three-month moratorium, saying it would consult further before reporting back to parliament. The time has shrunk and so has the government's room for manoeuvre. It has but a matter of weeks to confirm the final bidder and then finish the handover process before the prime minister calls an election. Even senior Nats managers feel the government could easily delay until after the election. It has the legislation in place and can take its time. Better to drop it now and take stock of a privatisation that never was necessary. Bank imbalance After the 7% fall in HSBC's share price yesterday it would have been easy to conclude the business of banking has gone into secular decline. Yet this rarity - a British bank with a true international spread - had just reported bigger profits than any London-listed bank before it. It has been a busy period for HSBC, completing the takeover of CCF in France, hot on the heels of Safra in the US. Even problems surrounding the introduction - in conjunction with Merrill Lynch - of its bank for the rich should not detract from HSBC being among the first to wake up to this new area. The hub of the City's disappointment was the fact that only a quarter of the 28% rise in year-on-year profits came from growth in its existing business. What is more, costs rose faster than income - breaking the rule that most bankers chant in their sleep. Analysts were also spooked by HSBC's far from upbeat assessment of the coming year. Given its bulk, HSBC is financially exposed across the globe and the bank is more susceptible than many to the weakening US economy. Meanwhile, Britain, which counts for 20% of revenues, is highly competitive, as is Hong Kong, its other core market. So far, lots of short-term worries. But, for those with a longer-term investment view, this is a bank with a diversification strategy that appears to work. HSBC should be put on a par in investment terms with Citigroup of the US, not Barclays or Royal Bank of Scotland.

webTitle: Vets battle to keep track of outbreak

fields.headline: Vets battle to keep track of outbreak
fields.standfirst:
Thousands of checks to be made as web of sales is revealed

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Vets were struggling to keep track of possible sources of foot and mouth infection after five new cases - the largest daily total so far - were confirmed yesterday.
fields.byline: Paul Brown, Nicholas Watt  and  John Vidal
fields.body:
Vets were struggling to keep track of possible sources of foot and mouth infection after five new cases - the largest daily total so far - were confirmed yesterday.

European countries reacted to the crisis by closing markets, tracking down all live sheep and pigs exported from Britain and killing thousands of animals as a precaution.

With a new outbreak confirmed at an abattoir at Bromham, in Wiltshire, for the first time in sheep, an incredibly complex web of auctions and trading began to be revealed. Checks involving many thousands of animals from dozens of farms - all of which could have been in contact with infection - threw up three new confirmed outbreaks within a few hours.

There are now three each in Devon, Northumberland and Essex, two in Wiltshire and one in Herefordshire.

The outbreaks in the west are all connected to the Devon sheep dealer Willy Cleave, who had a confirmed case of foot and mouth in cattle at his home at Burdon Farm, Highampton on Sunday. All 1,100 sheep on the 10 farms Mr Cleave owns in Devonare to be slaughtered as a precaution.

A further confirmed outbreak yesterday, bringing the total to 12, was in Northumberland, at a pig farm close to the oldest known outbreak at Heddon-on-the-Wall and thought to be an infection carried on the wind.

In a statement to MPs, Nick Brown, the agriculture minister said he still hoped that the total ban on the movement of farm and zoo animals, combined with the tracking of all suspected herds and animals by officials would be enough to contain the outbreak, but investigations were continuing at "a number of premises where there is reason to believe there may be disease."

He said that in addition to the 100% compensation farmers will get for the value of the stock that is destroyed, the government was considering applying to the EU for an extra £200m to compensate farmers for loss of markets. This kind of compensation has never been given in the UK before, although during the recent swine fever outbreak in East Anglia, animal welfare payments were given to farmers who were forced to look after pigs in overcrowded conditions because they could not send them for slaughter.

At the end of the week the government will review the total ban on the movement of animals. It may allow some animals to go to market in areas free of the disease.

Farmers were less calm than Mr Brown about the crisis. Ben Gill, who saw the prime minis ter yesterday said: "This is a nightmare for the whole farming community. People are scared out of their wits."

Ian Johnson, of the National Farmers Union in Devon, said "We are on the threshold of Armageddon. We are talking about a threat to 2m cattle, 1m pigs and 4m sheep in the west of England alone. Farmers are at their wits' end but we are asking them to stay put."

Farmers and Mr Brown are asking the public to stay away from farms. Mr Brown told MPs that officials were making plans temporarily to close footpaths and rights of way.

The agricultural crisis is also beginning to influence the government's calculations over the date of the election.

There was speculation at Westminster yesterday that the outbreak of foot and mouth disease may kill off any chances of the poll being held on April 5, making May 3 a more likely date. Parliament would have to be prorogued by March 12 to allow for an election on April 5, something that is unlikely if movement is still restricted in many areas of the country.

Ben Gill, president of the NFU, last night warned the government that it could not hold the election until the disease has been eradicated.

Speaking on Channel 4 News after meeting the prime minister, Mr Gill said: "To have a campaign in the countryside would not in my mind be possible. In fact it would be counterproductive against the control of the disease until such time as we have this disease under control."

The impact of the crisis on the timing of the election was raised in the commons by the veteran Labour backbencher Tam Dalyell. Mr Brown said he would pass the matter "to those who can take more interest in it than I can".

The number of animals af fected across Britain is rising quickly. There are now thousands of sheep to be killed and disposed of in addition to more than 3,000 cattle and pigs already killed and incinerated.

Yesterday Ian Scudamore, the government's chief vet revealed that he believed pigs from from Heddon-on-the-Wall had spread infection to sheep in nearby Ponteland. The sheep had been sold at auction in Hexham, sent on to Longtown in Carlisle, and thence to Devon and on to the slaughterhouse in Bromham.

He said that at any of these steps on the journey the sheep could have passed on infection to other animals and all those links were being investigated. In addition sheep from the Devon farm had been sent to market in Northampton. These had also been sold on. All these animals had to be traced too.

"We can only hope that these sheep at Ponteland were incubating the disease and were not spreading infection as they travelled down to Wiltshire. They may not have been infectious all the while but we have to check to make sure," he said.

As tracing infections became more complex, vets were being brought in from the EU, Australia, New Zealand, and the United States to help.

webTitle: Post Office turns to Andreessen's Loudcloud

fields.headline: Ready to deliver
fields.standfirst:
Post Office turns to Andreessen's Loudcloud

More net news
fields.trailText: The Post Office is today expected to announce that it has chosen an ambitious young web-hosting firm set up by Netscape founder Marc Andreessen to run its entire internet operation.
fields.body:
The Post Office is today expected to announce that it has chosen an ambitious young web-hosting firm set up by Netscape founder Marc Andreessen to run its entire internet operation.

Loudcloud, which is based in Silicon Valley and is preparing a flotation on the Nasdaq stock exchange, will take charge of all of the Post Office's web operations including hardware, software, hosting and disaster recovery.

Loudcloud was co-founded by Mr Andreessen and another former Netscape executive, Tim Howes, in September 1999.

Mr Andreessen became one of earliest symbols of the dot.com boom in the late 1990s when at the age of 24 he earned £120m from the flotation of the web browsing business which has subsequently been sold to AOL.

The Post Office has said it intends to become a leading player in the e-commerce arena.

"This is an significant contract for us and we're extremely pleased," Mr Howes said.

"The UK is an important part of our overall strategy and we're working hard to sign up more customers here."

In an initial filing to the securities and exchange commission last September, Loudcloud said it planned to raise $110m (£75m) in a share issue that would value the firm at $1bn. In the first six months of 2000 it reportedly made losses of $50m.

Analysts say the success of any Loudcloud flotation will be closely watched, given Mr Andreessen's involvement. Backers include Benchmark Capital and Morgan Stanley.

fields.headline: Precautions start to bite
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: • Dartmoor, in Devon, has been declared a no-go area to protect livestock because of confirmed cases of foot and mouth on farms near the national park. The decision prevents public access to 200 square miles of land
fields.body:
 Dartmoor, in Devon, has been declared a no-go area to protect livestock because of confirmed cases of foot and mouth on farms near the national park. The decision prevents public access to 200 square miles of land

 The traditional Shrovetide football match in Ashbourne, Derbyshire, in which hundreds of people compete to carry a ball across three miles of farmland, has been cancelled. It was due to be started by the Prince of Wales tomorrow

 Three royal parks - Richmond Park, Bushy Park and Hampton Court Home Park, all in south-west London - were shut yesterday to protect deer herds

 Authorities at Exmoor national park, straddling Devon and Somerset, are considering measures to close the entire 265 square mile moor to prevent foot-and-mouth being spread by hill walkers

 London Zoo is asking visitors to cross disinfected matting to gain entrance while Paignton Zoo, Edinburgh Zoo and Whipsnade Animal Park in Buckinghamshire will remain shut for the rest of the week

 The weekend rugby international between Wales and Ireland in Cardiff may be postponed or travelling restrictions may be placed on Irish fans to prevent the outbreak reaching Ireland

 A planned military exercise involving aircrew and ground troops in Otterburn, Northumbria, is being reviewed as a result of the outbreak

 Precautions against foot and mouth are being taken at the Prince of Wales's farm at Highgrove, Gloucestershire, and on Duchy of Cornwall land controlled by the prince. No signs of the disease have emerged

 An animal welfare group was criticised yesterday for staging a demonstration by up to 100 people against a guinea pig farm near Burton on Trent Staffordshire, despite police warnings that it could spread the foot and mouth outbreak

 Magdalene College, Oxford, was closed to the public yesterday to protect herds of deer that graze in the college grounds

webTitle: Industry finally plugs into the concept of net profits

fields.headline: Industry finally plugs into the concept of net profits
fields.standfirst:
Manufacturers have discovered the benefits of getting wired - just as the wireless era dawns

More net news
fields.trailText: Move over Henry Ford. The dawn of the dot.com era may have proved a false one for some but now big industry is getting wired. For the first time since Mr Ford opened his Rouge River plant in 1927 and changed the way cars - and much else - were made, big business may be on the threshold of similarly significant change.
fields.body:
Move over Henry Ford. The dawn of the dot.com era may have proved a false one for some but now big industry is getting wired. For the first time since Mr Ford opened his Rouge River plant in 1927 and changed the way cars - and much else - were made, big business may be on the threshold of similarly significant change.

That sounds like the sort of hyperbole which typified dot.com boom and bust. It is not. True, production techniques have been developed and refined since Ford's production lines took raw materials in at one end and cars rolled off the other. Think no further back than the Japanese concept of just-in-time manufacturing which threatened Ford's heirs among others or the introduction and rapid rise of the use of robotics.

True, too, that though Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan may have become a cautious convert to the productivity revolution brought by the development of e-business, there are still sceptics who argue the improvements have largely been cyclical not structural, a product of the long US boom rather than fundamental changes in the economy.

Collaborative commerce

What has changed is not so much the technology as the impact its application has made to the relationship between business and customers. The Ford system was geared towards the needs of production. The carmaker famously summed up his relationship with his customers when he said they could have any colour they wanted, provided it was black. Even today, carmakers offer a range of body forms in every colour of the rainbow but press for ever greater commonality in terms of platforms and power trains.

According to executives such as Jörgen Centerman, the new president and chief executive of engineering group ABB, new technology offers new ways of doing business. ABB calls it adaptation industrial IT, a system of online links that connect ABB's manufacturing operations with customers and suppliers. Such "collaborative commerce", Mr Centerman enthuses, "will radically change the way companies operate and thereby create opportunities to improve productivity and efficiency that we can just barely imagine".

Inevitably, talk of the new economy comes with enough buzz-words to intimidate a chainsaw but ABB has figures to back up its enthusiasm. The group is already producing operating systems with integrated software packages which provide significant boosts to production efficiency. One such system provided the plant in which it was installed with the equivalent of an additional month's output a year.

By hooking up diagnostic technology to the internet, it allows remotely located engineers to monitor and anticipate machine malfunctions hours, even days ahead. Mind you, there has to be a downside. Imagine the call at 3am.: "It's machine three here. I'm going to have a total breakdown unless you come and see me now!"

ABB has revamped its websites to make them more user-friendly but Jouko Karvinen, the head of automation technology products insists there is more to ABB's online strategy than an additional channel of communication.

Take one of the group's standard product lines: electric motors. Traditionally it took four weeks between a customer ordering and receiving a motor with a customised shaft configuration. Using the internet, customers can program ABB's machine tools to provide the required configuration. ABB claims delivery time is down to two days and the cost from $205 to $31.

On bigger projects, you get bigger results. Preparation and pre-engineering for an electricity substation used to take customers four-person weeks and another three-person weeks for ABB's response. Using the new web-based system the pre-engineering work can be done in 10 minutes and ABB's reply is delivered in 24 hours. Ships can now be designed online using systems capable of simulating the design's performance in different weather conditions.

The group has a plant in the US where its sales force and its materials suppliers are linked to the highly automated plant via the web. The combination of e-commerce and robotics can cut labour costs in half, floor space by 60% and cycle times by 90%.

"This is not how we win; it is how we stay in business," Mr Karvinen said. He dismissed the idea of separation between the old and new economy. "The economy is still the same, what has happened is that technology has revolutionised the way in which we do business."

Siemens is another firm reshaping itself to take full advantage of the new environment. Its president and chief executive, Heinrich von Pierer, has committed the group to achieving 25% of overall sales and half of all consumer products sales - worth €18bn - via the internet in the next three years.

"It is in the fabric of the company," said Alan Wood, chief executive of Siemens' UK operations.

Like ABB, Siemens has clocked up some impressive manufacturing efficiencies using the internet.

Its subsidiary manufacturing personal computers, Fujitsu Siemens, has found that its "clean-order ratio" - the proportion of purchases that do not have to be revised because the machine requested is not on offer or cannot be built - has been reduced from 62% to 98% by using a specially designed website. Using the internet has also slashed the time it takes to receive orders.

By applying new technology across the business - Siemens has set up centres of what it calls e-excellence in the US, Singapore and close to its Munich base - the group aims to squeeze out around 5% of costs, looking at links with suppliers, customers and its own internal organisation. It is not expecting that saving to fall straight through to the bottom line, however. In a competitive world a hefty chunk will have to be passed on to consumers. Echoing ABB, Mr Wood observes: "You have to do it to be there."

He argues that some of the benefits will come through in the form of better services to customers. E-commerce will not mean cutting a swath through the ranks of the company's sales engineers, for example.

"We are not going to see them all being fired. Customers are still going to need that personal interaction. What is happening is that it frees the sales engineer to add value, rather than spending time having to check what is happening to the customer's order."

Back-office areas, however, are likely to be affected as areas such as travel arrangement and expenses are dealt with using central online systems

As business seeks to change in order to take advantage of the benefits of e-commerce, Mr Wood has a warning for those who are hoping that the process of that change is finite. The introduction of third-generation mobile phones "is going to bring true internet on the move. It is going to change the way we do business even more."

Collaborative commerce What has changed is not so much the technology as the impact its application has made to the relationship between business and customers. The Ford system was geared towards the needs of production. The carmaker famously summed up his relationship with his customers when he said they could have any colour they wanted, provided it was black. Even today, carmakers offer a range of body forms in every colour of the rainbow but press for ever greater commonality in terms of platforms and power trains. According to executives such as Jörgen Centerman, the new president and chief executive of engineering group ABB, new technology offers new ways of doing business. ABB calls it adaptation industrial IT, a system of online links that connect ABB's manufacturing operations with customers and suppliers. Such "collaborative commerce", Mr Centerman enthuses, "will radically change the way companies operate and thereby create opportunities to improve productivity and efficiency that we can just barely imagine". Inevitably, talk of the new economy comes with enough buzz-words to intimidate a chainsaw but ABB has figures to back up its enthusiasm. The group is already producing operating systems with integrated software packages which provide significant boosts to production efficiency. One such system provided the plant in which it was installed with the equivalent of an additional month's output a year. By hooking up diagnostic technology to the internet, it allows remotely located engineers to monitor and anticipate machine malfunctions hours, even days ahead. Mind you, there has to be a downside. Imagine the call at 3am.: "It's machine three here. I'm going to have a total breakdown unless you come and see me now!" ABB has revamped its websites to make them more user-friendly but Jouko Karvinen, the head of automation technology products insists there is more to ABB's online strategy than an additional channel of communication. Take one of the group's standard product lines: electric motors. Traditionally it took four weeks between a customer ordering and receiving a motor with a customised shaft configuration. Using the internet, customers can program ABB's machine tools to provide the required configuration. ABB claims delivery time is down to two days and the cost from $205 to $31. On bigger projects, you get bigger results. Preparation and pre-engineering for an electricity substation used to take customers four-person weeks and another three-person weeks for ABB's response. Using the new web-based system the pre-engineering work can be done in 10 minutes and ABB's reply is delivered in 24 hours. Ships can now be designed online using systems capable of simulating the design's performance in different weather conditions. The group has a plant in the US where its sales force and its materials suppliers are linked to the highly automated plant via the web. The combination of e-commerce and robotics can cut labour costs in half, floor space by 60% and cycle times by 90%. "This is not how we win; it is how we stay in business," Mr Karvinen said. He dismissed the idea of separation between the old and new economy. "The economy is still the same, what has happened is that technology has revolutionised the way in which we do business." Siemens is another firm reshaping itself to take full advantage of the new environment. Its president and chief executive, Heinrich von Pierer, has committed the group to achieving 25% of overall sales and half of all consumer products sales - worth €18bn - via the internet in the next three years. "It is in the fabric of the company," said Alan Wood, chief executive of Siemens' UK operations. Like ABB, Siemens has clocked up some impressive manufacturing efficiencies using the internet. Its subsidiary manufacturing personal computers, Fujitsu Siemens, has found that its "clean-order ratio" - the proportion of purchases that do not have to be revised because the machine requested is not on offer or cannot be built - has been reduced from 62% to 98% by using a specially designed website. Using the internet has also slashed the time it takes to receive orders. By applying new technology across the business - Siemens has set up centres of what it calls e-excellence in the US, Singapore and close to its Munich base - the group aims to squeeze out around 5% of costs, looking at links with suppliers, customers and its own internal organisation. It is not expecting that saving to fall straight through to the bottom line, however. In a competitive world a hefty chunk will have to be passed on to consumers. Echoing ABB, Mr Wood observes: "You have to do it to be there." He argues that some of the benefits will come through in the form of better services to customers. E-commerce will not mean cutting a swath through the ranks of the company's sales engineers, for example. "We are not going to see them all being fired. Customers are still going to need that personal interaction. What is happening is that it frees the sales engineer to add value, rather than spending time having to check what is happening to the customer's order." Back-office areas, however, are likely to be affected as areas such as travel arrangement and expenses are dealt with using central online systems As business seeks to change in order to take advantage of the benefits of e-commerce, Mr Wood has a warning for those who are hoping that the process of that change is finite. The introduction of third-generation mobile phones "is going to bring true internet on the move. It is going to change the way we do business even more."

webTitle: 'Cost-cutting hides true extent of Britain's investment'

fields.headline: 'Cost-cutting hides true extent of Britain's investment'
fields.trailText: Higher output per worker is the holy grail of economics, enabling an economy to grow faster without igniting inflation. With Britain approaching full employment, getting more out of the existing workforce will be the only way it can sustain the strong growth rate it has enjoyed since 1992.
fields.body:
Higher output per worker is the holy grail of economics, enabling an economy to grow faster without igniting inflation. With Britain approaching full employment, getting more out of the existing workforce will be the only way it can sustain the strong growth rate it has enjoyed since 1992.

So far there are no signs of an improvement in the 2% average rate which has prevailed for the past 40 years. But Sushil Wadhwani, one of the four independent members on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee, is confident it will accelerate. He believes it may already have done so - but is not being picked up.

Mr Wadhwani argues that official statistics fail to take full account of the extent to which the price of computers and software has fallen in recent years, thereby underrecording the volume of IT investment.

British workers, therefore, have more capital to work with than assumed. He is impressed by the way established companies, such as BT and GKN, are using new technology to cut costs and transform their supply chains.

"I believe that productivity growth is likely to be above average over the next two years, primarily because of the likely response of firms to competition in the intensified product market, the beneficial effects of B2B [business to business] e-commerce, and the fact that the pay-off from the significant amount of information and communications technology investment that has occurred is due soon," Mr Wadhwani said in a speech in October last year.

One of the tests of the theory that new technology has transformed the US economy will be how it performs during the downturn.

When it announced the first of January's two cuts in interest rates, the US Federal Reserve issued a statement predicting that the productivity gains achieved in the upswing would be sustained.

Bob Gordon, a leading "new economy" sceptic, of Northwestern University, doubts that new technology is as important as air conditioning in boosting productivity. He believes most of the gains made during the late 1990s were cyclical, the result of demand pressures forcing companies to raise their game. He figures that only 0.4 or 0.5 percentage points of the recent annual increase in productivity growth is likely to be lasting.

But even an advance of that size would be huge. A half-percentage point rise in productivity growth adds $1.2 trillion (£685bn) to the US government surplus over 10 years. The chancellor, Gordon Brown, who will once again make improving productivity one of the main themes of his forthcoming Budget, will eye such sums with envy.

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: There's a lot of talk about impending recession, but perhaps these fears are overdone. The property market does not appear to be on the brink of collapse.
fields.body:
 There's a lot of talk about impending recession, but perhaps these fears are overdone. The property market does not appear to be on the brink of collapse, at least not in London and especially not in lovely Islington, where property developer Goldcrest Homes is flogging flats in a manner reminiscent of the crazy days during the late 1980s housing boom. "A stunning landmark development capturing the Islington lifestyle," runs Goldcrest's advertising sign, "with Armani suited concierge."

Of course, it would be easy to mock the pretensions of anyone who wants to live in a block because it has a concierge dressed in a posh suit - and it does have the advantage of warning the rest of us away. But, according to David Hodgson of Goldcrest the apartments are very popular (despite the cheapest one-bedroom flat going for £209,000).

"The Armani suit will more fit the lifestyles of the people we envisage living there," says Mr Hodgson. How does Armani feel about its brand name being used to shift flats in north London? "I'm sure they would be highly delighted," Mr Hodgson breezily declares. Ah, I wouldn't be so sure.

 There should be a special prize for accountants PricewaterhouseCoopers, who managed to mangle nonsense management consultant-speak and dangerous metaphors in the same enticing phrase on their website last week: "PwC Southern Africa invites you to enter the Boom Room, where entrepreneurs can detonate new economy mind fields."

 Keith Vaz MP may have his knockers, but I have some cheering news. Should this Hinduja business turn nasty and Keith suddenly need a new career, then he could easily become a writer for an advertising agency - judging by the copy produced by Keith and proudly displayed in the window of a restaurant in south London. "After a hard day at the House of Commons," writes Keith on official notepaper, "there is no better way to relax than to eat at the Imperial Tandoori and I am certain that many of my colleagues feel the same." OK, perhaps just a third-rate advertising agency, but it's a start.

 I'm not going to make a habit of this, but a heart-rending fax arrives from Charles Ponsonby at Bankside Consultants (a PR firm), boldly headed Alumasc Board Appointments. "Over three weeks has elapsed since on February 1 Alumasc announced two executive board appointments," writes Charles in a desperate note, "but the release has still not got to the top of anybody's pile!" Oh dear.

Well, it's a slow news day and even though I've never heard of Alumasc ("the specialist engineering and building products group," it says here), it's a warm "hello!" to Paul Hooper, Alumasc's new group managing director. Paul is 44 years old, with an MBA from Cranfield University, and his first decision as managing director might involve hiring a new PR firm.

 Last week I mocked cable company NTL's customer service agreement, which forbade clients from using the internet from one of its connections for more than 24 hours in a day. A surprisingly large number of readers (yes, both of them) suggest that NTL is marketing services to users on other planets in the solar system. In which case 24 hours seems highly restrictive for internet users on Venus (where a day is 2,802 hours long).

 Psychologists in New York have been studying men's neckwear on Wall Street and concluded that the colour of a man's tie can give away his personality. A yellow tie means a person is shifty, a spotty tie that he is oversexed, while purple or green suggest the wearer is a back-stabber. Red is totally predictable.

webTitle: Britain to boost aid for developing world

fields.headline: Britain to boost aid for developing world as EU relaxes tariff barriers
fields.trailText: Britain is to spearhead a concerted move to boost the aid budgets from the biggest western economies after a plea yesterday from Nelson Mandela.
fields.byline: Larry Elliott and  Andrew Osborn in Brussels
fields.body:
Britain is to spearhead a concerted move to boost the aid budgets from the biggest western economies after a plea yesterday from Nelson Mandela to put saving lives of children in developing countries at the top of the global agenda.

At the end of a one-day conference in London on combating child poverty, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, and the international development secretary, Clare Short, announced that Britain would increase development assistance and urged other wealthy nations to do the same.

Meanwhile, in Brussels, the world's 48 poorest countries yesterday won the right to export almost any product they make to the EU in unlimited quantity and, for the first time, free of all import duty.

The British government had planned to boost aid to 0.33% of GNP by 2003-04, but Mr Brown has agreed to go further after pressure from Ms Short.

Mr Mandela, former president of South Africa, had said the purpose of the conference was to "get specific commitments...and get specific results."

The chancellor said the closing declaration said the meeting had encouraged the various bodies to "work together to commit to a clear set of specific actions for which we all be individually accountable".

He added that the pledges were vital if the international community was to make up lost ground in achieving the targets for 2015 set by the UN six years ago of halving global poverty, cutting infant mortality by two-thirds and providing universal primary education.

"We aim, through achieving these targets, to offer this generation of poor children the opportunities denied to their parents," Mr Brown said.

Government sources said the real achievement of the conference had been to secure specific commitments from the UN agencies Unicef and UNDP, the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund, developed and developing countries.

Britain is to launch a fund to help provide primary education in the Commonwealth and is working with Italy for a $1bn fund to provide cheap drugs for poor countries - with half coming from donations of $500,000 each from the world's 1000 biggest corporations and the rest from developed governments.

James Wolfensohn, president of the World Bank, attacked developed countries for cutting back on aid budgets and "turning their backs on Africa and its children" at a time of unprecedented prosperity. "It is a time for a concerted appeal to the heads of governments of major aid donors to make it clear once and for all that development assistance is not charity, but a vital investment in global peace and security."

Yesterday's decision by EU foreign ministers in Brussels to back the "Everything but Arms" initiative, in the face of French opposition, is designed to alleviate poverty in the developing world and will pile pressure on the US and Japan to grant similar trade concessions.

The measure proved controversial, however, because Europe's farming lobby feared the concessions were too generous and would spark a flood of cheap agricultural imports.

The EU trade commissioner, Frenchman Pascal Lamy, agreed to water down the proposal for the three most sensitive product sectors concerned - bananas, sugar and rice. Zero import tariffs for these products will now be subject to a long phasing-in period and will for the most part not come into force until September 2009.

How the aid breaks down

George Bush has inherited a $1.3bn aid programme aimed at shoring up the Colombian government and fighting the drugs trade. Reflecting growing concern over cocaine and heroin exports, Colombia is now the third-largest recipient of US military aid after Israel and Egypt.

Military aid

Colombia will receive $860.3m. Because US law prohibits funding for an army unit without a clean record, the money comes with strict human rights conditions, but Bill Clinton invoked a presidential waiver to pass the aid package last year, arguing that it was in the national interest. Part of the money will fund an offensive against drug installations in Putumayo and Caqueta states. The largest chunk of aid will pay for 62 combat helicopters - 20 UH-60 Blackhawk helicopters and 42 UH-1H Huey helicopters will be used to escort fumigation missions and lead assaults on cocaine-processing labs.

Intelligence gathering

$290m will be spent on reconnaissance aeroplanes and intelligence-gathering aimed at narcotics installations deep in the Amazon jungle.

Alternative development

$68.5m will fund development schemes to help small farmers switch from drug crops to alternatives such as rubber, tropical fruit and cattle-ranching.

Human rights

$51m will go to projects to improve Colombia's atrocious human rights record.

Attention to war refugees

$22.5m is earmarked to help Colombia's internal war refugees.

Aid for other countries

$180m will be spent in Peru, Bolivia, Ecuador and elsewhere in South America.

fields.headline: How the heroes of Russia turned into the tormentors of Chechnya
fields.standfirst:
Anna Politkovskaya is one of Russia's most respected journalists, writing for the Moscow paper Novaya Gazeta. Last week she travelled deep into Chechnya to investigate reports of torture, rape and detention camps run by the Russian army. If there were any doubts about the veracity of the shocking stories she heard, they vanished when she was herself detained by Russian troops. The journalist had turned victim. Yesterday an inquiry was launched as 30 bodies were found in a mass grave outside Grozny...
Special report: crisis in Chechnya
fields.trailText: Last week Anna Politkovskaya travelled deep into Chechnya to investigate reports of torture, rape and detention camps run by the Russian army. Then she was herself detained by troops. This is her story
fields.body:
It all began when 90 families living in several villages in the Vedeno district of southern Chechnya brought their collective complaint to our editorial office. The text was unprecedented: several hundred people were asking to be helped to to move out of Chechnya to any place in Russia, as soon as possible.

The reasons: constant hunger, unbearable cold, total isolation from the outside world, lack of medical care - and a special complaint about brutal punitive raids on their villages by the federal forces stationed on the outskirts of the village of Khottuni.

The facts were as fantastic as they were glaring. So they had to be verified on the spot. The visit began on February 18. I heard dozens of harrowing accounts from people who had been exposed to torture and maltreatment by Russian troops: stories so horrific that one's hand refused to jot them down.

And then I experienced at first hand events in which I myself was the victim.

It is as if pictures had come to life to confirm the accounts I had heard. Now the person to whom they shouted: "Stop! Get a move on!" was myself. And an official of the FSB - the successor to the KGB - a first lieutenant of tender age, whispered dirty insults in my ear: "You are one of them... You should be shot..."

One of the first accounts of torture was given to me by Rozita, from the village of Tovzeni. She can barely move her lips, her eyes have a vacuous expression, and she still walks with difficulty. Her feet and kidneys ache.

A month ago Rozita was brought to what she called a filtration camp for "sheltering militants". It was a real concentration camp, run on a commercial basis, on the outskirts of the village of Khottuni, in the Vedeno district, where the Russian 45th Airborne Regiment and 119th Paratroop Regiment are stationed.

Rozita is no longer young. She has many children and several grandchildren. The youngest of them is three and previously spoke no Russian, but having seen how her grandmother was detained, now constantly shouts: "Lie down on the floor."

Rozita was arrested in her home at dawn when everybody was asleep. They took her completely by surprise and they did not let her to pack her things properly. She was thrown into a pit in the grounds of the camp outside Khottuni.

"Did they push you? Did they kick you?"

"Yes, that's the usual thing."

Rozita spent 12 days in the pit. The soldier who guarded it took pity on her one night and threw her a piece of rug.

"I curled up on it. The soldier is a human being after all," she said.

The pit was shallow - 1.20 metres (4ft) - and arranged so that the occupant seemed to be in cold mountain air in winter, with no roof overhead, but was unable to stand up because of massive logs across the top which could not be dislodged with the head. So she spent 12 days squatting or sitting on the piece of rug.

Rozita never learned whom she had "sheltered". No charges were ever brought against her, although she was interrogated three times.

Officers young enough to be her sons introduced themselves as FSB people. They put "children's mittens" on her. That means that she had one end of a live wire attached to the fingers of one hand and the other end to the fingers of the other hand. And the wires were slung across the back of her neck.

Torture

"Yes, I screamed something terrible," she said. "It hurt a lot when they turned on the current. But I didn't scream otherwise. I was afraid to provoke them. The FSB people said: 'You aren't dancing well enough. Let's add some more voltage.' And so they did." And Rozita screamed louder and louder.

"Why did they torture you? Did you know?" "No. They didn't ask any specific questions".

Meanwhile the officers told Rozita's relatives through go-betweens that they had better raise money for a ransom. They were told to hurry up because Rozita was not enduring her stay in the pit very well and she might not last too long. After a while the money was brought and Rozita, filthy and unkempt, shuffled toward the regimental checkpoint and her freedom.

So, who is granny Rozita from Tovzeni? A militant? If not, why was she detained? If so, why was she released?

The commander of the 45th Regiment is an attractive-looking, strong-willed man. A colonel who has seen action in Afghanistan and Chechnya. He curses the war, thinks aloud about his children, who are growing up without a father and, if he had his way, would like to end the Chechen war at once. He has had enough.

He is taking me on a guided tour of the grounds of the regiment's garrison in Khottuni, where Rozita was held. Eventually we come to the most essential place. He shows me the pits into which Chechens are thrown after the mopping up operations. He is considerate and he holds my elbow lest I fall into a six-metre hole in the ground.

The pit looks exactly as it was described by the numerous people who have been in it. It measures three by three metres. There is a stench coming from the pit, despite the winter frost. The Chechens are meant to urinate and defecate in the pit. And they spend day and night standing. They have a choice of sitting down.

The commander appears to be very uneasy about what is happening, and he tells me some surprising things. One day a general flew in to inspect the regiment. He saw the detained Chechens standing in the field and ordered them to be kept in the pits, originally dug for dumping rubbish in. The colonel sounds sincere when he says: "But we put only the rebels there. Not ordinary people."

Then there is the account of Isa, who lives in Selmentauzen, also in the Vedeno area of southern Chechnya. He was brought to the camp in early February. They stubbed out cigarettes on his body, they pulled out his nails, and beat him over the kidneys with Pepsi Cola bottles filled with water. Then they threw him down into a pit called the "bathtub". It was filled with water. After throwing in the Chechens, they threw in smoke sticks. Isa survived. Not all did.

Isa shared the pit with five other men. The junior officers who interrogated them told them that they had nice butts, and raped them. And they added as an excuse: "Your women wouldn't let us fuck them."

These Chechens now say they will spend the rest of their lives taking revenge for "nice butts".

Isa never quite recovered from the shock. Like Rozita, he was later released for a ransom raised by his whole village.

Two minutes after I said goodbye to the commander, I was detained. First they made me stand in the middle of a rutted field for more than an hour. Then an armoured vehicle with armed fighters led by a first lieutenant arrived. Their identities were unknown. They seized me, pushed me with their rifle butts, and took me away.

"Your papers are false, you are one of them [the Chechen rebels]," I was told. Then followed interrogations for hours on end. Young officers reminded me pointedly that they were from the FSB and that they took their orders only from President Putin himself. They made it clear to me that freedom was over.

I omit the most disgusting details of the interrogations, because they are utterly obscene. But it is these details - and my tormentors couldn't have imagined it - that provided the key proof that everything the Chechens had earlier told me about tortures and man-handling was true.

From time to time the zealous young officers were joined by a senior officer, a lieutenant-colonel with a swarthy face and dark, stupid, bulging eyes. Every now and then he sent the youngsters out of the tent, switched on what he thought to be romantic music and hinted that if I behaved right I could count on a "favourable outcome".

Screeching

In the intervals between his appearances, the "youngsters" did a competent job touching upon the most sensitive spots: looking at the pictures of my children they did not forget to tell me what they would do to them. It lasted more than three hours.

Eventually the lieutenant-colonel, who tried to arouse my sympathy by saying that he was spilling his blood for nothing, looked at his watch and said: "Let's go, I'll shoot you." He took me out of the tent. It was pitch dark.

We walked a short distance and then the colonel said: "Ready or not, here I come." Suddenly there was a terrible racket, screeching and flames. The lieutenant-colonel seemed to be gratified that I had bent down from horror. It turned out that he had brought me right up to the Grad mortar at the time it was fired.

"Come on." Before long, we came to another flight of steps. "This is a bathhouse. Take off your clothes." When he realised I was not going to oblige, he grew very angry. He kept saying: "A lieutenant-colonel wants you with all his heart and you, wretched bitch."

And he added: "Remember? Ready or not, here I come."

Another officer, who said he was from the FSB, barged into the bathhouse. The lieutenant-colonel drew the line: "She doesn't want to take a bath".

The FSB man put the bottles on the table and said: "Then I'll take her." We circled for a long time through the darkness. Finally he again ordered me to climb down the stairs. It was the bunker which was to become my refuge until I was released in the afternoon of February 22.

On the wall was a poster: "119th Paratroop Regiment". The captions underneath informed you that 18 of its servicemen were holders of the title Hero of Russia.

I demanded to be charged. Or that I should be sent to jail, where my relatives could visit me. "No way! You are one of the bandits! If you worked for us, you would get everything. But you came here to look at the pits. You are a bitch ..."

The nightmare ended with a flight out of Chechnya to Mozdok, in southern Russia, and from there back to Moscow. On the way back, all the isolated stories I had heard, all the episodes of my trip, clicked into one whole. That's when I drew thefinal conclusion.

All this is happening in our country, here, now. Under the existing constitution. Under a "strong-willed" president who is its guarantor. With the prosecutor general's office still functioning. With human rights activists, both government and independent, working to ensure people's rights.

And still, despite all that, there are the pits, the "children's mittens", the "dancing", "ready or not, here I come". And nobody will dare to say that I have not seen it or heard it or touched it. I have experienced it myself.

webTitle: AEA Technology returns to profit warning mode

fields.headline: AEA Technology returns to profit warning mode
fields.trailText: AEA Technology, the last business to be privatised by the Conservatives, yesterday issued its second profit warning in five months, after encountering a variety of problems.
fields.body:
AEA Technology, the last business to be privatised by the Conservatives, yesterday issued its second profit warning in five months, after encountering a variety of problems.

The company spun off from the Atomic Energy Agency in November 1996 at a price of 280p per share saw its stock plunge nearly 30% yesterday to 205p.

In its heyday AEA was worth more than £10 but two years ago the first of what became a series of profit warnings knocked 40% off the price in one day. Last night analysts were again downgrading their profit forecasts.

A statement from the group said its trading performance in the second half would "not meet management expectations". As a result its full-year figures to March 31 would be "significantly below current market estimates".

To counter this, AEA said, it would accelerate its disposal programme. Industry experts say the future of the famous science establishment at Harwell could be undermined if AEA pulled out.

The company said its difficulties stemmed from factors including:

 a slowdown in software engineering deals at a cost of around £5m;

 reductions in orders from BNFL (£2m);

 cost overruns in a number of Ministry of Defence contracts (£1m);

 project losses in one of its environmental businesses (£1m).

The only sector where business has been thriving is the rail sector where AEA has been acquiring businesses.

AEA would speed up its rationalisation programme in the future technology and nuclear technology divisions, which would result in exceptional charges in the current year.

Charles Pick, analyst with fund management group Prudential-Bache, said he had cut his AEA profit forecast from £26m to £16m. He pointed out that only a couple of months ago a previous profit warning forced him to reduce his forecast from £34m.

"Some of the problems are bad luck but we are going to need to see some firm disposals before confidence can be restored."

Last month chief executive Peter Watson appointed Stephen Thornton from BOC as chief operating officer and a new financial director is being sought.

fields.headline: Jazz FM makes first profit
fields.trailText: Jazz FM, favoured by 40-something funksters, claims its growing credibility with a younger, more-hip crowd has helped bring a pre-tax profit for the first time in its 10-year history.
fields.body:
Jazz FM, favoured by 40-something funksters, claims its growing credibility with a younger, more-hip crowd has helped bring a pre-tax profit for the first time in its 10-year history.

Hed Kandi, a wholly owned record label producing CDs for what it dubs "the post-clubbing generation", has grown faster than expected and was a main contributor to a £60,000 pre-tax profit in the six months to December 31.

"The growth of Hed Kandi has been phenomenal," said Jazz FM chief executive Richard Wheatly, pictured right. "It's aimed at 18 to 30-year-olds who don't go to clubs so much any more but still like bars with DJs. Its popularity has far exceeded our expectations."

Turnover from the niche label is expected to exceed £3m in 2001. Jazz FM group turnover was £3.9m, up from £2m on the previous period. Listening hours increased by 37%.

Guardian Media Group, publisher of The Guardian, is a 19% shareholder in Jazz FM. In common with other commercial radio stations, Jazz FM has been bidding for digital licences in anticipation of listeners eventually upgrading their analogue radios ones.

"We don't envisage seeing any real revenues from them for two or three years but we see them as an important way of increasing our national reach," Mr Wheatly said. Shares closed unchanged at 172.5p.
