fields.headline: Chrysler's £2.5bnshake-up
fields.standfirst: Car makers combat global overproduction in different ways - one by shedding 35,000 jobs, another by promoting a supercar
fields.trailText: Car makers combat global overproduction in different ways - one by shedding 35,000 jobs, another by promoting a supercar.
fields.byline: Mark Milner and Jonathan Watts  in Tokyo
fields.body:
DaimlerChrysler yesterday won the backing of its biggest shareholder for a €4bn (£2.5bn) restructuring plan involving 35,500 job losses which is mainly aimed at turning round the fortunes of its struggling Chrysler business.

Deutsche Bank, which owns almost 12% of DaimlerChrysler shares, threw its weight behind chairman Jürgen Schrempp's plans to restore the group's profitability.

The bank's support is a key factor in Mr Schrempp's efforts to rebuild investor confidence in the wake of heavy losses in the US in the second half of last year.

German chancellor Gerhard Schroder added his support for the group's chairman. "I consider Jürgen Schrempp to be a fantastic manager and I am certain he is going to get the job done," he said.

DaimlerChrysler has already announced that it is planning to lay off 26,000 workers and close six plants at Chrysler; yesterday Chrysler's Japanese partner Mitsubishi revealed its own heavy cuts as part of DaimlerChrysler's global restructuring.

Mitsubishi, where DaimlerChrysler has a 34% holding, plans to cut 9,500 jobs and trim its production capacity by 20% while the two companies plan to rack up significant cost savings through platform sharing with Chrysler.

Yesterday DaimlerChrysler reported operating profits, excluding one-off factors, had fallen 49% to €5.2bn and blamed second half losses in North America for the fall.

If the recovery plan is effective the group expects Chrysler - which lost €1.4bn in the fourth quarter alone - to be back in the black in 2002 and making profits of more than €2bn in 2003.

"Today we have a business strategy which gives the best conditions for a successful future. We believe we can do it and we should not speculate about anything else," said Mr Schrempp.

The DaimlerChrysler chairman appears to have convinced Deutsche Bank that his plans will work. The bank's spokesman said: "We are convinced that DaimlerChrysler under the leadership of Jürgen Schrempp will achieve a turnround in its profits situation in the next 12 months.

"The restructuring measures at Chrysler and Mitsubishi are ambitious but plausible, concrete and convincing."

As part of its restructuring programme Mitsubishi, which is Japan's fourth largest car manufacturer, said it would close its plant in Oe, central Japan, and halt production of more than 10 of its 24 passen ger car models. "The programme will be a milestone in the history of MMC leading to an operating profit margin of 4.5% by 2003," said Mitsubishi's chief executive, Rolf Eckrodt, who was dispatched from DaimlerChrysler last year.

Mitsubishi expects to post a loss this year of ¥140bn (£832m) after a steady decline in sales and market share since last July, when the company was forced to recall 1m cars after admitting it had systematically covered up vehicle defect complaints for more than 20 years.

Under the plan, drawn up at the behest of DaimlerChrysler, which has a 34% stake, Mitsubishi aims to cut its material costs by 15%, management ranks by 30% and its 65,000 workforce by about 14%. The company said the restructuring operation would cost ¥100bn to ¥150bn.

Analysts reacted to DaimlerChrysler's plans with caution, arguing that they could be hit by continuing weakness in the US. "Anyone buying the stock now is buying the company's ability to restructure not its ability to make profitable cars," said one analyst.

Two leading US rating agencies cut their ratings on DaimlerChrysler's debt.

fields.headline: Minister rejects Neta fears
fields.trailText: The government swept aside fears yesterday that the March 27 start for a new £1bn electricity trading system could cause a California-style power crisis.
fields.body:
The government swept aside fears yesterday that the March 27 start for a new £1bn electricity trading system could cause a California-style power crisis.

Energy minister Peter Hain told a meeting of power generators, suppliers and consumers that he accepted assurances from the regulator, Ofgem, that the new electricity trading arrangements (Neta) were on track.

Neta has been put back once and further delays would be politically embarrassing with an election impending. But at least one senior industry executive warned privately at the weekend of trouble unless Neta were delayed.

The final decision will come on March 16 with a recommendation from Callum McCarthy, chief executive of Ofgem. Last night he expressed confidence that all was proceeding to plan.

"The central programme is where we expected to be at this stage. I would be surprised if we are not able to recommend to the secretary of state that he should make the decision to 'go live' on March 27. All concerned should plan on the basis that this is likely to occur."

A spokesman for Innogy, the power utility demerged from privatised National Power, said his company was "ready and eager" for Neta.

Nick Baldwin, chief executive of Powergen, said: "We are keen to avoid further delay."

webTitle: Alldays struggles to find a buyer

fields.headline: Alldays struggles to find a buyer
fields.trailText: Alldays, the troubled retail group that put itself up for sale in November, has not been able to find a buyer, it announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Alldays, the troubled retail group that put itself up for sale in November, has not been able to find a buyer, it announced yesterday.

The convenience stores company was said to have been in bid talks with Sainsbury and reported to have received a £90m offer from retail entrepreneurs, Carlisle Group.

"None of the offers that came forward would have been sufficiently attractive to our shareholders," Stuart Lawson, Alldays' finance director, said.

The announcement came as the group posted a pre-tax and pre-exceptional loss of £14.7m for the year to the end of October, compared with £5.9m last year.

The firm also reported exceptional charges of £49.3m, due to acquisitions and continuing operations.

Alldays, whose customers spend on average £2.50 per transaction, increased its debt to £198m, due to restructuring and the integration of over 450 stores, some loss-making, which it took full control of last year.

"It is going to be a long haul. We are carrying a high debt burden so it is going to take a number of years to get the benefits through," Mr Lawson said.

The group also reported a 4% increase for the year in like-for-like sales, with turnover up from £446.9m to £526.7m.

Analysts yesterday said there were few buyers that would be interested in the whole business, however. "They are part way through a long and difficult process. You now have a business that has been seriously damaged," one analyst said.

The company admitted first-quarter trading is below expectations with sales and margins failing to meet targets.

According to Mr Lawson, Alldays hopes to increase the levels of return from its existing portfolio. Shares in the group fell 0.25p to 15.5p and the board decided not to pay a dividend.

The convenience stores company was said to have been in bid talks with Sainsbury and reported to have received a £90m offer from retail entrepreneurs, Carlisle Group. "None of the offers that came forward would have been sufficiently attractive to our shareholders," Stuart Lawson, Alldays' finance director, said. The announcement came as the group posted a pre-tax and pre-exceptional loss of £14.7m for the year to the end of October, compared with £5.9m last year. The firm also reported exceptional charges of £49.3m, due to acquisitions and continuing operations. Alldays, whose customers spend on average £2.50 per transaction, increased its debt to £198m, due to restructuring and the integration of over 450 stores, some loss-making, which it took full control of last year. "It is going to be a long haul. We are carrying a high debt burden so it is going to take a number of years to get the benefits through," Mr Lawson said. The group also reported a 4% increase for the year in like-for-like sales, with turnover up from £446.9m to £526.7m. Analysts yesterday said there were few buyers that would be interested in the whole business, however. "They are part way through a long and difficult process. You now have a business that has been seriously damaged," one analyst said. The company admitted first-quarter trading is below expectations with sales and margins failing to meet targets. webTitle: Stock market worries prompt slump in Isas

fields.headline: Stock market worries prompt slump in Isas
fields.trailText: Sales of individual savings accounts (Isas) are expected to fall by a quarter by April as worried retail investors shun volatile stock markets.
fields.body:
Sales of individual savings accounts (Isas) are expected to fall by a quarter by April as worried retail investors shun volatile stock markets.

The Association of Unit Trust and Investment Funds (Autif) predicted the slump after it produced figures yesterday showing a fall of more than 5% in January compared to the same month last year.

Gross sales of Isas fell to £637m in value during the first month of the year, compared to £673.5m in January 2000, Autif said.

A spokeswoman said annual unit sales were likely to reach 3m at the end of the tax year in April, as against sales of 4m for the year to April 2000.

Many investors are nursing large losses after a year in which all leading stock markets slipped into negative territory. Funds that invested heavily in internet-related companies proved popular in the first three months of last year but were big losers as the rerating of the technology, media and telecom (TMT) sector began to affect prices.

In the year to the end of December 2000 the technology-heavy Nasdaq dropped 39.3%. Investors who stuck with the previously successful tracker funds were also undone after the FTSE 100 fell 10.2% and the Dow Jones 6.18%.

Sales of specialist funds, which include the TMT sector, fell to less than 4% of total gross sales in January, down from a peak of around 16% in the same period last year.

Investors have switched to broader-based funds. In January, company funds and funds investing in Europe - excluding Britain - were the most popular sectors among retail investors.

Overall, savings and investments sales figures registered a rise, however. Net sales of unit trusts, open-ended investment companies, Isas and Peps were ahead of January 2000 at £1.8bn compared to £616.5m a year earlier.

Total gross sales were up 23% on January 2000 at £4.5bn.

The increase suggests that, while the number of people taking up their £7,000 Isa entitlement this year has shrunk, those investors that remain are increasing their holdings in non-Isa funds.

fields.headline: Microsoft judges talk tough
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of Microsoft
fields.trailText: Lawyers for the US government yesterday faced tough questioning from appeals court judges with the power to overturn their landmark victory against Microsoft - which was last year judged to have abused its stranglehold on the world's computer market.
fields.body:
Lawyers for the US government yesterday faced tough questioning from appeals court judges with the power to overturn their landmark victory against Microsoft - which was last year judged to have abused its stranglehold on the world's computer market.

Seven judges, led by chief judge Harry Edwards, opened the two-day court of appeals hearing yesterday by focusing on the heart of the government's case - that Microsoft behaved illegally in trying to maintain its monopoly of operating systems used in personal computers.

The US justice department and 19 US states won their case, last year, after accusing Microsoft of trying to crush Netscape, the web browser company. Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson ruled that the world's largest software company should be broken into two because of this illegal behaviour, a ruling which prompted Microsoft to appeal.

The appeal court judges focused their vigorous questioning on the question of whether monopolies were a standard feature of the successful hi-tech industry, whether Netscape really represented a great threat to Microsoft and what powers they had to overturn Judge Jackson's findings of fact as opposed to his judgment.

Judge Edwards returned several times to the question of whether the nature of the software industry led to monopolies. He referred to Netscape's share of the browser market before Microsoft brought out a rival product. "It looks like one monopoly replacing another . . . Are we fighting for the newest, latest monopoly status?"

Jeffery Minear, the government's lawyer, said that Microsoft was simply trying to protect its monopoly. "There ought to be competition on the merits of the two browsers."

The severity of the questioning led some observers to suggest that the conservative nature of the appeals court would act against the US government in this case. Two of the seven judges have previously ruled in favour of Microsoft in a similar, but much smaller, anti-monopolies case.

The appeal court decision is likely to take several weeks, if not months.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Agere offer scaled back
fields.body:
Agere offer scaled back

The potential market value of Lucent Technologies' Agere Systems unit fell by $6.7bn as the optical component and circuit-maker yesterday announced changes to its initial public offering, reflecting falling share prices in the sector.

Agere increased the class A common shares it plans to sell to 300m from 222.7m, in an amended IPO prospectus filed with the securities and exchange Commission. The price range dropped to $12-$14 apiece from $16-$19 but Agere maintained it still planned to net $3.75bn.

Gearhouse in receivership

Gearhouse, which provided lighting and video systems for pop concerts and corporate events, has gone into receivership with debts of around £20m.

The company's shares were suspended on the stock exchange at the turn of the year after it said it was in talks with bankers.

Andrew Wollaston, of receivers Ernst & Young, said the company's core businesses were sound, but: "It had invested in other areas such as building the largest tent in the world, and something called Optiscreen which is a tower of TV screens, and these were not paying their way."

He hoped to sell the company, which employs 700 people worldwide and had a £70m turnover, as a going concern.

Blue Circle boss to resign

Rick Haythornthwaite, chief executive of Blue Circle Industries, made it clear yesterday that he would be looking for another job once Lafarge of France takes control of the cement group, due this summer.

Mr Haythornthwaite will accept a non-executive title with Lafarge but said he would then "be going into the market to see what opportunities there are in publicly-quoted companies."

He was speaking after Blue Circle reported pre-tax profits before exceptionals up 20% at £325.4m, slightly lower than many expected.

Ofgem frees up British Gas

Ofgem, the energy regulator, yesterday said it would remove the last price controls on British Gas from April, provided the Centrica-owned company kept special charges for late payment or pre-payment in line with its other tariffs.

British Gas announced this month that gas prices would rise by an average of 4.7% from April.

webTitle: Resorts seek bucket loads of aid

fields.headline: Resorts seek bucket loads of aid
fields.standfirst: England's seaside resorts are in danger of falling into terminal decline unless they receive a significant cash injection from the private sector, a new report has warned
fields.trailText: England's seaside resorts are in danger of falling into terminal decline unless they receive a significant cash injection from the private sector, a new report has warned.
fields.body:
"Sea Changes - creating world class resorts in Eng land", a report from the English Tourism Council published today, says resorts need better marketing and transport links and to make more use of available regeneration grants if they are to stem the tide of holidaymakers who are preferring to take their summer breaks overseas. "The decline of resorts has been slow and subtle . . . [but] the seriousness should not be underestimated," said English Tourist Council chairman Alan Britten.

Mr Britten said the government needed to encour age resorts to think of new ways to entice visitors; public-private partnerships were a must.

The report was drawn up in response to figures showing that the number of Britons taking overseas holidays has more than doubled over the past decade, while the number holidaying in England grew by only 59%.

The number of people spending eight nights or more at an English resort fell 14% in the 1990s, according to the ETC.

Seaside resorts, such as Blackpool, pictured above, which remains Britain's number one tourist destination with 7m visitors a year, generate around £4.5bn in spending each year. However, the British now spend more than two-thirds of their annual holiday budget overseas.

webTitle: P&G profits down after lira collapse

fields.headline: P&G profits down after lira collapse
fields.trailText: Procter & Gamble yesterday became the first multinational to issue a profits warning in the light of last week's collapse of the Turkish lira.
fields.body:
Procter & Gamble yesterday became the first multinational to issue a profits warning in the light of last week's collapse of the Turkish lira.

The US's largest consumer group said Turkey's economic problems would shave 3 cents off its earnings estimate for the third quarter of between 69 and 72 cents a share.

Turkey is its 12th largest market, accounting for more than $400m (£277m) in annual sales.

Anglo-Dutch group Unilever, the American business's main rival, said it saw no reason to change its recent forecast of double-digit earnings growth.

However Renault, the French-based carmaker, later said it had been hard hit by the Turkish crisis, although it was too early to quantify the impact. The group is the leading car manufacturer in Turkey which is its largest market outside western Europe. Its Turkish sales fell 30% in January, and are expected to fall by a similar amount this month.

P&G, which is best known for Tide and Ariel detergents, Crest toothpaste, Pampers disposable nappies and Pringles snacks, saw its share price fall by more than 5% after its profits warning.

The market is now expecting P&G's full year earnings per share to be about 5 cents below the current forecast of $3.15.

Alan Lafley, who took over as P&G's president and chief executive in June last year, said: "The sudden crisis in Turkey is unfortunate. However we will not sacrifice plans undertaken elsewhere around the world to get the business back on track in order to offset this short-term issue."

P&G is the market leader in Turkey for laundry detergents, soap, hair and feminine care products and nappies.

The Turkish lira has fallen about 28% against the dollar since it was floated last Thursday. The country's central bank intervened yesterday to reduce interest rates by lending money to banks at well below last week's sky-high levels.

fields.headline: £800,000 salary top-up
fields.trailText: Sir John Bond, the chairman of HSBC, received an extra £800,000 last year, taking his total pay to £1.6m, because the bank decided he was underpaid.
fields.body:
Sir John Bond, the chairman of HSBC, received an extra £800,000 last year, taking his total pay to £1.6m, because the bank decided he was underpaid.

His discretionary bonus was among eight such payments made to HSBC's top executives last year. Keith Whitson, the chief executive, received £700,000 while Bill Dalton, who runs the UK banking business, received an extra £300,000 into his pension.

Overall the bank paid out £2.5m in such discretionary bonuses which were paid following an "independent survey of remuneration" during 2000. It is not clear how shareholders - who keep a close watch on directors' pay - will react to the payments which have already been made.

The payments, contained in the bank's 2000 report and accounts published yesterday, were defended by HSBC. "We have 29 executive directors and management collectively with 760 years of service, 24 of them with over 20 years each," a spokesman said. The annual report said the payments were made in line with the guidelines of an independent survey and endorsed by the remuneration committee, which decides the wages of the board directors.

With the discretionary bonuses, Sir John's pay was more than double the £750,000 he received in 1999, And Mr Whitson was paid a total of £1.3m, compared with £620,000 in 1999.

The payments do not take account of gains on share options made during the year. Sir John made a gain of £1.5m from exercising options to buy shares granted to him in 1993.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • Concern mounts for boulevardier Andrew Neil, whose media diary persecution complex deepens by the day. Yesterday's rant in our Media section, in response to the previous week's suggestion that he has blown £120m of the Barclays' money, was memorable for his whine about "the most unflattering picture" of him being chosen (isn't that typical though? Kate, Linda, Jaquetta, Andrew ... perfectionists, the lot of them, and they guard their images like demons). Would you believe an even longer version of this rant appeared in the Scotsman (we'll come to that tomorrow).
fields.body:
 Concern mounts for boulevardier Andrew Neil, whose media diary persecution complex deepens by the day. Yesterday's rant in our Media section, in response to the previous week's suggestion that he has blown £120m of the Barclays' money, was memorable for his whine about "the most unflattering picture" of him being chosen (isn't that typical though? Kate, Linda, Jaquetta, Andrew ... perfectionists, the lot of them, and they guard their images like demons). Would you believe an even longer version of this rant appeared in the Scotsman (we'll come to that tomorrow).

For now, let's consider Andrew's email to the Telegraph media diary on the crucial question of whether it was then editor Jane Procter's dog Kenzo or Diary pundit Steptoe who used to go to Tatler. "I have checked with Jane: she assures me it was Rebecca's dog (Steptoe) which came into the office on a regular basis, which the Telegraph wrote about. Since I know Jane to be honest and your diary to be dishonest, I'm pretty sure I know who is telling the truth. I look forward to more lies and distortion from you next week. You're a credit to our profession," writes Andrew, concluding with a waspish: "Who the hell are you, anyway?" Mayday, Mayday, Andrew Neil to anger management, Andrew Neil to anger ...

 We also share with the Telegraph an interest in Alan Duncan's dealings with the Clinton-pardoned crook Marc Rich. Yesterday my so-called rival carried Little Alan's denial of ever having spoken to Mr Rich, in whose employ he made millions, and so be it. It's odd, though, that on all his Christmas skiing holidays in St Moritz, where Mr Rich owns a huge chalet, Alan never shared an eggnog with his old boss. Meanwhile, although the nationals are ever more interested in him, constituents in Rutland and Melton can expect to read nothing critical in the local press. More on this soon.

 With the UK Press Gazette awards decided last Friday, my colleague Marina Hyde calls the mag's editor Philippa Kennedy about special arrangements for David Yelland, who believes that the Sun will be newspaper of the year. "You're going to quote me, aren't you?" says Philippa, refusing to confirm David's victory. "Well, I am not going to say anything about a carer. David ... well, he's a grown-up person and is perfectly capable of looking after himself." Mm. It seems harsh to recall David's behaviour two years ago when eschewing so petty bourgeois a mode of furniture as a chair in favour of direct contact with the carpet. Yet we must. "I'm not going to say anything about that," says Philippa firmly.

 Film buffs will recall Valerie Leon as the shop assistant who erected Charles Hawtrey's tent in Carry on Camping, and Guardian scholars know her as the mother of our feature writer Merope Mills, but to me she is London's most relentless, terrifying PR - and when she faxes something over, in it goes. Val's latest venture is a chamber music concert at Kensington Palace on March 13, in the presence of Prince Charles (must be a while since he's been there for an outing). Lady Solti, Georg's widow, will also be there on Hungarian National Day to hear the Liszt Academy perform. Hats off to the Magyars, then, and here's to a peaceful month or two before Val's next project.

 The Times plug crisis roars back into life. When we left the kitchen, the microwave plug was back and all was well. Alas, an anonymous source calls to report that it vanished again, curiously just before original suspect Val Elliott left on holiday. Now a severed plug has been found in Val's top right drawer, although many think it as much a plant as the scissors spotted semi-hidden on political writer Andrew Pierce's desk. Will this nightmare never end?

 Does anyone know whatever happened to Brentford Nylons?

webTitle: Buchan moves in as new chief at Durex

fields.headline: Buchan moves in as new chief at Durex
fields.trailText: SSL International, the Durex condoms-maker, has moved quickly to appoint a new chief executive just a week after its former boss Iain Cater was "invited" to step down.
fields.body:
SSL International, the Durex condoms-maker, has moved quickly to appoint a new chief executive just a week after its former boss Iain Cater was "invited" to step down.

The position will be filled by Brian Buchan, the former president of Procter & Gamble's £2bn-a-year feminine care operations. The 48-year-old, who masterminded the European launch of P&G's successful "Always" feminine protection range, will join the Cheshire-based healthcare firm on March 12.

"We are delighted to have secured him. I think he has got exactly the right experience," outgoing chairman Stuart Wallis said.

The stock market was less impressed by the appointment, however, marking SSL shares 4p lower at 471p.

Last Monday, a bitter four-month battle for control of SSL ended in dramatic fashion with Mr Cater leaving immediately and Mr Wallis agreeing to follow in June. The departures came as SSL issued its second profits warning in less than four months. Mr Wallis denied the appointment had been rushed and said it carried the full backing of the board.

"He has been president of a £2bn feminine care products business, very relevant to the things SSL gets involved in because you are selling to the same sort of markets and outlets around the world," Mr Wallis said.
fields.bodyText: SSL International, the Durex condoms-maker, has moved quickly to appoint a new chief executive just a week after its former boss Iain Cater was "invited" to step down. The position will be filled by Brian Buchan, the former president of Procter & Gamble's £2bn-a-year feminine care operations. The 48-year-old, who masterminded the European launch of P&G's successful "Always" feminine protection range, will join the Cheshire-based healthcare firm on March 12. "We are delighted to have secured him. I think he has got exactly the right experience," outgoing chairman Stuart Wallis said. The stock market was less impressed by the appointment, however, marking SSL shares 4p lower at 471p. Last Monday, a bitter four-month battle for control of SSL ended in dramatic fashion with Mr Cater leaving immediately and Mr Wallis agreeing to follow in June. The departures came as SSL issued its second profits warning in less than four months. Mr Wallis denied the appointment had been rushed and said it carried the full backing of the board. "He has been president of a £2bn feminine care products business, very relevant to the things SSL gets involved in because you are selling to the same sort of markets and outlets around the world," Mr Wallis said.

webTitle: New evidence of life on Mars

fields.headline: New evidence of life on Mars
fields.standfirst:
Scientists say meteorite shows conclusive evidence, but others disagree
Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Researchers examining the world's most dramatic meteorite claim today that they have "conclusive" evidence for life on Mars.
fields.body:
Researchers examining the world's most dramatic meteorite claim today that they have "conclusive" evidence for life on Mars.

Tiny crystals of magnetite inside a 4.5bn-year-old lump of rock from outer space called ALH84001 could only have been left behind by living organisms, they report in the US Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

They suggest that long ago, the decomposed remains of magnetotactic bacteria - microbes with a kind of built-in compass - slipped down fissures in a rock. This was dislodged from the planet in some cosmic collision, and sent adrift in space for millions of years. Then it crashed into the Allen Hills region of Antarctica about 13,000 years ago.

"These crystals match all the criteria for biologically formed chains, and as far as I am concerned it's conclusive evidence that Martian bacteria were in this meteorite," said Imre Friedmann, of the University of South Florida. "I cannot guess how my colleagues will react but in my opinion no reasonable person can doubt it any more. The evidence is so strong."

The finding is sure to intensify the study of the Red Planet. Two robot missions - from Britain and from Nasa - are to land at the end of 2003.

The meteorite has been a focus of furious debate since a Nasa team in 1996 announced that they had detected what they called "nanofossils" inside the rock, and that these fossils of unimaginably small bacteria could only have come from Mars.

The claims were supported a year later by a robot rover and an orbiting survey of Mars, which produced convincing evidence that there had once been lakes and rivers on what is now a cold, arid, lifeless husk. For water to have flowed, there must have once been a thick, warm atmosphere, which could have nurtured life.

There is no doubt that the meteorite came from Mars: trapped inside it are tiny bubbles of air that exactly match the composition of the atmosphere of Mars. But one group of scientists said there were no such things as nanobacteria, which would be 10 times smaller than any bacteria found on Earth, and argued that the supposed nanofossils were accidents of chemistry.

But in 1999, a geologist in Queensland, Australia, found nanobacteria in clay mineral samples and reawakened the debate. Meanwhile another team found that the meteorite contained traces of organic carbon and the amino acids that make proteins, and said that these were likely to have got into the meteorite on Earth, rather than on Mars.

Dr Friedmann and three colleagues used a new kind of electron microscope technique to look again at the tiny crystals. "The chances of finding so many bacteria in a two kilogram rock from another planet are quite slim," he said. "It means bacteria must have been very widespread on Mars."

In 2003, Nasa will launch a craft carrying two landers, and the Europeans will launch Mars Express, bearing a British lander, Beagle 2, with instruments that will "sniff" for the chemical signatures of microbes.

But Beagle 2's chief scientist, Colin Pillinger of the Open University, was not convinced by the US claims. "I think we are not going to get a conclusive answer out of these meteorites ever, now. The next step is to go there - and bring some samples back, eventually."

webTitle: IRA chief warns of return to war if talks fail

fields.headline: IRA chief warns of return to war if talks fail
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The IRA could return to violence to achieve a united Ireland if the current political process fails, the organisation's reputed leader has warned.
fields.body:
The IRA could return to violence to achieve a united Ireland if the current political process fails, the organisation's reputed leader has warned.

In a rare public speech, in the republican stronghold of south Armagh, to commemorate two members killed by their own bomb in 1988, Brian Keenan told supporters they should not fear the collapse of the Good Friday agreement.

Mr Keenan is not believed to be heralding the imminent breakdown of the IRA ceasefire, particularly with Sinn Fein poised for substantial gains in the general election, but rather signalling that all options are still open.

But with discussions over policing, the scaling down of British security and paramilitary decommissioning deadlocked, his views make any radical move on republican disarmament very unlikely.

Mr Keenan, jailed for 14 years for his role in the 1970s bombing campaign in mainland Britain, said armed struggle and political negotiations were both legitimate forms of revolution.

"Both of them have to be prosecuted to their utmost," he said. "Those who say the war is over, I don't know what they're talking about. The revolution can never be over until we have British imperialism where it belongs, in the dustbin of history."

Mr Keenan, a backer of Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams and the peace process, also has an eye on further defections from the Provisionals to groups such as the Real IRA.

"The republican negotiators who have taken on the enemy at the point where the enemy is, at the negotiation table, need the support of a united organisation," he stressed.

All sides agree the window of opportunity to resolve the current deadlock is fast closing as election fever looms. A review of the agreement and suspension of the power-sharing Stormont government are possibilities if there is no breakthrough in the next few weeks.

webTitle: Peres talks Labour into coalition with Sharon

fields.headline: Peres talks Labour into coalition with Sharon
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel's divided Labour party agreed yesterday to join the country's prime minister-elect, Ariel Sharon, in the unity government that he hopes will check a Palestinian uprising and chart a new course for Middle East peacemaking.
fields.body:
Israel's divided Labour party agreed yesterday to join the country's prime minister-elect, Ariel Sharon, in the unity government that he hopes will check a Palestinian uprising and chart a new course for Middle East peacemaking.

After a stormy session of the 1,600-member central committee, 67% of delegates voted in favour of the move, while 32% voted against, said Labour's secretary general, Raanan Cohen.

"The country has a chance for peace and the party has a chance for renewal," Shimon Peres, one-time Labour prime minister, said after the vote.

In one of his most fiery speeches in years, Mr Peres tried to rally the centre-left party behind his vision of a political partnership with Mr Sharon, who he said would make "painful concessions" for peace.

"The time has come to listen to the people," Mr Peres, 77, urged the gathering, raising his voice above the din of hecklers and gesturing from the podium.

"For once and for all, listen to the people."

Mr Sharon crushed Labour's Ehud Barak in the February 6 prime ministerial election in an indication of deep public dissatisfaction over what many Israelis viewed as over-generous peace proposals offered by the outgoing leader.

Mr Sharon is insisting that Palestinians must halt the uprising - which erupted in late September after he visited a hotly contested Jerusalem holy site - before any peace efforts can resume.

Mr Peres told his audience in Tel Aviv that the uprising and what he said were future dangers such as Iraq possibly developing a nuclear option, meant that the Labour party could not turn its back on the challenges facing the Jewish state.

"We won't be part of this struggle? Isn't this our country? Do we have another country? We'll sit and wait for what? To make a few more speeches in opposition?" he asked the audience.

Fresh violence in the West Bank yesterday underlined the challenges facing Mr Sharon and the unity government.

Israeli troops shot dead a 15-year-old Palestinian during stone-throwing clashes near the city of Ramallah, local hospital sources said.

Since the uprising began, 333 Palestinians, 61 Israelis and 13 Israeli Arabs have been killed.

Mr Peres said Mr Sharon had offered Labour the key posts of foreign minister and defence chief and agreed to coalition guidelines that enshrined the principle of territorial compromise and honoured past peace accords.

"I am not giving up on Oslo," said Mr Peres, who was awarded a Nobel peace prize along with Yasser Arafat and then-prime minister Yitzhak Rabin a year after the 1993 interim peace deal was signed.

"I believe they offered us [these cabinet posts] in order to find a common denominator, to extract the country from trouble, to open up a source of light and hope for the future," said Mr Peres, who received a standing ovation from the central committee.

Mr Peres has said he would like to serve as foreign minister and told the assembly he would be prepared to answer a future call to become Labour's chairman again. Mr Barak resigned the post last week, starting what he called a timeout from politics.

Mr Sharon's alternative to unity was a rightwing government that would find it harder to revive peace talks. He must form a government by the end of March or face a general election.

The outgoing foreign minister, Shlomo Ben-Ami, told Labour's central committee meeting he was "nauseated" by the spectacle of the party "slithering on its belly" to join up with Sharon.

"You are hastening the clinical death of this party," he said, addressing supporters of a unity administration. Reuters

fields.headline: Miners closer to emphysema payouts
fields.trailText: The scandal of delayed compensation payments to 100,000 former miners with emphysema will come closer to an end today when the government admits that the victims must be given extra cash to make up for their loss of pension earnings.
fields.body:
The scandal of delayed compensation payments to 100,000 former miners with emphysema will come closer to an end today when the government admits that the victims must be given extra cash to make up for their loss of pension earnings.

Government lawyers calculate that it will cost £400m to make good the deficit. As much as £30m will go to widows. The deal should clear the way for thousands of miners to receive full and final payments, instead of interim handouts.

The energy minister, Peter Hain, said yesterday: "The coal health compensation scheme is the biggest compensation scheme in legal history, and reaching agreement on pensions was the last piece of the legal puzzle. We have finally swept away the last major hurdle and can crack on with making full and final offers."

Mr Hain was appointed campaign organiser for Labour's Welsh election campaign last week, and he knows that Labour cannot afford to enter the election without addressing the growing criticism in coalfield areas of the delays in implementing the scheme.

The high court ordered British Coal to pay compensation three years ago, saying there was a link between deep mine working and emphysema.

Even though £1m a day is being paid out, the government has been attacked by mining unions, some Labour backbench MPs and by Plaid Cymru for delaying compensation. Over 130,000 claims have been tabled with British Coal and the government, but few cases have been settled.

As many as 6,000 miners have died since the court rul ing in September 1997 without receiving any compensation. The deal to be announced today will settle the level of pension payouts to miners who had to quit early or transfer to less well paid jobs.

Mr Hain admitted yesterday: "There have been too many delays in the past with people not seeing money they deserve quickly enough. We are driving forward improvements all the time and working on a range of practical ideas to get things moving."

Labour MPs representing former mining communities blame complex medical assessments of claims, including a paper chase of claimants' full medical records, including unrelated issues such as broken legs. The medical records have to be copied at doctor's premises which has delayed the hand-outs.

In South Wales alone where more than £100m has been given in compensation, doctors face 26,788 chest complaint claims. Britain is suffering from a shortage of doctors with expertise in respiratory diseases capable of assessing a compensation claim.

Mr Hain has visited medical testing centres in South Wales, and has negotiated a deal whereby doctors can work for more than 15 hours week on compensation claims and not be found in breach of their NHS contract.

The government is also examining whether to increase fees for doctors to test claimants for chest diseases. At the beginning of 1999 the Department of Trade and Industry stated that it would be completing full medical assessments at the rate of 2,500 a month by March 1999, and 4,000 by the summer of 2000. However, by the end of 2000, not even 2,000 a month were being carried out.

webTitle: Austrian minister of women to fight for men

fields.headline: Austrian minister of women to fight for men
fields.trailText: It can never be easy winning approval as women's affairs minister when you are a man. But Herbert Haupt has just made his task a lot trickier by announcing that his ministry will soon be opening a men's department.
fields.body:
It can never be easy winning approval as women's affairs minister when you are a man. But Herbert Haupt has just made his task a lot trickier by announcing that his ministry will soon be opening a men's department.

A member of the Austrian far-right Freedom party, Mr Haupt was a controversial choice as women's minister when the ministry was absorbed into the social affairs ministry in the autumn.

Yesterday he explained that women's lib had achieved more than enough, and these days it was men who were suffering discrimination.

He added that the new department, to be set up later this year, would work with existing organisations and advice centres for oppressed Austrian males, and would aim to produce important studies on significant male issues.

What precisely those might be he did not say.

Feminists, opposition politicians and leading women MPs reacted with predictable outrage, accusing Mr Haupt, a veterinary surgeon by profession, of provocation, insulting the nation's womanhood and pursuing cynical policies.

Martina Ludwig of the opposition Social Democrats said Mr Haupt had let women down badly.

"But instead of balancing out his deficits, he chooses to swap women's affairs for male affairs," she said.

Madeleine Petrovic, a Green MP, went further, saying that the minister's "chauvinistic whingeing" had "absolutely nothing to do with reality". She pointed out that a recent government survey showed that Austrian women were paid about a third less than men for doing equivalent jobs.

A spokeswoman for the social affairs ministry admitted that the idea of a men's department in the women's affairs ministry might sound a trifle strange. "But the minister takes his job very seriously," she added.

"He's not taking sides in this battle of the sexes, just giving both of them fair and equal treatment."

fields.headline: Security guards 'to patrol streets'
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's 10-year crime plan was criticised by the police and libertarians last night, within hours of its launch, for its proposals to put private security patrols on the streets and disclose previous convictions to juries in some criminal trials.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's 10-year crime plan was criticised by the police and libertarians last night, within hours of its launch, for its proposals to put private security patrols on the streets and disclose previous convictions to juries in some criminal trials. But normally critical penal reform groups gave a warm welcome to the "tough but tender" plan.

When he announced the proposals, the prime minister renewed his pledge to tackle crime and its causes while breaking the "cycle of reoffending" which makes the 100,000 most persistent of fenders responsible for about half of all crime.

In parliament, the home secretary, Jack Straw, gave the details of the package, which is designed to end the long term decline in detection and conviction rates: they have halved in the past 20 years.

A key proposal is the introduction of a "custody plus" sentence to replace sentences of 12 months or less passed on 46,000 people each year. Those released would be subjected to intensive supervision, treatment and training, under threat of returning to prison if they failed to comply or offended again.

But it is unclear whether sentencing would be tougher or more lenient under the proposal, which would affect half the people jailed each year.

Mr Straw said it had not yet been decided whether they would serve shorter or longer periods before their release under supervision.

The package was less of a root and branch shake-up of the courts and sentencing laws than had been trailed, because ministers have been forced to wait until later in the year for two reports, from Lord Justice Auld and a Home Office civil servant, John Halliday, which are expected to propose more fundamental changes.

Two key proposals immediately ran into trouble. The scheme to introduce police-accredited private security patrols to supplement the police outside schools, busy commuter stations and similar places was criticised by the Police Federation.

It said the plan was simply trying to provide "a substitute for properly trained police officers". The last attempt to introduce such a measure was made by Michael Howard when he was home secretary.

The police were so opposed that they would not let him call it patrolling, so he had to say it was "walking with a purpose". Labour's document avoids the word "patrolling" too, but makes clear its intention.

Civil liberties groups criticised the package too, for the proposal to give the prosecution more powers in court, in an attempt to increase the conviction rate.

Liberty called the limited disclosure of previous convictions to juries "a serious erosion of a key principle of the criminal justice system".

But penal reform groups, such as the Howard League, welcomed the package, describing it as "the most constructive of this, or the last century".

They particularly liked Mr Blair's recognition that the causes of crime are woven into the fabric of society.

In a speech that lacked the usual politician's rhetoric about a "war on crime," Mr Blair said: "Family breakdown leaving kids without a stable framework from which to grow up; unemployment leaving families without hope for the future; kids dropping out of school; hard drugs; teenage pregnancies; a lack of respect for the law becoming breaking the law: common sense tells us that these are long-term problems that require long-term solutions."

webTitle: Child defendants need more protection, say experts

fields.headline: Child defendants need more protection, say experts
fields.trailText: Crown courts can be intimidating places even for adults. But for the increasing numbers of child defendants, the formality and adversarial nature of the proceedings often make appearing in court an overwhelmingly stressful and frightening experience, writes Maggie Murray
fields.body:
Crown courts can be intimidating places even for adults. But for the increasing numbers of child defendants, the formality and adversarial nature of the proceedings often make appearing in court an overwhelmingly stressful and frightening experience.

Now, leading child law experts, social workers and others working in the criminal justice system say that it is time for a radical overhaul of the way child defendants are dealt with in England and Wales. Some practitioners are also calling for the age of criminal responsibility to be raised.

The call for reforms comes in the wake of the case of a 12-year-old autistic boy accused of killing his brother.

The boy, who had been exposed to years of abuse, appeared at Bristol crown court accused of murder although his plea of manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility was accepted.

Both the judge who heard the case and Lady Helena Kennedy QC, who defended him, have raised doubts over the suitability of the crown court as a means of trying such young defendants.

"There has to be some better way of dealing with children in the criminal justice system," says Helena Kennedy. "There should be a public debate and possibly a commission in the wake of the Bulger case and cases like this one to look at the procedures that we have for dealing with children.

"One possibility would be a High Court judge sitting possibly with a panel. In Scotland they have the children's panels and we could look to other countries to see if they handle these cases more effectively."

The Bristol case was one of the first involving a child defendant of such a young age on a murder charge since the James Bulger case. As a result of the criticism of the way in which the Bulger case was handled, efforts were made in Bristol to minimise the formality of the courtroom.

Lawyers dispensed with their wigs, the public was excluded and the press presence was kept to a minimum. A small part of the court was cordoned off to hear the case and the windows were taped with brown paper to ensure privacy. The boy sat in the main body of the courtroom with his social worker and solicitor rather than the dock, and he was allowed frequent breaks.

But even with these attempts to make the courtroom a less intimidating place, Justice Toulson expressed grave doubts over the present system.

"It is certainly a matter for legitimate public discussion how well our present system of criminal justice is attuned to handling cases of this kind."

Allan Levy QC, a leading child law expert who has campaigned for changes for many years, agrees that the way children are dealt with in criminal cases is unacceptable.

"We are treating them as adults and expecting them to cope with the adult language and adult procedures of the legal system. I would take children out of the crown court and they would not appear there at all. For cases of murder and manslaughter particularly there should be special courts for children with specially trained judges. It is quite wrong to have children appearing in the crown court,'' he says.

''The most radical suggestion that I advocate is that the age of criminal responsibility should be raised to 14. At 10, we are way out of line with the rest of Europe. We are taking away the protection that childhood should bring."

Kate Akester, criminal justice director of the human rights organisation, Justice, also agrees that the system is seriously flawed and requires radical re-working.

"Other countries take a more child centred approach. Scotland for instance through the children's hearing system is an example of the way in which young offenders can be diverted out of the criminal process. Children are seen by a panel of three lay people who meet the child in an informal atmosphere, although serious cases like murder, manslaughter, rape and serious assault are dealt with in the adult courts,'' she says.

"There are concerns that the lack of legal advice for children who come before the hearings in Scotland - who are not legally represented in the majority of cases - can leave their human rights infringed. But countries like Scotland, New Zealand, Austria and New South Wales in Australia have an approach which places the best interests of the child as the paramount consideration and such a guiding principle is absent from the system in England and Wales."

Hilary Cross, spokeswoman for the NSPCC, stresses that the priority in any system is making sure that the child understands what is going on.

"We stress that if young people, whether they are defendants or witnesses, are to receive justice in the courts, they need to understand and follow the legal process that is taking place, they should be given every opportunity to have their story heard, and their specific needs as children should be taken into account," she says.

fields.headline: Sir Donald Bradman
fields.standfirst: The greatest cricketer of the 20th century, he embodied the Australian dream
fields.trailText: The greatest cricketer of the 20th century, he embodied the Australian dream.
fields.body:
Sir Donald Bradman, who has died aged 92, was the greatest cricketer of the 20th century and the greatest batsman who ever lived. He was also arguably the most famous of all Australians - and among the most influential. Sport played a major role in giving the young nation of Australia global standing, self-belief and a sense of identity. The tragic boxer Les Darcy and the racehorse Phar Lap played a part in this process, but nothing could match the phenomenon of Bradman.

His batting statistics are indelible and incredible, incomparably ahead of everyone else who has played the game. Seventy-two other players - including some indifferent ones - have scored more runs in first-class cricket; his totals of Test runs and centuries have been surpassed. But, in Bradman's time, a first-class match in Australia, let alone a Test match, was an event, and then the war intervened.

He thus went to the crease in major cricket only 338 times, but in 117 of those innings returned with a century - a strike-rate above one in three, better than twice the ratios achieved by such greats as Jack Hobbs, Len Hutton, Walter Hammond or Denis Compton. His first-class average was 95.14; his nearest rival is on 71.

Most famously of all, he went out at the Oval in his last Test innings needing only four to finish with an average of 100, and was bowled second ball by Eric Hollies, of Warwickshire, for a duck. It was as though the gods of cricket had reclaimed the invulnerability they had loaned him - though his final average, 99.94, remains so resonant that the Australian Broadcasting Commission uses it as its post-office box number.

In life, as in cricket, he came closer to immortality, outliving his contemporaries, rivals and enemies; there were always plenty of those - despite the near-perfection of his cricket, he was a complex, often troubled, man. Though he achieved everyone else's fantasies, he never seemed to find true fulfilment.

Yet he embodied the Australian dream. He was a country boy, born in Cootamundra, in rural New South Wales; his father was a farmer and carpenter - not rich, not poor. None of his schoolfriends lived near him, so, in solitary moments, he invented a game which involved throwing a golf ball at the base of the family water tank; he then had to whack it with a cricket stump. Though the ball fizzed off the tank at high speed and unpredictable angles, by the time he was 10, Bradman could whack it with the stump more often than not.

When he was 12, he made a 100 for Bowral high school against Mittagong. For a while, he played more tennis than cricket and seemed to be settling for a career in estate agency. However, when he was 17, Bradman played for Bowral against Wingello, who had the ace leg-spin bowler Bill O'Reilly. Bradman was dropped twice early on off O'Reilly, who got him out first ball when the game resumed the following week. In between, he scored 234.

Next match, he scored 300. In October 1926, he was invited to Sydney to practise for the state squad; a year later, aged 19, he was in the New South Wales team, scoring a century on debut. The following year, he scored 1,690 runs, a new Australian record. By November 1928, he was in the Test team, and seared by a match which England won by 678 runs. Bradman made 18 and one, and was dropped from the next game to be replaced by one Dr OE Nothling. He was soon back; no one ever thought of dropping him again.

England, at this stage, were in one of their rare intervals of superiority over Australia, and had the world's leading batsman in Walter Hammond. Bradman scored two centuries in the series, one in defeat, one in a consolation victory. No one had the faintest idea that England would not win the Ashes again by fair means for another 24 years, and that one man would be primarily responsible for this.

They got an inkling in the first week of 1930, when Bradman scored 452 not out for New South Wales against Queensland. But he was still rated behind another youngster, the more stylish Archie Jackson. Bradman's unclassical backlift would, it was thought, find him out on soft English wickets. In the event, Jackson failed in England (he died of TB three years later) and Bradman's tour was a triumphal procession.

It might be easy to imagine Bradman from this distance as a dull and mechanical batsman, something of a Geoffrey Boycott. In fact, he scored his runs at a phenomenal rate; the 452 came in 415 minutes, barely imaginable today. When he got to England, the style became more firmly established. It was almost metronomic, starting with the push for one first ball.

He was the master of timing; his eye was so extraordinary that he could make up his mind what shot to play a micro-second later than anyone else; and his judgment was so impeccable that the decision was almost always right. He eliminated the risk that comes from lofting the ball, and hardly ever hit a six in consequence.

His batting was both intuitive and intellectual; as Neville Cardus said, he was that rare and devastating combination, "a genius with an eye for business". A Bradman innings was not as beautiful as one by Trumper or Woolley or Jackson, but it was awesome, and he drew unprecedented crowds from people just anxious to say they saw one.

In England in 1930, he became a colossus. He began by inaugurating his tradition of an opening double-century at Worcester, and hit 1,000 runs before the end of May. In the five-match Ashes series, he scored 974, 69 more than the record set by Hammond 18 months earlier: 254 at Lord's, 338 at Leeds, 232 at the Oval. At Leeds, he made 309 in a day; a modern Test batsman does well to score a century in that time. Cardus insisted that essentially this was a triumph for cricketing orthodoxy: "He is a purist in a hurry: he administers the orthodox in loud and apostolic knocks."

Hammond was displaced completely as the world's batting champion, and there are those who argue that he never recovered as a cricketer or as a man. There have been moments when other cricketers - Denis Compton in 1947, Brian Lara in 1995 - have been almost as dominating, and perhaps even more exciting. But for Bradman, this was just the beginning.

He returned to Australia a hero, and progressed east from Fremantle by train to be greeted rapturously at every railway halt along the Nullarbor Plain. His team-mates, meanwhile, were making the transcontinental journey by sea, and growing ever more jealous. Though Bradman was assiduous at giving credit where it was due, the classic cricket team dichotomy between the individual hero and the collective was now in place. Inevitably also, skirmishing began with the Australian cricketing authorities, who fined him £50 for writing a book about the tour.

These battle lines remained in place throughout the 1930s, and, in 1931, he came close to accepting an offer to play Lancashire League cricket for Accrington. There was insufficient money in cricket to provide the income his celebrity demanded, and a hasty sponsorship deal had to be cobbled together. The wicket was made slightly higher and wider in 1930-31; still Bradman scored prodigiously with further double centuries against the West Indies and South Africa. Some in England thought they had spotted a weakness in him against top-class wrist-spin. But as England came to Australia in 1932-33, their new captain, Douglas Jardine, had other plans.

Thus began the most notorious Test series of all time, in which England regained the Ashes by unleashing their fast bowlers to bowl bouncers at the Australians, with a field (now illegal) concentrated behind the stumps on the leg-side; this meant the batsmen had no alternative but to fend the ball to the fieldsmen, or get hurt. Imperialist arrogance, and poor reporting of the tour, ensured that the English establishment and public were slow to realise the sheer degeneracy of this strategy. The initial reaction was that the Australians were whingeing, and that a way had been found to beat them again and blunt Bradman at last. Even in these circumstances, he averaged nearly 57.

When bodyline was repudiated, and normality restored, Bradman resumed his un troubled progress. He was a fraction less domineering in the remaining three Ashes series of the decade, but only a fraction. In 1934, he scored another triple-century in the Leeds Test; in 1936-37, he led Australia back from 2-0 down with triumphant performances in the last three matches; in 1938, as captain, he again scored 1,000 runs in May, and averaged more than 100 throughout.

It should have been the happiest, as well as the most triumphant, decade any sports- man has ever had. It was never quite like that. After the 1934 tour, Bradman was taken ill with acute appendicitis and peritonitis; he missed the 1934-35 season while recuperating. He moved from New South Wales to South Australia to accept an offer from a cricket-loving stockbroker (later jailed for fraud), which left some ill-feeling. Even the travelling got to him; he was seasick and later airsick.

And the tensions within the Australian team worsened. Bradman, a pernickety, near-teetotal Protestant (religion mattered in 1930s Australia) with a Calvinist work ethic, was not a natural soulmate of the witty, happy-go-lucky, left-leaning Roman Catholics like O'Reilly and Fingleton, both of them later journalists with a waspish turn of phrase, often used against Bradman. "Fingleton," Bradman complained later, "conducted a vendetta against me all his life."

Moreover, though his marriage to Jessie was a triumph - and was to remain so for 65 years until her death in 1997 - the Bradmans' eldest son was to live for only a few hours; their daughter, Shirley, developed cerebral palsy; and their surviving son, John, had polio as a child. He pulled through, but was often estranged from his father later. Son and daughter survive their father.

The whispering increased after 1939, when cricket became less relevant. While other Australians had daredevil wars, Bradman - bizarrely enough - was declared to have defective eyesight, and spent the time in Adelaide. He was apparently often unwell, and there was some doubt that he would ever return to play for Australia in the hastily-arranged series of 1946-47.

He did appear, though, and carried on where he left off, striding to 187 in the first postwar Test, more than England made in either innings, but only after refusing to walk for what England were certain was a perfectly fair slip catch by Jack Ikin when he had 28. In the next game, he scored 234. And so on. In 1948, pushing 40, he came back to England for his farewell tour.

By now, he seemed a mellower figure, willing to return the adulation of the crowds. His enemies in the dressing room had retired; the newer generation were less inclined to question his deification; and, when cricketing mortality finally seized him at the Oval, it was possible to see it in very human terms.

John Arlott was commentating. "I wonder if you see a ball very clearly on your last Test in England, on a ground where you've played out some of the biggest cricket of your life, and when the opposing team has just stood round you and given you three cheers, and the crowd had clapped you all the wicket . . . I wonder if you really see the ball at all." But, came the cynical riposte: if Bradman had a tear in his eye, it was for the first time.

He was knighted in 1949, then slipped easily into the role of cricketing elder statesman. He gave up stockbroking and became a selector and administrator, dealing firmly with the throwing crisis that convulsed the game at the end of the 1950s. He played golf, off scratch (of course), remaining rooted all the time to his marriage and suburban home in Adelaide.

With elaborate courtesy, Bradman replied personally to all his correspondents into his 90s. But the answer was nearly always "No", if it was a request for an interview. He spoke about bodyline in 1983, the 50th anniversary. After that came near-total silence. Eventually, he stopped going to the Adelaide Oval, and became reclusive, indeed a bit of a curmudgeon, boycotting the celebrations laid on for his own 90th birthday.

However, when a Wisden panel in 2000 voted him the cricketer of the century, with 100 votes out of 100, he issued a statement of delight. His reputation as a cricketer has never been questioned; as a man, he remains enigmatic. Though his fame extended only to the cricketing countries, within its limits it far exceeded the transient public obsessiveness with a Gascoigne or a Beckham and, in his own buttoned-up way, Bradman found it desperately hard to cope.

"You can't tell youngsters today of the attraction of the fellow," said one of his opponents, the England bowler Bill Bowes in 1983. "I mean, business used to stop in the town when Bradman was playing and likely to go in - all the offices closed, the shops closed; everybody went up to see him play." Our Don Bradman was a song of the 1930s. But he was always his Don Bradman.

He played golf, off scratch (of course), remaining rooted all the time to his marriage and suburban home in Adelaide. With elaborate courtesy, Bradman replied personally to all his correspondents into his 90s. But the answer was nearly always "No", if it was a request for an interview. He spoke about bodyline in 1983, the 50th anniversary. After that came near-total silence. Eventually, he stopped going to the Adelaide Oval, and became reclusive, indeed a bit of a curmudgeon, boycotting the celebrations laid on for his own 90th birthday. However, when a Wisden panel in 2000 voted him the cricketer of the century, with 100 votes out of 100, he issued a statement of delight. His reputation as a cricketer has never been questioned; as a man, he remains enigmatic. Though his fame extended only to the cricketing countries, within its limits it far exceeded the transient public obsessiveness with a Gascoigne or a Beckham and, in his own buttoned-up way, Bradman found it desperately hard to cope. "You can't tell youngsters today of the attraction of the fellow," said one of his opponents, the England bowler Bill Bowes in 1983. "I mean, business used to stop in the town when Bradman was playing and likely to go in - all the offices closed, the shops closed; everybody went up to see him play." Our Don Bradman was a song of the 1930s. But he was always his Don Bradman. Donald George Bradman, cricketer, born August 27 1908; died February 25 2001

fields.headline: Inequality street
fields.standfirst:
Women are still being paid less for doing the same job as men, according to a new survey. Why is Britain the most sexist country in Europe, asks Cristina Odone

Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: Women are still being paid less for doing the same job as men, according to a new survey. Why is Britain the most sexist country in Europe, asks Cristina Odone
fields.body:
Poor Baroness Jay. There she was, hoping to hand in her notice as leader of the House of Lords and minister for women and tiptoe out of the back door with as little fuss as possible - and then those nasty busybodies at the Equal Opportunities Commission complete a survey trumpeting the failure of her women's unit. To be fair, the findings, published today, are as much an indictment of New Labour as they are of the unit it created to look after women's interests: in terms of equal pay and equal opportunities, Britain is the most sexist place to work in Europe.

Red faces all around. The party that had raised such hopes and manufactured such hype about its pro-women agenda - remember all the boasts about more female MPs than ever before? The ground-breaking, breastfeeding Blair babes? - will now enter the general election with a set of statistics that will further alienate female voters, a million of whom say they've gone off the government.

The picture is bleak indeed. If you care about how your wage packet compares with the man who does the same job as you, you're better off in France, Germany or even Portugal. The wage gap in these countries is less than in Britain - where a woman working full time earns just 82% of her male colleague's salary. (For a part-time female worker that sinks to 60%.) If you care about paid maternity leave, you'd better up sticks and move to Italy (where a mother gets five months' paid leave) or Finland (nine months, as well as 42 days for paternity leave); in Britain, you get a paltry 18 weeks. Add to this poor childcare provision and, in predominantly female professions such as nursing, an average pay of 6% less than overall average male earnings in the UK, and you can see why the European Council of Ministers told the UK to get down to work on closing the pay gap.

They have their work cut out for them. Thirty years since the Equal Pay Act was passed, women find the workplace as inimical as the factory caricatured in Charlie Chaplin's Mod ern Times. Talk to staff at the EOC, and they can name endless cases of women who have had to take their employers to court to receive fair treatment. Take Dr Lorna Chessum, a female lecturer at Leicester's De Montfort University, who discovered she had been appointed on a lower salary - £6,000 less - than a similarly qualified male colleague. She received £10,000 compensation in an out-of-court settlement in September 2000.

Then there's Doreen McManus, who worked as a payroll administrator for Rentokil. She claimed that over three years she did the same work as a male colleague, whom she trained, and who was paid £3,000 more than her. She took the matter up with her employer, who agreed to review her pay. Her salary was increased - but she was still earning less than her colleague. She lodged an equal pay claim and Rentokil settled the case, paying her £10,500 compensation.

Two small victories in a war we thought was won long ago. A war in which we cannot count on either government or employer as an ally. Jill Rubery, as the co ordinator of the European Commission's expert group on gender and equality, was present when the commission, having seen the UK's National Action Plan for Employment last year, publicly reprimanded the country for its appalling employment figures. "Immediately, our civil servants started to rubbish the data as insufficient and emphasise the high employment rate we have for women - which is well above the 60% target by 2010 set in Lisbon in 1999." The spin machine is likely to go into overdrive after the EOC survey, too, despite its impressive credentials: the research was carried out by the NOP group in the summer last year. It involved a telephone survey of senior human resource managers in 301 organisations with at least 200 employees; telephone interviews with national trade union officials; and in-depth case-study research in 21 selected organisations.

While government apologists may spin against the EOC survey for painting too gloomy a picture of the working woman's lot, critics of the government suspect that the survey in fact lets the government off lightly. Mary Davis, who heads the Centre for Trade Union Studies at the University of North London, argues: "Industry by industry, the gender pay gap has actually widened since 1997. I see no evidence, apart from the introduction of the national minimum wage, to support the view that we are wit nessing a narrowing of the gap. Among working-class women, certainly, things have got worse. If you're living in a textile town, for instance, with the industry bottoming out beneath your feet, you are far poorer than before."

Rubery, who with Damian Grimshaw carried out the research for the EOC, feels that even some of the state's poverty-busting initiatives have had a negative impact on women's wages. The working families tax credit, for example, "contradicted the equal-pay ethos by trapping the second income-earner in a low- paying job". Moreover, as both Davis and Rubery point out, a government that believes that any regulation hinders the market, and has abdicated all responsibility for pay structure, cannot intervene in the one area that most affects the gender pay gap.

The market, indeed, has become a fig leaf behind which employers can hide discrimination: you can get away with paying Jane less than Joe by signing them up to individualised contracts. There are a million weasel words that allow you to claim that what she is doing is not exactly the same as what he does. Equally, there are many ways of explaining away why promotion keeps eluding her.

The trade unions, once the battering rams for victims of unfair treatment at work, have lost their bite. Collective bargaining has declined in recent years; today, less than one in three workplaces is covered by it. Meanwhile, employer accountability has grown ever more nebulous. In an increasing number of situations, there is no single, clear-cut employer - as is the case when work is subcontracted, or joint ventures or partnerships operate. This makes it difficult to uphold legislationbased on "comparable work for the same employer". The fragmentation of the public sector, through the contracting out of services to the private sector, also contributes to the difficulty in monitoring the wage differential. Not surprisingly, this state of affairs gets the thumbs up from employers - 93% of those who took part in the EOC survey cheerfully believed their pay systems were fair.

Those of us who feel that if Jane and Joe carry out the same work they should bring home the same pay packet will simply have to provide fodder for the EOC's case studies. Or move to Lisbon.

 This is a version of an article first published in this week's New Statesman.
