fields.headline: The networker
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: Timesheet: The stallholder
fields.body:
Timesheet: The stallholder

Marcus Stansbury, 39, sells fruit and vegetables in Westmoreland Road, south-east London.

5:00: Arrives in van at Borough market. Buys about 70 boxes of fruit and veg.

7:30: Arrives Westmoreland Road. Starts to unload van.

8:04: Rain. "If the sun's out it's not too bad. People don't mind coming out and having a look around. Rain wears you down."

8:20: Puts out tomatoes, cabbages and broad beans. Puts up another table: two crates, a piece of wood and a stretch of fake grass.

8:35: Cauliflowers, more beans, sprouts, broccoli.

8:42: Another table for courgettes, strawberry punnets and spring onions.

8:44: Arranges 11 bunches of bananas.

8:46: Man in checked trousers buys a pear. "That your breakfast, eh?"

8:47: Hangs up six bunches of bananas on hooks above till.

8:52: Cuts cucumber in half. Sorts onions. "Every day we have to do this."

9:00: Woman in blue puffa jacket buys bunch of bananas. "One ten."

9:02: Man in cord jacket buys broccoli and banana. He pauses, then decides to buy 1lb of rhubarb, some onions, and fennel. And 1lb of broad beans. Man says he cannot believe they have broad beans.

9:20: Drinks cup of Oxo.

9:23: Burglar alarm goes off across the road at William Hill.

9:53: Woman buys strawberries.

10:00: Marcus's wife Lorraine arrives to help. They met at the stall. "She was going to the pie and mash shop and I just started talking to her."

11.23: "People don't come out now til about 12 o'clock. You can see how many shops are closed down there."

11:53: Man comes to buy grapes. "One thirty. D'you want a bag for it?"

12:15: Butcher arrives for some eggs. "'Ello, butcher."

12:18: "I'm still working on pounds. I had to buy scales to say kilos. The old people don't understand kilos."

12:30: Lunch. "You just work and if you're hungry you eat."

1:20: Waits for customers. "There's odd passing trade, but mainly regulars. Some come from Croydon to get their pie and mash."

2:16: "That's the thing with stalls now, everyone likes to help themselves. It's come from abroad, they've brought it with them. We used to have signs saying "Do Not Touch'. If someone touched an apple they'd chop your hand off. But that's a thing of the past."

2:24: Waves to a friend.

3:33: Man with moustache buys tomatoes. "Thank you very much."

4:07: "There aren't seasons now. The runner beans are from Zimbabwe, the broad beans are from Italy."

5:00: Starts to pack up. "I used to peg it up here after school, on my bike, to help my dad clear up. It's a dying trade now, really. My son won't take it over. He's 18 and a landscape gardener. Maybe my daughter will."

5:30 Goes home. Lorraine cooks dinner - "hopefully a roast".

Pay check: What you can do for £30,000

 Web designer, Cambridge

 Senior physiotherapist, Tyneside

 Government e-learning manager, Sheffield

 Accountant with geophysical exploration company, Lagos, Nigeria

 Brain injury rehabilitation centre worker, London

 FA Carling Premiership footballer (per week)

On the radar : Paranoia at 30,000ft

Oh, yes, those might look like soporific sales spreadsheets, those diagrams on the laptop of the business traveller in the airplane seat next to yours. And, let's face it, they probably are. But ooh, wouldn't it be thrilling for the jetlagged executive in question if he could at least pretend that they were top-secret documents that must be protected from enemy eyes at all costs?

That, surely, must be the ego-boosting motivation behind a sudden new spate of gadgets designed to combat the "problem" of corporate espionage on business flights - such as 3M's new privacy filter, which renders your screen invisible to nosy neighbours.

There's no sign as yet of any product designed to block signals from the chip that they planted in your brain to broadcast your thoughts to the CIA. But it's surely only a matter of time.

Debunker: General manager

There's something about a soldier, it seems, that catapults management gurus further than usual into the realms of higher meaninglessness. Because work, you must understand, is war. Think about it: the death-ravaged trenches of the Somme; your office. See? Consider Patton on Leadership (Prentice Hall), a big, manly, hard-backed, thick-skinned beast of a book in which workplace expert Alan Axelrod decodes the sayings of the great WW2 general. To the uninitiated, Patton's utterances - "Hold the enemy by the nose and kick him in the pants!" or "I am the best damn ass-kicker in the US Army!" - might seem like the rantings of a power-drunk lunatic. But no: the former is really a helpful "deploy your resources so you control the situation". As for ass-kicking: "Subsitute a milder noun - perhaps 'motivator'," writes Axelrod, "and you have a goal to which any manager might aspire."

Debunker thumbed breathlessly through the pages for a few of Patton's other managerial practices. But where was his famously sensitive handling of staff sickness (slapping a shell-shocked soldier in hospital to motivate him)? Or his clever way with nepotism and human resource management (sacrificing lives in order to free his son-in-law from a PoW camp)? Or his inability to prevent himself unleashing tirades of profanities on his underlings? Inexplicably, they have all gone Awol.

Email Work at work@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Perfect Houseplants wilt in Sheffield
fields.trailText:
Perfect Houseplants
Eccleshall Non-Political Club, Sheffield
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Perfect Houseplants
Eccleshall Non-Political Club, Sheffield
Rating: ***

Devoted fans of East Anglian folk songs will find much to enjoy in Perfect Houseplants' new repertoire, particularly if they have always wanted to hear these tunes deconstructed into slightly convoluted jazz arrangements. With their album New Folk Songs, the Houseplants are bravely ploughing their own little furrow, evoking the charms of the English countryside and occasionally indulging in a bit of gratuitous free jazz.

Despite admirable inten tions, their folk-funk fusion only occasionally rises above the moderately interesting, and an air of pastoral self-indulgence hangs heavy in the air. Pieces called Pageant and Nancy from Yarmouth are as gentle and meandering as their names imply, and although there are occasional nuggets of tightly intricate composition, the abundant solo sections have a tendency to waft as aimlessly as a breeze ruffling a field of corn.

The players have clearly developed their own distinctive sound after many years together, but this is unexpectedly a shortcoming. Each musician gives an immaculately understated performance, but the sense of comfortable familiarity is oddly claustrophobic, with the musical components locking together too snugly to generate any real tension or excitement. Additionally, none of the instruments is plundered for any unusual or visceral sounds. From the amiable bass playing of Dudley Phillips to the chirpy reeds of Mark Lockheart, musical politeness is the order of the day. Perfect Houseplants tread most dangerously in their harmonic explorations, which are more cerebral than emotional. There are precious few memorable tunes on offer, despite the enhancement of Huw Warren's moody-sounding electronic keyboard.

Nevertheless, there are moments of fun, with Slippery's scampering piano and babbling clarinet conjuring images of bustling country villagers enjoying themselves around the maypole. Towards the end of the show, things even get slightly exciting. Mason features a very fast rhythm section thundering away beneath a slowly drawling saxophone - exactly the kind of stimulating juxtaposition that has been absent throughout much of the evening's performance.

At Kettles Yard, Cambridge (01223 503333), on Thursday.

fields.headline: Brilliant brass at the Barbican
fields.trailText:
BBCSO/ Slatkin
Barbican, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
BBCSO/ Slatkin
Barbican, London
Rating: ***

Leonard Slatkin's concert with the BBC Symphony Orchestra presents a programme of musical conundrums and unsolved riddles. The first half is dominated by HK Gruber's Aerial, a concerto for trumpet and orchestra, performed by the brilliant Hakan Hardenberger, while the second half contains the baffling contradictions of Shostakovich's 15th Symphony.

Gruber's two-part concerto, which was composed for Hardenberger and the 1999 Proms, is both wonderfully crafted as a musical structure and vividly compelling as an emotional journey. A quotation from Emily Dickinson ("Done with the compass/ Done with the chart") provides the title of the first movement, and the music opens with an epic stillness. Hardenberger creates primeval melodies from the inchoate musical space that surrounds him. This sense of timelessness is focused in a long solo for cow-horn, an ancestor of the present-day trumpet. It's as if Gruber is composing the creation myth of an instrument and a repertoire.

The second movement, Gone Dancing, dispels the serenity of the first, with music of vibrantly eclectic energy. Gruber makes references to 1940s show-tunes and raucous folk melodies, but he creates a scintillating synthesis of these with his own style. The piece ends with a sound, and an image, that returns the trumpet soloist to the cosmic calm of the opening. Hardenberger walks to the piano and plays a single note that resonates, creating a shimmering aura of sound. His performance is even more impressive than it was at the work's premiere, and he projects the extraordinary technical challenges of Gruber's music with conviction.

Shostakovich's 15th was his last symphony, and it's an appropriately ambiguous work to cap one of the most disturbing series of symphonies ever written. The music is a bizarre mix of references, allusions and images. Quotations from Rossini (the William Tell Overture) and from Wagner (a motive from the Ring cycle) protrude from the first and last movements, while the slow movement juxtaposes everything from a long cello solo to funereal brass chords and an eerie vibraphone melody. Is this nihilistic deconstruction, or a benign "toy-shop at night", as Shostakovich himself described it?

Slatkin's performance avoids the issue. He and the BBCSO play the piece as an attractive succession of individual moments to be knitted together in the audience's imagination. But hearing the work simply as a musical structure is a hollow experience: from the glitter of the opening movement to the emptiness of the final chord, there seems to be only surface and superficiality.

Beside the dazzling complexities of Shostakovich and Gruber, Slatkin's earlier performance of Haydn's Symphony No 99 is superfluous. He and the orchestra have obviously had no time to properly rehearse the subtleties of one of Haydn's greatest symphonies, and the result is a stodgy, workmanlike run-through.

fields.headline: See you in court
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: There was a time when I thought that, if workplaces could somehow be filled with invisible, lighter-than-air recording equipment, most of the cases that go to tribunals would crack open neatly like nuts (or like some kind of idealised nuts, not the ones you get at Christmas that spurt shards at you).
fields.body:
There was a time when I thought that, if workplaces could somehow be filled with invisible, lighter-than-air recording equipment, most of the cases that go to tribunals would crack open neatly like nuts (or like some kind of idealised nuts, not the ones you get at Christmas that spurt shards at you). Hours would no longer be spent arguing about exactly what someone said, or what tone of voice they said it in.

I don't think that any more. Take my case this week. The applicant's post-adolescent squeaky-voiced solicitor hurried up to me importantly in the tribunal hallway at the beginning of the week to announce that the applicant had taped the crucial interview with his manager at which (allegedly) a lot of intolerable bullying had gone on. This "bullying", the solicitor argued, justified the applicant's resignation. Did my employer client want to write him a big cheque?

Me: "Well, I guess I'd better listen to this tape."

Squeaky: "Oh, umm, well, actually my client can't lay his hands on it at the moment."

Me: "Why not?"

Squeaky: "He's mislaid it."

Me (mentally closing employer's cheque book): "Well, I guess we'd better fight it out then."

The thing was, I was finding it hard to visualise Mr Manager as a big bully. He was quite a small and wizened man, with a paunch which seemed to swill about beneath his shirt like a basketball and a somewhat depressing habit of discussing the Weightwatchers points attached to any item of food anyone might be thinking of consuming at lunchtime. But he didn't come across as a Mr Mean, and I've seen a fair few workplace bullies in my time, oh yes.

The tribunal, however, seemed to feel otherwise. A typical exchange as Mr Manager gave his evidence ran thus:

Mr Manager: "I was trying to raise the performance issues in a tactful and sensitive way with the applicant."

Tribunal chair: "But were you glaring at the applicant?"

Mr Manager: "Uh, I really don't think so."

Tribunal chair [writing note busily, no doubt along the lines of "witness unable to say was not glaring at applicant"]: "But you're not sure?"

My sinking feeling intensified on day three, when Squeaky strode up to me again to say that the applicant had at last found the tape of the interview. So off we went to a consultation room and listened to it.

It was full of Mr Manager saying things like, "I'm really sorry to have to raise this with you, Steve." And "Obviously we'll give you as much support as we can to improve your figures." All delivered in the same mild tones in which he'd been lecturing me daily about the evils of cheese. Squeaky and his client were looking at me triumphantly.

Me: "Well, I'm happy for you to play that to the tribunal."

And they did. The tribunal chair looked increasingly deflated. The applicant lost.

Moral: all the surveillance equipment in the world ain't going to put lawyers out of business.

 The author is an employment tribunal lawyer. This is an occasional column.

webTitle: Customers blacked out as HSBC takes record profit

fields.headline: Customers blacked out as HSBC takes record profit
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: More than 8m customers of HSBC were denied information about their accounts yesterday as the high street bank suffered a computer failure on the day it announced record profits of £7bn.
fields.body:
More than 8m customers of HSBC were denied information about their accounts yesterday as the high street bank suffered a computer failure on the day it announced record profits of £7bn.

The embarrassing glitch, which had still not been rectified last night, meant that people calling the bank's customer hotline were either unable to get through or told that they could not receive information about their account. Customers were unable to check whether payments, such as salaries, had gone into the accounts or whether withdrawals had gone out.

Callers to First Direct, HSBC's telephone bank, were also told that they could not receive in formation about their accounts because of "a computer breakdown".

Customers trying to access such information online, through HSBC's internet service, said they encountered similar difficulties accessing account details.

Industry experts said that for a computer difficulty to be so prolonged and to be nationwide was "very rare". The precise nature of the problem at HSBC was unclear last night.

One customer was told that the bank's back-up systems, which usually run between 1am and 2am, had inadvertently begun operating mid-morning. According to this source, when the back-up system was switched off, it appeared to re-start automatically and could not be stopped. HSBC was unable to confirm this sequence of events last night, or when bank accounts had become inoperable, or when customer information would be available again.

A spokesman said: "HSBC Bank identified a data management problem today which meant that customers were unable to access account information. All customers are still able to withdraw cash from ATMs (cash machines) and branches".

He insisted that no customer information had been lost. "We apologise for the inconvenience and are working as hard a possible to solve the problem," he said.

fields.headline: Tender tunes from Tindersticks
fields.trailText:
Tindersticks
Subterania, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Tindersticks
Subterania, London
Rating: ****

Although cruelly ignored by the majority of the record-buying public, Tindersticks command undying love and absolute respect from the discerning few and are having to get used to lots of "Sshhhhh" sounds tonight. Anyone brave enough to utter a word as the purveyors of dark waltzes do their melancholic thing is met with a steely stare and a request to be quiet. Very, very quiet.

That admiration has always been there for the Nottingham band. Critics have fawned, and it was obligatory for any indie fan in the 1990s to name-check Tindersticks among their favourites. Limited-edition singles on a variety of small labels added to the must-have cool.

Tindersticks exist to create beauty out of heartbreak, verbalising emotions and tapping into half-remembered memories. They are the sound of late-night reflections, their shuffling drums and mournful vocals conjuring up images of seaside towns in winter. It's end-of-the-pier music for star-crossed lovers with nicotine-stained fingers. But reality creeps in sometimes. Frontman Stuart Staples sits forward on his stool, acoustic guitar in hand, and it all goes a bit wrong. "I've fucking fucked up the words already," he says, staring at his guitar forlornly before sharply beginning again.

Immaculate in denim jacket and patterned shirt - with the top three buttons undone, revealing a hint of white vest underneath - Staples combines an Elvis sheen with a Nick Cave intensity. He is hypnotic, caressing the microphone, his vocals, full of smoke and regret, resonating against a mellow backing. The poetic lyrics are obscured by his mumbling delivery and he draws us in largely by mood. His eyes closed, Staples is far away, his body jolting and twisting to Blood, like Ian Curtis on tranquillisers.

Each song has an innate sadness, but this isn't music to drown in. Dickon Hinchliffe's violin provides an uplifting juxtaposition to Staples's sighing phrases. The gentle rhythm of Nectar allows us space to think before Can Our Love adds some soul to the sadness, summoning up the warmth and tenderness of the classic I'd Rather Go Blind before we're back in bedsit- blues territory with a guitar squelch. It's this ability to enjoy one-song relationships with many genres that keeps Tindersticks out of the indie ghetto - they refuse to be defined.

Marbles is a country-and- western soundtrack made by Duane Eddy, the rock and guitar adding drama to the fast, nagging drums. And throughout the set the songs build in tension. Staples's vocals grow more determined and passionate, and the band ups the tempo and crescendos before the emotion drains away. Obscurity can be picturesque after all.

fields.headline: LPO/Berglund
fields.trailText:
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating: ***

Pavo Berglund has been an infrequent visitor to London of late. He was in charge of the Bournemouth Symphony Orchestra during the 1970s and has since held a succession of posts with Scandinavian orchestras. At a time when a younger generation of Finnish conductors (Salonen, Vanska, Saraste) has established itself in spectacular fashion, it was good in this London Philharmonic Orchestra concert to be reminded of the virtues of his honest, uncomplicated music-making. Sibelius has always been a Berglund speciality - he made the very first recording of the Kullervo Symphony - and the Fourth Symphony was the highlight of a programme in which all three works were in a minor key, even though Mendelssohn's Violin Concerto is anything but melancholic.

Berglund took a fierce, uncompromising line through the symphony. He made no attempt to apply a cosmetic continuity to the bleak block-construction of the first movement and allowed only the tiniest glimmers of warmth into the scherzo. In the largo, which seemed more than usually haunted by the world of the third act of Wagner's Parsifal, the fragments of the theme were assembled into a despairing statement; the coda of the finale was nothing but tragic. The torn-off endings to all the movements had an unmistakable bleakness; if the Fourth really was Sibelius's reaction to modernism (it was composed in 1910 after he had heard some of Schoenberg's early pieces), then, Berglund's discomfiting performance suggested, it was a response that saw no musical future whatsoever in such radicalism.

The LPO was on solid, responsive form, with their sturdy brass providing a baleful commentary; and they had produced a burnished depth of dark tone for Brahms's Tragic Overture, which Berglund carved out in grand rhetorical paragraphs. They accompanied the Mendelssohn concerto adroitly enough, even if that was a rather routine account. Soloist Tasmin Little played well enough, though her phrasing was unremarkable; if the automatic-pilot button hadn't quite been pressed, her finger was certainly hovering very close to it.

fields.headline: Robert Holl
fields.trailText:
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
Rating: ***

The Dutch bass Robert Holl has developed a formidable reputation on the European mainland, both for his operatic performances and as a singer of lieder. Whether that reputation is entirely justified was, however, open to doubt at this Schumann recital.

A number of factors contributed to the evening's awkwardness. Holl seemed to be having an off night. During the first half of the concert he repeatedly cleared his throat as if suffering from a cold. There is little doubt as to the quality of his voice, a huge, dark sound with a wide-ranging palette of tonal colouring, but there were moments of unwieldiness and suspect intonation. Only after the interval did he seem to settle down. Most of the time, Holl sings with his eyes shut or downcast, as if lost in a world of meditation, and you can't help feeling you're being kept at arm's length.

His programme consisted of Schumann at his most depressive, culminating in the famous Eichendorff Liederkreis, with its images of exile and existential isolation. It was here that Holl finally struck form, generating a palpable sense of unease. The opening song, In der Fremde, was plangently introverted. The weird confrontation between the narrator and the seductive, destructive Lorelei opened up an abyss of sexual terror. With pianist Roger Vignoles at his superlative best, Auf einer Burg created an eerie resonance that seemed to echo through vast spaces. The closing song, Frühlingsnacht, far from implying emotional release from nightmare, hinted at mania.

Holl's variability in the first half of the concert was disquieting, however, particularly since he opted for two little-known sequences of songs, one of which is a masterpiece that deserves to be heard more often. This is the Lenau-Lieder, written in 1850 as Schumann's response to the news of the death of the poet Nikolaus Lenau. The sequence opens in a mood of deceptive optimism, with the depiction of a blacksmith cheerily forging a horseshoe. The mood gradually darkens until images of human mortality become omnipresent, before a sudden shift in gear leads to Schumann's contemplation of Lenau's soul being wafted heavenward. Though it ranks with other Lenau-inspired works by Liszt and Strauss, its impact here was intermittent.

Much the same can be said of Holl's performance of the Harfenspieler-Lieder, based on sections of Goethe's Wilhelm Meister. Moments of terror and tragic intensity were offset by stretches in which Holl's vocal unease was more than once apparent.

fields.headline: RSNO/Alsop
fields.trailText:
Usher Hall, Edinburgh
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Usher Hall, Edinburgh
Rating: ***

Michael Torke's funky post-minimalist style lends itself so well to writing for percussion it is surprising that he hasn't composed anything for that medium before. Composed in close collaboration with Colin Currie, Rapture for Percussion and Orchestra - his first new work as the Royal Scottish National Orchestra's associate composer - is wonderfully idiomatic.

Torke's idea of using the solo part as a sharp focus, with the orchestra adding depth and colour, is an ingenious one. But by "shadowing" the percussion - rather than supplying a melodic or harmonic dimension - the orchestra is invited to play a part that is in places almost mechanical. Problems arose when, reiterating the vigorous gestures of the solo part, standard orchestral timbres - in particular, unison strings - sounded feeble and ill at ease with themselves.

Any orchestra would be hard put to match Currie's dazzling virtuosity. But over-cautious playing, with cross-rhythms and syncopation stilted and wooden, flattened the outer movements rather more than they could take. The central slow movement, where the drums give way to brighter, more sensuous writing for marimba and vibraphone, fared much better and was finely shaped and balanced. The audience's response by far exceeded polite applause for a new work: Currie, Alsop and Torke were called back five or six times to whistles and cheers.

If the RSNO had sounded a little repressed in the Torke, Alsop's account of Mahler's Fourth Symphony provided some clues as to why this might have been. Mahler's finicky performance directions can be inhibiting, even apparently contrary. The precision and assurance of Alsop's approach suggested considerable time spent studying the score and trying to absorb the logic of all those tempo changes. It was a performance that had vision as well as accuracy, and there was some marvellous playing: not a phrase was shaped carelessly or insensitively.

The problem was pacing: with each movement starting on the pedestrian side, gentle dips in tempo became slumps, and even the most beautifully crafted phrasing was unable to sing. Where time was supposed to stand still - just before the transition to the finale - Alsop was at her best.

Mahler's setting of the Wunderhorn poem The Celestial Life evokes a wide-eyed sense of childish wonder. Janice Watson's soprano is a little on the fruity side of childlike, but her natural manner and relaxed stage presence suited the finale well.

Composed in close collaboration with Colin Currie, Rapture for Percussion and Orchestra - his first new work as the Royal Scottish National Orchestra's associate composer - is wonderfully idiomatic. Torke's idea of using the solo part as a sharp focus, with the orchestra adding depth and colour, is an ingenious one. But by "shadowing" the percussion - rather than supplying a melodic or harmonic dimension - the orchestra is invited to play a part that is in places almost mechanical. Problems arose when, reiterating the vigorous gestures of the solo part, standard orchestral timbres - in particular, unison strings - sounded feeble and ill at ease with themselves. Any orchestra would be hard put to match Currie's dazzling virtuosity. But over-cautious playing, with cross-rhythms and syncopation stilted and wooden, flattened the outer movements rather more than they could take. The central slow movement, where the drums give way to brighter, more sensuous writing for marimba and vibraphone, fared much better and was finely shaped and balanced. The audience's response by far exceeded polite applause for a new work: Currie, Alsop and Torke were called back five or six times to whistles and cheers. If the RSNO had sounded a little repressed in the Torke, Alsop's account of Mahler's Fourth Symphony provided some clues as to why this might have been. Mahler's finicky performance directions can be inhibiting, even apparently contrary. The precision and assurance of Alsop's approach suggested considerable time spent studying the score and trying to absorb the logic of all those tempo changes. It was a performance that had vision as well as accuracy, and there was some marvellous playing: not a phrase was shaped carelessly or insensitively. The problem was pacing: with each movement starting on the pedestrian side, gentle dips in tempo became slumps, and even the most beautifully crafted phrasing was unable to sing. Where time was supposed to stand still - just before the transition to the finale - Alsop was at her best. Mahler's setting of the Wunderhorn poem The Celestial Life evokes a wide-eyed sense of childish wonder. Janice Watson's soprano is a little on the fruity side of childlike, but her natural manner and relaxed stage presence suited the finale well.
